PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showed that:

1. Many Australians agree with the stated aim of the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship, namely to encourage the return of world class expatriate researchers, to support high quality research and to develop research skills fundamental to the nations national interest with the aim of boosting Australia's research and technology push.
2. We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship continue to be tenable at the Institute of Advanced Studies of ANU and CSIRO.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia should retain the current National Flag which has flown over the country since Federation. This flag
symbolises the world's oldest democracy
represents our history, our culture and our language
enjoys the support of the vast majority of the Australian people
symbolises the sacrifice of our armed servicemen and women
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should retain the current national flag.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating should be condemned for his disgraceful public attack on our national flag in a foreign country. The petitioners note that his public remarks
discredited our proud history and unique culture
degraded the efforts of all servicemen and women
insulted and embarrassed proud Australians
damaged our international reputation as a united and patriotic democratic nation
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Mr Keating apologise to the Australian people for his demeaning behaviour in a foreign country.

PETITION.TITLE: ABC: Asia
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the Senate to the fact that:
the Australian Broadcasting Corporation intends to transmit television programs into Asia
apart from an initial grant from the Government it is intended to finance this venture by the introduction of corporate sponsorship
the Government intends to alter existing broadcasting legislation to allow this to be done

this course of action would set a precedent which, in our view, would introduce pressures of corporate funding into the ABC and endanger the independence of our national broadcaster in its vital role as Australia's main disseminator of news and information at a time of unprecedented concentration of media ownership in this country
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate either
to ensure that the proposed Asian service be wholly funded by Government
OR that the proposed Asian service not commence until Government funds are available

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.

PETITION.TITLE: Benders Quarry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned, noting that the Australian Democrats have introduced a Bill into the Senate to ensure that no further blasting at Bender's Quarry is permitted without the consent of both Houses of Parliament, respectfully call upon the Federal Government to support the Bill.

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned are citizens of Australia; who are believers in the Almighty God, in His Son the Lord Jesus Christ and in the teachings of His apostles. We are persons who recognise the Holy Bible as the infallible Word of God, its teaching is mandatory and provides every help and practical guidance. We therefore respectfully draw to your attention the contravention of the injunctions of the Bible in the general practice of abortion in Australia.

Generally, abortion is carried out to terminate life; NOT to save life. Scripture states "thou knowest the commandments, do not commit adultery, do not kill, do not steal . . . " Mark 10:19 and "naked came I out of my mother's womb and naked shall I return thither, the Lord gave and the Lord hath taken away; blessed be the name of the Lord!" Job 1:21.

The constitution of this country, was enacted "humbly relying on the blessing of the Almighty God". The nation can only expect God's blessing and prosperity as His supreme rights are recognised. The righteous resolution of the practice of abortion in Australia is an urgent, critical and moral issue.
Your petitioners therefore as duty bound pray and ask the Honourable House, that:-"There be an immediate cessation of funding by the Government through Medicare of abortions."

PETITION.TITLE: ABC: Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the electors of Tasmania sheweth:
That your petitioners draw to the attention of the house that—

PARA.TAB: 1. We the electors of Tasmania condemn the plans of Dr John Hewson and Warwick Smith to:
(a) cut $50 million from the ABC's budget, and thereby
(b) threaten the capacity of the ABC to continue to serve provincial cities and rural areas.
2. We call on the Government and the Opposition to guarantee that the current ABC services to northern Tasmania are maintained at their present level.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that our request be heard.

PETITION.TITLE: Drug Use
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth; that we support your efforts to strengthen our family and community life particularly by increased penalties for "drug pushers" and distributors. We, however, wish to register our firm opposition to any legal changes which would increase or encourage the distribution or availability of so-called "soft drugs" such as marijuana. We believe such drugs to be harmful to the physical and psychological health of the individual and therefore to the interest of the community of which such individual is part. Although there is current controversy concerning the question of such harm it appears to us quite foolish to legalise and encourage the use of such drugs unless or until it be shown that such drugs are in fact harmless. The serious social problems of alcohol should provide sufficient warning to our society.

PETITION.PARA: Any efforts to legalise or decriminalise usage or distribution of such drugs will have the following results:

PARA.TAB: 1. Encourage and inculcate a social acceptability towards such drugs.
2. Increase the volume of usage of such drugs in schools and the community by present users and by "drug pushers" through the proposed one ounce legal possession.
3. Extend the usage of such drugs to persons who would previously have abstained because of the legal sanctions.

4. Put pressure upon Parliament to establish and license import, growth, manufacture and/or distribution of such drugs, that is, to regulate another destructive industry contrary to the best interest of the individual and society.
5. There would be the probable temptation to tax such drugs as another source of Federal revenue.

PETITION.PARA: We urge the Government to increase the medical and counselling facilities for the assistance of drug users and to expand existing Drug Referral Centres and Clinics. We have general confidence in the existing law and its sympathetic implementation by the Police and Courts.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will firstly take no measures that could extend the major social problem of drug usage and secondly will oblige those who are promoting marijuana and/or similar drugs to prove without doubt that such drugs are harmless before any legalisation or decriminalisation of use is introduced.
And your petitions as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: International Year for the World's Indigenous People

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)10 December 1992 marks the start of the International Year for the World's Indigenous People,
(ii)humans have lived as hunters and gatherers for 99.9 per cent of their existence on earth,
(iii)indigenous people developed complex and varied social patterns by which they have lived in balance with their environments throughout this time,
(iv)industrial civilisation is very recent and is not living with the environment in an indefinitely sustainable manner,
(v)indigenous cultures throughout the world are being pushed aside by industrial patterns of environmental exploitation and are in danger of disappearing, and

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion relating to the order of business on the Notice Paper, namely a motion to postpone consideration of Government Business order of the day no. 4 (Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992) until 3 sitting days after today.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an incredible attempt by the Government today to ram through this chamber fundamental changes to the industrial relations system in Australia. The matter concerns the attempt by this Government to take from the Victorian Government at least part of its industrial relations responsibility. This is a political exercise undertaken by the Government to try to demonstrate some failure on behalf of the Victorian Government, which was overwhelmingly elected to put right the terrible economic situation which it inherited in that State.

PARA.TAB: It is one thing to run a political argument, but it is intolerable to abuse the processes of this place in order to pursue that argument. That is what the Government has done. It is seeking to take up a matter that has been on the Notice Paper for some time and to attach to it these very fundamental changes, which are perhaps some of the most significant changes to the industrial relations structure in this country in the last 90 years.

We were given these amendments 24 hours ago. There is no Minister's second reading speech available; there is no explanatory memorandum. It has not gone to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. There obviously has been no allowance for the Opposition parties in this place to process it properly through their shadow Ministry, through their party room. Has this ever occurred before in the history of this Senate? Has there ever been an attempt by a government to ram a political opportunity through this place and so abuse the processes of the Senate? I know of no occurrence such as this in the past. It is something that is shameful and inexcusable on the part of this Government.

We are seeking by this suspension of Standing Orders to allow the Senate to place this item of business on the Notice Paper so that it can be dealt with this parliamentary session and be processed properly by the Opposition. We have a party room meeting scheduled for Wednesday, when the House of Representatives comes back. It is sensible that the debate be adjourned until after then in order that our party room might reach a conclusion and in order that we might be properly instructed for this debate.

If this suspension of Standing Orders is carried, I will seek to move the substantive motion that the item of business be deferred for three days, which will mean that it will come on on Wednesday. On Wednesday morning we can have our party meeting. In the meantime—and I think the Australian Democrats are agreeable to this—we will be seeking to refer these fundamentally important amendments to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in order that the constitutionality can be properly considered. It is well known publicly, from what we know about the Government's intentions, that the Government is engaging in a highly dubious constitutional exercise for political purposes.

This chamber, which is the House of review and which is charged with giving full and proper scrutiny to these matters, should have the advice of its committee process. This Committee, under the chairmanship of Senator Cooney, has a proud record of doing its job properly. When the time comes to debate this matter on Wednesday, the Senate will be properly informed and the debate will be better as a result of that. I am putting forward a sensible proposal which is consistent with the Government's program, but which will allow this chamber to act properly according to its responsibility.

Only a few days ago this Government was condemning the Victorian Government for pressing through its industrial relations legislation without proper scrutiny. Now it seeks to do even worse in this chamber of the Federal Parliament today. It is a disgraceful political exercise; it is abusing the processes of the Senate. The Government ought to take up the challenge it has now been given and withdraw it. Senator Cook ought to have the courage to say, `I shouldn't have done what I'm seeking to do, and I will agree to the adjournment'.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason that we are opposing this motion for the suspension of Standing Orders is not—as I have indicated to Senator Parer, and as I tried to indicate to Senator Hill but he would not stop talking to listen—that we are other than appreciative of the fact that Senator Parer has had great difficulty discussing this matter with Mr Howard over the last 24 hours, since we gave the amendments to him. In the 24 hours that he has had those amendments, the Opposition has been a bit preoccupied, and we understand that very serious concern.

PARA.TAB: Everybody in Australia knows that members of the Opposition have that serious problem. Everybody knows that they are confronting great difficulties with regard to what their own industrial relations policy should be. Everybody knows that those 24 hours have been a very difficult 24 hours for the Opposition, and we are sympathetic that it has had a bad 24 hours.

We made it quite clear that we are prepared to put off the committee hearing stage of this legislation. We have already said that; we made that offer to Senator Parer substantially earlier.If, for some reason—and let me not be any more provocative by speculating about the reason—Senator Parer has not been able to get agreement with Mr Howard about what should be done with regard to these amendments, that is a serious issue and, therefore, the process for dealing with those amendments can be put back. We proposed a committee hearing tomorrow. People said, `No, we want to call witnesses. Can we do it on Monday?' We said, `Yes.' Now we find that the Opposition does not even want to have the second reading today.

TALK.START.PARA: —We haven't seen the explanatory memorandum.
—Those opposite know what the amendments are, and everybody knows what the issues are. The second reading is about the date—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —They know exactly what the Bill is. They all have it; they have had it for 24 hours. They just have not had time to think about it. Why do they not talk to each other about this, instead of talking to each other in that heated frenzy about all those other things they have been talking about.

PARA.TAB: We are prepared to say that the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee should have a look at the Bill. That is fine. We said, first of all, tomorrow, and then when Senator Parer said tomorrow was too early and could we do it on Monday, we said yes. But none of the argument goes to why the second reading should not be able to be done today. None of the argument goes to any indication that there is anybody in Australia who does not know what the principles and the issues to be dealt with in this second reading debate are.

It is possible to argue that those opposite have not had time, for whatever reason, to consider the words and details of the amendment and, therefore, want a bit more time. That is what the committee hearing stage is about and, therefore, we are prepared to put off that stage. But on what possible basis could anybody in Australia, let alone anybody who is supposed to be an elected representative, pretend not to know what the principles and issues to be debated are and, therefore, not be ready to proceed with the second reading? That part of it is a joke. Why do those opposite not just admit that we can do the second reading; we will give them the chance to do the committee hearing stage later, in the hope that some time in the next week they can actually sort out what their policy position is so that they can be ready to go on with that committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a most extraordinary attempt to defend a position which is untenable. All of us know what the Labor Party said about the Victorian Government for pushing through its industrial relations legislation, and the Labor Party is now attempting to do exactly the same thing in this chamber. It is quite obvious what the Labor Party is attempting to do.

PARA.TAB: The tradition has always been that when Bills are brought in—and this is effectively a new Bill, and can be looked at in no other way—the Opposition has an opportunity to take it to its shadow Ministry and to take it to its Party meeting. The Labor Party knows full well that the House of Representatives is not coming back to Canberra until Wednesday of next week. For us to have called a special Party meeting and brought our members of the House of Representatives back to Canberra today would have been a totally irresponsible way of spending taxpayers' money and would have been totally unjustified. No argument has been given by the Labor Party as to why this Bill needs to be rammed through this chamber today; not one reason.

The whole of the speech by Senator McMullan related to attempting to try to embarrass us, which the Government will not succeed in doing, because there is nothing about which we have to be embarrassed. We have not been given the opportunity to look at the detail and the constitutionality of these amendments. Certainly, we have had the opportunity to read what has been said in the newspapers, but we want a little more detail than that if we are to be responsible senators dealing with legislation which affects the lives of so many people—and the Labor Party knows that.

This matter should not proceed in this place today. It should be adjourned so that we have a proper opportunity to look at it. It is not a question of our shadow Minister in the Senate talking to the shadow Minister in the House of Representatives. That may be a part of the process, but that is not the way that we do business. We do business by allowing members of our Party to have an opportunity to have input into the issues involved, and that is being denied to us; that is being denied to the people that we represent.

I would like an honest explanation from the Labor Party as to why it is pursuing this legislation in this manner. People want to have an opportunity to have a say. Some of us might even want to consult with some of our constituency about what we do in a matter like this and how it affects them. But no, the Labor Party wants to make sure that nobody gets an opportunity to deal with this. We are saying that, as a matter of urgency, this legislation should be postponed so that it can be given proper consideration. I would be interested to hear why the Labor Party is attempting to deny all conventions about the way business is dealt with in this place in order to push this legislation through today.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit difficult for the Democrats to be involved in the dispute that is occurring between the coalition and the Government with regard to who is trying to score points off whom and when Opposition party meetings ought to occur and ought not to occur. What we see, of course, is a technicality which has not been met by the Government. We agree with the coalition that it is important that that technicality as to the timing, the sequence and the provision of correct documentation and information be complied with by the Government. We agree that that is true. We also agree that that information should be provided before we reach the committee stage of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The argument as to the principles of where the coalition and the Government stand on this matter is clear; it has been debated. We have heard Mr Howard say several times that the coalition policy on industrial relations is such and such; we have heard other people say that it is something else, and that is amusing but not relevant to this debate. What is relevant is that we consider the amendments by the Government to the Industrial Relations Act and how we react to them. The Democrats are ready to conduct that debate. We see no reason why the second reading debate should not occur. We also see no reason why we should not agree with the coalition that the details of the legislation should be discussed at a later date. We agree that the offer by the Government to discuss the details on, say, next Wednesday should not be taken up. We therefore see no reason for a suspension at the moment because there has been an offer made by the Government which should be taken up. We also agree with the coalition that the details of this discussion should take place at a later date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have again seen an example of the Democrats taking a position and, within 15 minutes, because they had a visitation, changing their minds as to the position they were going to take. In fact, I have just had a minor dispute with one of my own colleagues because no-one in this chamber has seen these amendments, except for a few of us who have received them through the good graces of Senator McMullan.

PARA.TAB: It is an absolutely appalling situation that amendments of this magnitude are brought into this place without an explanatory memorandum or a second reading speech from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). These amendments go to the very heart of federalism in this country and raise a whole series of questions about constitutional validity. I will give an example. An amendment to the objects of the Industrial Relations Act is taken partly from our Federal Constitution—a Constitution which, incidentally, a whole bunch of people opposite want to destroy. Section 51(xxxv) of the Constitution says:

SPEECH.PARA: 51. The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to:-
(xxxv.) Conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes extending beyond the limits of any one State:

In the amendment brought in by the Government, the words `extending beyond the limits of any one State' are omitted. That raises the question of constitutional validity, and it is the responsibility of this Parliament to assure itself that the legislation it passes is constitutionally valid. I am not sure about that with these amendments, and many other people are not sure about it. Until we have the opportunity to investigate that, it is most improper that this Government should pursue these amendments. It is being done simply on the basis of Paul paying back Wally Curran and John Halfpenny because they supported him in the assassination of Bob Hawke—which is what it is all about. Everyone knows that it is about maintaining the power of Trades Hall in Victoria, a trades hall which has the worst reputation in this country because of the way it has participated in the management of the Victorian Government over the past 10 years and has been the contributor to the destruction of that State.

PARA.TAB: It is important that the amendments to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 be deferred until Wednesday to give everyone the opportunity to study them in detail. I cannot believe the change of attitude of the Australian Democrats. They have absolutely changed—

TALK.START.PARA: —They will be deferred.

—I can hear them yabbering, but they are speaking a different language, which is not unusual. It is important that we support the suspension of Standing Orders so that this legislation, which, as my colleague Senator Hill said, will make the most profound change in industrial relations in this country for 90 years, can be properly debated and not rammed through this place by the sort of standover union bully tactics that Government senators are well versed in.

—I cannot let the phrase `rammed through' go without comment. The legislation in Victoria was rammed through the Victorian Parliament. As a result, it is generally conceded that that industrial relations legislation is extremely faulty. Indeed, it imposes draconian measures not only on the people directly affected but on the people of Victoria as a whole. I mention that in passing; it has nothing to do with the motion that Standing Orders be suspended for the purpose of allowing Senator Hill to move his motion.

PARA.TAB: I am going to support the suspension of Standing Orders, but I will oppose part of Senator Hill's motion when it comes forward. I do not think that we need three sitting days to consider the amendments because that will take us to Wednesday next week. But I acknowledge what Senator McMullan has said, which is that the Government is proposing not to have the Senate consider the committee stage until next week and until the matter goes before the relevant parliamentary committee. That is a reasonable proposition. But the second reading stage of the Bill enables members of parliament to state their views on the principles governing the measure.

I have thought deeply about this question. I have always been of the view that once we get outside the conciliation and arbitration powers of the Commonwealth, when it comes to industrial legislation we are opening gates which may not be able to be closed if and when another government comes into power. Thus, I am very strongly opposed to the use of the corporations power, as an example, to be relied upon for amendments to industrial legislation.

I clearly see the need for this Parliament, in some way, to overcome the situation that exists in Victoria where workers are denied the opportunity to go to the independent umpire. I have a difficulty, because for many years I have opposed strenuously the use of the external affairs power for purposes other than those for which it was originally designed in the Constitution. I am still deeply concerned about that matter and I am consulting fairly widely on it.

At this stage I am not in a position to deliver any views in a speech today on that aspect. That is one of the reasons that I am supporting the proposal by Senator Hill for a suspension of Standing Orders. But I make it perfectly clear that, if necessary, at the end of the day this Parliament must do something to protect the livelihoods of those who have been so grievously wronged in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning we have heard from the man who passes for the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator McMullan, a poor excuse that says that we can somehow discuss an amendment which goes to the fundamental nature of a Bill without an explanatory memorandum. The reasons we have explanatory memorandums are enshrined in much literature. He is saying that we can get up in this chamber and talk about legislation which is not even fully available for senators to examine and discuss.

PARA.TAB: I remind honourable senators that when we rise to speak in a second reading debate we are actually addressing a Bill and its amendments. We need the full documentation before us to know precisely what we are discussing; otherwise we would simply rise in here to discuss a motion that it would be a good idea if we had some legislation on a particular topic. That is not what the procedure is about.

Senator Harradine mentioned the powers that are relied upon in order to bring in legislation which purports to be within the powers conferred on this Parliament, and they concern a very serious parliamentary question. It is one which clearly the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) does not know, comprehend or care about.

We say in this chamber that we are a House of review. We have a group of people over here who call themselves the Australian Democrats, who like to say that they consider things on their merits. Clearly they are not doing that this morning. If they had any clear understanding of the way in which the Parliament works, they would say, `Without the explanatory memorandum before this Parliament, we cannot proceed to a proper speech in a second reading debate'.

We have often said in this place, `You cannot buy the Democrats, but you can certainly rent them by the half hour'. It would seem at this stage that we should ask them precisely what deal has been done here today. What other legislation or advantage are they going to get as a result of agreeing to proceed in this way? It is very disappointing. Don Chipp used to say that they were here to keep the bastards honest. I ask honourable senators: who these days are the bastards and who is keeping whom honest?
Senator Walters will tell honourable senators that she had a conversation with these same Democrats earlier today—

TALK.START.PARA: —Two minutes ago.

—She had a conversation two minutes before they got up and said that they were going to agree with the Government, but a conversation took place between the Minister and the Democrats following her conversation. So we are in this disgraceful situation where proper debate of serious legislation with full constitutional implications is being treated as a farce. Once again, there has been that little deal between the Democrats and the Government because the Government has given some commitment to Mr Kelty—the unnamed member of the Cabinet—that this legislation will be delivered on a particular date.

PARA.TAB: The ugly face of trade unionism is again showing itself here and setting the agenda in this Parliament—and those trade unionists are not elected. The only trade unionist who is elected in this place that we know of publicly is the Minister—and we frequently do not know whether he speaking on behalf of the BWIU or as a Minister of State. We are seeing the ugly face of trade unionism dictating the agenda in this chamber so that we are not even in the position of having the full documentation before honourable senators to commence this important debate on legislation that is bound to end up in the High Court.

Indeed, we have even passed the Acts Interpretation Act in this place so that courts are entitled to take note of explanatory memoranda and second reading speeches as a determining factor in interpreting legislation, yet we are in the position where we do not have the correct documentation to properly debate those important issues. As my Deputy Whip has pointed out to me, the Democrats did agree with us and then changed their minds and agreed with the Government. We ask ourselves: why is it so? Given the seriousness of what has been done here this morning, the Australian people will have to make a judgment about whether a contribution is truly made in this chamber by people who purport to consider things on merit but are obviously available for a deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Comment has been made about the Constitution and what is legal under that document. One of the most influential awards in Australia, and happily so for employers, has long been a Federal award—ever since about 1929—covering the metal manufacturing industry. What we propose is not to go away from the Constitution but, under a provision which has not been questioned up until this time, to widen that provision.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition talks about the extension of a dispute beyond the boundaries of one State. The facts are that there have been many disputes in enterprises in Australia that were wholly within a State. Because of their connection with the metal trades employers and the Federal award, those disputes have been dealt with by the Federal commission—of course, always with the approval of those on the other side of the chamber. Those opposite talk about the Government being in an enormous hurry to get this legislation through the chamber. This is a response from a ramming through by the Kennett Government of those sorts of provisions that will take away wages and conditions from workers that they fought and argued for in the Arbitration Commission, given to them by the umpire and as requested by the Opposition over the whole 31 years of government by the Opposition.

Those opposite talk about our proposition as though we are forcing something on somebody. I guess the legislation would take away the right to dictatorially put conditions on workers as the Kennett Government has done. We are saying to workers that we will provide the opportunity for them to come across to a Federal award. If they wish to do that, they will; if they do not, they will stay with the State position.

In the colonies as they were before Federation, all of the provisions that covered employment—there were not a great number of them because at that time we were not very sophisticated in that area—were State provisions. But the people who put together the document we know as the Constitution decided that there should be Federal involvement. There is not any doubt that the type of people who sit across the chamber today are the same type of people who decided that Federal awards should be brought into existence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Would you please make Senator Burns speak to the suspension of Standing Orders? He is giving his speech on the second reading debate and it is absolutely ludicrous that you are letting him get away with it.
