DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL CHEMICALS (NOTIFICATION AND ASSESSMENT) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992COAL INDUSTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992INTERNATIONAL LABOUR ORGANISATION (COMPLIANCE WITH CONVENTIONS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate on Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 resumed from 15 October, debate on Coal Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 resumed from 17 September, and debate on International Labour Organisation (Compliance with Conventions) Bill 1992 resumed from 11 November, on motion by Senator Cook:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating three Bills together: the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, the Coal Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and the International Labour Organisation (Compliance with Conventions) Bill 1992. I will separately address the three subjects.

PARA.TAB: The Industrial Chemicals Amendment Bill acts on the recommendations of a consultant's report on the practical business effect of the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme. In 1989 a Hawke Government Act set up a scheme for the regulation of industrial chemicals. The consultants appointed by the Government to gauge the industry's response to the scheme reported that there should be less regulation.

Three specific areas have been covered in this Bill. There is still insufficient recognition of foreign assessment of chemicals. However, Australia is still reinventing the wheel too often, and there must be an impetus to a system which will accept a proper assessment from abroad without requiring a completely new assessment for use in this country—another example of unnecessary duplication. Clause 8 of the Bill creates an amnesty period. I understand that an amendment has been put in by the Government which will set the amnesty period at two years, rather than doing so by regulation.

There has been a national register of chemicals since at least 1977. However, business has sometimes failed to use the register. The Industrial Chemicals Act 1989 provided for heavy criminal sanctions for those businesses which introduced chemicals into Australia without first submitting information to the Director of Chemicals Notification and Assessment. Some companies, aware of the register, were nevertheless misinformed by their foreign suppliers about the constituents of imported chemical products, and some chemicals were overlooked. The inventory was formally closed in February 1990, making it impossible for companies to take any steps after that time to put themselves within the law. It has taken the Government another three years to get its house in order.

The coalition suggests that the Government should learn from the failure of the publicity campaign following the 1989 Act and create a kit to help businesses identify their duties under the law. There is an eligible chemical category which provides for chemicals which could have been registered on the Australian inventory but which were not. It will be merely necessary to prove that the company in question was manufacturing or importing the chemicals before the inventory closed.

Consultants to Worksafe Australia, working with the industry, have proposed two further areas of amendments to the 1989 Act. The first amendment relates to industrial chemicals to be used in small amounts only. Low volumes of chemicals, often imported as minor constituents of a complex chemical product, are unlikely to create a threat to health or to the broader environment. The cheaper and faster processes which are available under the Bill can make a difference between profit and loss for a product with only very limited sales opportunities or potential. Of course, if the chemical is imported in amounts that bring it into the usual volume categories, the regular provisions and sanctions of the Act will apply.

The second area of reform recommended by the consultants to Worksafe covered a radical simplification of the process of assessment of those chemicals known as polymers of low concern. These polymers are those synthetic polymers with characteristics that satisfy the regulations to be made under this Bill. Typically, they will be extremely stable, non-volatile and non-susceptible to easy transfer across biological membranes. Polymers filling this bill are most unlikely to make for a threat to public health.

The chemical industry remains concerned at the slow progress of changes to the national chemicals industry notification assessment scheme concerning the importation of chemicals recognised by appropriate organisations overseas. The coalition shares the concerns expressed by the industry. We also call on the Government to work with industry to encourage the use of published reports prepared by the exporting country when considering whether to accept a chemical for export into this country. It is pointless and a waste of public money to prepare extensive reports for the national chemical scheme under the principal Act when there may be perfectly acceptable research from the exporting country on which Australia may make a rapid decision on import permission. It has all the earmarks of a continuing make-work program.

The reporting scheme requires the payment of hefty fees, making delays in the assessment process yet another cost to industry. There is a point at which the importer will say, `Why should I bother making the product or using the process if the red tape over chemical assessment makes the whole business proposition a marginal one?'. The Liberal and National parties understand that the industry, through the Australian Chemical Industry Council, is discussing the question of recognition of assessments prepared by the exporting country or another country to remove the need for doubling up of the work in this country. Let us hope that the Government gives support to those discussions so that Australia does not do what it has done so often under this Labor Government, and that is cut off its employment nose to spite its regulatory face. The coalition will not be opposing the Bill.

The second Bill we are debating is the Coal Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. It provides for amendments to the Coal Industry Act 1946 and the Industrial Relations Act 1988. The aim of the Bill is to transfer administrative support for the Coal Industry Tribunal from the Joint Coal Board to the Australian Industrial Registry. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) noted in his second reading speech that the Bill does not in any way alter the Tribunal's powers and functions and he has commenced a process of consultation with a view to making changes to those powers and functions.

This legislation is a gutless wimp-out of yet another opportunity to reform our most major export industry in Australia. The question of whether the Joint Coal Board—which includes the Coal Industry Tribunal—should continue to exist was examined by the Industry Commission, which recommended that the Coal Board be disbanded and any necessary ongoing functions be allocated to other bodies. This view was rejected by the Government, not because it did not believe it was well overdue but because the militant trade union movement would not have a bar of it. At one time, Senator Cook was responsible for resources. He would know the intransigence of those union people in what should be the modern updating of this industry. Everyone in the industry knows, and has known for two decades, that the Coal Industry Tribunal is an anachronism. Successive governments have regrettably shied away from abolishing it. I am not entirely sheeting the blame home to those opposite because it goes back 20 years.

In February 1987, the Coal Association produced a comprehensive 72-page document entitled A case for change relating to the Coal Industry Tribunal. The thrust of the submission was to return the industry to mainstream industrial relations as an essential requirement for the future health and viability of our most important export industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with it.

—I thank Senator Cook. Historically, the Coal Industry Tribunal—it is worth going back to show what an anachronism it is—was established in 1946 by the then Minister for Post-War Reconstruction. I would have thought—I am sure Senator Cook will agree—that we are past those days. The Tribunal arose out of anarchy in the coalmines when Australia was going through its most troubled time in history, the Second World War. The Joint Coal Board and the Coal Industry Tribunal were supposed to solve the problems of the coal industry in New South Wales. It did not work then, as evidenced by the Chifley Government bringing troops into the mines. It has never worked, yet successive governments have not addressed the problem, and neither has this Government, although it has moved in the right direction to some degree. For that reason, we will not be opposing the Bill.

PARA.TAB: As I mentioned earlier, coal is our largest single export, with over $7 billion worth of coal going to 30 different countries around the world. We mine about 160 million tonnes of coal and export around 120 million tonnes per year. Despite the best efforts of the Whitlam Government and the mentor of the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating), Mr Connor, to stop the growth of that industry, it has become Australia's leading exporter. Without this industry, Australia would be in diabolical trouble. Australia is in bad enough trouble as it is, but it would be entirely down the gurgler without this industry.

However, it is important—I have said this on a number of occasions—to keep the whole thing in perspective. Australia is not the only producer and exporter of coal in the world. If we read the popular press and listen to some of the idiotic remarks made by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly, or Senator Coulter, we would think it was. While it is our major export industry, it pales into insignificance compared with countries such as the United States and China. Whereas we export some 80 per cent of our production, those countries consume most of their coal domestically. Our production of around 160 million tonnes becomes insignificant compared with the one billion tonnes produced in both China and the United States. Over the next few years China plans to increase its production from one billion to 1.4 billion tonnes simply to meet its own anticipated demand for energy.

It is all right for people in Australia to talk about carbon levels and all those sorts of things in the enjoyment of their own armchairs where they can flick a switch and the electricity comes on, but it is very different to be in a place such as China where people walk around with hurricane lamps. Those people would quite properly like to be able to flick a switch and have the same comforts that these armchair extreme environmentalists have in Australia.

These statistics are not meant to downplay the importance of the coal industry in Australia—far from it. They are meant to highlight some of the nonsense, as I mentioned earlier, spoken by people such as Minister Kelly and Senator Coulter. Every time a silly remark is made about carbon taxes and so on, it leads to nervous customers not just in the power and cement industry but also in the world's steel industries. Our very poor record in industrial relations has led to diversification. Every time a stupid remark is made by these people just to attract a few minority lunatic groups in our society, it is to the detriment of our most important export industry and thus to every person in this country.

Last month we saw the biggest balance of payments deficit for three years—$1.8 billion—and our gross foreign debt was in excess of $200 billion. Without our coal exports of $7 billion a year to the world's steel, power, cement and chemical industries, Australia would be in the hands of the receivers; yet we have irresponsible people—people who should know better—in this Parliament making remarks which are to the detriment of their own country.

The Executive Director of the Australian Coal Association, Meredith Hellicar, has warned that despite productivity increases of 70 per cent between 1980 and 1990, labour cost increases have outstripped productivity improvements. That is worth dwelling on because that in itself shows the failure of the centralised industrial system in this country. We cannot go on having labour cost increases in excess of productivity. It is inevitable if that occurs that we will see more and more mines shutting down and more and more countries supplying the coal that currently comes from Australia. Over that 10-year period productivity increased by 70 per cent, with labour increases greater. So much for the award restructuring, the accord and micro-economic reform!

Those who argue that a reduction in the value of the dollar by 15 per cent will benefit the industry are ignoring two vital factors: firstly, the capital equipment, most of which is imported, will cost more; and, secondly, with reduced demand on overseas markets—that currently is the position—Australian coal suppliers will be very hard pressed to maintain last year's prices in the coming negotiations. I know that everyone would like to encourage them not only to maintain their old prices but also to increase them. We have to be realistic and very cautious because it is important that nothing we say here should in any way affect their negotiations.

It is appalling that because of the constraints of time caused by the Labor Government, which is incapable of organising its own business properly and which has brought Australia to the brink of ruin, we are limited in engaging in a full scale debate on our single most important export industry. The Opposition is of the opinion that yet again the Government has wimped out in addressing the functions of the Joint Coal Board and the Coal Industry Tribunal. However, as I mentioned earlier, as it is a step in the right direction, the coalition will not oppose the Bill. As has been indicated in the coalition's Fightback package, the Joint Coal Board will be abandoned on the coalition being elected to government.

Finally, I refer to the International Labour Organisation (Compliance with Conventions) Bill 1992. The Bill seeks to amend the Migration Act 1958 and the Navigation Act 1912. With regard to the Migration Act, the Bill makes inconsequential amendments to provisions relating to the production of identity documents and mustering of crew, the production of identity documents by persons on board resource installations, and production of identity documents by persons on board sea installations.

In the past, with regard to foreign crews coming to Australia, the system has been that the Customs official would go aboard the ship and the skipper or the master would have all the documents. Now the individual will hold the documents and there will be a line-up so that—I presume for our benefit—the Customs official can see that the documents line up with the crew member when the ship arrives and that the same documents line up when he leaves. So we have no opposition to that.

With regard to the Navigation Act, the Bill seeks to make amendments to provisions for adequate storage of water and food, adequate catering facilities and regulations to give effect to the Medical Examination (Seafarers) Convention. We have no concerns with that.

As I have indicated, the amendments appear to the coalition to be of an administrative nature, given the current agenda of the Government to implement ILO conventions on industrial relations. But we also believe that this should be approached with a degree of caution. We will not oppose the Bill. But we stress as strongly as we can our total disapproval of the Government's agenda of using overseas conventions—in this case the ILO convention—to interfere with the free choice of employers and employees to decide how the terms and conditions of their employment are to be governed. It is our view that the external affairs powers were to be used entirely for that reason, not for any internal domestic matters. That matter will be the subject of debate on the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill (No. 2). (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering three cognate Bills—the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, the Coal Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and the International Labour Organisation (Compliance with Conventions) Bill 1992—all of which are essentially administrative in nature and do little to change any thrust or philosophy.

PARA.TAB: The Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Amendment Bill has been in gestation for some time, which has given the Australian Democrats the opportunity to speak with vested interest on behalf of people who represent paint industries and users of chemicals. We have been able to receive their representations and to consider the effect that such a Bill would have on the industry. We have also been able to speak with those people who express concern about the way that we use chemicals within our country, how we dispose of them and how they impinge on our industrial activities, social activities and normal daily business.

A growing concern in our community is that chemicals should be used in a responsible manner and that we should not have unnecessary chemicals free in the environment affecting things which they should not affect. We have had time to look at this Bill in light of the concerns that are expressed by a growing number of people. We are satisfied that what is proposed does not add any danger to the amount of chemical effect that is not intended. It seems that a great deal of commonsense applies in this Bill. It proposes to remove some of the undue bureaucracy which is attached to assessing whether chemicals will be a danger to people other than the direct users.

I support Senator Parer's suggestion that it is commonsense to accept the research documentation which is provided from overseas rather than to repeat, in an unproductive manner, the doubling up of research on the same chemical which happens in Australia. I also agree with Senator Parer that it seems common sense and would be a good idea to create a kit to help companies identify their obligations under the law. It seems that far too often we add obligations without considering cross-referencing and the relevance that these new obligations might have to existing ones. Senator Parer's suggestions are good, but are not being delivered at the moment, although the proposition does remove some of the previously cumbersome bureaucratese.

When this Bill first saw the light of day, we were concerned that an open-ended amnesty, which I think was intended to be transitional, might apply. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee shared that concern. I am pleased to see that the Government has taken that matter into account and addressed it so that it will not deliver an open-ended amnesty.

I turn to the Coal Industry Legislation Amendment Bill. Senator Parer identified that essentially it embraces an eminently desirable administrative change. But then Senator Parer spent some minutes—and I will not attempt to use the same amount of time—addressing the coal industry in its wider perspective. He gave some statistics of which I am sure those who are interested in the Australian industry would be well aware. He said that coal is a major component of Australia's export earnings; that it is the significant industry in that area; and that, even considering that fact, it is still far overwhelmed by the size of the industry in China and the United States.

Senator Parer then took a couple of cheap passing shots at people who had expressed concern at the way in which the use of coal affects the common environment that we share with the rest of the world. I was slighted by Senator Parer's disparagement of people who express concern about the profligate way we use energy. People who express such concern—and Senator Parer in his insult singled out such people as Senator Coulter and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly—were described by Senator Parer as passing stupid remarks. I challenge the suggestion that they are stupid. I suggest that those who express concern about our profligate use of energy are very wise and that their wisdom will be vindicated by the passage of history.

The stupid ones are those who do not recognise that coal is a finite resource. It is by definition `finite'—we cannot create it. What is there will eventually be used. What is there is being used, I would suggest, at an unsustainable pace. Of course, by definition we cannot sustain the use of something that is finite. But to reduce its use, to consider carefully how best to gain the utmost productivity out of each kilogram, is a much wiser way of using that resource than use that is cavalier and pays no regard to the fact that eventually we will run out.

A carbon tax has been suggested, but its immediate effect would be to increase the price. The effect of increasing a price is that people will seek to squeeze whatever possible productivity they can out of the resource and that users are keener to exploit a particular resource to its fullest, rather than to allow inefficiencies to creep into its usage. It has been said that any suggestion that we should slow down our use of this resource will affect our export industries. The suggestion may be accurate, but it is a subjective consideration to label such concerns as stupid.

I suggest that there are many other effects on the bargaining process of our export industries—not the least of which are the exchange rate, remarks made about the state of our economy and the status of the Government. If we were to ignore all these concerns and quiver in our boots rather than to make any comments about them, then we need not bother coming into this Parliament. This Parliament is a forum at which we should exchange ideas, and we should not be intimidated by the suggestion that we may have an effect on some other industry around Australia. With all that out of the way, the opportunity to oppose this Bill is not there. We agree with what it is proposing to do.

I wish quickly to address the International Labour Organisation (Compliance with Conventions) Bill. Of course, this is a perfectly reasonable proposition. The Democrats agree with the Bill whose contents are welcome. It is logical that the identity of foreign crews should be in the hands of individuals rather than that we should adopt the paternalistic idea that the master of the ship should say who the particular individuals are. We should readily comply with the sections in the Navigation Act as to the provision of sufficient water, food and catering within a ship, and we should be anxious about such matters.

I challenge the comment by Senator Parer that we should be careful in using overseas conventions—which, in his words, `interfere with the employees' and the employers' free choice'. I remind Senator Parer that the International Labour Organisation is a tripartite organisation. It certainly does not exclude employers, government or labour from the opportunity to participate in its proceedings. In fact, the ILO deserves greater respect than to be written off as just another international show. It is a forum in which all interested parties and individuals are able to be represented. It is wrong to suggest that the ILO interferes with employers' and employees' opportunities to indulge in free choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Using conventions to bypass the Constitution was my argument.

—I well understand Senator Parer's argument. I would challenge it, because there are instances of the virtual enslavement of people employed on international vessels. Those who are interested in this matter may have taken note of an incident which occurred some months ago when a crew of an international vessel arrived in Hobart. I would only describe the situation of those seafarers as destitute. I was unable to visit the vessel myself and make my own assessment, but I think the photograph on the front page of a newspaper of the crew and the description of the conditions explained the position quite clearly. Crew members had insufficient clothing and food. Certainly their living conditions could not possibly be described as adequate; they were living on a seagoing slum.

PARA.TAB: The journalist who reported the incident described the opportunities for the crew to be able to leave the vessel as almost zero. The seafarers themselves were under an obligation to pay any travel fees that they incurred when the vessel went from one port to another. Such travel fees exceeded the measly wages that they were paid, so these poor souls were enslaved to the ship.

That is a disgusting state of affairs and we should join in any international obligations to prevent such things happening in future. Behaviour of this kind amounts to a crime; it is immoral and disgusting. If it is being suggested that the International Labour Organisation imposes international conventions to bypass the freedom of employers and employees to choose their own agreements, then I believe that there are many situations in which that should occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the interference in domestic matters with which I was concerned.
—If it is interference in domestic matters, there are some domestic matters which I believe should be interfered with. The Democrats support this package of Bills. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—As the previous two speakers have said, we are debating cognately—to use the affectation of the Senate—three Bills: the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, the Coal Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and the International Labour Organisation (Compliance with Conventions) Bill 1992.

PARA.TAB: As has been said by the previous two speakers, Senator Parer representing the coalition and Senator Bell representing the Australian Democrats, both the coalition and the Democrats support the Bills that the Government has brought forward.Since these Bills are industrial relations Bills, perhaps it should not go unremarked that on a day on which we have had some degree of controversy in this chamber on that subject, we follow it up immediately by all of us jointly supporting legislation on industrial relations in these three areas. That is at least some indication that there is an element of cooperation about basic provisions in this field, although that does not go to the areas of philosophical difference between the major parties on industrial relations.

Since the Opposition and the Democrats support the Government on this legislation, it does not require me to say very much at all about the arguments brought forward in debate. This has been an opportunity, as sometimes occurs in this chamber, for the contributors to the debate to use the subject heading of the Bill to talk more widely about their views in that field than about the substance of the Bill. I am not critical of that. It happens on both sides of the chamber, and it happened again today. While it is interesting to hear those views, nothing was put that ought to dissuade this chamber from giving the Bills passage.

I will foreshadow now that when the Industrial Chemicals Bill and the International Labour Organisation Bill reach the committee stage, I will move to each of those an amendment. That amendment has been referred to by the speakers who have preceded me. It is known and anticipated, and I expect it will be unanimously accepted and carried.

I therefore now turn to a couple of the remarks that have been made. I will start in the middle and out of order, just to make it a little more interesting than otherwise would be the case. I acknowledge that Senator Parer, as an old coal man—and I am sure he would not mind me sourcing his interests to the industry in which he spent so much of his time—has had some remarks to make about the coal industry, its importance as the leading export commodity for Australia and Australia's standing as the largest exporter in the world of coal although, of course, not the largest producer of coal. I note his comments about that.

This legislation that we are enacting is to complement legislation passed by the Fahey Government in New South Wales to manage the Joint Coal Board. There are a lot of things that Senator Parer said with which I have considerable sympathy. They relate to the future of the Coal Industry Tribunal. It is a question, as are many others in this country, where we might agree on where we ought to go but we do disagree on how we should get there, what method of consultation we should use and how we manage change, but I note for the record those remarks. I do not want at this stage to get involved in the argument about the environmental impact of the coal industry. I do not think it is relevant to this debate.

In the case of the Industrial Chemicals Notification and Assessment Bill, one of the comments that was made by Senator Parer, and echoed to some extent by Senator Bell, was the responsibility of Government, upon enacting these changes, to promote them to industries so that industries are aware of their obligations under the law. While it is true that, in any court, ignorance of the law is not a defence, it is a fair point to make that when a government changes the law, it does have a responsibility to make it clear to those who would be affected by that change what the changes are and how their obligations have altered consequently.

I am advised that Worksafe Australia, the national occupational health and safety authority, the body responsible under our Government for the propagation of this information, is currently preparing a strategy to promote the new scheme and to ensure that industry is well informed about it. It has prepared a comprehensive handbook which explains to industry what it needs to do to comply with the scheme. I mention that as a point of information because I do think the point both speakers have made is a virtuous one in this debate.

I turn in conclusion to the third Bill, the International Labour Organisation (Compliance with Conventions) Bill. The purpose of this Bill was explained in the second reading speech. We are, by this legislation, bringing Australian maritime law, by and large, into compliance with international labour standards. The changes are not major—they are minor changes—but they correct, if you like, the body of law in Australia so that we conform to the international standard that the ILO has recommended to governments.

The ILO is an agency of the United Nations. It is to labour law what the World Health Organisation is to health standards in the world. It recommends, in the field of labour regulation, what acceptable minimum standards should be. It is for the various governments to decide to accept those recommendations. Australia has a reputation in the world as a country that supports the United Nations and wants the United Nations to be an effective pacifying influence in the world, and to enhance the degree of civilisation and respect for civilised standards.

It is for those reasons that we cleave to a recognition of the standards that the United Nations agencies recommend, right across the board, in health and other areas. In this case, the International Labour Organisation recommends for labour law. I might say the process of adopting these conventions has been exhaustive. The conventions themselves are given life by an exhaustive process within the agencies of the ILO itself.

As Senator Bell rightly said, this is a tripartite body. It is a body made up of delegates from all countries that are affiliated with it, which is most in the world, and those delegates are split into three groups: workers' representatives, government representatives and employer representatives. The conventions that the ILO recommends have been endorsed by a combined session of all of the countries represented in that tripartite way. So it represents, if I can put it in these terms, the comprehensive view of all of the interest groups who are involved in industrial relations, be they workers, employers or governments, meeting together from all the countries that are affiliated with the United Nations. Therefore, they carry a particular force. They are not partisan; they are not one group's view as opposed to another group's view; they are the adopted view of all and they carry a particular force. Because we recognise the role of the United Nations, it seems appropriate for us as a country to ensure that we do not fall below those minimum standards. This law that we are enacting now will ensure, in the case of the maritime industry, that that is not the case.

While I say the changes are minor, the pleasing feature of them is that it enables us to conform with the conventions and adopt them. It also provides that there will be regular reviews between the Commonwealth Government and each of the State governments under these conventions in a way in which the States and the Commonwealth can work together in the interests of Australia in international forums of the ILO and in monitoring the effect of those changes. It is for those reasons that I support these Bills and accept the remarks and support of the other speakers.

There is another Bill that is in the wings which will come on for debate later today. It is a Bill of much greater controversy. It is a Bill which relates to changing an existing provision in the Industrial Relations Act which will enable workers under State awards, where those State awards have been frozen and the access to independent arbitration abolished, to then opt for a fast track method of re-establishing their awards as Federal awards rather than State awards. The legislation applies, of course, in the State of Victoria, but it is national legislation which will apply where access to independent arbitration has been abolished by a State government. The head of power in the Constitution under which it will operate is the existing head of power that it operates under now, which is the arbitration power. But that is a debate for another time; that other time will be soon, but it is not now. I commend these Bills, with my foreshadowed amendments, to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: INDUSTRIAL CHEMICALS (NOTIFICATION AND ASSESSMENT) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendments to be moved to the Bill. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 8, page 4, proposed section 20B, lines 5 to 8, omit the section, substitute the following section:

PARA.TAB: "`20B. For the purposes of this Division, the amnesty period is the period of 2 years from the commencement of this Division.".

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make six very brief points in relation to the amendment. This is an amendment to clause 8 of the Bill. Clause 8 adds division 4 to the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989, an amnesty for eligible chemicals—`eligible chemicals' being as defined. The amendment substitutes a new proposed section 20B for that originally proposed. The originally proposed section 20B provided for the amnesty period for eligible chemicals to be prescribed by regulation. But the proposed new section, which is the point of this amendment, provides for a fixed two-year amnesty period. So we would prescribe the amnesty period in legislation rather than by regulation.

PARA.TAB: The change reflects agreement within the Government, which has consulted with the industry and with unions. The industry organisations support it, as does the ACTU. The fixed period provides additional certainty and will be supported by a promotion strategy, as I said in my earlier remarks. I commend the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition supports this amendment. In fact, it removes one of the concerns we had, in that it does, by legislation, impose a two-year limit. I would like to ask the Minister a couple of questions in respect of the Bill. A publicity program was put out in respect of people complying with the original Bill and the comment was made that it failed to reach the people who needed the information most. Is that publicity program continuing and is there some intent on behalf of the Government to make sure that it does reach those people who need it most?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be that Senator Parer was not in the chamber—I think in fact he was absent—when I made a remark about this in reply to the second reading debate. The point I made was that, while of course it is true that ignorance of the law is not a defence in a court of law—people are supposed to know the law—the question Senator Parer had raised in his remarks, supported by Senator Bell in his remarks, is that nonetheless when the law is changed there is some sort of obligation, particularly when the change may go unnoticed, on the Government or its agencies to promote the change to those who are affected so they are aware of the change and can comply.

PARA.TAB: I take that as the sense of Senator Parer's question: what are we doing about this? A strategy is being developed by Worksafe Australia, which has also prepared a comprehensive booklet of explanation which it will provide to industry. The strategy will underpin that so that there will be information supplied in a targeted way, so that those who will be affected by these changes will be aware of them.

It should also fairly be said that organisations like the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the peak employer body, which has been involved in talks with the Government about these changes and which supports the amendment I have just moved—as does Senator Parer—provide as a service to their members information of this character. While all employers are not members of that body, I would certainly recommend to them that they should join. It is an efficient organisation representing their interests; it will keep them informed on these matters and it will be to their advantage. In any case, the Government will maintain its own publicity program and it will work with the organisation in order to see that all those affected are reached.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that response. The purpose of this legislation is to cover technical breaches. However, I notice that no indication was given of the number of technical breaches that have occurred. I wonder whether the Minister can give me some indication of the number, any consequences of those breaches, the number of companies involved and the total amount, if any, of penalties waived?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Parer is correct in saying that one purpose of this Bill is to cover technical breaches. He asked about the number of breaches that have occurred. No prosecutions have occurred but from time to time there is a finding that people are out of conformity. When they know that, they usually bring themselves into conformity as soon as possible. So there has been no stand-off at law resulting in a prosecution. But there is sufficient traffic through the various agencies of the Commonwealth to indicate a need to cover this prospect.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: COAL INDUSTRY AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: INTERNATIONAL LABOUR ORGANISATION (COMPLIANCE WITH CONVENTIONS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill. Senator COOK (Western Australia—Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support) (11.27 a.m.)—I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendments and ask leave to move the two Government amendments together.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)After clause 2, page 1, insert the following Part:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "PART 1A—PROVISION FOR GIVING EFFECT TO THE TRIPARTITE CONSULTATION (INTERNATIONAL LABOUR STANDARDS) CONVENTION, 1976

PARA.TAB: "2A. The Governor-General may make regulations prescribing procedures to be observed for the purposes of the Tripartite Consultation (International Labour Standards) Convention, 1976 adopted by the General Conference of the International Labour Organisation on 21 June 1976.".

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Title, page 1, after "An Act to" insert "make provision for giving effect to an international convention and to".

These amendments propose the creation of a regulation making power to enable procedures to be prescribed for the purposes of the Tripartite Consultation (International Labour Standards) Convention 1976 No. 144. The Convention was adopted by the ILO on 21 June 1976 and ratified by Australia on 11 June 1979.

PARA.TAB: Convention No. 144 requires the Government to consult, at least annually, with the most representative organisations of employers and workers about a variety of matters specified in the convention, which include action proposed in each member state—in this case, Australia—in connection with newly adopted conventions and recommendations; the re-examination at appropriate intervals of unratified conventions and/or recommendations to which effect has not yet been given to consider what measures might be taken to promote their implementation and ratification as appropriate; questions arising out of reports to be made to the International Labour Organisation office under article 22 of the constitution of the International Labour Organisation concerning ratified conventions; and proposals for the denunciation of ratified conventions.

A matter of particular significance involves questions, often in the form of direct requests, arising out of reports made to the ILO office under article 22 of the ILO constitution. Under this article, member states are required to report at regular intervals—each two years for human rights conventions and each four years for other conventions—on the current situation with respect to law and practice for each convention that they have ratified.

Direct requests emanate from the ILO committee of experts on the application of conventions and recommendations and can raise issues about Australia's compliance with ratified conventions. Where the Committee concludes that Australia does not comply with a particular convention, it may request the Government to make an appropriate change to Australian law and practice. Direct requests and the Government's responses to them can therefore be very significant. Accordingly, the Government considers it desirable to formalise procedures for the consultation required by convention No. 144 by the making of appropriate regulations, particularly in respect of the handling of direct requests. It is for those reasons that I commend the amendments to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support these amendments. However, with your approval, Madam Temporary Chairman, I will now respond briefly to a remark by Senator Bell in order to save me from making a personal explanation later.

PARA.TAB: In response to an interjection on my part that the Opposition was opposed to the use of overseas conventions to bypass the Constitution for what were clearly domestic matters, Senator Bell said that I was opposed to ILO conventions in respect of the conditions of crews on ships visiting Australia. That is the misrepresentation to which I refer. I said that I was opposed to the use of conventions to bypass our Constitution on matters which were purely of a domestic nature by the improper use of the external affairs power.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 reported with amendment; Coal Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 reported without amendment; and International Labour Organisation (Compliance with Conventions) Bill 1992 reported with an amendment and an amendment in the title; report adopted.
Bills (on motion by Senator Cook) read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Before the Senate moves to the next item of business, which is the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) whether an explanatory memorandum is available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—It is my understanding that an explanatory memorandum for the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) will be circulated today. I understand, given the procedures adopted by this chamber, that there will be a committee hearing and a committee procedure at the committee stage of the Bill and that, as a result of the committee hearing, it may be appropriate to amend the memorandum. I understand that that will depend on what comes forward.
—What is the point of that? We want to have it now.
—As I said, in direct answer to the question, there will be an explanatory memorandum available later today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of that answer by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion relating to the conduct of business, namely a motion to postpone Government Business order of the day No. 4 (Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992) till the Government has tabled an explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendments to be moved to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Acting Deputy President, you know as a result of earlier debate today the unsatisfactory process that the Government is adopting in relation to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. This is legislation upon which the Government is seeking to force today's second reading debate without the proper process being observed. Not only are we being put at a disadvantage by not being permitted the usual courtesy of taking this matter to our party room for decision—this is the first time in recent history, certainly in the 11 years that I have been here, of which I am aware that a government has acted in such a discourteous way—but also we are being asked to go on to the second reading of this Bill without an explanatory memorandum being available as to the content of the Bill.

PARA.TAB: As I said in an earlier debate, serious constitutional questions are involved in this debate. As one of my colleagues correctly pointed out, under existing law the explanatory memorandum can and should be taken into account by judges in the interpretation of what is being legislated.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a critical part of the Bill.

—It is an integral part of the legislative process. It is unheard of that the Government would seek to require the second reading debate to take place without that explanatory memorandum being on the table—in other words, without the Senate having the advantage of the Government's advisers' assessment as to the content of the Bill.

PARA.TAB: As I said, the explanatory memorandum is particularly important in relation to this Bill because of the constitutional consequences. We are unsure, from reading the amendments that have been given to us but I do not think yet publicly circulated—that is astonishing in itself—as to the constitutional basis for the Government's amendment. There is a question as to whether the Government, for example, is relying upon the external affairs power. This legislation seems to move away from the constitutional head that deals with interstate disputes, but we are not told in the documentation before us at the moment on which head it is relying.

That is important information that should be before the Senate before the commencement of this debate—not some time later in the day, tomorrow or following a committee hearing. That is an irrelevant consideration. Therefore, I seek to suspend standing orders in order to move a motion that debate be adjourned until the Government observes the proper process.

I listened to the Australian Democrats' spokesman in this area in the earlier debate today. Whilst I was particularly disappointed that the Australian Democrats were not prepared to agree to an adjournment of the second reading that would allow our party room processes to take place, I understood the Democrats' spokesman to nevertheless say that they were of the view that the explanatory memorandum should be available before debate took place on the second reading of this Bill.

If the Democrats said that, they are, with respect, stating the correct and proper position. I hope that they will stand by that position and, in responding in this debate, agree that it would be wrong to commence this second reading debate without that explanatory memorandum being available. It is bad enough to expect us to debate an issue when we do not have an opportunity for a proper party room decision upon a piece of legislation. I think it is recognised that the only way that we could do that would be by calling all of our House of Representatives members to Canberra at enormous public cost, which no-one would wish to see expended at the moment in the parlous state of the Australian economy. Be that as it may, that is a debate that we had this morning and the Democrats joined with the Government, as they often do, and they did not see the importance of that issue.

However, I trust they will now see the importance of this issue: that before a government expects this chamber to commence the debate on the second reading of legislation the explanatory memorandum is put before the chamber since that, in turn, becomes part of the debate. It may be argued by us in the second reading that the explanatory memorandum is incorrect. That, in turn, becomes important in the subsequent interpretation of legislation that gets passed. I am disappointed that the Government is behaving in the way that it is today and I hope this time the Australian Democrats will stand up for what is right and proper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is yet another foray by the Opposition to try to delay this chamber dealing with the merit of the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. We can have every technical obstacle thrown up and dealt with, but this chamber knows full well that the procedures in a second reading debate are not about debating the amendments that there might be but about debating the principle of the legislation and, when we complete that debate, whether the principle is agreed or not agreed; and if it is agreed we then complete that debate and go to the detail of how that principle is expressed. At that time, the explanatory memorandum is appropriate.

PARA.TAB: However, we now have this technical opposition raised by the Opposition which would occasion a delay of a couple of hours to the Government in introducing this Bill, at which time honourable senators in this chamber could debate merit and principle and decide the issue one way or another in a clean and open way rather than through a technical opposition. I think it is desirable that we get to the debating of merit as soon as we possibly can. I also think it is worth while to consider to what extent we are able to accommodate the Opposition so that we do not get derailed in this debate on merit on technical procedural matters. Therefore, I am of a mind to accept the proposal put by the Opposition.

Before I do, I want to say one other thing. There is a disinformation element to all the things that get said in this debate. The disinformation element consists of this smokescreen about constitutionality; what head of constitutional power the Government is relying on. In this legislation, there is no doubt that there is only one head of constitutional power upon which we are relying—the head of constitutional power that this Parliament has always relied on since Federation—and that is the constitutional provisions enabling us to make laws to prevent and settle industrial disputes that go beyond the borders of more than one State; the arbitration power, as it is colloquially called. That is the only head of constitutional power upon which we are relying.

There is a debate, because the Government has foreshadowed its intention, about relying on the external affairs power to enact minimum labour standards in Australia taken from the conventions of the ILO, the United Nations agency. But we are not bringing that on now. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on Monday in Perth, when dealing with the Heads of Government, decided that there would be a further consultative process which I would chair concerning that approach. So we are not proceeding with those matters.

However, we are proceeding with the announced intention of the Government to legislate to enable the existing right of State organisations to refer State awards to the Commonwealth in an appropriate way, if they choose—and `if they choose' is an important element here. That right exists under the Constitution now. It has not, to my recollection, been challenged as a right, but if it has, it has surely been upheld because successive governments have made laws on this basis. I do not think there is any doubt about the constitutionality of it.

What we are proposing to do is expand this right, as I said in an earlier debate, to cases where a State government has abolished the independent access to arbitration in a State. Of course, the Victorian Government has abolished the right of organisations to seek arbitration of a grievance or dispute and settle the dispute. But it will be a national law applying around Australia and will be triggered where a State government has abolished that right in the State. It will enable people affected by those changes in laws to have a choice of what system they want—the Opposition's or ours. We accept the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that the Government has accepted Senator Hill's motion, but I want to make this simple point: contrary to the decision made this morning, the Government has now made the right decision.
—Partially right.

—Yes, partially right. The conventions of this place and the proper order and running of it are important. What the Government did this morning defied that and ran in the face of it. It should not be a debate about this Bill.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition spoke very strongly about the decision made this morning. However, it still leaves one matter open, that is, the right of reference of Bills or amendments back to whoever happens to be in opposition in the other place. The Government should think very seriously about the decision made here this morning, because it is not in the best interests of the proper running and order of the Parliament of Australia.

I wanted to make that point at this time, because the traditions and conventions which have been adopted by common practice, and not written down on a piece of paper, are crucial to the good order and running of the Senate and the operations of Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The conventions.

—I have mentioned the word `conventions' and I will mention it again. What Senator Bell and the other Democrats did this morning, even though we had discussed this with them earlier in the day, is no credit to them.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order! There was a point of order called earlier about relevance. I ask Senator Crane to be relevant to this motion to suspend Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure how I am not being relevant, but I will try to phrase it differently. I re-emphasise the point that in terms of this decision, the convention which has been adopted—the unwritten law of the Senate—has been upheld. In the decision made earlier in the day, it was not upheld.

PARA.TAB: The Government and the Democrats need to rethink their position in terms of what has just happened and what previously happened. I can assure Government members that in a very short time they will be sitting on this side of the chamber, and they could suffer the consequences of what happened here earlier in the day. I want to remind them of that. It has nothing to do with the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you threatening us?

—The Minister is the last person to talk about threatening anyone. In this case the right decision has been made. The decision made this morning was not the right decision and it will reflect very badly on the proper running and order of this chamber.

—I do not support this motion. However, I can understand why the Government would. I would like to say why I do not. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask Senator Powell to use the proper designations for the people to whom she just referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would suggest, Senator Powell, that you are getting away from the relevant aspect of the debate. I ask you to return to the motion.

PARA.TAB: I can understand the situation of the Democrats because they have members in this place only, so they can have their party meeting and come to a decision. Senator Powell has had enough time to produce 10 pages of amendments to this Bill that is to be debated in this chamber. We, as a proper party, were not given the courtesy of seeing that Bill. Senator Powell is an Independent. I still have not have been presented with the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —You need to talk to your leaders.

—I do not need to talk to my leaders. The Minister should distribute the amendments, as Senator Sherry should be well aware, even though he has been here only a short while. He should be aware that not only the amendments, but also the explanatory memorandum and the second reading speech are meant to be on every honourable senator's table before the second reading debate. That is the traditional, proper and conventional way to go about this.

PARA.TAB: However, this Minister, who has complained about the Kennett Government in Victoria rushing Bills through, is attempting to rush a Bill through this place today without even using the correct and proper procedure. Furthermore, he has been supported by the Democrats and Senator Powell. Both have supported a second reading debate without giving this Opposition—Her Majesty's Opposition—an opportunity to meet in the proper fashion by having a party meeting to discuss the appropriate amendments that it would like to put forward.

The Government has behaved in this fashion because it is running scared. Now the Government is running scared. I advise the Minister to read Mr Ramsey's article in this morning's paper as I know he will be able to relate to it.

It is up to the Parliament, and the Senate in particular, to uphold the normal conventions of this chamber. When we were in government and introduced a Bill, we always gave the Opposition an opportunity to debate it in its party room. We have never presented a Bill without an explanatory memorandum and the relevant Minister's second reading speech—never in the life of the Parliament. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the best attempts of Senator Walters to repeat the debate we had earlier today, I do not think she heard Senator Cook's response to the Opposition's proposal. The Government has accepted what the Opposition is putting forward on this particular issue.
—Until this afternoon.

—Senator Walters's very lame excuse is that the Opposition needs a party meeting. —I did not see that it was necessary to contribute to this debate because the Government had anticipated that the Democrats would see the merit of the motion that Senator Hill intended to move, especially the very important component of his argument that the explanatory memorandum is part of the legitimate and legal interpretation of an Act of Parliament. PARA.TAB: However, I have been provoked into responding to certain things that have been said in discussion. When I rose to participate in the earlier debate, I said that we agreed with the coalition that it is not appropriate for parliamentary proceedings to go ahead without adequate documentation outlining what is proposed. We did agree with that and I spelled that out quite specifically. The question that then arises is what happens to redress that situation. This question of the timetable was the subject of discussion. The original proposition put forward by the Government was acceptable and, as Senator Crane said, partly right. I thought it would have provided at least an adequate foundation for future debate.

I reject the contention that the coalition needs to have all sorts of meetings to determine its position with regard to the principles being discussed. That can be demonstrated by Senator Powell's production of 10 pages of amendments. Senator Powell did not need the fine detail of what was being proposed to understand the principles that were being discussed here. I submit that the coalition should not need a party meeting today, tomorrow or even next Wednesday to determine its response. What is being proposed was flagged several weeks ago, and indeed was responded to by Opposition party spokespersons several weeks ago.

Yet some hours ago we had a contradiction in, or at least a differentiation of, those positions. Perhaps that is causing the flap. We, the Australian Democrats, know exactly what our response will be to the principles being discussed. We are quite ready for the debate. However, we can see the merit in the motion. As I said, I agree with the coalition that it is certainly improper—if not downright wrong—to expect us to debate any item without the proper documentation. I have said that we agree with that; I still agree with it. It is what happens as a result of that which is up for debate. Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Hill) agreed to:

That Government Business order of the day no. 4, (Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992) be postponed till the Government has tabled an explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendment to be moved to the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH INSURANCE (QUALITY ASSURANCE CONFIDENTIALITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1992MEDICARE AGREEMENTS BILL 1992NATIONAL HEALTH AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 9 December, on motion by Senator McMullan and Senator Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night before the adjournment debate we were discussing the Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill 1992. The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the confidentiality of information supplied to bodies investigating and evaluating the quality of medical services and to provide immunity from civil action for members of investigating bodies. Quality assurance refers to the process of monitoring the improvement of the quality of medical services provided. The main purpose of this Bill is to encourage efficient quality assurance activities by prohibiting the disclosure of information gained as a result of, and the protection from civil liability of people who in good faith engage in, these activities. In other words, it provides statutory confidentiality.

PARA.TAB: As I mentioned last night, the coalition supports this Bill. However, there are problems with it. Once I have outlined these problems, I am sure that the Government will seriously consider them. All health bodies that have been contacted support the basic principles of the Bill. But obviously there has been inadequate consultation; otherwise we would not have the problem that has become apparent. For example, the Australian Medical Association was notified of the Bill on 20 October. It was told three days later that the Bill would need to be finalised by 26 or 27 October. The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, the Medical Protection Society and the Australian Association of Surgeons were all put in a similar position.

Quality assurance has been a feature of the medical system almost from time immemorial. It has been formalised in recent times because of the necessity for and recognition of public accountability for the activities that occur in the public hospital system, particularly the teaching hospitals. The Australian Hospitals Association, which represents the public hospitals of Australia, has forwarded a letter which states:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that section 106N will have unintended and unwelcome consequences.

The coalition agrees with this. Clause 106N permits the Minister to authorise the disclosure of quality assurance information for the purposes of law enforcement or a royal commission where that information relates to a serious offence, defined as punishable by imprisonment for more than one year. The coalition acknowledges the intention of this clause but believes that its presence or application would seriously undermine quality assurance activities.

PARA.TAB: Quality assurance largely relies on the voluntary disclosure of clinical information by doctors. There can be frank disclosure and discussion only where both the committee members and the attending practitioner are assured of the confidentiality of the proceedings. It is regarded more as an educational than a punitive activity in which practitioners are able freely to discuss their actions with peers. There are many other avenues for pursuing sanctions against a doctor—for example, the hospital credentialling and professional disciplinary tribunals or criminal or civil actions. These forums all have rights of access to normal medical records for pursuing these investigations.

I will give honourable senators an example of what can happen in a clinical practice. A doctor, knowing that clinical notes can be subpoenaed by a court of law and revealed, obviously would not put anything in those clinical notes that may be construed as being of a defamatory nature. A specific example, for the benefit of the departmental officers present, is that if a doctor thinks that a patient is malingering, the doctor does not write that on the notes because those notes may appear in a court of law and the doctor would then have to defend that situation. So the doctor writes something else—two queries, for example, because that means to the doctor that the patient is malingering. The same thing will occur with quality assurance if clause 106N proceeds. In other words, because clause 106N allows retrospective disclosure and the discretionary power of the Minister, it will not achieve the very laudable objectives that are hoped to be achieved. There will be dissimulation, if you like, by the doctor going before the QAC so that this will not be apparent to any Minister or health insurance commission body investigating it.

What is being proposed has been enacted in New Zealand. It is interesting to discover that what has occurred there is the very thing that I have pointed out. Experience in New Zealand has shown that, after the first occasion when this power was used, the whole process collapsed as individuals perceived the threat to themselves and declined to participate. That will be the unintended consequence of proceeding with clause 106N as it exists today. The Government has to decide whether it wants something that will work or something that appears to work on the surface. It can easily be got around. Dr Cass, the executive director of the quality assurance network and obviously somebody very experienced in this field, has written to me and said:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that this discretion can be retained and be effective and not lead to the quality assurance process being ineffective. If the quality assurance process becomes ineffective, then of course the ministerial discretion is also useless. No-one will say anything real if an individual can be identified. This is the problem with quality assurance activities right now without statutory immunity.
Clause 106N states:

If it appears to the Minister that information that became known after the commencement of this Part solely as a result of a declared quality assurance activity relates to conduct, whether the conduct took place before or after that commencement—
this is the retrospectivity aspect—

that may have been a serious offence against a law (whether written or unwritten) in force in any State or Territory, the Minister may, by signed writing, authorise the information to be disclosed in a way stated in the instrument of authority for the purposes of law enforcement, a Royal Commission or any other prescribed purpose.

It is a catch-22 situation. Do honourable senators really think that a doctor will go along to a quality assurance committee, knowing that anything he or she says at that committee can be used against him or her in a criminal or civil action, and volunteer information in the interests of the outcome of the quality assurance committee? Apparently, that is not clearly followed.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, put yourself in this situation. In the interests of improving the clinical care of patients, doctors go along to a quality assurance committee and are asked `How did this occur? What are the circumstances in which this incident occurred?' This goes on every day in hospitals where various clinical meetings occur. If the outcome is not what was expected, the clinician goes before his peer group and justifies the action that was taken. If this becomes subject to civil or criminal action, there will not be disclosure.

I have no doubt that the Minister, the Government and the Department are trying to achieve the right objective—that is, to provide confidentiality. However, if clause 106N is retained in the legislation, that will not be the outcome they achieve. The answer is to modify clause 106N, and submissions have been received on that from the bodies I mentioned previously, including the Medical Protection Society, the Australian Association of Surgeons and the Quality Assurance Network.

The objectives are straightforward, as I mentioned previously. The health care professionals are encouraged, under the protection of the legislation, to discuss openly and fully the care they provide to particular patients, even admitting deficiencies that can be recognised with the wisdom of hindsight. In this way, it is hoped that the quality assurance process can help improve the quality of care, which cannot ever be completely science-based but must always have elements of subjectivity as an art. To this day, medicine is an art as well as a science. Into it comes the objectivity and the input of the individual practitioner.

With the ministerial discretion remaining in clause 106N, if doctors are treated in the way patients expect to be treated by being fully informed of all the implications of the courses of action to be undertaken—including treatment, with possible failures, or statutory immunity, with its possible retrospective removal—how many are likely to participate in quality assurance processes for which statutory immunity has been provided? Would you, Mr Acting Deputy President? You would not put yourself in that position. If, through fear that that circumstance could arise, doctors or any other health care professionals decline to participate—and they cannot be forced to participate in quality assurance programs—we are where we will be, and that is nowhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say that again; I might have missed it.

—The Government will be nowhere if it proceeds with this. Quality assurance programs have been in place for many years. If this discretion is allowed to proceed and is enshrined in the Act, it will not achieve its objective. At present, if there is any suspicion that a misjudgment might have occurred, it would be natural, under the circumstances of this Bill, for people to close ranks and protect others.

PARA.TAB: The objectives of the Bill are correct. As I said, the coalition supports the objectives of the Bill, but in the committee stage it will move to eliminate the ministerial discretion and modify clause 106N.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Medicare Agreements Bill 1992 has not yet been agreed to by the States. I do not see how it can be called the Medicare Agreements Bill because the States of New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania have not yet agreed to it. So to begin with, the name of the Bill is totally incorrect. If it were called an agreement that the Government intends to force on the States, we could debate a properly named Bill, but at the moment there has been no agreement and therefore I do not believe that we should be debating it.

PARA.TAB: Tomorrow the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs will be considering this Bill. It will have before it all the State Ministers who want to come and the private hospitals. The Committee asked the Australian Hospitals Association, which represents the public hospitals, to come, but, whilst it has put in a submission, it will be unable to come on that day. The Committee has also asked consumer organisations to appear, and it has received about 16 submissions. We asked that the second reading debate be postponed until the Senate Committee sat. As I said, there has been no agreement; to debate a Bill upon which no agreement has been reached is ludicrous.

The basic principles of this Bill have not been agreed upon by Victoria, New South Wales, Tasmania or Western Australia. We all remember that Mr Keith Wilson, the Labor Minister for Health in Western Australia, decided that he was no longer able to support this Government's health policy. He said that he would rather resign, and he put it very succinctly. Upon his resignation, Mr Wilson appealed for the health debate to be depoliticised in the interests of Australia—not in the interests of the Labor Party, but in the interests of Australia. He lashed the Federal Government and its ideology in a hard hitting speech which criticised both the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Health (Mr Howe). He said:
I have no concern for Canberra because it has no concern for WA and under successive governments we have always had a bad deal.
The Federal Government has been more prepared to cater for the middle class socialists on good incomes—

SPEECH.PARA: Is Senator Tate listening? Does it sound familiar?

PARA.TAB: The Federal Government has been more prepared to cater for the middle class socialists on good incomes, who see it as their right to access public hospitals for free.
Yet they know people on low incomes, including elderly pensioners, must wait for prolonged periods.
The middle class socialists know they need never wait because they can afford to procure hospital care in the private sector.

I do not wish to answer for a final outcome that does not make provision for the place of private health insurance and believe I must leave it to someone else who will feel easier about completing the task.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what Mr Wilson said before he resigned. As the Labor Minister for Health in Western Australia, Mr Wilson was not prepared to oversee a system that had no place in it for private insurance. He is not on his own: the Minister for Health in New South Wales, Mr Ron Phillips, the Minister for Health in Victoria, Marie Tehan, and the Minister for Health in Tasmania all say the same thing.

PARA.TAB: The Government has to acknowledge that the public health system cannot cope on its own to look after the needs of Australians and give access to all Australians, no matter what their income is. Let me explain the ideology of this Government. It said, `We believe everyone should have free access to hospitals. It does not matter whether you are a millionaire or not; everyone should have access to the public hospital system'. It then realised that money was going to blow out and that it could not cope, that in our present public hospital system we cannot cope with the enormous number of people who would access public hospitals.

We had problems as soon as the Labor Government came into power. By 1987 the waiting lists throughout Australia were so long that the Prime Minister of the time, Mr Hawke, said in his election speech that he would allocate $25m in order to overcome the long hospital queues. In 1988-89, the Budget said:

The second major initiative is an expanded program of hospital funding involving the expenditure of $3,000 million, and an additional $1,100 million in the next five years over and above previous arrangements.
This will be devoted to providing more public hospital beds, shortening hospital queues.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 1988-89 Budget, $3,000m was also allocated to do the same thing. The $25m which was allocated in 1987 was eaten up. After the $3,000m had been allocated in 1988-89, hospital queues were still going up. They went up by 47 per cent in Western Australia alone. In this year's Budget, another $50m was allocated for 1992-93, and an additional $20.9m for 1993-94, so that hospitals could put in place better procedures for managing waiting lists.

PARA.TAB: Since 1987 we have had you throwing more money around to try stop your hospital queues. None of it has succeeded because you are very successfully making things so impossible for people to continue their private health insurance that they are giving it up and going into the public hospital system. You have ruined the economy of this country to such an extent—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator, your remarks should be through the chair. I am not quite sure that they have been.

—This Government has ruined the economy to such an extent that it will increase the Medicare levy next year. It was never going to be increased to more than one per cent, but now it is 1.25 per cent and it will soon be 1.4 per cent. The Government is making sure that people cannot afford to pay their Medicare levy as well as their private hospital insurance. What will happen as people get out of private hospital insurance? What has happened to the $25m? What has happened to the $3,000m? What is happening to this additional $50m?
