The Government has put aside $3m just for public relation services to see how it can cope with the waiting lists. None of the other schemes have worked. The latest figures show that 78,571 people are on waiting lists. Every State, except Queensland, now publishes its waiting lists. The headline of an article from yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald reads `The fatal list: 44 heart patients died waiting.'

PARA.TAB: The article went on to say that with the bypass surgery lists the number could have been up to 60 deaths. Senator Tate is so uninterested that he is chatting to one of his colleagues. He is so uninterested in the fact that 60 people on the waiting list are dying because the Government will not supply the proper amount of money for the big public hospitals that he is now grinning and carrying on. It is not a political point that I am making.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course you are. You are a disgrace.
—It is not a political point that I am making; it is factual. The Minister can do nothing but smile and laugh about it.
—Order! The honourable senator will withdraw that remark.
—Which remark—that it is factual?
—The Minister will withdraw that remark.
—I beg your pardon. If I said that Senator Walters—I will not repeat it.
—I do not care what the Minister says about me, frankly. I could not care less. He is totally irresponsible.
—I withdraw it.
—Order! I do care, because I have to make sure that order is preserved in this chamber. It is withdrawn, I take it, Minister?
—It is withdrawn, but I want to make a personal explanation.
—Not now.
—Can I do that at this stage? I have been wrongly accused of being indifferent to the deaths of 46 people.
—At the end of the honourable senator's speech.

—He can do what he likes at the end of my speech. He can call me whatever he likes. The situation is that, while I was saying to the Minister that his Government is responsible for 44 deaths because it is not giving the financial commitment that it promised, and there could be 60 deaths, the Minister was chatting to one of his colleagues and smiling and grinning.
—I was not chatting.
—He says he was not. That is not true.
—He can talk to whoever he likes.
—Yes, he can talk to whoever he likes, but he was so unconcerned that he was chatting to one of his colleagues. It is no use his saying that he was not. We all saw him doing it.
—You are as mad as a hatter.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, you will withdraw that remark.
—Do not bother, Mr Deputy President.
—I withdraw, Mr Deputy President.
—Before Senator Walters continues, I think that we should quieten down a little.

—That is right. It is all right for honourable senators opposite. I would guarantee that Senator Tate has private insurance. He can afford it. He would be all right. I would guarantee that his relatives would be all right too. I have got private insurance, and I make sure that all my relatives are privately insured because I am not prepared—

—Mr Deputy President, on a point of order, I think it is completely improper for Senator Walters to drag my family or relatives into a debate in this chamber. It is an invasion of the privacy of my family and I do not see why I should stand here and cop it.
—I do not believe that I have invaded his privacy at all.
—Order! I have been asked to rule on a point of order. There is no point of order, but the Minister has made his point.
—Of course there is no point of order, and I have not attempted to invade his privacy in any way. What I have said is that I would guarantee—
—You just said you didn't believe that I—

—I believe that the Minister has got the brains to privately insure. I believe that he has got the brains not to run the risk. Perhaps he would rather me say that he has not got the brains, I do not know, but I am saying that I believe that he has got the brains to privately insure because, if not, he or his relatives could end up on the long list of 78,000-odd people waiting for hospital accommodation.

PARA.TAB: I have just rung the statistics service of the Parliament and asked for the figures. I have been given the figures that have been published in every State except Queensland. So it is not just 78,571; it is that number, with Queensland on top. Yet the Government is not acknowledging in the Bill before us even the simple principle that private insurance should be part of the public system.

We have the ideological situation—and Senator Crowley was in this up to her neck—where the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, got the leadership of the Labor Party and the prime ministership of this country only because he promised the radical Left that there would be no patient contribution. The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Howe, said that we cannot cope with the financial situation if we have not got patient contribution, and he introduced patient contribution. The only reason the Prime Minister got the prime ministership was that he gave way, and he got the votes from the radical Left so long as he did away with private contributions. What a way to run the country.

For heaven's sake, the important thing is the health of Australians; it is not whether a man gets the prime ministership or whether he gets the vote of the Australian people. That is not the way to run a country. I believe that this is based on sheer political ideology and sheer political motives. The base political motives of this Government are no better explained than in this issue presently before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just cannot let some of the comments that have been made in this debate go unanswered. The comments and the uncontrollable screeching from the other side of this chamber—

—Is Senator Crowley going to stand over there and perform like a trained seal or an imbecile or what? This is just unbelievable. I thought this was the Parliament of Australia, but we have had this endless screeching. I would just like to say a few words on this Medicare agreement. It is an undeniable fact that the Labor Party has lost one of its State Ministers because the Medicare agreement is untenable. We have a State Minister saying that the failure to encourage ordinary people to retain health insurance is `simply a failure to apply commonsense'. He continued:

SPEECH.PARA: I have always felt a personal responsibility for those many individual cases of people who cannot access ready hospital care. Someone has to be answerable ultimately for these continuing failures. No-one in Canberra is prepared to be. The Prime Minister tells pensioners with private health insurance they don't need it without understanding why they feel they do.
At the time of his resignation, Mr Wilson said:
The Commonwealth laid down the terms and the States were blackmailed into signing by the threat of `no sign—no money'.
He also said:
I have not held back from strident public criticism of this crucial failure on the part of the Federal Minister to review the place of private health insurance.
He went on:

Ignored also is the majority of Labor supporters with private health insurance and the need to encourage people who could afford it to see the membership of private health funds as a means of supplementing scarce public funds needed to maintain high quality public hospital services.

PARA.TAB: One would suspect, listening to those comments, that they are from Liberal State Ministers, but they are not; they are from a former Labor State Minister. I agree with Senator Walters that Senator Tate is a very intelligent man, because quite some time ago he acknowledged that he had private health insurance. There is nothing secret about that. I am not trying to pry into his private life; he acknowledged that and I think he is very sensible in doing so. I would hate to think that a member of my family was one of the 60 people who have died in recent times because of not being able to get access to hospital care.

All we are saying is that this agreement does not have to be signed until 30 June 1993 and there is no need for the Government to bully the States into signing forthwith. All the States want to do is come to an agreement whereby their concerns are resolved. Why will the Government not allow those concerns to be resolved? Why is it ramming this thing through when there is no pressure to do so and there is no need to sign it until 30 June 1993? It is of great concern to us. We cannot deny that there is still a need to resolve the Commonwealth and State roles and responsibilities. The States are very keen to work with the Commonwealth in a climate of cooperation in seeking to negotiate the Medicare agreement. Unfortunately, the Commonwealth approach has had elements of coercion for the States, although the States have indicated a genuine willingness to work cooperatively with the Commonwealth as equal partners.

I say to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), that it is not just my concern that there is coercion, that pressure is being put on the States. One of the Labor Ministers has reinforced that view: it was such a high concern for him that he actually resigned his portfolio. It is a very tragic situation when the Government not only will not listen to us and the Liberal State Ministers but also will not listen to its own Labor State Ministers.

We believe it is important to include some of the principles that my colleague Senator Walters was talking about. One of the major principles, of course, is freedom of choice so that eligible persons have the right to choose private health care and private hospitals, supported by private health insurance. That is a basic principle.

I am mindful of the time. I am sorry that I intervened in this debate to take up more time, but I had to respond to some of those things and to say to the Minister that it is not just our concern but a concern of the Labor Party as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I believe that the matters that have been discussed during the second reading debate on the Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill, the Medicare Agreements Bill and the National Health Amendment Bill are of great importance, but the debate on the Medicare Bill unfortunately deteriorated somewhat. I do not think there is any need for me to respond point by point. That can be done tomorrow in the Standing Committee on Community Affairs and when the Bills come back into the Committee of the Whole.

PARA.TAB: These are extremely important Bills which enable the restructuring of the Medicare principle in Australian society, a principle that has been so well supported by the Australian community. Seven out of 10 Australians still believe that Medicare provides a very sure foundation for the treatment they expect to receive in a society that is fair and compassionate and provides access to medical and hospital services of one type or another.

In so far as the other Bills are concerned, the National Health Amendment Bill 1992 is also an important one, but a rather technical one, concerning nursing homes. I thank Senator Herron for his contribution to the debate on the Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill 1992, which is to do with the question of confidentiality when health professionals are engaged in a process of assessment by their peers. I believe that all these Bills are important and ought to commend themselves to the Senate. I commend the second reading to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Pursuant to the order of the Senate agreed to on 12 November 1992, the Medicare Agreements Bill 1992 stands referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs for consideration and report by 14 December 1992.
—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this occasion, I wish to take some of the Senate's time to draw attention to some problems relating to sales tax registration, and the confusion that will arise as a result of the new, so-called streamlined, sales tax which is to operate from 1 January. Senators may recall that, on 26 November, I raised some problems with the sales tax registrations and exemption certificates, particularly with regard to the start-up date of the new, streamlined sales tax. I now raise a further, related issue of unclear classifications within the system as it relates particularly to the automotive spare parts industry.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that these sorts of problems typify the difficulties of many other industries. Perhaps the points that I am making will become a lot clearer if I draw attention to some particular problems in that industry. When is an accessory a good or material? Let me give an example. We have a business with a service station and body works combined, and it quotes for a repair on a customer's vehicle which has been damaged in its front suspension and other parts. The front suspension parts would be replaced and would, under the new law, be taxed at the lower rate.

Also in the quote could be repairs for the replacement of the driving lights which, in addition to the suspension, were damaged in the accident—which would not be surprising. The lights were fitted to the vehicle when new and, as such, are part of the original car. This now means that what is classified as an accessory, in the accepted sense of the word, now becomes a replacement part. Should it therefore be taxed under the new scale, or under the old? On page 2 of Streamlined sales tax and how it affects you, under the heading `What is a wholesale sale?', example No. 4 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Sales of goods or materials to a repairer who uses those goods in repair work.

At first reading, this would appear to mean that the product can be used to replace the damaged or worn parts of the job in question. But, if people read it again, it could mean if new tools also were supplied to be used on the job. Does this really mean that tools are sold, but not as wholesale sales—particularly if the vehicle is not a luxury vehicle?

PARA.TAB: Let me give a few more examples. When does a repair cease being a repair and become maintenance—for example, when an oil filter is replaced during an engine rebuild? Is a stop additive with antifreeze a repair or a service? Is such a simple thing as replacing a faulty grease nipple a repair, but if it substitutes for a plastic bung inserted during manufacture not a repair? If a damaged quartz halogen globe is replaced by one of stronger wattage than the original, is it a repair or is it maintenance? When is an accessory a hard spare? They are just some of the difficulties.
Let me go now to the problem of page 2 of this document about streamlined sales tax. In that section, we read:

SPEECH.PARA: The following examples are types of sales which are NOT wholesale sales under the new law.
So the problem is one of whether these sales are retail or wholesale. This is the difficulty that one runs into. No. 4 in the list reads:
Sales of Goods or Materials to a repairer or panel beater who uses those goods in repair work.

We then go to the explanatory note. The current sales tax law makes all goods and materials taxable in this area at 20 per cent, subject to a few exemptions regarding primary and mining conditions, and the tax can be charged at the normal place of selling—that is, at the second last point of sale. The new law means that, as it is not a wholesale sale, it must be a retail sale, which means that sales tax is charged at the wholesaler's cost price or buying-in price, and not at the retailer's buying-in price. This would occur in a whole lot of cases. I now put to the Senate seven different situations.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, millions of dollars of sales tax revenue could be lost to the Government as the tax would be collected at an earlier stage, that is, prior to the wholesaler's freight into store costs. I have raised this issue previously with the Government.

Secondly, all computers would have program alterations and invoice books would be reprinted to handle retail sales without sales tax being identified on the same invoice as the normal wholesaler's invoice. If the amount of sales tax collected was shown, it would mean another column would be required on an invoice to identify the 20 per cent tax on the wholesaler's buying-in price, as it obviously would be less than the required amount on the selling price.

Thirdly, there would be great resistance by wholesalers to identify the amount of sales tax involved. The competitor in the same trade, for example, would be able to calculate from the amount of tax involved how much the wholesaler had paid for his goods and how much profit margin he had on the goods at the time of sale. Fourthly, there is the difficulty for a wholesaler in identifying whether a product should be charged at the wholesaler's buying-in price plus 20 per cent or whether the normal method of taxing should be used.

Fifthly, there is the difficulty for retailers when identifying products on their shelves of knowing which tier of sales tax has been charged, for example, if there is a service station with an auto parts and accessory shop attached. Sixthly, there is the impossibility of policing such a situation.

Finally, there is the impossibility of determining when an accessory—which is going to be taxed at the reseller's buy-in price from the new ruling—is not an accessory but a repair, and I have given those examples. These particular classes of taxpayer are not accountants; they are manual workers all around Australia and they are going to have great difficulty with this so-called new streamlined sales tax. The interesting point is that a number of taxpayers have contacted their local sales tax divisions and cannot get answers to the sorts of queries that I have raised, yet the system is going to operate from 1 January.

This Government has inflicted upon the taxpayers of this country an insidious and unworkable sales tax. It is a sales tax first mooted as the simplification package, and I note the word `simplification' is no longer used. In fact, all the literature from the Australian Taxation Office is now calling these sorts of changes the streamlined sales tax. Considering the sorts of issues that I have just discussed, a lot of businesses are going to be in trouble with this so-called new streamlined sales tax.

The Government's inadequacies with regard to this legislation are going to cost Australian taxpayers dearly in terms of the taxes. Also, when they become subject to audit there are going to be all sorts of problems. Consider the simple example that I have just given of a service station which has a repair shop attached to it. How will the everyday taxpayer know he can claim an exemption if the Taxation Office does not advertise and is not able to give him specific advice? Who will pay for this? Obviously, in the end it will be the Australian taxpayer. Not only will further advertising be required, but that advertising should be taking place now through a direct mail-out to the 56,000 retailers and 135,000 sales tax registrants who have already been advised of a 1 January start up and who are not yet aware whether they can use an exemption declaration or whether they can continue using exemption certificates.

I believe this whole sales tax fiasco which has been created by this Government is a sterling case for the introduction of the coalition's goods and services tax. Along with the removal of the sales tax and all those other taxes that the John Hewson coalition has mentioned, the GST will place the burden of tax where it belongs and will reduce administrative problems and burdens and eliminate confusion. I ask Senator Button to address the issues, particularly in relation to all those poor people in the automotive trades who are going to be subject to such difficulty in interpreting whether they are wholesale or retail sales. Can Senator Button help?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is Human Rights Day, and I shall ask for leave to incorporate into Hansard a letter I have written to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, in response to a letter he wrote to me on 24 September concerning population policy and human rights, with specific reference to China. I will also be tabling a document entitled `Coercive Family Planning and Australian Aid Policy'. That document records the exchanges, over a period of five years, between me and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and, through him, the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, on the subject of population policy and human rights violations, with specific reference to China.

PARA.TAB: The document chronicles the responses of AIDAB and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to evidence of brutal coercion and brutal violation of human rights and workers' rights in China in the implementation of its population control policy. It shows the various response modes adopted by AIDAB and, to some extent, the Minister, over a period of four or five years. Those modes, first of all, ignored the evidence of coercion; then they recognised the evidence but denied its veracity; then they become ambivalent about the veracity of the evidence; and finally, when they can do nothing else, they admit some of the evidence but claim, falsely, that continued Australian involvement would lessen the coercive aspects of the program.

I believe this document should be studied by honourable senators, and I wish to table it in the hope that honourable senators and members in the other place might study it. I am hopeful that it will be useful for researchers, aid agencies and others who share a concern for the role Australian aid policy can play in protecting and promoting fundamental human rights. I now seek leave to table the document `Coercive Family Planning and Australian Aid Policy' and to incorporate in Hansard my letter to Senator Evans.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 10 December 1992
Senator G Evans,
Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Gareth,
On 24 September 1992, you incorporated into the Hansard of Senate Estimates Committee B a letter you wrote to me concerning population policy and human rights, with specific reference to China.

I then offered to provide a detailed response and you expressed the view that it would be particularly helpful if my response, also, was to be incorporated into Hansard at a future date, and supporting documentation were to be tabled and made available.
Accordingly, I am forwarding this letter to you together with documentation. The former I will seek to have incorporated into today's Senate Hansard, and the latter I will table.

You will recall that for a number of years I have raised, and sought to have answered by you and your Department, serious questions relating to Australia's commitment to human rights and its bizarre support, tangible or moral, for population control programs which, to the impartial observer, inherently violate these rights.

As far back as October 1987, when I questioned an AIDAB statement that the "United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) had let a $500,000 project related to its program in China to the Demography Department of the Australian National University", your Department stated that it was "confident that none of the UNFPA activities with which Australia is involved would in any way assist the implementation of coercive population policies.
Subsequent exchanges have made it clear that such an expression of confidence was never grounded in reality.
It is regrettable that you and your Department have remained firmly pegged to assertions such as this. This is despite the fact that UNFPA has
*coordinated international support—and applause—for China's "successful, yet brutal population control program;
*assisted IUD production for eventual use in enforcing compulsory IUD policies in China;
*supported, at the height of coercion in 1983, the awarding of the UN Population Award to the head of China's Family Planning Commission;
*enthusiastically embraced a program it has described as "totally voluntary", a pathetic claim which, to your credit, you have finally rejected in your letter to me of 7 September 1992.

Indeed, your September 1992 letter, although repeating some claims contradicted by up-to-date evidence I have provided, does indicate a willingness of behalf of yourself and AIDAB to come to terms with at least some of the issues I have been raising over a period of five years.
The process has been excruciatingly slow.

In October 1988, AIDAB told Senate Estimates Committee B that it "is satisfied that UNFPA operates entirely within the frameworks that are acceptable to the government where it is working." In December of the same year, I referred in the Senate to evidence of violations of human rights and urged the government to "have a good look at this question." Senator Cook responded on the Government's behalf that he thought that "it was for individual countries to decide what they should do about their own family planning programs.

In September 1989, in response to a question from me, you told the Senate that "the population control program that is conducted in China—although it has been the subject of allegations made by Senator Harradine and his ilk over the years—has never been one about which I have seen evidence to justify the allegations that are being made about coercive abortion, involuntary sterilisation and so on.

AIDAB meanwhile had been writing to concerned members of the public claiming that "the Chinese Government itself has stated that coercive population activities are illegal in China", despite the fact that it was forced to admit in September 1989 that it had produced written evidence of the documented evidence of coercion in China which I had provided.

Indeed, it has taken some time for yourself and the Department to come to terms with the issue of coercion. In September 1989, an AIDAB officer told Senate Estimates Committee B that the appropriateness of means used to implement a population control program is "a matter for political and foreign policy judgement" and that "AIDAB is not in a position to comment on these matters.

When I presented AIDAB with a case—commended by UNFPA—involving punishment for their villages if Indonesian women refused to have inserted an intrauterine device, AIDAB claimed that its officers would hold "a range of views", and admitted that "there is no consolidated AIDAB view" on whether this case involved coercion or not.

In a written response to me, AIDAB indicated that Australia interprets `coercion' in the context of population programs to mean "the use or threat of force". In Estimates, an AIDAB officer added that "it seems to me that that is not really a question which a development assistance agency, as such, is qualified to interpret." You later expressed concern that this response was incomplete, adding that "coercion can take many forms other than the physical exercise of force." Another AIDAB official added that "AIDAB recognises that there can be occasions when financial or other threats can have a coercive effect", but she confirmed the case by case approach.

In the light of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs Defence and Trade's recent rejection of this concept of "cultural relativism, and its strong endorsement of the universal notion of human rights, it is to be hoped that AIDAB has now jettisoned this case by case procedure. [A Review of Australia's Efforts to Promote and Protect Human Rights, JCFADT, December 1992, p.5]

In 1990, AIDAB's Appraisals, Evaluation, and Sectoral Studies Branch issued a brief on Population claiming that "population and family planning programs do work, adding that "without them there would be closer to 200 million more people in China and India today." On its own admission, AIDAB had a limited understanding at the time of the methods being used in China to enforce population control. Of course, the proponents of population control have rarely looked beyond the "if it works, endorse it" mentality.

This rare and candid admission of the effectiveness of coercion contradicts the more recent diversionary statements of such people as UNFPA's Executive-Director Nafis Sadik, who stated at the National Press Club in Canberra in August this year that actual or moral coercion is "unsuccessful from a practical point of view" and that "there is no such thing as `population control' ".

In February 1990, you wrote to me claiming that "no link has been established between UNFPA and coercive population activities in China, adding that "for many years the Chinese Government has consistently asserted that it is firmly opposed to coercive population activities.

I have always wondered, in lighter moments, whether your Government responded to critics of the Tiananmen Square massacre in June 1989 by informing them that "the Chinese Government has asserted that nothing happened.

In February 1990 you provided me with a copy of Australia's Policy Base for Population-Related Aid Activities. This statement included "a recognition of the right of the individuals to choose the number of children they have", but then denied this right by adding the nullifying rider of "the need to balance this right against the interest of society in maintaining population growth within manageable levels". The statement noted that Australia would avoid support for "programs using coercive element, but added the curious statement declaring Australia's "recognition of the right of individual governments to determine their own policies.

I was disturbed to discover that the new Policy on Support for Population Activities you issued in November 1990 deleted in the Policy Base all reference to the rights of couples to make the responsible decision as to family size. Replacing it was a "recognition that the number of children individuals choose to have now . . . is a legitimate concern for society as a whole", and a statement that the new policy is based on "the avoidance of support for coercive contraception programs while recognising the right of individual governments to determine their own policies in this area.

Most Australians would be astonished to learn, as indeed I was, that the Australian government does not support a universal, inherent right of individuals to determine family size free from government dictates. Many observers of population control organisations would be aware, of course, that the protestations of "reproductive freedom and choices" have been mere public relations slogans.

This new Policy also stated that "the goal of Australia's population policy is to support the development of effective population strategies and programs aimed at urgently slowing and eventually reversing population growth . . .

In September 1990 I raised at Senate Estimates the Shanghai birth control regulations which came into effect on 1 August 1990, and asked you whether you would characterise a violation of workers' rights as a fine on work units if they exceed their quota of births or a fine on the individual worker. You responded that "if there is any question of punitive sanctions being applied, that is not something that we would regard as an appropriate way of applying those policies.

After raising questions at this time on the possible use of Australian-funded ultrasound machines in enforcing compulsory IUD use in China, you asked me for evidence on possible violations of human rights in China's population control program. I pointed out that I provided such evidence to AIDAB at Estimates Committee hearings in 1989. AIDAB will also recall that I provided it in October 1990, upon request, with copies of documents detailing human rights abuses associated with China's population control program. The documents included a translation of current birth control regulations in Sichuan province.

In October 1990, AIDAB responded to a question I had asked in Estimates regarding the new Shanghai birth control regulations by providing me with limited information on new birth control regulations in Henan province. The response indicated that the Government would "consider raising the issue with the Chinese authorities if there was evidence that the Henan regulations were being enforced in a coercive and punitive.

No doubt AIDAB has since discovered that Article 24 of these new regulations for Henan state that "a woman of childbearing age who has had one child must use an IUD. If a couple of childbearing age have had two or more children, either the husband or the wife must be sterilised. . . . In case a woman becomes pregnant without permission under the state plan, remedial measures must be taken to terminate the pregnancy.

In November 1990 I asked you in the Senate why I had been supplied with information on Henan when I had specifically asked about the new regulations in Shanghai where Australian-funded ultrasound machines were being sent for use by the State Family Planning Commission. You indicated that you were "as puzzled as Senator Harradine is", and promised a "considered review" of the Shanghai program. You added that you "certainly do not think that [family planning programs] should be conducted on a coercive basis and in a way that interferes with other rights of the people in question." You indicated that you "propose[d] writing to Senator Harradine in some detail reviewing this material when I and my Department and AIDAB are in a position to formulate a full and considered response which is what he has now sought for a long time and what I think is owing to him.

On 12 November 1990 I welcomed the promised analysis and added that "it is quite obvious that the Department has not had the material on which to make a proper assessment as to whether these [ultrasound] machines will be used for coercive purposes." I noted that "the sort of pressure that is being placed on the women, in particular, in China is something which we should not be associated with. I feel it is high time that the sorts of statements that have been emanating from the Minister—presumably written by AIDAB—have to be closely examined because they do not stand up to the light of day.

On 29 November 1990 I referred to a US Senate motion on Tibet which condemned the "coercive population policies, including the use of forced abortion and forced sterilisation, and I asked you whether you were "aware of evidence from Tibet that these brutal policies are being inflicted by the PRC on women in that country." You responded that you were "concerned that Senator Harradine should have a properly considered reply to these matters, with as much data as we can compile" and that this response will be provided "as soon as possible".

In December 1990 you wrote to me providing the response by AIDAB to the evidence of coercion in China which I had supplied. The letter made the surprising claim that "the most authoritative available statement on the present nature of China's population policies" is an April 1990 statement of the Minister-in-Charge of the State Family Planning Commission of China which states that "in no case is coercion allowed as a means of implementing family planning policy.

The letter stated that "it is our clear understanding that there is no policy of forced abortion or sterilisation in China, including in Tibet" [emphasis added], and added that "there is no evidence of which we are aware that IUDs are imposed on women by forceful means". This, despite the fact that documentation I had provided actually detailed such evidence. You conceded that "the imposition of any fines of a magnitude causing genuine hardship, while perhaps not in the same category as physical coercion, does constitute unacceptable coercion and as such could not be supported by the Australian Government." You also indicated that you would make these views known to PRC officials, and would write to the Executive Director of UNFPA advising her of the Australian Government's position, and "urging her to exert her organisation's influence to encourage the termination of such unacceptable practices.

In December 1990 I congratulated you in the Senate on finally acknowledging that the imposition of fines by PRC officials for so-called unauthorised pregnancies constituted "unacceptable coercion." However, I called the response "shallow in the face of overwhelming evidence to what are widely held and profound concerns for the human rights of families, and particularly of the poor and powerless women who bear the brunt of state-sponsored population control violence." I said that to conclude that "there is no evidence that lUDs are imposed upon women by forceful means" indicated that the documented material provided by me "has not been studied" by AIDAB.

I doubted whether "the victims of such oppression will find comfort" in your promise to ask Dr Sadik, Executive-Director of UNFPA to exert her organisation's influence to encourage the termination of such unacceptable practices. I pointed out that Dr Sadik had told a Washington audience in 1989 that the Chinese Government was running a totally voluntary program. I said that "little attention has been paid to this subject for many years, and it is understandable that AIDAB finds itself surrounded by the alluring and sanitised pronouncements of foreign governments, and the shallow responses of organisations—international and local—with vested interests in population control." I urged AIDAB to "once again examine the material I have provided" and suggested that Dr John S Aird's 1990 book on Coercive Birth Control in China "should be priority reading.

In May 1991, AIDAB tabled an undated letter in Estimates to me in response to my comments in the Senate on 20 December 1990. Regrettably, the letter stated that AIDAB had only conducted "a preliminary evaluation" of Dr Aird's detailed expose of coercion in China, and even then only "by means of a review of the relevant academic literature on the question of coercion in China's family planning program." I would have preferred that AIDAB read the book thoroughly and evaluated the facts presented therein. Not surprisingly, therefore, the letter claimed that the "prevailing view" is that "the PRCs family planning program is not based on coercion." The letter also rejected the allegation that UNFPA's support for China's population control program helps to legitimise the means used by the PRC in its family planning program.

At Estimates in May 1991, AIDAB also tabled a response from Dr Sadik dated 25 March 1991 to a letter from Dr Blewett, Minister for Overseas Trade and Development. Dr Sadik stated that she is "familiar with Senator Brian Harradine's concerns with respect to the Chinese Government's population policies", but that "as you know, the Government has assured us that the policy is a voluntary one.. with a great number of exceptions to the one child policy." Dr Sadik indicated that she would be in China during the first half of April and "certainly will bring up the concerns which you have raised with the highest authorities.

I later noted in the Senate that to the best of my knowledge, "Dr Sadik has . . . never come out and criticised the coercive elements of the Chinese population control program." I pointed out that when Dr Sadik actually visited the PRC in April 1991 she was quoted on 8 April by the Xinhua General Overseas News Service as saying that "China should feel very proud of its achievements in effectively controlling the growth of its population.

I also questioned AlDAB's enthusiasm for population control in Vietnam given that a Reuters report had reported a government decree that "for those who have too many children the organs of direct management will mete out appropriate punitive measures.." You responded that you "share [my] distaste for anything in-the nature of coercion associated with these population programs in China, Vietnam or anywhere else." You added that "we will further pursue some of those issues in relation to China in the course of the human rights delegation.

In October 1991 I raised in the Senate the issue of the advice regarding PRC population policy and practice provided to the Australian Human Rights Delegation prior to its visit to China in September 1991. I noted that the advice was provided not by the Human Rights Branch of Foreign Affairs, but by AIDAB "which has a vested interest in this particular area." I noted that preparation of the advice was contracted out to a "vigorous protagonist of UNFPA and of population control programs". In response, you claimed that it was "physically impossible" for the Human Rights Branch "to do directly and personally the kind of detailed research that this and related issues demand" and that AIDAB itself does not have "the kind of in-house resources available to undertake this research in the necessary detail.

In December 1991, I noted in the Senate that the report of the Human Rights Delegation to China claimed that it was assured that abortion is never mandatory in Sichuan province, and I asked why the delegation was not informed prior to going to China of the actual Sichuan province regulations which state that abortion is compulsory in certain circumstances. I cited specific regulations, and asked who was responsible for the delegation being "so poorly briefed in respect of these gross violations of human rights in China." You responded that you will seek further information.

On 10 December you tabled your response in the Senate. You dismissed suggestions that the delegation was not fully briefed prior to visiting China, and claimed that advice you had received on the interpretation of Sichuan Province Family Planning Regulations rejected that they necessarily imply compulsory abortion and sterilisation.

On 27 December 1991 Dr Sadik of UNFPA wrote to AIDAB regarding UNFPA assistance to China. She made the ludicrous claim that "coercion has occurred when poorly trained grassroots family planning workers, some only marginally literate, relied on slogans and quotas that they seldom fully understood." Regrettably, AIDAB claimed in a letter in July this year that it was "satisfied" with this pitiful response from UNFPA.
In December 1991, AIDAB published Dr Hull's paper entitled `Recent Population Policy in China'.

In March 1992, I moved in the Senate that the report of the Australian Human Rights Delegation to China be referred to a Senate committee to examine why it was not briefed properly on China's population control program prior to departure, and why it failed to make reference to provisions in Sichuan which legally entrench violations of human rights. The move failed 34-31. The Government spokesperson~ Senator Maguire, used the odd excuse that the Government would reject the motion because the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, of which he is chairman, already had too much work to do.

In March 1992, I was surprised to receive a letter from new Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, John Kerin, in which he wrote that he was "concerned to be informed that the extent of [my] involvement, through both Questions on Notice and Estimates Committee hearings, is demanding an extraordinary amount of time and energy from a wide range of AIDAB staff', suggesting that "there is a limit to the resources it should invest to do that.

Naturally, fundamental issues of human rights must be relentlessly pursued irrespective of attempts to muzzle or brand people who raise such concerns. Mr Kerin's letter is particularly surprising in light of his Ministerial Policy Paper issued in November this year. In this document, entitled `Changing Aid for a Changing World', one reads that "the Minister has asked AIDAB to seek maximum community involvement to review development issues in the area of population. . . " [emphasis added]. It would be a great tragedy if attempts were made by idealogues to censor out certain views—and documented evidence—from this review.

In March 1992 you wrote to me reaffirming your confidence in the advice provided to the delegation by Dr Hull, and asserted that Dr Hull's report for AIDAB was "a balanced and objective study." You also rejected a suggestion that AIDAB should publish a response to Dr Hull's report.

In May 1992 I referred in the Senate to 1990 census figures for China "which show that for every 100 boys under two years of age there were only 89 girls", and asked you to "concede that the missing female millions were victims of the PRCs one child per family population control program". I also asked "why and on whose advice AIDAB currently has a delegation in China for the purposes of increasing Australian aid, directly or though UNFPA, for that barbaric program." You responded "that it is very much Senator Harradine's judgement that the Chinese population program is barbaric. Other judgements differ, including the judgements of the human rights delegation..
At this stage, I tabled a fully-documented, detailed response to Dr Hull by China scholar Dr John S Aird entitled `Foreign Assistance to Coercive Family Planning in China'.

In June 1992 you tabled in the Senate an AIDAB response to my question regarding an Australian family planning mission to China. The response alleged, without proof, that "clearly, if UNFPA programs were withdrawn or if Australia decided not to assist, the situation of the Chinese people would not be any better than it is", and added that "we will not be deterred from considering such assistance by the one-sided arguments of Senator Harradine.
Naturally, the gratuitous "one-sided arguments" comment required no response from me, reflecting, as it did, on the professionalism of the AIDAB officer who prepared your brief.

In August 1992, Reuters reported that family planning officials in China were urging "greater vigilance in enforcing strict population control policies", and cited comments by State Family Planning Commission Director Peng Peiyun that China "could not afford the slightest bit of relaxation or optimism" in its population control efforts.
On 7 September 1992 you wrote to me detailing your and AIDAB's response to Dr Aird's report tabled in the Senate on 27 May.

After five years, you and your Department finally conceded that China operates a "compulsory family planning policy [which] has held down the number of children to fewer than most couples want." You noted that it is "important to acknowledge that the required nature of the birth limitation policy which the Chinese government has adopted to tackle the population problem has many deleterious consequences.

Your letter noted that "most commentators agree that if the state's requirement to limit and plan births to specified levels were lifted, many couples would not restrict themselves to one or two children as currently required." You also acknowledged that "the introduction of the [one-child] policy . . . also has resulted in significant increases in the ratio of abortions to live births in China. Abortion is the only method by which women, once pregnant, can prevent births inconsistent with policies or contracts and remain within the terms of the law.

This, of course, contradicts the assertions which UNFPA and Chinese officials have been making for many years, and which have been merely repeated by AIDAB and which were repeated in the report of the Human Rights Delegation which visited China in 1991.

Your letter noted that the focus of the program is on "meeting birth targets" which results in an emphasis on `low-cost, poor quality IUDs and sterilisations—which are controlled by service providers rather than by users themselves." Your letter noted the role of UNFPA in "supporting the production and expanded use of high-quality, modern IUDs in China." Indeed, it is most important that UNFPA's continuing contribution to the control exercised by "service providers" be exposed, although I rather suspect that this is not the interpretation you intended.

The letter referred to the new Administrative Procedural Law purportedly "intended to give citizens some recourse in law against abuses by officials." This, of course, is the latest diversionary line being adopted by UNFPA, and by Dr Hull in his paper. The evidence cited by Dr Hull, in fact, reasonably leads to the opposite conclusion that the new APL is designed not to curb the powers of family planning cadres, but to strengthen them and make sure that the rules are enforced.

Nevertheless, I welcome AIDAB's and your conversion from the stance that there is no evidence of coercive practices condoned by the Chinese authorities in its population control program, to now admitting that the program is inherently coercive.
Had I accepted the original responses, or even bowed to pressure from people such as Mr Kerin, none of this would have become open to public scrutiny.

The evidence of human rights violations continues to lead me to the view that there can not be constructive involvement with regimes pursuing population control where such involvement will be interpreted and used, both domestically and internationally, as endorsement of the regime's population control policies.
As Dr Aird has written:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "Improving the quality of services, even in family planning programs, is certainly, possible and may be beneficial to some people in China, but the advantages of doing that must be weighed against the disadvantages that result from lending support to a coercive program and thereby helping to perpetuate its inhumanities. . . .

SPEECH.PARA: The choice is between the unrealistic hope of `helping in a very small way' by supporting the Chinese family planning program on the one hand and, on the other, sending a strong message to the top political leadership by refusing cooperation until coercion is effectively terminated.

The victims of population control mania—who are almost invariably poor and powerless women—deserve to have the world hear the truth. As we have discovered over these past five years, strong vested interests have impeded this search for truth which must, of necessity, be ongoing.
Yours sincerely,
Senator Brian Harradine
Encl. Documentation: Coercive Family Planning and Australian Aid Policy

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It is important, and I believe it would be instructive for AIDAB and other agencies, including the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, to study this document and the response I have made. If Australia continues with its policies, then it is my view that we should hang our heads in shame. When democracy ultimately comes to the people of China they will remember the suffering in that area which has been condoned by Australia and its aid agencies.

PARA.TAB: The second matter I want to raise on this Human Rights Day is also, I believe, a serious reflection on the treatment of the human rights of individuals by Australia. This Senate has prided itself on its responsibility and its role to uphold the rights of individuals. I am proud to have been amongst those senators who vigorously opposed the legislation the Government rushed through the Parliament, in May of this year, to prevent certain Cambodian refugees and boat people from approaching the Federal Court to obtain release from detention pending the outcome of their refugee status claims.

I have had an opportunity to look at the High Court decision of Tuesday, 8 December, which ruled invalid that part of the legislation which was passed by this Parliament in May. I add that that legislation was passed against my wishes and against the wishes of a number of other honourable senators. I will quote some sections from that judgment which I believe the Government will find most interesting and which will have quite dramatic ramifications for the Government. On page 16, their honours said:

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, it has not been suggested on behalf of the Minister or the Commonwealth that any of the plaintiffs was arrested pursuant to the old s.38 . . . or the subsequent s.92 . . . of the Act or that any order of detention of any of the plaintiffs in custody was ever made under either of those sections. The result is that the continued detention of each plaintiff in custody after the destruction of the boat on which he or she arrived in Australia was unlawful.
The High Court justices said that those people had been kept in detention unlawfully—some of them for over two years. Prior to that comment, on page 13, their honours had said:

Nor, in the absence of legislative provision to the contrary, does an alien within the country lack standing or capacity to invoke the intervention of a domestic court of competent jurisdiction if he or she is unlawfully detained.
The following comment is something that the Government should consider:

If the unlawful detention is by a person who is an officer of the Commonwealth, the status of that person as such an officer will of itself neither confer immunity from proceedings against him or her personally in the ordinary courts of the land nor provide an answer to an application for habeas corpus in any court of competent jurisdiction.

If I were the president of the union responsible for the industrial interests of those Commonwealth officers who were instructed to hold those Cambodian boat people in detention and who are now exposed to court action, I would certainly be asking the Government to take the necessary steps to settle the matter with honour.

PARA.TAB: The Cambodian boat people have been denied their fundamental human rights by the Government. The Court has said so. They have been incarcerated unlawfully for over two years. The Court has said so. The Court has now said that those people have standing to approach courts for remedies and that the officers who have detained them are personally liable. That raises very serious questions for the Government to properly address.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity today to refer to three matters, and I shall do so briefly. The first arises from a question I asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on 3 December. He replied and incorporated his answer in Hansard on 8 December, which meant I had not seen it when I asked the question and could not take note of it at the time. It related to the question of a calculation of superannuation guarantee payment on the termination of employment of components of holiday pay, long service leave and some sick leave. In answering, the Minister indicated that superannuation guarantee is paid on those items and so they would be in the normal course of employment. But the significance of my question was in the words `upon the termination of employment' and that part of the question has not been answered or dealt with in the answer which the Minister has incorporated.

PARA.TAB: The significance of the words `upon the termination of employment' is that if an employer has somebody who leaves on Friday he pays these additional amounts upon termination. I see no reason why they should attract superannuation guarantee. It seems to me that that is something that would be paid on a person's wage, on his holiday wage—while he is away from work on holidays—or when he is sick. But to pay it on those amounts which have accrued at the time of termination means that the employer is paying twice. If someone leaves work on Friday, and another person starts on Monday, the employer is liable to pay the superannuation guarantee levy from the Monday. I would like Senator Button to take the matter back to Treasury and ask it to focus upon the phrase `upon the termination of employment' in answering the matter.

The second part of the question asked how much additional revenue would be raised if the interim ruling required an employer to pay on those items which are calculated as part of the termination pay. It indicates further that the question was not understood when Senator Button said, `I am advised that there will be no additional revenue as a result of the ruling'. That clearly is not the case; there is additional revenue as a consequence if the ruling of the Treasury is interpreted in the way that it seems to be, in regard to the words `upon the termination of employment'.

Last week we heard, I think through an announcement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), that all primary school children would be learning an Asian language by the year 2000. I do not argue with that as an approach. I ask the Prime Minister what he is going to do about those who are graduating in 1992 with Asian languages—who are fluent in the language and are competent to go to work and use the language—who cannot get a job anywhere. I could give a number of examples, but in particular I know of a student in Canberra who has an economics degree, an Asian studies degree and a major—perhaps honours—in Mandarin. He is fluent in Mandarin and he has applied everywhere for a job which would use this language. He is not the only one I know of with Chinese. I know of people with Japanese language skills who would want to use them in the area of trade in the places they are talking about.

In one newspaper referred to, Mr Goss said that the fact that few prominent Australian businessmen and women speak any Asian languages is unfortunate and places major constraints on the development of trade and investment opportunities. Dr Lawrence referred to this as being important to improve cultural and trading links with Asia. She said that she believed that it is absolutely essential, if Australia is to be serious about its future with Asia. That phrase might have been from Mr Goss.

There are students here and now in whom this country has invested thousands of dollars in learning languages and who are now fluent who cannot—in 1992, at the end of this academic year—get jobs. I know one who is employed parking cars. Of course, that job ought to be available to somebody who does not speak fluent Mandarin and whose skill would be parking cars. But the job is being filled at present by a young man who has fluent Mandarin, who cannot get into the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, AIDAB or any of the places in Canberra or anywhere else.

To come out and say that by the year 2000 everybody will speak an Asian language is commendable but what about jobs for those people? What is really being done to provide jobs or opportunities for people who already have these skills and are not able to use them? It seems to me that the announcement last week was pretty meaningless. It was designed to make the Government look as though it was doing something rather than actually doing something, because we know that at the present time there are people who are highly qualified who are not able to use their skills.

I come to the third matter, which is again to do with people with skills. I was intrigued by the answer that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) gave earlier this week to a question asked by Senator Sherry. The question was clearly designed to enable the Minister to make a ministerial statement on the Disability Services Act. Senator Bolkus said that the achievements of the Government in this area had met `all the needs' of people with disability. I wrote down his words.

I want to tell him that that is not the case and I want to refer specifically to the group in Canberra called Chartwell Crafts. All honourable senators present would be aware of the work done by these young artists because their tapestries are hanging in a number of places in this building and in other places. For some reason, it has been determined that the Disability Services Act definition does not apply to them. Last year they were given some money but they have been told constantly that the Disability Services Act does not apply to them because the art they are pursuing is not work.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I wonder what would happen if you or I or any other senator told the Sydney Symphony Orchestra, the Australian Ballet or the Australian Opera, bodies that are heavily funded by taxpayers in this country, that what they are doing is not work. Yet these young artists are told that, under the Disability Services Act, what they do is not work. They will be assisted to get jobs. I ask: where are the jobs that these young people with disabilities may be able to do? It has been suggested that some of them may be able to do photocopying or they may be able to get a job detailing a car. They might be able to do those jobs if they were able to get them.

I wonder what is the real thrust of the Disability Services Act. One of the documents, a summary of amendments to the Disability Services Act, said that it would allow the Minister to fund on a case by case basis. That does not seem to be happening in relation to these young artists. They have been taught their skill all through their time at school, at the Woden School, at Woden Valley High School and at Dickson College. They are now in this group that has been set up, called Chartwell Crafts, where they do tapestries on commission, but they need some assistance in addition to that to enable it to continue.

Thanks to their parents, it looks as though they will be able to keep it going until about February of 1993. Then they are doomed to going home and having nothing more to do with their day than to watch the Midday Show. Not one of them has been given the slightest opportunity to obtain a job anywhere else. As artists, as they are at the present time, their confidence is as high as one could possibly expect it to be. They have self-esteem. They are much better integrated into society. But, because of the interpretation of the Disability Services Act, they will be sent home from Chartwell Crafts, and watching television will be about the best that they can hope for to fill in their days.

When we talk about getting people with disabilities into the community and into employment, I believe that it is time we had a serious look at the actual skills that these young people have. A great deal of time and effort has been invested in training them for the skills that they have. They are artists. All of them have been in classes previously where it has been attempted to teach art in this way to many more students, but these are the ones who have actually gone on and developed their skills, not only in tapestry but in drawing and other things.

I wonder what sort of a society it is we live in when we say, `You are a person with a disability; therefore you will not be supported to pursue your skill as an artist. You can go and do photocopying or car detailing or weed a garden'. Why do we fund other arts groups—orchestras, ballets and operas? We fund them because they are a valuable addition to our society. But for some reason art is not included as work for people with a disability and so they do not qualify for any assistance.

The irony of all of this is that there are a couple of groups in Canberra, including from DEET, which have sent people for work experience to Chartwell Crafts, because of the value of what is being done there and because of what they can learn by spending up to six weeks with the students at Chartwell Crafts. DEET see it as a valuable part of our society. I think ACT TAFE has also been involved with them. But the Disability Services Act administrators will not be shifted. I say to Senator Bolkus that all of the needs have not been met. I invite him to have a look at this particular area, and to have some regard for the skills that artists have in this area, just as we do with able-bodied people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate the matter of the granting of five sandmining leases by the Commonwealth to Pivot Projects Pty Ltd and Pivot Mining NL. I attempted to raise this matter the other day when Senator Collins, the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly), failed to provide an answer to a series of questions on this matter, which I had lodged with the Minister back in August.

PARA.TAB: In September, the Minister wrote to me saying that she still could not provide an answer. That was roughly within the 30 days in which she should have provided an answer. The Minister only just provided me with an answer the other day. I found that answer unsatisfactory in its contents and there was no explanation as to why it had come so late. I have spoken many times in the Senate of my opposition to this mining project at Shoalwater Bay. I have spoken quite vigorously in defence of the proposition that Shoalwater Bay should become a World Heritage area. It has absolutely magnificent wilderness qualities. The value of that whole area—roughly 1,000 square kilometres—has been extolled by CSIRO scientists as an ecological laboratory.

Some 30 per cent of Australia's species occur in that area. It lies at the intersection between the tropical area and the more temperate parts of Australia. It runs from a coastal region, which involves the waters contiguous to the Great Barrier Reef, right back through mangrove swamps, tropical rainforest areas and mountains. It runs about 30 kilometres inland. It has very unusual, diverse landscapes and dune systems, and, of course, the species which accompany them. It has pristine and reliable water sources which are absolutely essential to the well-being of the people of Rosslyn Bay and various other local communities. The irreversible destruction that would be caused by the mining of the dunes and the impossibility of restoring the dunes to their original condition is something which should cause a great deal of concern.

The short term nature of the proposed mining project, compared with the long term benefits of eco-tourism, the fishing industry—which is very concerned about damage to the dunes—and the preserving of the water supply are all issues that are of very high priority. There is a very high likelihood of the project not being viable economically. The former Bureau of Mineral Resources has stated that there is a 98 per cent probability that the project would show zero, or less, rate of return.

Many agencies, including the Australian Heritage Commission, DASET, the Australian Water Resources Council, the CSIRO—as I have mentioned—and others have all indicated at various stages of the approvals process that they have grave concerns about this project going ahead in any way whatsoever. Finally, on the environmental aspects, there is widespread opposition by local and national environmental groups to the project. The local shire council has come out quite strongly against it. I think many honourable senators would have seen Peter Garrett's program about this on Channel 7 a week or so back.

I would like to raise other issues in relation to Pivot Projects Pty Ltd, Pivot NL and the Pivot Group Ltd and the one individual involved in these projects, Mr Peter Laurance. Mr Peter Laurance, one of the directors of Pivot Projects Pty Ltd, has been recommended for investigation by the royal commissioners into the Tricontinental affair. According to a report in the Courier-Mail of 24 September 1992, Tricontinental lost $55m on its loans to Mr Peter Laurance's company Pivot Group Ltd. According to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 18 November 1992, Victorian taxpayers footed the bill for more than $80m in debts incurred by companies owned by Mr Peter Laurance and his family. It just so happens that Mr Peter Laurance is the chairman of the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation. He and his family are the sole shareholders of Q-West Company, which is mainly an investment and management consultancy.

Transaction report No. 16 of the report of the Tricontinental commissioners records the investigation relating to a portion of Tricontinental shares in Windsor Resources NL, a company whose main activities were gold production and mineral exploration. The portion of Tricontinental's shares in question were held on a profit share arrangement on behalf of Mr Laurance of Q-West. The report refers to the secretary of Q-West informing Mr Ian Johns of Tricontinental on 18 June 1987 that its fee for the provision of investment and property advice was $86,000. It further records that Mr Laurance had returned the cheque for $72,000 and requested that a cheque be made payable to a company by the name of Portsaid Investments Ltd. I have been unable to trace this company through the Australian Securities Commission database and I therefore presume that this company is based offshore.

The report records that due to time constraints the Commission was unable to fully investigate an investment banking facility relating to Windsor. However, it did state that further matters to be investigated are whether any information relating to Windsor not generally available in the market was provided to Mr Laurance of Q-West and the terms of any arrangement between Tricontinental and Mr Laurance to share profit on the sale of Windsor shares.
The Commission concludes by recommending that the Australian Securities Commission should investigate whether there was any fraud in respect of these transactions. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission finds that the various dealings outlined in this transaction report have an air of contrivance about them which warrants further investigation by the Australian Securities Commission. The amounts involved, and the possibly fraudulent nature of the activities, are sufficient to justify such a course, which the Commission recommends.
In the light of that recommendation, the Commission believes it would be inappropriate for it to express any tentative conclusions on the issues involved.

The Sydney Morning Herald of 20 November 1992 ran a story that the Australian Securities Commission is currently examining the business deal involving Mr Peter Laurance and his company Q-West. The question therefore must be asked: is it appropriate for the Commonwealth to be entering into a contract with an individual who is being investigated by the Australian Securities Commission?

PARA.TAB: I now turn to the Pivot Mining NL company. This is one of the companies involved in the sandmining project at Shoalwater Bay. According to the 1992 annual report of the company, Pivot Mining has entered into irrevocable contractual obligations to purchase interests in sandmining areas at Shoalwater Bay. The annual return of the company states that the company's principal activity during the year ending 30 June 1991 was that of enhancing and developing mining interests. Prior to that, the principal activity of the company was that of hiring marine recording equipment. Another question must be asked: what does this indicate about the experience and expertise of this company in carrying out mining activities particularly in such an environmentally sensitive area as Shoalwater Bay?

The issued capital of this company on 30 June 1991 was a mere $1. This was increased to $5, subsequent to the date of the accounts attached to the 1991 annual returns. Although the accounts reflected efficiency of working capital, they have been drawn up on the basis that the company is a going concern. This is based on the potential of the lease agreements for mining in Shoalwater Bay. As I have mentioned, the former Bureau of Mineral Resources has indicated that there is a 98 per cent probability that the project will show a zero or less rate of return.

These matters raise serious concerns over insurance and about the ability of the companies concerned to raise sufficient capital to provide comprehensive insurance for the project. One could refer here to the shocking state in which the Magnetic Keys development on Magnetic Island has been left as a consequence of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority not carrying through its deed of agreement in relation to $20m worth of insurance on that development.

The 1991 financial statements of Pivot Projects Pty Ltd reveal that the company involved a massive loss of over $22.5m, and this raises further very serious questions about the financial viability of the companies and the appropriateness of the Government's involvement. That is the point that I want to come back to. The accounts of Pivot Group Ltd, the holding company of Pivot Projects Pty Ltd, for the year ending 30 June 1991, reveal that notice has been received of proceedings in the Federal Court against Pivot Projects Pty Ltd and other related parties, claiming damages under section 52 of the Trade Practices Act 1974. Section 52 provides:

SPEECH.PARA: A corporation shall not, in trade or commerce . . . engage in conduct that is misleading or deceptive or is likely to mislead or deceive.

So questions must be asked about the appropriateness of the Commonwealth engaging in an agreement with companies and individuals that have not proved in the past to be financially responsible. One might rather cynically note that, Tricontinental having lost over $80m with respect to Mr Peter Laurance's companies, Mr Peter Laurance is now head of the Tourist Corporation in Queensland, trying through his advertising, which has been much criticised in recent days, to inveigle other Victorians to go up to Queensland and spend even more money there.

PARA.TAB: Leaving that aside, the ability of this company to carry out these activities is very much in question. Of course, I am particularly interested because, having asked questions about this matter back in August, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) found that she could not reply in September and we still have no explanation as to why the Federal Government, a Federal Labor Government, has not provided an explanation as to the delay. It certainly smells of an implication of the Federal Government in a deal with the Queensland Labor Government to protect the interests of Mr Peter Laurance.

One needs to be very concerned that an area of such prime importance from an environmental point of view is likely to be despoiled as a consequence of activities by a company that has such a shocking record and which, on all the evidence, is not capable of carrying out the mining operation and is not likely to make any profit for itself or for Australia. It is very important that these matters be put on the record and that the Federal Government rethink its attitude with respect to the leases in this important area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday, together with my fellow Queensland Liberal senators, I brought a matter of public importance to the attention of the Senate. It was in relation to an alleged bribe of a Cabinet Minister in the Queensland Government and I made a plea that the reportage of the material tabled be done by the Courier-Mail in Queensland. It was interesting to note that that did not occur. The only note in the metropolitan press was by the Sunday Telegraph on 6 December where it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Courier Mail newspaper did not run the contents of the transcript after it was tabled in Federal Parliament . . . saying its legal advice was that to do so could affect a trial involving Mr Vasta and an appeal by Mr Coco.

Prior to tabling that material, legal advice was sought from a number of sources which contradicted the statement of the Courier-Mail. The report, however, was carried by the Gold Coast Bulletin. It was also carried by the Sunshine Coast Daily but no further reports occurred. People should be aware that there is a monopoly in Brisbane at least where the Courier-Mail is the only daily newspaper.

PARA.TAB: I made a plea on that occasion for the media to investigate the material that was tabled. I was even mocked, or at least it was said by Mr Ian Warden in the Canberra Times—and I must say that I am a member of the Ian Warden fan club; I do not deny his great ability in his satirical articles; I think he has a talent that is not matched by anyone else in Australia—that I moaned about the Courier-Mail. I did not moan about the Courier-Mail. I made a plea for it to investigate the material that was tabled. Considering that it has a monopoly position, I think it has a duty to do so.
On Tuesday, 8 December, the Courier-Mail at least ran a report entitled, `Media blocks reform, journalist tells EARC'. It stated:
Mr Phil Dickie, the 1987 Gold Walkley winner, journalism's highest accolade, said reform had occurred in most other public institutions in the state apart from the media.
"Indeed, it (the media) has become more derelict in the performance of its public information function and less accountable.
He said, "It is my view that Queensland is by and large poorly served by its media organisations and its journalists.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Dickie was a journalist with the Courier-Mail and, if anybody should be aware of the circumstances surrounding these matters, it is he. He wrote a series of articles, of course, exposing corruption which contributed to the establishment of the Fitzgerald inquiry.

PARA.TAB: Since that occasion, further events have occurred in Queensland. There has been the dismissal of the Deputy Police Commissioner—an extraordinary event that is still an ongoing saga because the Deputy Police Commissioner has appealed over this matter. There is a continuing smell of corruption in Queensland that cannot be covered up. Further material has come to my attention which I will be presenting at a future date. I believe that this is of fundamental importance to the continuing development and reforms that must occur as a result of the Fitzgerald inquiry because there are matters being covered up. There are rumours, as yet unsubstantiated, of corruption within Queensland. I believe that this saga will continue. It will be, I know, exposed by certain elements of the media who have the facility and the ability to investigate the matters that have been laid before the Senate chamber.

I wish to make a statement on one other small matter that is totally unrelated in the short time available. I have to make a confession that I misled the Senate last night. I am sorry Senator Crowley is not present because—

TALK.START.PARA: —Five Hail Marys for that.

—My confession may be not what Senator Colston thinks. I said last night that there was an 18-week waiting list to get an outpatients appointment at the orthopaedic department at the Royal Brisbane Hospital and that, once having obtained the appointment to the orthopaedics department of the Royal Brisbane Hospital, there was a 24-week waiting list if someone required an operation.
—Forty-two weeks.

—I thank Senator Tambling. I have discovered today that the actual waiting time for an outpatients appointment is 26 weeks and, if someone is fortunate enough to get that appointment to the outpatients department, the minimum time for surgery is 15 months; it is between 15 months and 18 months from the time that the decision is made to have the operation.

PARA.TAB: I mentioned last night that one patient in her late seventies, who has an arthritic knee, has been put on the waiting list. She has pain and disability that is continuing. When she was seen, after a 26-week wait to get the outpatient clinic appointment, the knee was painful, she was unable to sleep with it, and she was put on a waiting list for a total knee replacement—in 15 months time.
