Because of her general physical debility, it is unlikely that she will be fit for surgery and it is anticipated that at that time she will be told, `Sorry, it is too late. You are not fit enough for the operation'. So, while my sin was a small one, I do not think it warrants the contrition that was proposed to me of five Hail Marys; I think it could be of a lesser degree.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reid referred earlier in this matters of public interest debate to comments by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) earlier this week with regard to the disability field. I would also like to correct a very obvious misstatement, whether deliberate or not, by the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services.

PARA.TAB: On Tuesday, 8 December, Senator Sherry asked Senator Bolkus a question relating to proposals to increase the disability support pension. Senator Sherry went on to ask:

SPEECH.PARA: Has the Minister seen other proposals to support the disabled? Are those proposals feasible and will the Government implement them?
Senator Bolkus engaged in quite a lengthy answer which really did not get to the point. However, when he started to refer to the coalition's policies in this area, he said:
For instance, the Fightback package proposes a number of measures, the main one of which is a fortnightly allowance of some $45 for the severely disabled—
At that point, Senator Bolkus was interrupted by various interjections and when he came back to the record he went on to say:

I really need to go to the point that Dr Hewson in recent weeks told a number of disabled people in Adelaide at a conference of ACROD that he would extend the $45 allowance to cover all DSP pensioners.

That quote is patently wrong. Senator Bolkus then indicated that he had had some advice—I hope it was not from the Department of Community Services, which should have been better advised—by means of which he drew out figures from the initial Fightback costings of $57m. Senator Bolkus's guesstimate—and I can only call it a guesstimate—was that the changes would, in effect, cost some $200m.

PARA.TAB: Again, Senator Bolkus must have been drawing a wild and fanciful story, because I am sure that departmental officers were present at the ACROD conference in Adelaide, which was very well attended. I need to put on the record exactly what Dr Hewson said. Let me quote from the transcript of his speech:

SPEECH.PARA: I don't want to raise unrealistic hopes about what Government action can achieve and I certainly don't want to make exaggerated promises about what the coalition will do. But I can point to Fightback's significant benefits for people with disabilities, both as a target group and as members of the wider community. The most important direct benefit in Fightback—
here he is referring to that disability audience that he is talking to—

I believe is an entirely new allowance of $45 a fortnight to be paid to people with severe disabilities. I am aware that there has been some confusion about whether this would apply to all people with 70 per cent disability or only those who are also receiving the disability pension. So let me clear that up here and now. All people with 70 per cent disability will receive that allowance irrespective of whether they are receiving the pension. So not just the pensioners but everybody with a 70 per cent disability.

Senator Bolkus made no attempt in his answer, or in his obvious guesstimates of finances, to draw on the statement of fact by Dr Hewson relating to the provision of these facilities—very importantly, to people who have a 70 per cent disability. In that respect, Senator Bolkus totally drew on false information and misled the Senate.
