TALK.START.PARA: —The Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 makes minor technical amendments to the Christmas Island Act 1958 and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act 1955. This legislation has been requested by the Western Australian Government in the context of the Western Australian Government's decision to move forward with its own legislation. The Indian Ocean Territories (Administration of Laws) Bill was introduced into the Western Australian Parliament on 11 November 1992, passed through the Legislative Assembly on 26 November, and the Western Australian upper House, without amendment, on 2 December 1992.

PARA.TAB: The two amendments are not controversial, with one amendment relating to the technical manner of application of Western Australian laws. That is, the Christmas Island Act and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act currently provide that the provisions of the law of Western Australia are in force in each Territory `so far as they are capable of applying to the Territory'. This is logically prior to the modification of applied laws by ordinances, which causes Western Australia concern regarding the applicability of these ordinances. The Bill removes the reference in both the Christmas Island Act and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act to the applicability of Western Australian law. This will remove any doubt. Provisions incapable of application will still not have any real effect, but will be described as part of the law in force in the Territory.

The other amendment concerns the exercise of judicial and related powers that are applied to laws by Territory or State courts and court officers. Western Australia has sought a range of amendments of these provisions to refer to court officers rather than judicial officers, as currently applies. This will enable officers to be able to deal more comprehensively and consistently with the full range of courts and tribunals of the State.

Honourable senators will recall that earlier this year this Parliament passed the Territories Law Reform Bill 1992, an important piece of constitutional legislation. Essentially, it replaced a Singaporean based regime with a Western Australian based body of law. Some 700 pieces of Western Australian Acts of Parliament were transferred in their administration to these Indian Ocean islands as a result of this legislation. These Western Australian laws are subject to modification by ordinance under the Christmas Island Act and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act. We have already seen a number of pieces of legislation which have been repealed or their operations suspended, or modification of the legislation for application on the islands. I have noted with interest the comments made by the Western Australian member for Kingsley, Mrs Cheryl Edwardes, who is the shadow Minister in this area, regarding the Indian Ocean Territories becoming part of the Western Australian State electorate. She says of Christmas and Cocos (Keeling) Islands:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . could become part of our electorate at some time in the future. That has already been recommended, although it has not been taken up in this legislation. However, I am sure that within the next of couple of years that series of islands could become part of Western Australia.

In the long term, this is a very valid point. My main concern at present is that, given that the laws of Western Australia now apply to Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands, the residents of these islands have no representation in the Parliament of Western Australia where the bulk of their laws will now be made. These islands are, coincidentally, part of my own electorate and they are also part of the electorate of Senator Collins for voting purposes at Federal elections.

PARA.TAB: A very formal community of interest, particularly in the provision of education and health services, has been built up with Western Australia. The community of interest of many of the families is now, as Mr Acting Deputy President would be aware, with communities in Perth and with those in Port Hedland. Looking to the future, the application of Western Australian law will inevitably lead to the incorporation of those islands into the State of Western Australia. I am certainly looking at initiating discussions on behalf of the Federal Opposition with the respective representative bodies on both of those islands to ensure that constitutional progress can be made in that regard in the long term.

I would also like to comment on the operation of the Christmas Island casino. The member for Kingsley made further comments about the operation of casinos in Western Australia. The applicability of this legislation applies very much to that casino. In her speech, Mrs Edwardes said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Commonwealth Government must bring the infrastructure of the islands up to mainland standards. The establishment of the casino complex may mean that the Island achieves financial independence from Australia. The casino is expected to bring around 40,000 people to the islands mainly from Indonesia. It is important that this Bill be passed to ensure that the Christmas Island casino will provide the same level of operation and service that is provided by the Burswood Casino. From a Western Australian point of view any competitor to the Burswood Casino should be operated under the same conditions.

The operation of a casino on Christmas Island is intended to be effected at some stage in this financial year. In the recent Estimates and Appropriations debates, I was able to ascertain from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and her officers that that particular program has been slowed because of problems with the construction details and the construction program. However, it is important that laws and the applicability of these laws are in place to ensure that if and when that casino is up and running—and hopefully the target date of March 1993 will be achieved—we ensure that there is a comparability and an appropriate checking of those operations.

PARA.TAB: I have also noted in recent days the appointment of a new administrator, Mr John Read, to Cocos (Keeling) Islands. The appointment by the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Ms Fatin) is nothing less than a job for the boys. Mr Read is a former Cabinet Secretary to the Western Australia Inc. Premier, Brian Burke. He received $15,000 from the discredited Labor leader's account in 1989, and after he was not re-elected to the Western Australian Parliament in that year, he was also given a special State development job.

It is very interesting to note that Mr Read has held party political positions in branches in Western Australia associated with the Minister for Arts and Territories, and there have been associations in the various preselections that date back to 1982. It had been widely rumoured in Western Australia that Mr Read was in line for preselection for a safe Labor upper House seat, but obviously in some deal that has been done in Western Australia as part of the numbers game that was changed and he was given the job of Administrator, Cocos (Keeling) Islands.

In this regard, I have placed questions on the Notice Paper to both the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the senior portfolio Minister, Mrs Kelly. I hope they will be answered in the next week or so to ensure that we have a full documentation of all the issues surrounding Mr Read's appointment that should be properly available to this Senate before he assumes the position of Administrator for the Islands. I will continue to question this appointment as there are serious questions surrounding an appointment to such an important position that will have particular relevance to this legislation.

I was pleased to note that last week there was an election for a new shire council on Christmas Island and a number of new councillors have taken office. It will be important that under the Territories law reform legislation the new council exercises a proper and full consultative role in implementing all of the legislation and any changes necessary.

Although the Opposition supports this legislation, it is concerned that such a small piece of legislation could have been dealt with through the correct process of the Territories Law Reform Act. If the Department had consulted with the relevant authorities in Western Australia, instead of rushing the original legislation through Parliament—honourable senators will recall that that took place last June—with virtually no consultation with the island communities or the Western Australian Government, this piece of legislation would not have been necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the hour, I will agree with the accuracy of the detail given by Senator Tambling on the Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, but I will ignore the politics in his contribution. I thank him for his contribution to the debate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 24 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will keep my remarks to a minimum to see whether we can deal with the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill before 2 o'clock. Very briefly, this proposal is a result of a backflip by the Government. In 1990 new proposals by the Government were brought into force. The Opposition did not oppose the Bill and, indeed, what occurred on that occasion was that the number of people who were to be eligible for the EMDG scheme was limited.

PARA.TAB: I will give honourable senators some statistics. In the grant year of 1990-91, Austrade processed 2,002 claims for grants under the EMDG scheme, with a value of $143m. This compared with 3,035 claims with a value of $179.6m in the 1989-90 grant year. The decline in numbers was attributed to the change in the scheme which came into effect on 1 July 1990, so that in 1991-92 a total of 2,401 claims were processed, with a total value of $127.4m. In other words, the scheme was to be limited because, as a result of a report by Professor Helen Hughes, it was found that there was no particular causal link between exports and the scheme itself. However, in desperation, the Labor Party, looking for some sort of initiative to try to make up the volume of exports that it might be able to try to claim some credit for—panic measures, one could call them—has made a complete reversal of policy and let back into the scheme those people that its amendments and its policy excluded in 1990.

This is yet another back flip by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), a turnaround, a reversal of policy—any of those emotional terms could be used. It is a clear example of the desperation politics of a Labor Government that has given us one million unemployed, an international debt of $162 billion, and no policies to deal with that problem. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) was the first one to admit in the chamber that there were no policies. We had a whole debate on it here yesterday. Again we see that the Labor Party has no policy at all to deal with the economic decline in Australia. On the other hand, the Fightback package will allow $1.7 billion in taxes which are presently imposed upon exports to be abolished. That will effectively make us more competitive and allow us to have the chance to export in a far more meaningful way than the manner which the Government proposes by this back flip on its policy.

The Business Council of Australia and the Industry Commission have said that the implementation of the policies advocated by the coalition—to abolish, along with other taxes, payroll tax, wholesale sales tax and the fuel excise—could boost gross domestic product by a figure of at least 15 per cent, or some $60 billion, and that would go a long way towards meeting the monthly repayments on the huge debt that the Government has allowed to be built up. The Fightback initiatives, particularly those aimed at accelerating micro-economic reform, will benefit exporters to a far greater extent than any back flip on the EMDG scheme. In this context, we have a government with no policies trying to turn around and reintroduce a failed policy. What we need is an election and the Fightback policy to give Australia a chance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The one thing I have always admired about Senator Bishop is that she has got more front than Woolworths. I do not think anyone else in the Senate other than Senator Bishop could have used the words `back flip' and `Fightback' in the same sentence with a straight face. With those few words, I thank her for her contribution to the debate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to today's terrible unemployment statistics and, in particular, to the fact that between October and November a further 78,400 Australians lost their jobs. In light of these awful figures, I ask the Minister again, as I have almost every day for the last few weeks, whether the Government is going to do something about this continuing list of jobless, this jobs collapse. When are we going to see something from this Government that can be directed to the tragedy that its policies have created?

—So far as the last part of the question is concerned and the allegation that this Government's policies have created these levels of unemployment, we have to make similar criticisms of other governments around the world which have exactly the same levels of unemployment—particularly the model that those opposite always use, the Thatcher type model in England, which has produced extraordinary levels of unemployment and a huge deficit. The unemployment figures for the November period are very disappointing and tragic.
—Disappointing? For heaven's sake! Tell that to those on the dole queues.

—They are not disappointing to those opposite, of course. They always get excited when unemployment figures go up because they hope they can benefit from them. During November full time employment fell by 15,700 and part time employment fell by 62,000. The figures are showing, however, a great deal of volatility and they are jumping around almost as much as coalition policies have been jumping around. The decline in employment was concentrated in New South Wales. In Victoria and Western Australia, employment actually rose: for example, in Western Australia the unemployment figure was reduced by one per cent.
—Do you believe that?

—I have difficulty in believing it in respect of any of these figures State by State, but these are the ABS figures. However, the unemployment rate moved around substantially driven by changes in the labour force participation rate: for example, the unemployment rate fell in New South Wales and rose in Victoria despite the rise in employment in that State.

PARA.TAB: We will see a sustained improvement in employment with further consolidation of recovery in economic activity. The September quarter national account showed GDP growth at 2.1 per cent over the year. Job market indicators suggest that we can expect an improvement in employment. For example, CES job vacancies rose in the September quarter to their highest level in two years; the ANZ employment advertisement index for November shows a modest and continuing pick up; and the DEET skilled vacancy index shows a continuing rise in recent months.

Budget measures will create further jobs, assist the recovery and ensure employment growth in the longer term. With last year's November statement, One Nation, and the youth employment measures, this Government has allocated $2.7 billion of expenditure to infrastructure and labour market programs in 1992-93—all of which Dr Hewson, the leader of those opposite, says he would walk away from. We do not know what he will say next week, but that is what he was saying previously, just as he tried in this place to abort the recovery by talking down the importance of lowering interest rates in 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am pleased that, finally, the Minister seems to be at least recognising the tragedy that is out there. I know that an awful Christmas is ahead for almost another 80,000 as demonstrated by these figures. But the Minister seems to be saying to the Senate that the Government is still not going to offer anything new—no new policies at all, no change of direction; in fact, nothing but more of the same, and that is those Government policies which have been demonstrated to have failed, and which are continuing to fail. I give him another opportunity in this supplementary question: will the Government announce new policies or changes that can give some hope to those thousands of Australians who are out of work as a result of the Government's economic incompetence?

—As I have already said in the answer to the first part of the question, there are no changes of policy which can produce instant results in respect of employment. The employment situation will improve as we get a recovery in the Australian economy. Senator Hill talks about my recognising the tragedy. Yesterday Dr Hewson discovered that the recession was deeper than he thought. After a year of peddling Fightback around the community, stuffing it up drainpipes and things like that, he suddenly found the recession was worse than he thought. Or did he find something else was worse than he thought—the judgment on Opposition policies as being much worse than he thought when he announced Fightback. The only alternative offered here is some relief on payroll tax and that, for reasons which I have outlined before, is not a viable option.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of comments by Dr Hewson last night that the coalition would be looking to see whether it could improve its Jobsback industrial relations policy, released about six weeks ago? Does the Government propose to introduce a Jobsback style policy for individual work contracts in place of a system of fair awards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a truism that a house divided against itself cannot stand. Today the newspapers are blaring and the airwaves are abuzz with dissent in the coalition over its industrial relations policy. On one side we have Dr Hewson saying he will look at that policy again to see whether it can be improved. On the other side we have Mr Howard saying, `No change'.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question was whether those opposite will implement Jobsback, and with their record unemployment and the failure of their IR policies, one would have thought that the answer would probably be yes. The point is that the Minister cannot, under the guise of that question, debate Opposition policy. You have made that ruling many times in recent weeks and I would suggest, with respect, that it is time you enforced it.

—In reply to the point of order, Senator Cook was asked about a certain policy and whether the Government would introduce it. I ask him to answer that part of the question and not to debate Opposition policies.
—I will answer the question of whether we would introduce a policy which involves—
—You're a slow learner, aren't you.
—Order! Senator Macdonald will you cease interjecting.
—The question asked whether we would introduce a policy which involves individual work contracts rather than fair industrial awards determined by an independent Industrial Relations Commission.

PARA.TAB: The Government will plump for fairness and independence when there are disputes between employers and workers. It will have reference to an independent umpire, such as the Industrial Relations Commission, to make determinations rather than a situation in which individual employers and workers are required to strike individual work contracts, with employees being called into the office of the employers, as the policy of the Opposition requires, in order to reach an agreement, and to be confronted by unscrupulous employers with the choice, `Take these terms or be dismissed'—the contract or the sack.

What is fundamental about our industrial relations system is that we uphold the tradition of an Australian fair go. It is a fair go, fair industrial relations policy. We uphold the institutions that have served this country well over nearly the whole of the last century. We will not throw them out as the Opposition proposes to do. We will modify them in order to meet the sharper needs of the market and for Australia to move to be more internationally competitive, but we will not overturn them. They are institutions that have served us well.

We will preserve the right at law for individuals to be protected and not exploited. We will create a framework of trust in the workplace, as we have done now, which has given rise to 600 enterprise agreements being registered in the Commission, covering 15 per cent of the Australian work force, with many more in the pipeline and more to come, to create the quiet revolution of change without dispute in Australia, pushing forward a higher level of productivity.

We will recognise the flexibility that our system gives—a flexibility with fairness; not a flexibility to exploit but a flexibility to advance and work with the institutions in society. We will not make an ideological war upon trade unions because we hate them, as the Opposition proposes to do. We will work with the positive interests in the trade union movement to create a framework for significant workplace change. If Dr Hewson wants some advice, he will adopt that policy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Prime Minister's comments on 25 October 1992 when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . our biggest single problem is unemployment. And it's the one which I've devoted myself greatest to in the period I've been Prime Minister. The labour market was the thing I devoted myself to in all the years I was Treasurer.

Unemployment is now 11.4 per cent—a 72,000 increase since Mr Keating became Prime Minister. These are the worst unemployment figures ever recorded by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, with 78,000 jobs lost last month and a further 78,000 simply giving up looking for work. Why has the Prime Minister's devoted attention to creating jobs resulted in such a disaster?

TALK.START.PARA: —During the period when the Prime Minister was Treasurer, when we had growth rates which far surpassed any growth rates which had been achieved since the early 1960s, more than one million jobs were created in this country. For example, 100,000 new jobs were created in manufacturing industry up to 1990, and that reversed a trend which had been going on for a very long time. In so far as the question draws attention to the labour market consequences of our policies, that claim of the Prime Minister's is completely valid. The unemployment levels are what they are at present as a result of the recession in Australia, just as the recession around the world has resulted in high unemployment.
—Who caused the recession?

—Senator—`Four legs good, two legs bad'—Parer keeps bleating, `Who caused the recession?'. The point I am trying to get through to him is that that question can be asked of any government around the world now, except in Asia, and the answer will be the same. If miscalculations in terms of the world marketplace and so on have resulted in worldwide recession, the consequences have been the same in terms of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Since 25 October, or in the period since 1 July of this year, the Government both in the Budget and the youth statement has added to its expenditure on job creating programs and so on, and these things take time to take effect. But they will take effect as the recovery in the Australian economy also takes effect—our economy being one of the few in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development which is growing at the present time. That will help with unemployment as time goes by.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My supplementary question relates to Senator Button's comments regarding various job creation funds that he referred to. Exactly how many of the 800,000 jobs that were promised has One Nation created? Exactly how many of the 13,000 jobs announced in the Budget's local capital works program have been created? As Senator Button has previously been asked: does he rule out any new policy initiatives?

—The Government has a number of major policy initiatives related to the recovery in the Australian economy and to the question of employment. I indicated in the answer to the first part of the question what we saw those policies as being. I also indicated in answer to a question from Senator Hill that we are not pretending about this issue as the Opposition is. The Opposition spokesman on industry created 12,500 jobs out of the blue; they just did not exist. We are not about invention in respect of this matter; we are about reality. The Opposition spokesman on industry created 12,500 jobs just because he does not understand what is going on in industry. He just invented them. We are not about the process of invention.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask the Minister: what is Australia's reaction to the US-led United Nations enforcement operation in Somalia? Will Australia be making a contribution? How does the current UNOSOM operation relate to the expanded UN enforcement action? Thirdly, how will the enforcement action and UNOSOM contribute to the objective of supporting national reconciliation and the restoration of government in Somalia?

—I am sure that all senators will join me in very warmly welcoming the commencement of Operation Restore Hope and, in particular, America's leadership in breaking the impasse that had developed over Somalia and in providing an effective and coherent response, again using the machinery of the United Nations to do so. This is a chapter VII UN Charter enforcement operation which the Security Council has unanimously authorised. While it does break quite new ground by committing the United Nations to enforcement action to secure humanitarian relief, not too many people—with the possible exception of Dr Kissinger, whose remarks I noticed this morning—would think that it is a bad precedent to be set, at least for extreme situations like the one prevailing in Somalia.

PARA.TAB: The immediate objective of this operation is the alleviation of the horrendous suffering that has been created by famine and civil and political chaos in the country and the disarming of factions and other freelance bandits as far as possible. Both of these objectives should be capable of achievement within a relatively short time frame of two or three months, but we cannot get a conclusive opinion about that at this stage.

The US expects to deploy up to 28,000 of its troops to Somalia by early January. A number of other countries, including France, Canada and Zimbabwe, have also offered specific contributions at this stage. As to Australia's contribution, I was asked by the US Ambassador earlier this week whether we would consider, first, contributing to this enforcement operation and, secondly, making an additional contribution to the existing UN peacekeeping operation in Somalia known as UNOSOM. The Government is considering various options in this respect, and decisions will be taken shortly. I am not in a position, however, to indicate right now what our reaction will be.

Australia remains committed to participating in UNOSOM, at least to the present extent already committed through the 30-member movement control unit of whom 11 are already deployed, seven of them in-country. UNOSOM is a peacekeeping operation which will need to replace the shorter term enforcement operation once that shorter term operation has completed its tasks. We hope that the enforcement action and then the expanded UNOSOM will be able to quickly create the conditions conducive to the formation of a stable government in Somalia. The task ahead for UNOSOM is to support national reconciliation in Somalia and to prevent a return to chaos and lawlessness once the enforcement operation is completed.

We all recognise that the enforcement operation, particularly disarming the factions and other individual bandits and locating any caches of weapons, will be a dangerous, difficult, perhaps protracted task. However, we are hopeful that the coordinated international action now occurring in Somalia will offer the best chance of ending the human tragedy and restoring stable government in Somalia. Certainly, we in Australia will be doing our best to contribute to that result.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is asked of the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. Why has the Australian Heritage Commission imposed a de facto moratorium on nominations by community groups to the register of the National Estate? Why are Commission staff being discouraged from actively protecting National Estate areas? Given that the Commission's collaboration with State forestry agencies in regional assessments in Western Australia and Tasmania has resulted in an increasing cooption by those agencies, will the Minister terminate such collaboration and instead establish more open and independent regional assessments under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act? Finally, will the Minister review the operation of the Commission and its Act to restore its independence, its cooperation with public interest groups and its obligation to protect this country's heritage?

—The Minister has provided me with no information in respect of Senator Coulter's question. I was given some notice of this question about 20 minutes prior to Question Time. We are pursuing an answer for Senator Coulter and, hopefully, I will be able to provide it to him later today.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Has the Minister seen an advertisement, paid for by the Australian Doctors' Fund, suggesting that the Australian Government is involved in `a proposal to computerise every doctor, hospital and health care provider in Australia—and to link their computers'? Can the Minister say whether this is true. What are the facts of this matter? Will there be any privacy concerns and, if so, will they be dealt with before any such proposal is put into effect?

—I did see such a full-page advertisement in, I think, yesterday's press, from this particular group. I do not know its official status. I do believe that it is simple scaremongering which has no basis in reality at all. There will certainly be no centralised or any other sort of computerised base of information. All information on patients will be held by the doctors or the service providers as is the present case. If doctors wish to participate, they may, but it is purely voluntary; there is no mandatory or compulsory element in this whatsoever. Doctors who wish to participate may do so, and that is the proposal. But, of course, it has not yet come to fruition and there is still a tremendous amount of work to be done.

PARA.TAB: I am quite confident that doctors would not participate in it voluntarily unless they were assured that they could keep their oath of confidentiality and other matters intact and sacrosanct, as they should. If one takes privacy considerations as being paramount in these matters, which, of course, we as a government do, then I believe it is important also to note that none of the clinical information that will be available on this network to doctors who wish voluntarily to participate will be made available to governments. That is completely wrong and is not part of the scheme that is proposed.

It is also important to recognise that in so far as there are any privacy concerns—and I acknowledge that they could be held by some people in good faith—unless those privacy concerns are met and dealt with, this network will not proceed. That is an absolute assurance that I can give to the Senate and I believe it is an important one. But I believe that is only building on the foundation of the doctors themselves deciding whether they will participate. They will make a judgment as to whether confidentiality and so on can be maintained. I certainly emphasise that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Except the public hospitals.

—Even in relation to public hospitals, what I am saying is that this will not go ahead unless privacy concerns are met. That is absolutely paramount so far as the Government is concerned. I need to emphasise once again that there will be no storage of information in any sort of central facility in relation to this. It is simply a matter of trying to assist doctors in dealing with their patients in an efficient and helpful way and to provide the best medical care possible. In that respect, I believe that we should pursue the proposal, but it should not be implemented unless all privacy concerns are met.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer. Does he have any information at this point about what is claimed to be the data that will be kept on this record that might breach confidentiality?

—As I understand it, the sort of information that will be transferred will be as though it is over a telephone. There will not, as I say, be a centralised body of clinical information stored anywhere; it will just be the normal information that the doctor or health provider would keep in relation to the patient that he or she is treating. In that regard, I believe that one need have no great fears about an accumulation of clinical data. Certainly it will not be centralised and certainly it will not be available to government agencies.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the further increase in the unemployment rate in November to 11.4 per cent. Given that to alleviate that problem the business community needs to take more people on, what plans does his Government have to give business the confidence it needs to take more people on and get Australia going again? I ask that question in light of the fact that the BRW-Telecom MobileNet survey to be released tomorrow reveals that of those surveys 82 per cent believe that the coalition's policies will deliver a better productivity result than the Government's, 86 per cent expect employment in their business to be the same or lower over the next six months, 70 per cent intend no change or reduction in their investment spending over the next six months and 60 per cent see no sign of recovery from the recession in their business under this Government's policies.
—These types of surveys are always of interest, but the survey to which Senator Vanstone refers does contrast sharply with some other surveys, and I will refer her to them.
—I haven't asked you about other surveys; I asked you what you were going to do to get the country going.

—Let it be quite clear: we do not make policy on the basis of one survey. The Opposition made policy on the basis of one opinion poll which frightened hell out of it. Those opposite make policy on that basis, and look at the sorts of policies they are going to make. For example, with respect to the GST, Senator Baume wants to retain the GST on food and Warwick Smith and the National Party want to get rid of the GST on food.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Vanstone's question had nothing to do with the GST, and I ask you to draw the Minister's attention to the relevance of his answer to Senator Vanstone's question.

—The question of the GST is very relevant because we are not going to have one. That is quite clear. I make the point in respect of tariffs, for example, that Senator Boswell wants to change the coalition's tariff policy, as does the President of the National Party.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I refer you again to your ruling of 18 December, which you upheld yesterday, when you said that if a Minister chooses to answer a question the Minister should confine himself to points contained in the question with which the explanation only will render the answer intelligible. Clearly, the Minister is flouting that ruling of yesterday. I ask you to call him to order and ask him to answer the question in the terms of the question, if he chooses to answer at all.

—Order! In reply to the point of order, Senator Button was asked a question about unemployment and there then followed what I consider to be a statement. He is entitled to use an argument. I believe he was using an argument about tariffs and linking that with unemployment. However, I would remind the Minister to answer the question he was asked.

—I want to conclude the point about tariffs. The President of the National Party in New South Wales, Senator Boswell, the honourable member for Chisholm and a whole lot of people are saying that there should be a change to the coalition's tariff policy while Mr McLachlan, the shadow Minister, is saying there should not. These issues are very confusing.

—Mr President, on a point of order: my question was quite clear. It did not relate to anybody else's views and it did not relate to Opposition policies. The question was quite specific. It simply asked what is the Minister's or Government's policy to alleviate unemployment in this country. That is what we want to know—what are the policies. He is not relevant to that question when he is babbling on about anything else.
—Order! I asked Senator Button to be relevant, but it does not help if there are constant interjections.

—The point is that Senator Vanstone points to a survey done several weeks ago about the effects of Fightback on business, but we do not know what the effects of Fightback on business are any more. How do the people in the survey know what the effects of Fightback are any more? The Party of those opposite was not going to back away from it for one minute, but on Monday they backed away from it. How on earth can the people who answered that survey be a representative body?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Yesterday I raised a point of order concerning debate. I refer to standing order 73(4). I ask you to uphold the Standing Orders and to ask Senator Button not to debate an issue. I do not think you can, in any way, shape or form, say that it was an argument. He was debating the issue. I ask you to rule him out of order.

—Mr President, on the point of order: it is tedious for the Opposition to continue to raise these points of order and have them overruled and thus interfere with the smooth running of Question Time. I do recall that the question that Senator Vanstone asked contained a long statement about a survey; she covered many facets of that survey. It was an argumentative question, not a question calling just for an answer. In those circumstances, given the cast of the question, surely Senator Button has some scope to deal with all the other things contained in the question, save just the last part of it, which Senator Vanstone was so eager to ask.
—Order! In the question Senator Button was asked, reference was made to a survey and therefore I will allow the answer.

—The question was based on a survey. Those surveyed were apparently asked whether they preferred certain elements of Fightback and so on to Government policies. Senator Vanstone sought to make a virtue of that, but she cannot because the survey no longer has any validity. Fightback is up for grabs. The Opposition has different views in this room about what it should do about tariff policy and what it should do about the GST on food.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I point out to you that the question which Senator Vanstone asked Senator Button was very specific. It was, `What plans does your Government—the Keating Government—have to give business the confidence it needs to take on more people?' Senator Button persistently and wilfully wants to debate our policies. There is a time and a place for that in this Parliament, but it is not during Question Time. I ask you to bring Senator Button back to order.
—The question was about Fightback; this is quite absurd!

—Order! I am well aware of the question that Senator Vanstone asked, but she then finished with a long statement which included reference to a survey and I do not see Senator Button's answer as being out of order.

—When I began to answer this question, I referred to other surveys which were not based on Fightback; I then made the point that they are very positive surveys compared with the one which Senator Vanstone referred to.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his dissertation of his views on what views there might be on this side about Fightback and whatever else. I will put to him the main question that was put to him in the very beginning, and I will put it quite simply, without any additional flim-flam that he can be distracted by. The simple question is: what policies does the Government have to increase business confidence and thereby increase employment in this nation?

—When I answered Senator Vanstone's original question, I pointed out that surveys done by the ANZ Bank, ACCI/Westpac—all those surveys—show a totally different result in terms of confidence, investment expectations and so on from the survey to which she referred in the first part of her question. I have already answered questions from Senator Hill and others about this issue today. I made the point that this Government has announced some $2.7 billion of job-related expenditure. Those policies will have effect, just as the improvement in the growth of the Australian economy will also have effect. That is important and we will not be distracted from that task.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the outcome of aviation talks just completed in Japan?

—There could not be any more welcome news to this chamber than the successful outcome of negotiations between the Australian and Japanese governments to strengthen the aviation ties between our two countries. The outstanding success of these negotiations will be very welcome news indeed for the 500,000 Australians employed in the Australian tourist industry. The agreement that we have reached with the Japanese Government is also particularly welcome considering the current economic recession which is being suffered in Japan. The agreement provides for a major expansion of aviation rights, enabling carriers on both sides to increase their level of services between the two countries, effective immediately.

PARA.TAB: As part of the agreement, Australian carriers will now be able to service the new international airport at Kansai in Osaka when it opens in 1994. Provision has also been made to meet the growth requirements in the Australia-Japan market prior to the opening of the new Kansai airport. The capacity increases that have been agreed represent a 40 per cent increase in capacity between Australia and Japan over the next two years. In the context of the Pacific region this is a major increase in capacity and a highly successful negotiation. This capacity will enable Australian carriers to apply to the International Air Services Commission for the right to serve the Japan-Australia market, potentially leading to increased competition on this route.

This agreement follows on from successful agreements that have been reached now with major Asian markets in Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia. Our agreement with Japan is further evidence of the success of the Government's international aviation policy, particularly in the key Asia-Pacific region. I know that this news will be warmly welcomed by the Australian tourism industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister elaborate to the Senate on the benefits to Australian tourism as a result of these talks?
—I thought he'd already done that.

—The Opposition might hate hearing good news, but I am sure that everybody else would like to hear a bit. The Kansai region already provides one quarter of Japanese visitors to Australia and is expected to be the most significant generator of new tourists to Australia from Japan in the foreseeable future. The 40 per cent increase in capacity over the next two years reflects the importance for both Australia and Japan of maintaining the tremendous tourist momentum established in recent years. This agreement will facilitate growing trade and business ties. Japan is Australia's largest source of inbound tourists and, with this agreement achieved, this position can be maintained and further improved.

PARA.TAB: Currently, 12 million Japanese people travel abroad and it has been forecast that more than 22 million Japanese are expected to be travelling abroad by the end of this century. Aviation links between our two countries will enhance Australia's ability to tap this valuable tourist market.

As I said earlier, the Australian tourism industry employs over 500,000 Australians. This new agreement, providing this significant additional capacity for our most important tourist market, will be very welcome news indeed for the employment it will generate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Minister's continued rejection of criticisms of Mr Keating's half owned piggery group as `unsubstantiated muck' and to the recent receipt by these Keating companies of demands from the Australian Securities Commission for them to correct their annual returns, which I had demonstrated in the Senate were false and misleading. Now that Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd, in response to these ASC demands, has filed one year late a detailed but still unaudited set of accounts for 1990-91, which at last reveal the curious method by which Mr Keating's $430,000 purchase of a half interest in the group was turned in six weeks into a shareholder's equity of $4.2m, why has Mr Keating permitted companies of which he is a half owner, and on which his nominee is a director, to submit annual returns to the ASC which are both false and unaudited, in breach of the law and which require corrections, as the demand from the ASC to these companies and the filing of corrections by group companies already clearly demonstrate?

—That makes 19 questions that Senator Baume has asked this year as a shadow Minister—19 questions—and not one of them about his shadow portfolio. This is the Opposition at work: Senator Baume in here doing Dr Hewson's dirty work. Dr Hewson could ask these questions of Mr Keating himself in the House of Representatives if he wanted to, but he never does because he wants to be Mr Clean and Mr Listening. He puts up Senator Baume to ask these questions in this place.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume has a shocking track record in relation to this matter. The first allegation he made was that the Prime Minister or other Ministers had intervened to manipulate the foreign investment guidelines legislation in order to help the company in which the Prime Minister has a shareholding. It was quite wrong—a demonstrable untruth. Senator Baume tried it again with a second demonstrable untruth. And now he is trying again.

As I have said in this place all along, matters between the National Companies and Securities Commission and various companies are matters for them to resolve. They are not matters for people in this place to involve themselves with. They are not matters—just like matters between the Commissioner of Taxation and individuals—for this place to involve itself with. That is apart from Senator Bishop, who wants to interfere even in claims of sexual harassment against somebody and to introduce them into the Senate as a topic which honourable senators should discuss. I do not think any of these things are any of our business. Senator Baume can try as hard as he likes, but the National Companies and Securities Commission will deal with any matter such as this in a way in which it thinks appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I was not asking the Minister to intervene, except to the following extent. What is the Minister doing to encourage the Prime Minister to ensure that his half-owned piggery companies will at last abide by the corporations law and respond in a timely manner to the ASC's requirements, particularly in filing audited accounts for the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd for the 1989-90 and 1990-91 financial years, as required by the Australian Securities Commission?

—It is not my function to rush around this building encouraging people, whoever they may be, to do this and that. Senator Baume began his supplementary question—he is not interested in the answer—by saying that he was not asking me to intervene. All he was doing with this question was trying to get his name in the newspaper again when he cannot get his name in the newspaper as a shadow Minister for the arts, heritage and whatever he has left after being assigned this special role by Dr Hewson to ask his questions in the Senate, when Dr Hewson ought to have the courage to ask them in the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: I know that that is Senator Baume's special role. He was not interested in the answer because he was only interested in the question and the possibility of getting his name in the newspaper for once in his life—a life which has been characterised by failure in a hundred shadow ministries.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. If unemployment means that there are more people in or seeking paid work than there are jobs available, why does the Government persist with policies which put pressure on the labour force? For example, why does the Government persist in wage taxation and family policies which require many thousands of families with small dependent children to have both parents, against their will, stay in the paid work force? Since last month 80,000 people have lost their jobs. What are the circumstances of these people and how will they pay their bills? I have repeatedly asked the Minister to undertake a survey in respect of these matters, and I now ask him again.

—As I have said to Senator Harradine on numerous occasions, the Government is not about policies which would force women who choose to be in the labour force out of the labour force. They are not our policies and they never have been. We take the view that women—as well as every other person, whether they be men or young people—have the right to choose their own career paths and so on. We are not about policies which would force them to reach different conclusions.
—If they can get a job.

—Senator Newman interjects, `If they can get a job'. I concede that Senator Newman is quite right about that. Although there has been a decline in real wages in this country over the past few years, it is true to say that household disposable incomes have increased because of the social wage policies which the Government has introduced. Lower paid families have benefited from a range of family allowance supplements and other social policies which have increased household disposable income. Senator Harradine asked whether a survey was being done on this issue. I directed a question to the Treasurer a little while ago about whether any survey material was available on this question. I will seek advice from him again.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The people who heard the Minister's response will recognise the cheap, political statement that the Government is not about to force women out of the labour force. That was not the question. I stand here probably without peer in respect of my support for women in the labour force, equal pay and so on. I asked the Minister about those mothers or fathers who want to choose to look after their young children. Is it not a fact that in Victoria the biggest demand for child-care places is for children three months old to 12 months old? Why cannot those people who desire to look after those children be given the opportunity to do so without having to suffer an enormous drop in living standards?

—Senator Harradine has been asking this question for many years. He has asked the question in times of high levels of employment and in times of relatively low levels of employment. I do not know how people survey women in the home to see whether they would like to be in the work force or out of it at any particular time.
—Yes, they do survey them.

—No, they do not. They do not do attitudinal surveys. It is impossible for any body, such as the ABS, to do an attitudinal survey of that kind. It may be possible to wrap that question up in the context of other questions which are asked, but I do not know about that. As I said, I will direct this question to the Treasurer to get some detail on it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs heard yesterday that Austrade and our Ambassador in Copenhagen knew in September 1990 numerous details of Mr Keating's multi-million dollar pork joint venture. The Committee also heard that Austrade was told by Mr Hansen of the Federation of Danish Industries in November 1990 that, following his visits to Australia that year, all outstanding technical issues, principally quarantine ones, had been resolved and that an application had been made to government authorities to import live pigs and semen. Given that these matters concern the integrity of government at highest level, will the Minister undertake to table in the Senate all the relevant documents or information held on the files of the Embassy or Austrade as well as all other information held by the Department or Austrade elsewhere in relation to this matter? I seek leave to table for the Minister's benefit copies of relevant documents which show Austrade's involvement in this matter.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a mysterious thing, but I suppose a perfectly explicable thing, that whenever the coalition is in any trouble it descends back into the mire and the muck to wallow around in the pig troughs. We hear it again from Senator O'Chee, and this time I am the beneficiary of his question.

PARA.TAB: As I understand the situation—and I do not understand it very well, I am quick to concede—I do not believe that there is any substance in this particular suggestion that is being made. It is the case that a memo from Austrade back in November 1990 was tabled, I am told, under FOI in which it was said that `the fourth visit to Australia by representatives from the Federation of Danish Industries, as reported to us, as having been a great success, all technical—principally quarantine—issues are resolved'. What the Austrade memo writer was doing in that particular instance was simply reporting what had been said to him, as I understand it, by the returning representatives from the Federation of Danish Industries.

That subsequently, as I am further advised, proved to be an inaccurate report to the extent that all technical issues had not been resolved. Nonetheless, the understanding of the Austrade official is no less honest for that. There are all sorts of explanations that are available in these situations. Potential entrepreneurs are not unknown to rather overstate the status of a particular project and the degree of removal of obstacles that has been achieved in relation to a project when they are trying to drum up support from other investors. That may well have been the situation in this particular instance.

I will take advice on what further documents, if any, it might be appropriate to table in response to this question. But I do not believe, from what little I know about this, that there is any substance whatsoever in this particular suggestion that Senator O'Chee is now making.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In the light of the substantial increase in youth unemployment from 31.9 to 33.2 per cent, what urgent steps will the Government take to prevent a tragic and hopeless Christmas for a third of our young Australians? Will the Prime Minister make a pre-Christmas announcement when the House of Representatives returns next week; and, if not, why not?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a lot of interjection of `Hear, hear' from the other side of the chamber, but just let me make a first point in relation to those interjections. On a seasonally adjusted basis at the present time, there are 123,200 young people looking for full time work; the unadjusted number is a bit lower than that. This level of youth unemployment is considerably better than the 158,100 full time unemployed 15- to 19-year-olds we inherited from the Liberal Government when we came to office; it is a considerably better figure. So in respect of the `Hear, hears', let me say that.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, recently launched the training and employment offer for young long term unemployed people. He did that on 16 November. It is only a month since that was done and, of course, any success of that program would not be reflected in the figures to which Senator Sowada refers. This offer is one of the many initiatives arising from the youth summit held in July. I must say, as I have said before in answering questions on these figures, these initiatives are not magic wands; they will take time to take effect.

But the reason for the 22 per cent fall in full time youth unemployment which has occurred, of course, is related very much to education and labour market policies generally. I will await with interest the results of the initiatives which have been launched following the youth summit, but we will be announcing no new policies in respect of this matter for the reasons which I have given in an earlier part of my answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask the Minister: if he, being a Minister of the Crown, purchased shares in a company and then that company revalued its assets so that the value of his shares increased by $3.8m, would he consider that to be a bribe?
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I understand the Standing Orders to say that hypothetical questions are out of order.
—Senator McMullan is correct. It is up to the Minister whether he answers the question or not.
—I have not purchased any shares in any company.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it from that answer that the Minister is not prepared to tell the Senate whether he believes that increasing his assets by $3.8m would be a bribe. I then ask the Minister: is he aware that the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd increased its assets in such a way that the value of the assets of the Prime Minister increased by $3.8m? Is he is aware of that, and does he believe that to be a bribe?

—I am very sad to see that Senator Lewis has joined the slimy snail trail which was laid by Senator Baume in this place; Senator Lewis and Senator O'Chee are both following it along the floor of the Senate. As Senator Evans said, whenever those opposite get into grave difficulties, as they are now—leaderless, without policies, badly off in the polls—they start to go the grubby route. They came in here today at the start of Question Time beating their breasts about unemployment, all concerned for the unemployed, and after they got a couple of answers on that they dropped off because they do not care about the unemployed. What they care about is denigrating politicians in this Government—denigrating the Prime Minister. That is their best go. They have no policies in respect of the unemployed. They do not care about that issue any more. They are back on the snail trail.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Does the Minister concede that Austrade needs to be threatened with savage cuts to its funding in order to make that organisation more efficient? Does the Government have any intention of making cuts of such dimensions? Further, does the Government have any plans to dramatically reduce Australia's overseas aid budget? Is the Minister able to give an analysis of the impact that such cuts would have on Australia's aid program?

—I have an open mind on questions of possible financial cuts and I am prepared to accept advice from almost anyone. The Opposition has advised me that $70m is capable of being cut from the Austrade budget. That is what it says in Fightback, but I have had a look at that and I do not believe that any such cuts are remotely warranted.

PARA.TAB: An extensive program of restructuring and revitalisation of Austrade has occurred since the McKinsey report. It has meant that the organisation is more efficient and more productive than it has ever been, with a particularly effective emphasis now in place on promoting trade in the Asia-Pacific region, and that is very widely recognised by Australian exporters. The Commission has boosted its efforts in the Asia-Pacific area so that 50 per cent of its overseas resources are now concentrated in Asia, and a number of Austrade offices have recently been opened in the region in countries quite fundamental to our trading future.

The proportion of Austrade's operating budget spent on administration will be less than 20 per cent in 1992-93. If the Austrade budget were to be cut by the amount the Opposition suggests, it would mean a cut of more than 50 per cent in operating funds, and a major cutback in export promotion at a time when it is universally agreed by all Australian businesses that an increase in export promotion is vital to this country's future.

There is at least one person who agrees completely with what I have been saying; someone who knows that this kind of cut cannot be made, who has been going around overseas telling Australian exporters that it will not be made, even with a change of Government; someone who has been talking behind his Leader's back in this respect. I am referring, of course, to Mr Peacock, the Opposition trade spokesman, who said that that $70m cut will not be implemented. I think it is a fair question to ask whether this will be an area where Dr Hewson will come clean in his jellyback review next week, or will he continue to dissimulate about this and other indefensible and unachievable cuts still being on the table.

In relation to aid, the story is a similar one. Under this Government's policy, the aid budget this year is $1.4 billion which is equivalent to 0.36 per cent of gross national product. In contrast, the Opposition has said that it is possible to—and that it will—slash $209m from the aid budget, reducing it to 0.3 per cent of GNP in 1992-93 and 0.28 per cent in 1993-94. That would take Australia to the bottom third of the OECD ranking of aid donor countries.

Senator Hill is going around telling the aid and NGO lobbies that it is all perfectly achievable because most of that reduction will come out of the DIFF money that goes to support commercial enterprise. I am able to say, again, on reliable information I have received, that Mr Peacock is going around at the same time telling Australian exporters, `Don't worry, DIFF won't be cut'.

We have a classic example of utter dissimulation on the part of the Opposition. Again I ask whether Dr Hewson, in his jellyback review next week, will come clean about these indefensible and unachievable expenditure cuts, and put on the record some clarity about the Opposition's inability to make expenditure savings in these particular areas. Members of the Opposition are saying it behind people's backs, let them get out and say it publicly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister able to elaborate further on the impact those cuts would have on Australia's aid budget?
—No, I have said enough, Mr President.

—I refer the Minister for Defence to a report in the Sunday Times in Perth recently regarding the new book entitled Profits of War, by Ben-Menashe, in which it is alleged that the WA Government allowed a secret arms shipment bound for Iran to pass through Fremantle, including the parking of 4,000 anti-tank missiles at HMAS Stirling for two months. Is this correct?

—These rumours first came to my attention two years ago. I fully investigated them and, frankly, there is absolutely no truth whatsoever in them. I regretted a bit at the time having to devote resources to investigate these alleged claims, but I did. There is absolutely nothing on the record from a Defence point of view—I do not think there would be anything on the record from any point of view—but ultimately it was more a matter for Customs than it was for Defence. Neither agency could find the slightest skerrick of evidence to suggest that this claim had any validity.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—Mr President, I take a point of order.
—Is it arising out of Question Time?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Crane

TALK.START.PARA: —It relates to Question Time, yes. Mr President, today during Question Time Senator Button twice used the words `demonstrable untruth' in answer to a question by Senator Baume. Yesterday you made a statement in relation to unparliamentary behaviour, following a complaint by Senator Evans when the words `monstrous untruth' were used. You then went on to say:

PARA.TAB: As past rulings have made perfectly clear, it is not in order for a senator to accuse another senator of lying, or to use any other expression which has the same meaning, that is, that a senator has deliberately made a statement which the senator knows to be untrue. Interjections such as `Why don't you tell the truth?' are therefore also disorderly.
I ask honourable senators to refrain from using such language, and I inform the Senate that I intend to enforce the rule against unparliamentary language.

INTERJECT.PARA: Those are your words, Mr President. As I said, Senator Button today used the words `demonstrable untruth' twice. Quite frankly, we are sick and tired of Ministers giving answers that are not accurate and which do not reflect the truth. I ask: when Ministers answer questions are you going to enforce the rule that you brought down yesterday, or is it only to apply to those on this side of the chamber? I would ask that you request Senator Button, in view of that ruling, to return to the chamber and withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on the point of order: since I am the one who yesterday sought a ruling on whether `monstrous untruth' was unparliamentary, I think it is appropriate that I should suggest to you that there is no inconsistency whatsoever in treating `monstrous untruth' one way and `demonstrable untruth' in another way. A `demonstrable untruth' is an untruth that may have been uttered in ignorance in a situation of what the truth was, and it can be demonstrated to be untruthful, but that is not the same as saying that someone has said a lie. A lie is where there is an intention to tell an untruth. When a person uses a word like `monstrous', what he or she is implying is that it is a dirty, big, fat untruth that is being uttered; it is something that is deliberate; it is something that is in fact, for all practical purposes, a lie.

PARA.TAB: That is what I understood the reference to be yesterday. That is clearly what you, Mr President, understood the reference to `monstrous' to be about. It does imply that element of criminal intent which is appropriately regarded as unparliamentary. I would suggest that under those circumstances it is a perfectly consistent ruling that you have adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In reply to the—
—Mr President—
—Order! I am on my feet.
—I want to raise a point of order.

—You can take a point of order later, but I am on my feet now. I thought that Senator Button was not directly referring to statements made by a senator. I will look at the Hansard, and if that is not the case I will come back in here and I will correct it, as has happened twice in previous days.

—Mr President, I wish to speak to that same point of order. If I have to raise it as a fresh point of order, I will. When I read your ruling that you put on the record yesterday, I did so with grave concern. You have frequently said in this chamber that you will not make an adjudication as to whether or not a statement that anyone makes is a truth or a lie; you have said that that is not a matter for you. However, you have ruled that where a senator believes a lie has been spoken he or she is now unable to challenge that statement. Mr President, I refer you to page 1004 of Odgers Australian Senate Practice and the part dealing with freedom of speech.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Do you intend calling that loudmouth to order?
—Order! Senator Bishop has the call.
—Order! I am trying to listen to the point of order.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins interjecting—
Senator Campbell interjecting—

TAB.EMPHASIS: An incident having occurred in the chamber—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Campbell and Senator Collins. Order! Senator Bishop.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bishop

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. I am afraid that it is this sort of ruling—and I am going to ask you to reconsider it—that has led to this sort of disorderly conduct in this place. I again refer you to page 1004, which deals with freedom of speech, where it says:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . making to the House of a deliberately misleading statement may be treated as a contempt.

Indeed, there are many instances in this place where Ministers and others on the other side of the chamber deliberately tell untruths. Mr President, you are now denying us the right to even contest the veracity of those instances. Indeed, they are guilty of contempt, if you choose to bother, from the Chair's point of view, to concern yourself with whether the truth is spoken. How are we in this place to contend with the fact that members of the Government front bench repeatedly tell fibs while your ruling would say that we are not entitled to point that out? I ask you, Mr President, to reconsider the ruling that you made yesterday and to then apply whatever ruling you make in an even-handed manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bishop, I have listened to what you have said. I do not believe in any way that the two points are linked. I believe that your point about contempt has to be dealt with completely differently from the other point that I made. I made a ruling on unparliamentary language. That ruling is the same ruling that has been made by Presidents of the Senate since 1901, and it will stand. However, I will look at the two points that you have made and I will come back with a statement, because I am sure that you are wrong.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I am well aware that you were unable to hear the threats made by Senator Collins and his invitation to Senator Campbell to come outside.
—For a cup of tea, you fool!
—Order! Senator Collins, withdraw it.
—I withdraw, Mr President. I wish we could actually get on with a bit of business of the House.
—Order! Resume your seat. I am listening to a point of order from Senator Walters.

—Mr President, Senator Campbell immediately went over and accepted the invitation. Of course, Senator Collins did not have the guts to get up and take it. Mr President, is that parliamentary or is it not?

—Order! It is not a point of order. I do not believe that the actions of Senator Collins and Senator Campbell added to the dignity of the Senate at all. If people had heard some of the telephone calls and some of the comments from the gallery that have been made over Question Time in the last two days, they would agree with me.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I am not any longer going to put up with Minister Collins's gratuitous advice of what to do. You called the House to order during Senator Bishop's point of order. Senator Schacht and Senator Collins totally disregarded your call for order. At the same time, Senator Collins then said, `Step outside', which he tends to do all the time. I think the people over there should have far more respect for your rulings—the sort of respect that people on this side of the chamber have.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I was not going to raise this but, since Senator Campbell has had the audacity to get up again, I want to make the point that we all heard Senator Campbell at this end threaten and offer to take Senator Burns outside. I was just worried that Senator Burns might hear him. I think it is shocking that one of the youngest senators could threaten one of the oldest senators in such a way. I ask you, Mr President, in view of the fact that that started the whole thing, to set the record straight and warn Senator Campbell that he might make a mistake if he suggests the wrong people go outside.
—Order! What is taking place is a debate that is not adding anything to the image of this place at all. I ask people from both sides to cease interjecting.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Can the Chair give me any protection against somebody who threatens to assault me?
—Order!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week, Senator Archer asked a question about charges for the stevedoring of containers in Australia compared with New Zealand, using data from a report by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics and the New Zealand Ministry of Transport called Monitoring of Trans-Tasman Shipping. This report was released in May this year, but it clearly states that its data reflects a joint survey conducted in mid-1991. This was at least six months before all Australian ports were restructured through enterprise employment agreements.

PARA.TAB: Since then, the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority has confirmed that the Australian reform program has fostered intense competition between stevedores. This resulted in reductions in Australian container handling charges on the trans-Tasman trade from $278 to $294 quoted in that report down to $190 to $210 per container depending on commercial negotiations. This decline also is confirmed by the Chairman of the Australian Shipping Users Group, Mr Mark Reyner, in an article in the October 1992 edition of the Business Council bulletin magazine where current Australian container handling rates are quoted as between $180 and $200 per standard container.

I am not aware of any comprehensive, formal evaluation of the New Zealand process across all ports. However, the results arising from the Australian reform process, including the doubling of productivity, the halving of labour numbers and crane rates equivalent to comparable international ports, equate with anecdotal claims from New Zealand. There is no problem acknowledging that the previous Labour Government in New Zealand did a good job in reforming their waterfront. However, Australia has done just as well. It is a pity that critics continue to rely on outdated comparisons with New Zealand made before the Australian reforms were fully effective to try to discredit the achievements of the Australian stevedoring reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to clarify an answer I gave to Senator Aulich in the Senate concerning road and rail freight transport. I indicated in that answer that in respect of the National Rail Corporation the Federal Government and State governments had one vote each. In fact, I meant to refer to the National Road Transport Commission which operates under these arrangements. During the establishment period of the National Rail Corporation the Commonwealth has 39.5 per cent of the voting rights with the other rights being held by the New South Wales, Victorian and Western Australia governments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I have a matter of concern that I want to raise with you, Mr President. This is now being aided and abetted by the taxpayers of Australia by means of an imported sweetener being provided in the parliamentary cafeteria.
