SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Baume this day, relating to the importation of pigs.

SPEECH.PARA: Every time I ask questions about the Prime Minister's piggery companies breaching the law, all I get is personal abuse. I am never given a substantive answer.

PARA.TAB: Today the Canberra Times asked questions which were not given a substantive answer by the Prime Minister. Yet here we have a situation where the Government is pretending that a serious problem does not exist. It does exist and it simply will not go away. That problem goes to the heart of the integrity of the Prime Minister of this nation.

The Prime Minister's companies which he half owns, and on which he has a nominee as a director, have filed dodgy, shonky returns with the Australian Securities Commission which the ASC is forcing them to correct. The corrections that have been filed at the demand of the ASC have clearly shown that these returns were required to be corrected. They were false and misleading, and that is why they are being corrected by the companies themselves at the demand of the ASC.

We have only seen a few of these corrections so far, and many more are still required to be filed, but they reveal the incredible device by which the Prime Minister's investment of $430,000 for his half interest magically turned into $4.2m worth of shareholder's equity within six weeks.

Mr Keating has denied on television that he has made that paper fortune. He said that one had to be able to read a balance sheet to understand. I have news for Mr Keating: people who know very well how to read a balance sheet confirm exactly this problem. If Mr Keating has not made this paper fortune, he has to deny the accounts; he has to demonstrate that the accounts are shonky. The accounts filed and available to us this week confirm the point made in the Euphron accounts that he has converted a $430,000 investment into $4.2m. Mr Keating cannot get away with saying both that the accounts are correct and that he did not turn the investment into $4.2m. One of those things has to be wrong. The big question is: are the accounts wrong? That is for Mr Keating to tell us.

I have my own views about the accounts but, as they have not been audited—in breach of the law—one can have whatever sort of view one might like to have about them. The Canberra Times is one of the few newspapers in Australia with the courage to print the facts about this piggery group. The rest of the Press Gallery, with one or two honourable exceptions, have been terrorised by this Prime Minister. They have been personally rung up and abused; their editors have been rung up at home and insulted if they have dared to print anything about this prime ministerial investment in these companies which have an extraordinary capacity to breach the corporations law.

As the Canberra Times pointed out this morning, how they manage to revalue their piggery properties by $4.1m while they are continuing to make significant—$1 1/2m—losses would be beyond most rational people. No doubt Mr Keating has an explanation. If he has, let him give it to us. We have never had any substantive response from the Government on these self-evidently shonky accounts. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume, earlier in your speech did you refer to companies lodging dodgy returns?
—Yes, that is correct.

—I share Senator Baume's concerns about the matters he raised, but I have some other concerns that relate to the general investment scheme. Whilst Senator Evans is in the chamber, it might be appropriate to deal with them at this point. Senator Evans gave me an answer which was definitely in good faith. I previously provided him with copies of the documents which were tabled and with an explanation of those documents.

PARA.TAB: It may have slipped Senator Evans's attention, because he was not present at the hearing yesterday morning of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, but the head of the Quarantine Division of AQIS, Mr John Landos, indicated to the Committee that when he visited Copenhagen in September 1990 he had a meeting with both our Ambassador and the Austrade officer in Copenhagen. At that point in time, those two gentlemen indicated to Mr Landos numerous details about the proposed joint venture, including the value of the proposed joint venture; the target market; the fact that there was an intention to import genetic material; and other details about the proposal.

It is obvious that it was not just a single event. It was not just a case of Mr Hansen from the Federation of Danish Industries returning to Denmark from Australia in November 1990 and saying everything had been fixed up, because two months before his return Mr Landos was in Copenhagen and received numerous details from the Ambassador and the Austrade officer that related to the proposal—details which, it transpired, in the course of time turned out to be correct. There is very clear evidence that there was a course of dealings with Austrade, possibly with our embassy and with the Federation of Danish Industries.

This is very important, because it has been suggested by AQIS officials that there was never an application to import genetic material. It was suggested earlier on by AQIS officials—I know Senator Evans is not responsible for AQIS—that there had been no contact between AQIS and the Danes on this proposal between April 1990 and April 1992.

It subsequently transpired, when we examined all the documents, that contact did occur, as evidenced by newspaper reports, Austrade reports and faxes that went backwards and forwards. It goes right to the heart of whether the evidence which the Estimates Committee was presented with on 17 September and 21 October is correct. It also relates to who is doing the dealing with the Danes. If the Danes are saying that they have made an application to import genetic material and live pigs, but it has not been dealt with by AQIS, it could be that somebody at Austrade had given some sort of assurances. That is just one possibility. Whatever it is, I want to draw to Senator Evans's attention that there is a course of dealing which I do not think he was aware of and which has been evidenced by documents.

Austrade officials were involved in this project as early as 2 May 1990 when they attended a meeting arranged by Mr Girdlestone from AQIS. An Austrade officer, I understand, was present and maybe somebody from DFAT as well. Clearly, there has been a course of dealings. It does need investigation, and that is why I have asked Senator Evans today to table all the information on their files about that. This goes right to the heart of who is running Austrade, how the investment decisions are being made, how our quarantine system is being run for the benefit of the primary industries in this country and what involvement there was with people involved with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on this motion to take note of the answer on an issue that Senator Baume, Senator O'Chee and a couple of other Opposition senators have consistently raised, using what can only be called the worst McCarthy style smear tactics of insistently saying, `Here are all these documents; therefore, there must be something wrong'. When it was announced that the Australian Securities Commission was going to investigate this material, all would have accepted that that was a very proper procedure. Everyone would have welcomed it. There could have been no argument about it. My only regret is that we did not have an ASC back in the mid-1970s to deal with the allegations of impropriety on the part of Senator Baume when he was a partner in Patrick Partners. I am sure that, under the powers that now are vested in the ASC, Senator Baume would have been in a lot more strife and would not have been able to sit in this place as a consequence.

—I take a point of order, Mr President. That is a personal reflection on a senator, apart from being totally false. There was an inquiry which absolutely cleared me of any impropriety whatever. Not only is what Senator Schacht saying totally false, but also it is a slur on a fellow senator. It is totally in keeping with his style and status in this chamber.
—I think it is a matter that you should reply to afterwards, Senator Baume.

—As I said, I welcomed, as everybody else would have done, the ASC announcing that it was going to investigate the matters raised. That is properly done by an organisation that is given the responsibility by this Parliament to investigate such matters. Nobody complained. I only wish that back in the 1970s we had had such a body with such powers because I suspect that Senator Baume, then a partner of Patrick Partners, would not have got away with what he did get away with.
—I take a point of order, Mr President. That is clearly a reflection upon Senator Baume and should be withdrawn.
—I think you ought to withdraw that, Senator Schacht.

—I certainly withdraw. That is what the President asked and I have absolutely no reluctance at all in withdrawing on the President's advice. After sitting here over the last few months and having heard the level of attack on the integrity of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and the heap of abuse from Senator Baume in particular, I find it astonishing that he has the gall to get up and complain about what anyone may say about his activities as a member of Patrick Partners.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. Senator Schacht is continuing to reflect upon the senator by expressing himself in those terms. Senator Schacht should withdraw that comment. It is the same reflection being expressed in a slightly different way.

—Senator Schacht was referring to Senator Baume being a member of a particular organisation. I do not think that should be asked to be withdrawn. I am sure Senator Baume will ask for a personal explanation.
—The other thing that astonishes me is that previously in this debate Senator Baume inferred that there was something wrong or illegal with the Prime Minister having $300,000 or $400,000 to invest.
—No, I didn't say that.

—Yes, he did. Senator Baume should read the record; it is in the Hansard. He implied that there was something wrong with a Prime Minister or a member of parliament having $400,000 to invest in a firm. What astonishes me is that it is generally accepted—it has been on the record—that in a matter of a few years in his activity in the commercial sector the now Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) made a profit of $5m. I have not heard one word of criticism from Senator Baume or anybody else on the other side of this chamber querying how he made $5m. Dr Hewson may be a brilliant entrepreneur; no-one suggested that there was anything wrong with how he made that $5m. (Time expired)

—I have had my own concerns, during the incessant flow of questions from Senator Baume, about the piggery operation of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Perhaps I will raise the debate to a slightly higher level by voicing those concerns. Maybe next time there is an answer to one of Senator Baume's questions my concerns might also be answered. My concerns have to do with the pigs themselves. I wonder whether the sows are permanently kept tethered on short chains in this piggery, of which the Prime Minister is a part owner. I do not know whether the Prime Minister is aware that this system of keeping sows is widely regarded as obsolete and that the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare recommended in its report on intensive livestock production that this system should be banned.

PARA.TAB: Those are the questions that come to my mind every time Senator Baume goes on his slush trail and those are questions which I do not hear being answered. They are questions which many people concerned about the welfare of animals around this country are asking. In spite of the fact that some people in the animal rights movement, whom I support strongly, actually got into the piggery, those questions have still not been answered. So maybe next time Senator Baume gets up on this matter we might hear him speak on behalf of the pigs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —On this question of what has been known as `the pig issue', I have had the responsibility on behalf of the Government of appearing before both the Estimates Committee and the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs on this matter. Over many days these committees have conducted exhaustive examinations of the officers of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. They have conducted endless questioning of the officers of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.

PARA.TAB: The result of that questioning is that not only have the questions that have been put been answered but answered repetitiously. It is now getting to the point of boring tedium where the same questions are being asked. They may be framed differently, there may be different synonyms, but the effect is the same. The questions that are being asked are exactly the same as the ones that were asked before. No new evidence has been adduced. It now comes down to a question of whether we believe the evidence of the officers of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.

What have those officers said? Mr Landos said that he made a mistake. He has been asked to repeat that several times and he has done so. I think we ought to recognise that when someone is big enough to admit that they have made a blue, have accepted the blame and the criticism that comes with it and have repeated endlessly that they have and that that is the answer, they ought to be believed. It is not a question of the Government's veracity but the Department's veracity. Officers of the Quarantine and Inspection Service, whom we entrust to ensure that we are free of imported disease, are saying they made a mistake in the writing of one letter—and a couple of other mistakes too, which by comparison are not as important—and it is this one letter which has sparked this whole row. It is going on endlessly, and we have to put an end to it.

The Opposition is on a loser. It wants to smear Mr Keating, but it cannot find any evidence to do so. It wants to keep the hearing going so that it can keep asking the same question and pretend that, on each occasion when the same answer is given, a new and startling fact has been revealed. Sooner or later it will be just ruled off.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation on the grounds that I have been grossly misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht said that he only wished there had been some sort of independent inquiry that would have revealed what I got away with as a partner in Patrick Partners. He is going back to 1975, I think it was, when I was a non-owning, non-equity partner in a firm which collapsed. I advise Senator Schacht, because obviously he is ignorant of the fact, that a detailed inquiry into that collapse was conducted by Mr Masterman QC, who was appointed by a Labor government. That inquiry, if Senator Schacht is prepared to get off his backside and read it, clearly states that the partners of Patrick Partners, with the exception of Senator Baume, were aware of the fact that it had a financial difficulty when it was accepting deposits—the clear result of an inquiry exactly along the lines that Senator Schacht falsely claimed in this place could not and did not exist. The coalition would be overjoyed if the same sort of independent inquiry were conducted into the half-owned piggery companies of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) which have—
—Are you saying the ASC is not independent?
—Order! It is a personal explanation, not a debate.

—If Senator Schacht says that I should have been subject to an inquiry, which I was, I am quite prepared to call for a similar inquiry in relation to this matter. I have nothing to hide about my background. That is why when people attack me about something I respond factually, as I am today. My concerns are that when we present facts on this matter, all we get is the sort of personal abuse that Senator Schacht has given falsely in this disgraceful attack on me today.

PARA.TAB: It is the same sort of response that I have received from Senator Button and even from Senator Powell—and this is part of the personal explanation. They have accused me of being on a slush trail. I am revealing what the accounts filed with the Australian Securities Commission state about the Prime Minister's half-owned companies. I am not on a slush trail. I am revealing the truth to a Labor Party Government which is reluctant to recognise it or accept it and whose only response is to hurl personal abuse at me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition wishes to debate the No. 1 issue in the country, and that is unemployment. Therefore, pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely a motion to provide for discussion of a matter of public importance concerning the refusal of the Government to implement policies to address the results of its economic mismanagement.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the Australian Democrats have agreed that we should be permitted to debate this issue for one hour, so presumably this suspension motion will be carried. Moving this procedural motion gives me the opportunity to express personally how terrible today's figures are. We got the first sign today from this Government of any admission of recognition of the extent of the tragedy. In fact, I thought for a moment that Senator Button was going to attempt to answer this question seriously. Instead of doing so, of course, he tried rather to take cheap political points.

PARA.TAB: This Government has to face up to its responsibility sooner or later. Under this Government's economic management, pursuant to its economic model, we now find in this country unemployment at the highest level since the Great Depression, 11.4 per cent. It is a deplorable figure, a figure about which this Government should be ashamed. Day after day we have said to this Government, `What are you going to do about this tragedy? How are you going to change your policies? What hope are you going to offer Australia for the future?' On no occasion has this Government been prepared to answer that question. All it says is, `We have policies in place which we hope will lead to recovery, which we hope will eventually lead to the creation of jobs'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Government has indicated that it will accept this motion. That removes the need to debate it, since we will be debating it as soon as it is carried. Perhaps Senator Hill could assist the chamber by confining his remarks to the actual debate rather than trying to persuade us to accept something that we have already agreed to accept.
—Order! I do not regard that as a point of order. We have had this argument about what people can say in the five minutes before. I am sure it will assist Senator Hill.

—If ever I were to demonstrate a matter of urgency—and I am pleased to hear that the Government also is now going to accept the suspension—this would have to be that issue. The urgency, of course, is that the latest tragic figure was released only a few hours ago. That is why it is a matter of public importance and a matter of urgency that should be debated in this chamber today. We now have 11.4 per cent unemployment. What is in some ways even worse is that in the last month a further 78,000 Australians have lost their jobs. Unemployment has actually increased. Those employed number 78,000 fewer than a month ago. If any figure ever demonstrated urgency, it must be that. It is a deplorable situation.

PARA.TAB: If one looks at the youth unemployment figures, the tragedy is further developed: 33.2 per cent of Australia's young people are unemployed. If we take the breakdown of youth unemployment from the Department of Employment, Education and Training and look around Australia, for inner Sydney suburbs the figure is 44 per cent. Moving to Wollongong, which Senator Baume knows very well, the rate is 44.4 per cent. In the inner north-western Melbourne suburbs, the rate is 44.4 per cent; for outer western Melbourne, 48.8 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go to Adelaide.

—These are the levels of youth unemployment in this country according to Government statistics. They have never been worse. Mr President, I will go to Adelaide, as my colleague said. In the northern Adelaide suburbs the figure is 44.5 per cent; in the western Adelaide suburbs, 43 per cent; in the southern Adelaide suburbs—seats such as Kingston—54 per cent. More than half the young people looking for work cannot get work. If ever there were a demonstration of failure of government and government policies, it has to be these tragic figures. That is why this Government does not deserve to be re-elected. It is not even trying to put before the Australian people an alternative. It is a disgrace and it ought be thrown out.

—Very briefly, Mr President, I have to tell you that Senator Hill came to me this morning and then again at Question Time and stood over me most menacingly. As a consequence of that and a couple of other encounters with Senator Hill in a smoke-filled room outside, there was a dirty deal done between the Democrats and the Opposition and, unwillingly, we will support the suspension.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, there is no way that the Government would have agreed to debate unemployment.
—We just did.
—When you did not have the numbers. The one subject the Government does not want to talk about in this country is unemployment and the consequences of its policies.
—I will be talking about it in a minute.
—Not through choice. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter of public importance be discussed immediately for one hour:

The refusal of the Government to implement policies to address the results of its economic mismanagement, namely, 11.4 per cent unemployment, 33 per cent youth unemployment, and underemployment at the staggering level of 1.7 million Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that Senator Macdonald will lead the debate for the Opposition after this motion is carried.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Macdonald, I believe that an arrangement has been made about speakers. I still have not received any name from the Democrats.
—One hour in total.
—I have been told that there will be an unofficial limit of eight minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Happy Christmas! Labor's gift to Australia for Christmas 1992 is record unemployment and absolutely no plan to get that record number of Australians back in a job. The Smith Family has said that this Christmas will be its most demanding on record. The Wesley Mission is calling this `the recession Christmas' and `the worst Christmas for Australian families in 60 years'. The New South Wales Labor Leader, Bob Carr, was dead right when he told the Australian:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . record unemployment under the Federal Labor Government would make this Christmas the bleakest in Australia since the Great Depression.

A Labor leader in New South Wales said that. In the new year another 200,000 school leavers will join the ranks of the victims of Keating's recession; 200,000 school leavers will be either on the dole or locked out of universities and TAFE. So there will be even less hope for the one million already on the dole queue, thanks to this Government, thanks to Senator Cook and Mr Keating. According to the ABS, there are now 979,900 Australians out of work, looking for work but unable to find it.

PARA.TAB: The real extent of the unemployment crisis is much greater than that. According to Access Economics, 900,000 supposedly full time workers are working less than five days a week; 200,000 part time workers are looking for full time work; 300,000 part time workers want to work longer hours; and 250,000 people have simply given up looking for work altogether. In effect, there are another 1.7 million Australians who are now unemployed or underemployed who do not show up in the official figures. The real picture is more like 2.6 million Australians who are either officially unemployed or underemployed or have given up looking for work.

Australia's unemployment rate is now a record 11.4 per cent—a total of 979,900 without work—a new post-Depression high or, should I say, a new low for this Government. It is an absolute rock bottom low in the management of this country. In November alone 78,400 people lost their jobs. Almost 80,000 people in one month lost their jobs—and Mr Keating told us that the recession had finished a long time ago. Every single day in Australia another 2,600 Australians are giving up looking for a job; that is 78,000 people in November. They lose any hope of ever finding work and they resign themselves to the worst Christmas they have ever had.

Only a year ago we thought the unemployment rate was bad. We thought it was disastrous at 10.5 per cent—894,000 people without a job—but in the last 12 months, since Mr Keating became Prime Minister, another 85,700 have become permanently unemployed. That is out of a total full time work force of 5,844,000. Almost six million in full time work, almost one million without any form of work. The real tragedy is that of those figures, 33 per cent of our youth are unemployed, simply unable to get jobs.

The real tragedy is that from this Government we have no plan, no policies, no vision, only rhetoric and more of the same that has gone on. It has no proposal. It will not even talk about any policy. It had this thing called One Nation, but that is now absolutely dead in the water; it has been officially killed off. In the Budget there were some programs which the Government said would be the centrepiece of our employment package. Only yesterday, Senator McMullan and Senator Tate admitted that the local capital works program, that was supposed to create 13,000 new jobs, created no new jobs at all. All it did was stop people who would have been thrown onto the unemployment queues from being thrown onto those queues. It kept them in a job and it did nothing to create new jobs for the one million of our fellow Australians who are without work.
John Cain was spot on when he said recently:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor have. . . an economic vacuum. . . we are in no shape to govern for the next three years.

He was talking about Federal Labor: no policy, an economic vacuum and in no shape to govern for the next three years. By contrast, the Liberal and National parties do have a plan to do something about unemployment. What we have to do in Australia is sell more overseas. We have to export more. If we can export more—sell more overseas—we will create more jobs in Australia because we will have to produce more of our manufactured goods, our mineral wealth and our agricultural expertise, and if we are producing more we create real jobs to get that production.

PARA.TAB: How do we create additional exports in this big, bad, difficult world of international trade? We make our own exports cheaper. We do that in Australia by removing taxes from them. We propose in our policies to take $20 billion of taxes from business and exports in Australia. That is what Australia needs to get business moving, to create more competition with our exports and to sell more. In that way we will create real jobs that last, not like this Government, which throws money at them and when the money is stopped being thrown the jobs themselves stop.

We have the most comprehensive policies ever released by any political party in Australia, unlike Mr Keating, the man whose hypocrisy in dealing with the economy is simply quite breathtaking. He told us, `We won't let there be a recession'. Then he said, `This is the recession we had to have'. Then he told us a few months ago that the recession had ended. The Labor Party is running scared and as Alan Ramsay said, `They are wetting themselves'. The Labor Party is really in trouble and it knows it is finished.

Madam Acting Deputy President, do you remember when you were a child? We always got something at Christmas. Our children get things and we see how their eyes light up. But 700,000 children this year will get nothing because neither of their parents is working and those parents will be unable to afford to give their children anything. That is the tragedy and the sadness of this: those 700,000 kids who will look down the street and see their friends getting presents at this Christmas time and going on holiday, and they will not get a thing. That is the real tragedy and the sadness of this Government—those kids who will not have anything at this Christmas time because of this Government's policies. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's unemployment figures, it goes without saying, give us no joy and certainly those who are unfortunately unemployed no joy either. But it is not an occasion for simply handwringing and anguishing. It is an occasion to look at the positive indicators, and make an assessment about economic recovery and the likelihood of employment growth because of that. Everyone here knows that employment is the last indicator that moves after all of the other economic indicators have turned positive. There is a considerable lag between positive change in the leading economic indicators and the effect on take-up of employment.

PARA.TAB: So we do not want to wallow in self-pity about this nor do we wish to talk down the confidence levels in the economy. We do not see unemployment at these levels as a good thing; we see it as a bad thing for the economy. But we are not going to take fright or flight, and we are not going to be in a position of trying to politically exploit the situation as the Opposition does. Every time a negative number comes up, those opposite wallow in glee and pleasure that they can somehow score a political point against us.
There are two things that ought to be said at the beginning of this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order.
—Am I going to be heard, or am I going to be prevented from speaking again?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Senator Cook, there is a point of order. You will take your seat until Senator Hill has made his point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —The assertion that Senator Cook has made now, and has made on previous occasions, that we wallow in glee at the sight of nearly one million Australians out of work, is offensive and a reflection on all senators on this side of the chamber. He should withdraw it. It goes far beyond any reasonable debate. He would know that it is incorrect. It is an offensive thing for him to say and I ask that you require him to withdraw it.

—Senator Hill, I think in a debate such as this, where remarks of some emotional strength are being offered from both sides, it is fair enough to let the debate continue and treat that as a debating point.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. We all in this chamber knew that that would be the ruling. I was in a debate here a few weeks ago in which, for eight minutes, my whole time was taken up by points of order, as it now appears it will be again, to gag me and prevent me from being heard.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I will not consume much of Senator Cook's time. Quite frankly, I find it personally offensive that Senator Cook says that I take glee from the unemployment figures. I do not take any such glee. I find it personally offensive and I ask that he withdraw it.

—Senator Cook, in the interests of allowing you to continue your contribution to the debate uninterrupted by further points of order, you might like to consider tempering your remarks and not making the suggestion that you have made which honourable senators on the other side clearly find offensive. In that way I think you will be able to proceed without being interrupted further.
—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I might say that I found many things that were said by the previous speaker offensive. However, I am going to concentrate on the issue.
—Like what?

—Such as the accusations Senator Macdonald made against the Government, of which I am a member. There are some substantial things the Government needs to say on this matter. I am not going to be diverted into points of order, nor am I going to be gagged, as I was before, from presenting a viewpoint to this chamber. My point is that there are two issues that mark whether we are merely concerned, or concerned enough to do something about it. They are, in terms of major economic settings, vitally important to an understanding by ordinary Australians of this debate.

PARA.TAB: The first is that the Opposition's program for dealing with unemployment is to remove $6.4 billion from public expenditure. At a time when the OECD is urging its economies to invest in stimulating growth, the Opposition's proposal is to reduce growth by cutting public expenditure by $6.4 billion. The German economy is reflating itself. The Japanese economy is doing the same. Bill Clinton is promising that recipe for the United States. It is only here in Australia than an opposition is proposing to de-stimulate the economy and drive it into further recession by cutting public expenditure by that amount.

When one looks at where the Opposition wishes to cut, the story is more horrendous. If one looks at unemployment benefits as a mark of compassion and concern for the unemployed, the Opposition is proposing to terminate dole payments to unemployed persons after nine months. That is hardly a mark of compassion or concern.

Through the One Nation statement we have committed a huge amount of public expenditure to getting the infrastructure of Australia into a better working order and to support private sector development based on the stimulus of the economy through public sector investment which adds to the assets of the economy at the same time. There are a number of indicators which show that that is beginning to have some effect. Let me go to some of them.

We have gone now through four quarters of sustained positive GDP growth. Company pre-tax profits rose by 26 per cent in the October quarter, 67 per cent above the recession low. Retail sales increased by 2 per cent in the month of October 1992. The November skilled vacancy survey is up 13 per cent on November 1991. There are 13 per cent more vacancies for jobs now than there were this time last year. The CES unfilled vacancies are up by 24 per cent over the quarter, the highest since June 1990. The CES job placements are up by 119,000 over the quarter, of which 27 per cent are long term unemployed, the highest since September 1990. As well as that, the Australian Bureau of Statistics job vacancies indicator was up by 10.9 per cent in mid-May 1992. The ANZ Bank job vacancies survey was up by 0.6 per cent in November, 6.7 per cent over a year ago.

The level of overtime being worked in the economy is improving. Housing finance in owner occupied housing was up by 23.3 per cent in August 1991. Dwelling improvements have increased by 5.5 per cent. The number of people receiving Jobstart allowance and Newstart allowance fell by over 6,600 in October and November. In a reversal of the trend over the last couple of years, three of the last four months have shown falls.

I go to those statistics so that there can be an indication of the trends in the economy. The trends in the economy are for positive improvement. That may mean that the Opposition wishes to puncture that trend, but if we look at these latest figures today we see that the biggest effect is in New South Wales. Indeed, my colleague Kim Beazley said:

SPEECH.PARA: The national results are largely due to developments in New South Wales. In that State employment fell by 58,700 (three-quarters of the national decline) . . .

The unemployment level for the country was dragged down by the performance of the New South Wales economy. South of the border from New South Wales, in Victoria, we see Jeff Kennett mugging the populace of Victoria and creating industrial turmoil, which is hardly something that will bring forth economic growth.

PARA.TAB: The facts are that we are stimulating the economy. That is the internationally recognised way for getting growth and employment. The Opposition is proposing to destimulate, deskill and reduce job opportunities. The indicators are that in Liberal controlled States the worst impact of their policies is dragging down the national average. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Coulter, I remind honourable senators that the Premier of Victoria should be addressed properly.

—The figures that came out several hours ago showing 11.4 per cent unemployment are, of course, absolutely shocking, but I would have to agree with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) that there is no point in us standing in here simply wringing our hands. Something needs to be done about it. As we have already seen from both the Government and the Opposition, there is little hope on the horizon that that figure will improve substantially, irrespective of who wins the next election. I think both sides have said that in the short to medium term there is not a great deal of hope in either of their patterns. Indeed, in recent days in Victoria we have seen Mr Kennett, the new Premier of Victoria, firing large numbers of people—in fact substantially increasing the unemployment there—and being praised for doing so by the Opposition as part of the process of getting the economy going.

PARA.TAB: Linked with unemployment, we have the other problems in the economy. As has just been pointed out, we are running up very large foreign debts. We have over $160 billion worth of foreign debt. But the patterns of change which have been implemented by the Government and which would be furthered by the Opposition are substantially similar. This is the point that I have made previously. The Government has been reducing tariffs progressively and substantially; the Opposition has been complaining consistently that tariffs have not been reduced fast enough, and stating that it would pull them away even more quickly. Dr Hewson has argued with the car industry that a zero tariff policy would actually aid the car industry. The car industry is telling him very loudly and very clearly that that policy is likely to wipe that industry out altogether. So in relation to tariff reduction there is little to choose between the Government and the Opposition.

In relation to tax concessions, the figures are already in: the Labor Government's period in office has resulted in a massive redistribution of wealth upwards from the less well off to the more wealthy. That has been done as a deliberate policy in the hope that the wealthy will invest in productive investment. We have seen that that has not happened. We have seen that money flow off into speculation, particularly property speculation—we have seen it go overseas—and the wealth of this country has been frittered away. Real wages of ordinary workers have seen the lowest increase—in fact, in real terms have seen a substantial decline—during the period of the Labor Government, but despite that the Liberal Opposition and its friends in big industry want to see wages further reduced. There is no evidence that further reductions in wages would lead to a turnaround in the economy, to an improvement in employment or indeed to a reduction in our foreign indebtedness.

In recent days the argument has been made that the wealthy need to become more wealthy because that would provide money for investment. In the last 12 months we have seen that, while those on ordinary wages have become worse off, executive salaries have gone up by some 17 per cent. The wealth that has already been channelled in that direction has not gone into productive investment; it has gone to increase the salaries of the already wealthy and not back into the businesses of which they are the controllers.

Of course, this has come about through a policy of deregulation—deregulation of banking and deregulation of foreign exchange. There is nothing whatsoever in the Opposition's policy, in its Fightback program, which would turn that around. Indeed, Dr Hewson is on record specifically in relation to unemployment as saying that he would actually remove from the Reserve Bank the criterion that it has to take into account, namely, a concern for the employment in this country, and would leave the Reserve Bank only with a criterion of controlling interest rates.

In recent years we have all seen what happens to a country when that instrument is used as the instrument to try to prevent imports coming in. We have seen that the wealthy are the recipients of interest; that high interest rates in fact help them; and that they are then able to go out and buy more imports. In fact, increasing interest rates has not led to a reduction in imports. It is a very blunt and ineffective—in many respects a counterproductive—tool to be used. Yet that is the only tool that Dr Hewson would leave in the hands of the Reserve Bank.

So one would expect that under a coalition government one would not see a turnaround in these high levels of unemployment and the high and growing levels of foreign indebtedness. I think most people now are recognising—the Minister made this point earlier—that interventionist policies are now the order of the day. We need to intervene strongly in the economy. We need governments which are no longer beholden to some abstract economic ideology but are beholden to the people who elect them, are beholden to Australians, and intervene strongly in the economy to turn it around. The only program which has been put before the Australian people which would intervene, and intervene successfully, to do this is the Democrats' Getting to Work document.

We recognise that with the large and growing foreign debt we need to increase government expenditure. But that cannot be had at the expense of the deficit increasing the foreign indebtedness. The only way that we can do that is to generate the revenues in this country, and the only way we can do that is to impose a jobs levy, as contained in our Getting to Work document. It is a program in which those who are well off and those who still have jobs help those who are without jobs. Those who are looked on with envy—according to Senator Macdonald a few moments ago, because they have jobs and because they are already well off—need to help the less well off by providing through a jobs levy the funding which would provide the employment.

I have to agree with Senator Macdonald that we will not solve the unemployment problem by simply throwing money at creating jobs which disappear when the money dries up. We need to carefully target that money so that it goes into productive enterprises which have long term benefits.

We have identified in our Getting to Work document a number of specific industries which would provide not only employment but substantial import replacement, particularly in the energy area, and at the same time build up industries which provide very substantial exports. Those industries could address both the problem of unemployment and the problem of indebtedness, but at the same time—because they are in the energy area—they could also provide a very significant turnaround in the way in which we have mismanaged our environment.

We agree with the Opposition that payroll tax would be a good tax to remove. But I observe in passing that Mr Kennett is on record as saying that he will not remove payroll tax in Victoria because of the very poor state of the Victorian economy. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —How depressing it is to be contributing to a debate today where a government that has been in power since 1983 presides over 979,900 unemployed people—that is, those who are looking for work but who cannot find a job. As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, the situation is far worse than that. If one adds to the people who are looking for work but who cannot find it those who are underemployed and those who have given up looking for a job out of absolute desperation—they have tried for so long that they have given up—and who are no longer included in these statistics, the situation is even worse. If we add to that the people who have a job but who are looking over their shoulder wondering whether they are going to be the next unemployed under Labor, the situation is even more depressing.

PARA.TAB: I have said before, and it bears repeating, that in one sense it really does not matter what the unemployment rate is because those who are unemployed are 100 per cent unemployed. That is true at a personal level for someone who is unemployed. But for the nation's unemployment rate to go to where it has today is an absolute disgrace. In my State of South Australia, the situation is even worse than the national average. Western Australia scores in a sense the `best' unemployment rate at 10.3 per cent. What a disgrace for us to be saying that a State has the `best' unemployment rate at 10.3 per cent per cent. It is unbelievable! New South Wales follows with 11.1 per cent unemployment; Queensland, 11.3 per cent; Tasmania, 11.4 per cent; Victoria, 12.1 per cent; and then my State, 12.2 per cent, having shifted up from 11.4 per cent. It is an absolute and utter disgrace.

In addition, the job participation rate has fallen; people are no longer looking for work. So the percentages should be worse. If the people who have stopped looking for work were still looking for it, the percentages would be worse. As Senator Macdonald pointed out, 700,000 children this year will have a Christmas where neither of their parents—or their parent, if it is a sole parent household—has a job. It is not a very happy situation for people to be in.

The Government acknowledges this situation. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), who normally comes in here in a bombastic and argumentative way, came in and spoke much more softly today and said that this is not an occasion for hand wringing. That is true. But it is an occasion for the Government to start being honest with Australia and to admit what its policies will be at the next election—or to admit that it has none and that it has simply run out of ideas as to what to do.

The very best that the Minister could come up with were some indicators. He says to the nearly one million unemployed—or the well over one million unemployed if the underemployed and those who are no longer looking for work are included—`Don't worry, look at some of these economic indicators, they are getting better; so in the end employment will get better'. But we have been told month after month after month that recovery is on the way. Clearly, in the unemployment area, recovery is not on the way. It does not matter therefore that retail sales have gone up, that growth has been going up or that more people are working overtime.

Senator Cook might reflect on the fact that if more people are working overtime there might be fewer new jobs. In a situation where we have over one million unemployed or underemployed, the best that Government members can come up with is to scratch their heads and say, `Well, retail sales and building improvements are going up and there are more vacancies than there were before'. That is the best they can offer. It is simply not good enough.

The nation wants to hear of a plan from the Government to get Australia back on track and to get employment going. One might say that the Government has had 10 years in which to do that—and of course it has. It might bear repeating in this chamber what Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, said on 25 October this year in a Meet the Press program. He said that unemployment is our biggest single problem. He is quite right in that respect; it is probably one of the few points on which he is right. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . and it's the one which I've devoted myself greatest to in the period that I've been Prime Minister. The labour market was the thing I devoted myself to in all the years I was Treasurer.

What a great job he has done. It is something about which I would have thought he would not be proud. But I am at a loss to imagine why, as recently as October this year, he would be prepared to admit the heavy hand that he has had in this matter.

PARA.TAB: In contrast, as Senator Macdonald said, the coalition does have a plan. Day after day honourable senators opposite pick something that they think is wrong with the plan or they choose to misinterpret it. Some people have said that Government members tell straight out lies about the plan. For example, it is an untruth to say, as Senator Tate did on one occasion, that the coalition would make private health insurance mandatory. I believe that Senator Tate, if he did not know then, now knows that that is untrue. We hope that that sort of thing is not repeated.

Senator Cook did a similar thing today when he said, `You people will tip everybody off whatever benefit they might get for being employed after nine months'. That is true, but it is not the whole truth. One can deceive by telling a half truth. It is an absolute disgrace that the best those opposite can offer is a misinterpretation of what we are offering.

We have a plan to get taxes off the back of business—and that is how jobs are generated. As Senator Macdonald said, $20 billion worth of taxes that are currently put on the business community will be taken off it. They will be spread over the whole community. But that will mean that the price of the goods and services produced by the business community will come down. Obviously goods and services will become more competitive, but if the price comes down we will add a GST. The important thing to remember is that the price of those goods and services will be reduced without those $20 billion worth of tax on them. That means that we will be more competitive. We will be able to sell more goods overseas. If prices are more competitive, we will be able to export more. That is a very thin thumbnail sketch of a very extensive and well thought out program that we refer to as Fightback—but we have that plan.

As honourable senators opposite have noted, with the recession being as deep as it is, that plan might now need some finetuning. Things have become far worse under this Government than even we imagined they would. But at least we have the brains to do something about it and to amend our plan. We want to see a plan from these people opposite to improve the situation in this nation and to do something about the unemployment problem. We do not want them to just keep promising more of the same and pointing to some half-baked economic indicators that say `It will all be all right, Jake' when we know that it will not be.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you would know that over the last fortnight there has been question after question to this Government about its plan to do something about unemployment, manufacturing or whatever. It simply does not have one. That is why, when we finally go to the polls, this Government will be tipped out of office and the people on this side will be in government. We have a plan to get Australia going again, to take the taxes off the business community and to make it more competitive and thereby create more real jobs. We will not just shuffle wealth around, as the Australian Democrats suggest. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating the unemployment figures released today. I am very concerned by the figures. I find absolutely no joy at all in the labour force figures that were published today for the month of November 1992. As was pointed out earlier in this debate, using the seasonally adjusted figures, there has been a slight rise in the unemployment rate from 11.3 per cent in October to 11.4 per cent in November. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the trend figures that were published today, because they are very interesting indeed. They actually smooth out the month to month variations in the data that is calculated and published by the Bureau of Statistics. The trend figures show that there was no increase in unemployment between October and November; the unemployment rate was in fact constant at 11.2 per cent both in October and in November. I find that to be a high figure, but I do point out that there was no increase in the trend estimate between the two months.
—So things are pretty good, are they?

—As I have already said, I find no joy at all in the figures, but I point out that the trend figures show no movement upwards between those two months; however, it is a high figure. I would like to look at the figures for the individual States because one of the great worries I have as an economist is that there is something wrong with the economy of New South Wales at present. This is something I have been looking at for some—
—How about South Australia?

—I will get on to that in a moment, but I have been looking at the New South Wales economy since July because there is an emerging problem in that economy and it is something that really has to be looked at very carefully. When we look at the trend estimates of unemployment between November last year and November this year, we see that the biggest increase in the trend unemployment rate was in New South Wales. Clearly, the trend in that State is the worst of all in terms of jobless in Australia. Something is clearly wrong in that economy.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps something is wrong with the policies of the State Government. That is one individual factor that we can put forward as to what might be causing the problems in that State which make it different from other States in regard to performance. Maybe the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Fahey, should be looking at his own policies and calling an inquiry into the State economy, because something may well be wrong with the supply side policies that he has been adopting in New South Wales in addressing his economy.

It is no coincidence that the unemployment trend is like that for New South Wales because, coincidentally, yesterday the Bureau of Statistics also published the retail sales figures. Again, I invite honourable senators opposite to look at the retail sales figures for the month of October and for the year to October. They will see that New South Wales was a very poorly performing State in the month of October. In fact, according to the Sydney Morning Herald this morning, for the last four consecutive months there has been negative retail sales growth in New South Wales. I am sure that is not the case—

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe Mr Keating's policies had something to do with it.

—I point out to Senator Tierney that there is one factor we can point to which makes New South Wales different from the other States. It has a specific government with a specific set of policies. It may be that it has been reducing employment in the public sector. I do not know what has actually been going on in New South Wales, but maybe it has been slashing jobs in the public sector. Maybe, through its supply side approach to the economy of New South Wales, the State Government has been actually worsening the situation in that State compared with what it might otherwise have been.

PARA.TAB: It is undeniable that the figures today show that the biggest single trend upwards in unemployment over the last 12 months has been in New South Wales. As I pointed out, the retail sales figures published this week by the Bureau of Statistics show, apparently, four consecutive negative months of growth in New South Wales. But at the same time, the national figures are strongly positive; the national retail sales figures are up. In the year to October this year, the retail sales figures showed 4 per cent annual growth, which is well ahead of the figure in New South Wales and well ahead of the inflation figure in Australia. The consumer price index has recorded 0.8 per cent growth over the last 12 months, so we could say that there has been 3 per cent real growth in retail sales in Australia in the last 12 months, but that certainly is not the case in New South Wales.

There are a number of other positive signs in the national economy which it is very important to place on the record in the debate this afternoon. First of all, we have had four consecutive quarters—in other words, four times three months in a row—of positive growth in total production in the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are there another 80,000 without a job?
—We have had four consecutive quarters of real growth—2 per cent real growth in the Australian economy in the last 12 months.
—But you need over 3 per cent to get unemployment down.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator Tierney, you will be able to speak shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tierney comes from New South Wales and he is very sensitive about what I have said regarding Mr Fahey and his policies. But the figures are undeniable; something is wrong in the New South Wales economy.
—It is dropping in Tasmania.
—Order! Senator Tierney, you will have a chance in a moment.

—The New South Wales Government really should be calling an inquiry into the state of the economy in New South Wales because something clearly is going wrong in that State. There are other indicators that show a very bad pattern. But, nationally, we have had 2.1 per cent real growth in gross domestic product in the last 12 months.

PARA.TAB: In regard to world trends, 17 countries have reported their annual growth figures to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development—the organisation of the industrialised countries of the world. Australia has the fifth highest growth in national production of the 17 countries that have reported. We are being told time and again by those opposite that there is some sort of crisis in Australia. Certainly, there is a high unemployment figure, but internationally our level of production is growing faster than in other countries.

We have faster economic growth than Japan. We have faster economic growth than New Zealand. People opposite are always jumping on flights to New Zealand to see how to turn a First World country into a Third World economy. They are always jumping on planes to find out about the policies over there. The reality is that this country has higher economic growth than New Zealand. If they have not been going to New Zealand, they have been going to Great Britain to see how Mrs Thatcher and Mr Major ruined a developed economy. That country has had negative economic growth quarter after quarter.

We are told there is a crisis in the Australian economy but, as I pointed out, there have been four consecutive quarters of economic growth in Australia. Germany, the powerhouse of the European Community and one of the largest exporting nations in the world, has had four negative quarters of growth in the last five quarters. There is the comparison: four positive quarters of economic growth in Australia and four negative quarters out of five quarters of economic activity in Germany. So that is the reality and that is the comparison. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard an amazing piece of nonsense from Senator Maguire—a very selective citing of economic statistics. If he looks into the history of New South Wales, he will find that, during the recession that Mr Keating induced, New South Wales has been well ahead of every other State with regard to employment levels. This has only recently changed. It is one of the most highly industrialised States in Australia, and employment levels are dropping because of the policies of this Federal Government. I thought that would have been plain to anyone. Perhaps Senator Maguire should have talked about South Australia, where the figures for unemployment have gone up from 11.4 per cent to 12.2 per cent. I am surprised that he did not say anything about that.

PARA.TAB: Why did he not talk about Tasmania? Tasmania has a Liberal government. Senator Tate would be interested to know that unemployment has actually dropped from 12.2 per cent to 11.4 per cent. So we should go from the nonsense that we have just heard to the reality of the situation and what this Labor Government has done to the country. This country has 11.4 per cent unemployment, which is over a million people unemployed. That is an absolute disgrace.

Youth unemployment, which is now sitting at 33 per cent, is a further disgrace. Three out of 10 young people have no hope of getting a job. I have three children at school, and I thank the Lord that they are not going on to the unemployment market at this point—that was a freudian slip; I meant to say the employment market. It is more of an unemployment market for young people in this country. I am glad my children are not going on to that market to try to get a job in this recessionary climate.

Senator Maguire talked about experience overseas, but he needs to explain why this Government led the world into the recession. We were the first country to go into the recession, which was induced by Mr Keating. Everyone recalls that he said this was the recession we had to have. We have recently seen some amazing figures. For example, over the past month 78,000 people in Australia lost their jobs. Unemployment has reached one million, underemployment is now at two million and those figures are set to rise.

How much more horrifying do these statistics have to become before this Government acts on this problem? Labor's policies or lack them—as we keep pointing out week after week in this chamber—have failed to address the real economic problems facing this country. The Government has issued five economic statements over the last two years all of which have failed.

Let us recall the policies of this Government. There was the economic statement in May 1991 which failed and the 1991 Budget which failed. There was the November 1991 job statement—and what a misnomer that was! Unemployment kept going up and that failed. Then there was One Nation, which was a ploy brought in by the Prime Minister just before what he thought was to be the last election. He thought he was going to have a June poll, so he brought in One Nation in February. He thought how marvellously he was going to do, but then he did not have his election and the whole thing has fallen apart as the recent Estimates have shown. Then we had the 1992 Budget, and the Government has been fiddling with that and changing it recently because it has failed as well.

Let us look at the record of this Government, not only in Senator Maguire's State, but also right across Australia. We have record unemployment, record bankruptcies, a skyrocketing debt which now stands at $2 billion, and a current account deficit last month of a staggering $1.8 billion. Usually in most months the Government says, `Boy! It only went up $1 billion this month. That was a good month!' How long will it be before it starts to come down?

During the 10 years of this Government's term of office there have been record interest rates. Nominal interest rates have come down, but real interest rates certainly have not and are still one of the highest. The micro-economic reform trumpeted by this Government is moving at snail's pace. The Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, spoke in this chamber about the marvellous new changes in that rate. But before he got some of the public service involved, out in the private sector where it really counts only 3 per cent of the work force were covered. This is micro-economic reform at the end of the reform agenda that was supposed to dominate the Labor Government's fourth term. It is just a joke; it is not going anywhere at this stage.

Recently in the Additional Estimates we were looking at how the current policies of the Government show no hope of Australia getting out of this recession. Central to the Government's policy was the statement in the Budget about a capital works program. The sum of $345m was to be spent on that and it was supposed to create 13,000 jobs. It will not come remotely close to doing so. We talked about the example of Byron Bay where the Government spent $400,000 on footpaths but did not create one extra job. Right throughout the north coast councils revealed that they were not particularly targeting new employment and it was not creating new jobs at all. There has been a great failure by the Government in this program to put controls on what was happening, and it showed in the end that it was not creating new jobs. Not only was it not controlling who was getting the work, but it was not even controlling what the type of work was.

TAB.TAB: At the moment in this country we have the joke that a government which started with a capital infrastructure program earlier in the year—one that was supposed to be spending money on roads and rail—ended up spending it on cycleways. Cycleways are a great thing to have and a great community resource—there is one behind my house and I am very grateful it is there—but we cannot have a cycleway-led recovery. We need better roads and railways to get the economic infrastructure in this country right, but because of poor planning by this Government this will not happen at all.

PARA.TAB: This country desperately needs new policies and we believe that the coalition's Fightback policies have the answers. I believe these policies will get the country back on the right track. We have done the calculations very carefully and these policies will create real, long term, sustainable jobs between now and the end of the decade—two million jobs, in fact. Our industrial relations reform will ensure that the current snail's pace will disappear and the antiquated rules that we currently work under in industrial relations will not stand in the way of people obtaining work.

Our tax changes will give people more incentive to work and the sweeping micro-economic reforms that we are proposing will take the shackles off business. Education and training policies will make sure that people have the education and skills they need to get work. Fightback stands in stark contrast to the policies of this Government, particularly the failed One Nation policies. Unemployment continues to rise in this economy and we are in an economic nosedive. Fightback is needed to create new jobs and bring us back from the brink of disaster which Mr Keating and this Labor Government have created.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the issue of unemployment on a matter introduced by Senator Hill. Unfortunately, this is a very politicised debate. It really has not been in any way an analysis of the reasons why Australia finds itself with such a high unemployment rate. There has been no comparison with the situation in many of the countries of the world which now face slower growth, such as Japan, Germany and the United States, and no examination of the impact on us. Only Asia has not been in the position that we find ourselves in. The Opposition tends to ignore the world scene that we face. Naturally enough, the Opposition is concerned with scoring political points. We know in the last 48 hours that it is fairly desperate to take the attention away from the problems it has with the somersaulting that is occurring hourly in the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has said that the figures which have been referred to are tragic and disappointing. I certainly agree with that and my colleagues have made that clear. However, the Australian people facing this world slowdown know that Australia's rate of growth is still superior to a whole range of other economies that we can be reasonably compared with.

In Australia's present pre-election phase the Australian people also have to decide on and make a real analysis between the position this Government takes—which is a stimulatory one all the time—and the coalition's big bang, cut and burn policies. Senator Vanstone talked about the coalition's plan, but it is not really a plan. It is a policy of confrontation. I appreciate that individual senators from the other side have said that they are concerned when they are accused of being cynical about unemployment, but the objective position is that the coalition would use unemployment to reduce the standard of living of wage and salary earners.

That is very clear when one examines the coalition's industrial relations policy. It is designed to use the unemployment that exists to reduce the standard of living of wage and salary earners. The first part of that is manifest in the Opposition's attack on the unions. After all, the unions are the only weapon that wage and salary earners use. There is a very concerted attack on trade unions which are used by working men and women to achieve rates of pay. It is unfortunate that the coalition needs to use the despair of unemployed people in order to implement its industrial relations policies.

Premier Kennett in Victoria has shown just what a national coalition government would do. Senator Tierney talked about creating two million jobs, but one can see where two million jobs would come from. On the one hand we have Premier Kennett destroying jobs and the public infrastructure and reducing the standards of living of Victorians, and on the other hand, as my colleague Senator Maguire has said, we have a particular crisis or malaise in New South Wales which suffered from the assertiveness of Premier Greiner. But just as the national coalition is now facing a crisis, in New South Wales—because of the Premier Greiner's failure as a result of which he was effectively dumped—the present malaise is presided over by his replacement, Premier Fahey.

New South Wales is in that situation because it has a similar policy of reducing the public sector, reducing infrastructure and attempting to lower people's working conditions as a way of solving things. That is inhibiting the national Government's program which aims to increase the value of our human capital. We have developed the TAFE system, just to pick out one of the One Nation initiatives that is currently moving ahead to skill our work force. These measures are enabling import replacement and are successfully improving export opportunities for the manufacturing sector. To some extent, there is a reticence on behalf of the coalition in the State governments because they do not understand; they understand only cut, cut, cut. They understand only reducing the standards of ordinary people.

The coalition's basic strategy, which is implicit in everything it does, is to discipline the work force, to further destroy the ability of people to spend money and to have confidence in the economy at this time of recession. We have a conflict because of the optimism of the Federal Government—based on the skilling of the work force and the structural adjustment that has taken place throughout industry in this country—the negative policies followed by Liberal State governments and, of course, the carping criticism of the coalition opposite.

The coalition policies in Victoria are particularly dangerous precedents to look at. What a coalition government would do to arrest unemployment is based on trying to hurt those people who are weakest in society with individual contracts. This is what the unemployed have to face when the coalition says it will create two million jobs. The two million jobs would be created in an atmosphere where ordinary people—for example women, people of ethnic backgrounds whose English is not perfect and youth—would have to fight with the unemployed in a system where people have been denied reasonable access to the fairness which they have under the award system. They will no longer have that blanket of security to ensure that they cannot be exploited as individuals.

When the Opposition says that there are certain safeguards, it forgets the fact that the decent employers—and there are so many of them—will be disadvantaged when the employer down the street undermines the system because there is no award. They will very quickly face having to reduce the standards for their people. The significance of this is that it is all very depressing. It depresses the economy. The people in such a coalition government—which is the alternative to this Government—would be depressing everybody. They would be depressing wages and standards for people in employment and they would be offering the unemployed no solution at all. That is the stark choice. That is what I wanted to refer to in the short time available. I had intended to detail the many programs in the One Nation statement and the Budget, but time restrictions will not allow me the extra five minutes needed, so I will leave that for another day.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—That concludes the debate on the matter of public importance.

Members of the AHC represent about one third of the $3 billion dollar Australian horticultural industry. Horticulture is the third largest rural industry behind wool and beef, but is ahead of wheat, sheep, cotton and dairying. It is, therefore, not only a very significant rural industry, but also one of great importance and potential.

In Australia, as in most other countries, the diversity of the horticultural industry distinguishes it from most other agricultural industries. Hundreds of products grown in Australia are generally classified as horticultural products. But there are no hard and fast rules as to what constitutes a horticultural product.

PARA.TAB: Production occurs under a wide range of climates, from tropical to cool-temperate. Obviously, production differences exist between product groups. For instance, most fruit and nuts are perennial crops with long production lead times, while many vegetable crops have short production cycles and require regular rotation to maintain yields. For some products the geographic dispersion and seasonal variation of production mean that different regions have dissimilar marketing requirements. For example, citrus growers in Queensland operate in different markets and at different times of the year from citrus growers in other States.

During the year, the AHC and industry participated in a review by the Industry Commission into the effectiveness of the Australian Horticultural Corporation. In noting the relatively short time during which the AHC has operated and other constraints in obtaining definitive statistics, the Commission reported that many of the activities in which the AHC is engaged have the potential to be beneficial to Australian horticulture and are consistent with improving its international competitiveness. SPEECH.PARA: While the volumes of some products such as applies, pears and grapes increased marginally during the 1980s, the production of several newer commercial crops such as macadamia nuts, avocados and mangoes increased significantly . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not advertising, are you?

PARA.TAB: I want to compliment the farmers in our area. They know the problems these days of trying to grow crops when dry land farming. TALK.START.PARA: —You have some good dams near your property, haven't you?

It has not been satisfactorily attended to as far as the industry is concerned. It is being held in a reasonable condition but, once the disease is installed, it cannot be totally eradicated.
