SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology on gas and electricity, combining efficiency and greenhouse, together with a transcript of evidence and submissions.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report and to have a brief statement incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, this report follows the Committee's previous report into the greenhouse effect and energy conservation, Rescue the Future.

It focuses on measures required to ensure the efforts which have been made to improve the efficiency of the electricity and gas industries are maintained, while implementing sensible measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
The report's major objective is to identify methods of reconciling the conflicts between economic and environmental imperatives and between Commonwealth and State priorities.

It also reviews the extensive changes both proposed and under way in the energy industries and draws attention to the unforseen consequences of some of these changes, particularly the repercussions of some aspects of energy industry reform for both environmental and social policy.

Energy industries are mostly state controlled. However, an adequate response to both the economic and environmental problems associated with the energy industries requires a national approach. The past practices of making decisions solely on the basis of regional interests have not served either state or national interests well.
The Committee's principal recommendation is that a national charter be developed for public electricity authorities.

This charter should establish clear economic, social and environmental priorities. The report lays down ten priorities which the Committee considers should be addressed by the authorities in the next ten years.
While this recommendation is specifically directed at the electricity industry, the same principles are likely to be applicable in publicly owned gas authorities.

The Committee has recommended that in the future, governments and the authorities themselves take a broader view of their role and introduce whatever measures to reduce or control emissions which can be shown to be economic.

Commonwealth government agencies should lead by example in the implementation of `no regrets' energy efficiency principles. An example of where this could be done is with regard to government buildings and public housing stock.
There are a number of other significant conclusions and recommendations in this report. These include:
. a ten year moratorium on the construction of new conventional generation plant by electricity authorities
. greater use of natural gas as a direct energy source and as a fuel for power generation.
. qualified support for improved electricity interconnection between the states
. the National Grid Protocol to be given legislative force
. development of the role of the National Grid Management Council, the membership of which should be expanded
. measures to ensure standards of accountability of the energy authorities are maintained
. measures to encourage the greater application of alternative energy technologies.

The Committee considers it is possible to pursue economic, environmental and social goals simultaneously, and there is much which could be done within the energy industries which would have positive effects both for the economy and the environment.
I commend the report to the Senate.

The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing, in the committee stage, the Bill introduced by Senator Walters—a Bill for an Act to regulate certain video material. I wish to understand some of the clauses a little more fully. In particular, I seek some guidance on, and wish to discuss, the application clause, which is clause 3 of the Bill. As I read it, the clause appears to concentrate on Commonwealth and Territory jurisdictions or political entities.

PARA.TAB: I need to deal with a matter which I think is of importance when we are discussing a matter in the States' House, and that is the role of the States in relation to the classification of film and video material. I do so because when we met in the Senate before for the second reading debate on this particular Bill, we had not had the benefit of the meeting of the Council of Australian Governments which occurred in Perth last week. As I understand it, this Bill, because it does not in the application clause mention the States, does not, I think, take account of that important meeting, and I wonder whether Senator Walters would have wished that that be the case.

Honourable senators will be aware that at the meeting of the Heads of Government—and that is the Prime Minister, the Premiers and the Chief Ministers—a communique was issued, and if I may, I will read the relevant part, which is headed `Film and Video Classification'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: As part of its general concern about the level of violence in Australia, the Council considered the issue of violence on film, television and video and the value of achieving one classification system across these three forms of media.

The Council noted the discussions that the Prime Minister had held with the television networks and that the networks had undertaken to draw up a draft program code that adopts the system of classification currently used for film and video. It also noted that, under the new arrangements, two new `M' classifications will replace the current wide and indiscriminate `AO' category for television with the more violent films being classified as `MA'. In relation to film and video the new `M' category will be recommended for those aged 15 and over. The new `MA' category will be restricted to those aged 15 and over unless accompanied by an adult.
It finishes by saying:
The Council agreed to endorse the move to two new `M' classifications and agreed to amend the relevant censorship legislation by 1 May 1993.

I think that it is important, because Senator Walters's Bill, of course, very properly tries to address a matter of concern to many in the Australian community, particularly parents, in relation to the M category which, I think it is universally agreed, is too broad a category. We all know that the M category could include quite unexceptionable films which just have some course language in them, ranging from that milder end way up to The Silence of the Lambs or Fatal Attraction. Quite clearly, parents were confused and even those who wanted to go and see the films, whether they be children or adults, were not given sufficiently precise guidance by the M classification as to what they might expect when they sat down in the cinema or obtained the video.

PARA.TAB: It seems that there is a universal acceptance of the need to split that category into two. I think that Senator Walters's sincerity in this matter cannot be doubted. The fact is, though, that the States, as indicated at the council of government leaders from all around Australia, believed the question of censorship and classification to be properly a Federal matter, a matter whereby traditionally classification censorship is a Federal, State and Territory matter.

Each of the States and Territories has its own legislation dealing with these matters. Changes to the laws hitherto have come about by agreement between all the parties and it is quite clear that in Perth—and this was not available to Senator Walters when she drafted her Bill—there was unanimous agreement, as I am informed, by the Prime Minister, the Premiers and all the Chief Ministers as to a classification proposal which will have an effect on film and video that will have a flow-on and consequential effect on television programs as well. It seems all the Heads of Government certainly want more discriminating choices to be made in that M category and have put forward their endorsement of the M and MA bifurcation of that category.

I also think that it is very important that the Heads of Government all agreed that that classification system should be transferred into the world of television, so that with a common classification system, once again an area of confusion can be eliminated for those who are seeking to guide particularly their children in their viewing.

I believe that the elimination of the dual system is a further indication of the strength of the decisions that were taken in Perth by the Heads of Government. As I read Senator Walters's Bill—and this is not to criticise the honourable senator; perhaps she can elaborate—her legislation does not deal with that common classification matter. This was not her primary concern. I believe it is important to note that the Heads of Government decided in this way.

Further, in relation to the split M category, the Council adopted the idea that the milder M category be recommendatory; in other words, at the milder end if parents are informed. But the stronger films and videos in the new MA category will not be available to younger children. They will be restricted to those aged 15 and over unless they are accompanied by a parent or guardian. I regard this as extremely important and a good innovation. Parents will be assisted by the law in ensuring that when their children say that they are going to see a PG or an M film in one of the big cinema complexes, they do not see a MA film. It will be an offence for a cinema proprietor to allow an unaccompanied youngster of 15 years or under to view a MA film. I believe that is important.

In the case of a parent or guardian accompanying a child into a cinema to see a MA film, the Heads of Government are saying, `It is the responsibility of the parent or guardian, and that is where the responsibility should rightly and primarily lie'. The parent or guardian who accompany the youngster into an MA film will have been forewarned and they take the responsibility. In the absence of the parent or guardian, there will be further assistance from the law.

I believe that this is an extremely important part of the change that has occurred. I believe it is very important that Senator Walters clarify how her Bill will work in relation to the State laws governing the classification and censorship of videos and films in their jurisdictions, particularly the enforcement—not just the classification, but the restrictive part—of the MA proposal that came out of the Heads of Government meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, pursuant to Standing Orders, I ask that Senator Tate table all of the documents emanating from the Heads of Government meeting from which he has quoted—and I mean all of them, including what is being proposed to be included in MA and M.

—The only document I have from the Council of Australian Governments meeting in Perth of 7 December is an extract from the communique, and I am happy to table that. I have not quoted from any other papers. I will go through my bundle of papers but I do not believe I have any papers other than that extract, which I am happy to table.

—As the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) may know, all of the States wanted a national classification body. They did not want their own classification situation; they agreed on a national body. As the Minister would be aware, all the Attorneys-General throughout Australia met. At that stage, the then Federal Attorney-General, Mr Bowen, wanted to agree. He said that he would take back the States' desire to have a national classification body and that imported X-rated videos and films would be excluded. However, the Federal Government categorically refused to agree with the State Attorneys-General on that issue.

PARA.TAB: The question of the establishment of a national classification body has been before us for many years. I point out to Senator Tate that there is no problem at all with regard to my Bill. The States have already agreed to the establishment of a national classification body and it is that body which will look at the new classification system I am proposing.

The situation that Senator Tate has now put before us—he said that this matter was considered at the Premiers Conference—can easily be overcome. Senator Collins's proposed amendment to the Broadcasting Bill stated what the Prime Minister wanted; that is, a common film classification system to operate across the mediums of film, video and television. The classifications will be set by the Office of Film and Literature Classification and product will bear its classification across all mediums. The classifications will be G, PG, M, MA and R. He went on to refer to broadcast for television; nothing else, just broadcast for television.

It is very clear that G will stay as G, PG will stay as PG, M will be divided into M and MA, and R will stay as R. There is no query at all that it will be otherwise. M, which is the milder form of the old classification M, can remain under section 5(1)(f) of my Bill which relates to `video material not recommended for viewing by persons under the age of 15 years'. The MA classification will contain material not recommended for viewing for people under the age of 18. Only a very small amendment to my Bill is needed to fit in with the Government's intention on the division of the M classification. It is not insurmountable and it is not something that cannot be done this afternoon.

Bearing in mind that we have only one hour, I hope the Minister will not take up, as he did a few minutes ago, 10 of his 15 minutes debating this issue. I hope that he will not deliberately frustrate the passage of my Bill and that the Bill will get the vote in the chamber before that hour passes.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to deal with a few specific clauses in the Bill but, before doing so, say that this is an important issue. I congratulate Senator Walters on persisting with this over time. Looking back through Hansard, we see that her commitment to the issue goes back many years. I also note that this will not be the last time this issue is raised in the chamber because next week we will be having before us legislation on this subject at which time we can look very carefully at exactly what is proposed and have further opportunity for comment.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats put this Bill out to one of our working groups to look at it clause by clause. That group has raised a number of issues with us. I ask Senator Walters, initially with regard to education material, whether it is correct that, as the Bill stands, it appears that we quite severely limit what is now understood to be educational material and, in particular, material referred to now as sex education material or material used in sex education courses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it does not. Proposed subsection 5(8) states:

PARA.TAB: (8)Subsections (6) and (7) do not prevent the classification of video material which, in the opinion of the Classifying Body, depicts:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)matter of such educational, cultural, scientific, historical . . . . significance . . .

For instance, this would not stop pictures of the holocaust being shown. This Bill deals with the problems that Senator Lees is referring to. It does not limit at all any video for sex education, and it states that quite clearly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats' information is that subclause 5(3) is in no way tied to that subclause (8) over the page. Subclause 5(3) states:

PARA.TAB: Without limiting the generality of subsection (2), video material shall be refused classification for any of the purposes specified in subsection (1) if the material includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults, whether or not the material includes . . .

SPEECH.PARA: The subclause over the page that Senator Walters quoted, subclause (8), refers back only to `Subsections (6) and (7)'. I will not go through those because we are looking at classifications M and R. To give a specific example, the Democrats' advice is that the introduction of Senator Walters's Bill would mean that the sex education program on Channel 7, which was presented by Sophie Lee, would be taken off. Obviously the censor would have to make a decision on that. That program is quite valuable and it is one that would have to disappear, because there is no tying back from subclause (8) to subclause (3).

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to Senator Lees that subclause 5(3) refers to material with the X classification. These are the guidelines of the Office of Film and Literature Classification and they describe, in its words, what is to be included in the X category. By definition, that program to which Senator Lees has referred could not have been in that category because it could not have been a film that carried the X classification. The issue that Senator Lees raises is not relevant to subclause 5(3).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ask Senator Walters for an interpretation of some parts of her Regulation of Video Material Bill. What concerns me is subclause 5(3), which says:

PARA.TAB: Without limiting the generality of subsection (2), video material shall be refused classification for any of the purposes specified in subsection (1) if the material includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults, whether or not the material includes any depiction suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind.

SPEECH.PARA: Subclause 5(4) states:

PARA.TAB: It is unlawful to:
(a)sell or hire; or
(b)offer to sell or hire; or
(c)display for commercial purposes; or
(d)distribute;

SPEECH.PARA: I ask Senator Walters whether she has considered the situation that arises with the rapidly expanding popularity of private video cameras. I understand that they are being purchased by Australians at almost as rapid a rate as video recorders, so that they can make their own home movies. We have even had television programs promoting them by showing humorous home videos. A few months ago, we had a classic case on Channel 9 where the home videos were supposed to be naughty. Mr Packer took exception to that and halfway through the program he told them in very forceful words to take the material off the air immediately. I want to ask Senator Walters: will it be unlawful for consenting adults, using these home videos cameras, to film themselves or their friends recording it and then showing it to other friends at a later stage at a party amongst adults?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Subsection 5(4) of the Bill states very clearly:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) It is unlawful to:

PARA.TAB: (a) sell or hire; or
(b) offer to sell or hire; or
(c) display for commercial purposes; or
(d) distribute;—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, for commercial purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would happen if, under the definitions that Senator Walters has used, people made their own movies and then decided to put on a barbecue or a party where there was no entrance fee but where it just so happened that a reasonably stiff price was payable for a drink, a hot dog or a hamburger, so that in effect people were making money out of the provision of hospitality? How could Senator Walters prove `sell or hire; or offer to sell or hire; or display for commercial purposes', if people said, `You can see the movie free; it is only when you buy a drink or a hot dog that you pay any money'? Is that situation covered by this Bill? Does this Bill, under Senator Walters's definition, make that process illegal?

—We are all absolutely and thoroughly aware of what Senator Schacht is attempting to do. Those who have sat on a committee with Senator Schacht would be even more aware of what he is attempting to do. At the beginning, I made an appeal to Senator Tate not to talk this Bill out. I expect serious questions to be asked about my Bill. If the Government has any amendments, I would be grateful if it would tell me. Senator Lees has already informed me that she has no amendments. She is not filibustering or asking stupid questions. I and Senator Reynolds know—and I am quite sure Senator Tate knows—exactly what Senator Schacht is on about because we have sat on a committee with him. It is up to the Minister to pull his troops into line if he does not want to destroy the Bill by filibustering and by not allowing a vote on it.

—If Senator Walters had any knowledge of the way similar legislation in other areas works, she would know that there is great difficulty in prosecuting people for prostitution—and this has been publicised in South Australia. I am not an expert in the law—I am not a lawyer—but I believe that this difficulty is because the actual act of paying money has to be shown to be for that particular purpose. There have been cases in my own State and, I think, in other States where people have got round the provision by saying, `We are not actually purchasing a sexual act'—in terms of prostitution—`by paying the money; we are actually paying for something else'. They may be paying for the hire of the bed, for the room, for a glass of water, or for an electric light. That is what the money is being paid for; not for the actual act itself.

PARA.TAB: That is a legitimate question. I went through this Bill earlier today, because I thought—and understood—that Senator Walters would fall for exactly the same problem. Senator Walters wants to ban them. That is her view. No matter how she tries to achieve this, she will find that interpreting and operating this Act under law will be almost impossible. I am raising something with her that is occurring in the Australian community. People are purchasing video cameras at a very rapid rate. They can make their own movies amongst themselves, and can devise ways in which to use this Act which, I suspect, Senator Walters would not be able to do. People will claim that they were buying something else when coming along to see a showing of a video.

I raise this matter because the exact same problem has arisen in attempts to control and eliminate prostitution by making it illegal to offer money in order to procure a sexual act. That is the reason I raise it. I am sorry I was late for the debate, but I was at another meeting. Senator Walters may think I am raising a number of matters in this Bill which are irrelevant and are a filibuster. I am sorry. For Senator Walters to complain about filibustering has to take some cheek, because over the years I have been in the Senate I have observed the honourable senator speaking for her full half hour on countless numbers of Government Bills and getting up in the committee stage debating endlessly—as is her right under Standing Orders. But she should not tell me that she has not done a bit of filibustering to try to delay a Bill—creating problems, calling quorums and so on.

I believe it is legitimate for members of the Senate to ask how this Bill will operate. It is a Bill with sweeping powers to limit the activities of Australian people. I want to know exactly how it will work. I have raised a legitimate question and I want to know Senator Walters's answer. Can people do as I say, or are they liable to be charged?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —That may be a legitimate question from an imbecile; that is the only way it could be a legitimate question.
—That's very parliamentary, Senator.

—It would be a legitimate question if it came from somebody who had read the legislation. But if honourable members are concerned about the word `imbecile'—which I used in the generic sense—I withdraw it. I am not in the habit of using unparliamentary language. If Senator Schacht had read the legislation—
—I have read it.
—He should look at clause 5, `Classification standards', which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory makes provision for the classification of video material for the purpose of, or for purposes related to:
(a)prohibiting the importation of any video material;
that is, Customs legislation—
(b)registering video material; or

(c)prohibiting the advertising of, the sale of . . . or for any other purpose, the categories (however described in that law) into which the material may, subject to subsection (2), be classified . . .
Clearly, the matter raised by Senator Schacht will be triggered by the various State laws, as occurs now.

TALK.START.PARA: —But isn't this going to operate in the Territories as well?

—Yes, it will. But in respect of the South Australian situation which the honourable senator is talking about, the laws relating to video material in that State apply. As Senator Schacht ought to know, there are different laws in different States concerning the possession of material.

PARA.TAB: It is not for this chamber to talk about how those laws are to be implemented in the States. That is not the constitutional responsibility of this Federal Parliament. The Federal Parliament cannot legislate in respect of the matter which the honourable senator is talking about because it is not within the constitutional powers of the Parliament to do so. It is within the constitutional powers of the Federal Parliament to deal with the matter dealt with by Senator Walters's Bill—that is, the classification of video material. That is within the power of the Commonwealth.

We are talking about the censorship power. We are not talking about those powers that are to be exercised if the matters that Senator Schacht raised are to be determined. They are, of course, matters for the States.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I return to a matter that I started with before. I stress again that my interest is in education. As a former health education teacher, I am particularly interested in the whole area of sex education. I wish to go back to comments made a moment ago by Senator Harradine when I queried subclause 5(3). His reply to me was that this relates to the existing X classification. In fact, it does not.

PARA.TAB: In this Bill we have transferred the wording of the current classifications—and I have a copy here—over to the Bill under subclause 5(3). In the interpretation under clause 4 the words `explicit depictions of sexual acts' have been defined in an additional way. I am looking particularly at paragraph (c). The rewording will mean that in a sex education course there can be no demonstrations of any sort and, in particular, no demonstrations of practical things such as how to use contraceptive devices.

If we want to continue to ignore all of this and say to 15- and 16-year-olds, `You don't ever need to know any of this', that is fine, but, as a former teacher, I do not believe that this is the way we should be going in 1992. We do not have before us the existing X classification; we have something far tighter that will have enormous ramifications. It is going to spread over to programs such as the one that I mentioned previously. That may not be the intention, but part of my problem is with the way in which this Bill is written. It does not go to the heart of the intention that Senator Walters has. It goes far further. It will restrict things that I do not believe the Bill intends to restrict.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to the same matter: I was wondering whether Senator Walters can elaborate on the answer she gave to Senator Schacht in answer to his question about the classification standards under subclauses 5(3) and (4). Senator Walters quoted subclause 5(4) which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: It is unlawful to:
(a) sell or hire; or
(b) offer to sell or hire; or
(c) display for commercial purpose; or
(d) distribute . . .

As I understand it, because the word `or' is used, not `and/or', one could be distributing without any commercial connection. Because paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) use the word `or' and not the word `and', this could mean exactly what Senator Schacht was concerned about. One could have the distribution without any offer to sell or hire; that is, without any money involved. You would not necessarily even have to go to the extraordinary limits of charging a lot for your sausage. As I read that Bill, the point is that one could just have the distribution. Can Senator Walters make it clear to me whether or not what she said to Senator Schacht stands, when she looks at point (d) `to distribute' when there is an `or', not an `and/or'?

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be very similar to child pornography.

—I wish to pursue that line. I do not believe that answer elucidates the difficulty or the problem that I am asking about. Does the phrase `or distribute' make `distribute' a separate category? As I read plain English, this clause means that `to distribute' stands by itself. It is not as well as selling and hiring, it is just distributing; so it comes without any commercial attachment to it.

PARA.TAB: If what Senator Walters is saying is that, as in child pornography, material is distributed against the law because of the content, whether or not money changes hands, I can understand the intent of that. But I would still like to ask Senator Walters whether I am correct in understanding that the word `or' before paragraph (d) means that is not what this Bill is saying. It really should be `and distribute'.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the same point, in the case I raised about the widespread use of private video cameras, if a consenting couple—husband and wife—film themselves in some sort of sexual activity that is defined under (4)(a), (b) or even (c) and give that tape to some friends, an adult couple, for them to look at, would that be illegal, and would they be eligible to suffer a penalty as outlined in lines 30, 31 and 32?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the same clause, but on a slightly different point, under `Classification standards', it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Where a law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory makes provision for the classification of video material for the purpose of, or for purposes related to:
(a) prohibiting the importation of any video material;
(b) registering video material; or
(c) prohibiting the advertising of, the sale of, the offering for sale of . . . .

I pose a question to Senator Walters, through you, Mr Chairman. If magazines are imported into Australia which advertise video material, and if the video material has not arrived in Australia and therefore there has not been any classification of that video, would the importation of those magazines, and their distribution to people in the community, result in those people being liable to suffer a penalty, or would a restriction be placed on the person selling it after the classification was made? Would action be taken to confiscate the material held by the person who previously distributed it? It seems to me that there is some conflict in relation to people's rights. Should they buy a magazine that advertises materials—videos—which have not been classified by the board but are classified at a later stage, what is the position?

TALK.START.PARA: —This does not apply to magazines at all; it applies only to films and videos. The Film Censorship Board can gradually reassess the situation, as it is already doing with some classifications. It has reclassified some videos. It will be doing that along the same lines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand what Senator Walters is saying. The clause in the Bill is not quite clear, because it says:

SPEECH.PARA: (c) prohibiting the advertising of, the sale of, the offering for sale of, the letting on hire of or the distribution of any video material . . .

A magazine may contain advertisements for video material for sale, and talk about the video material in articles or whatever the case may be, when there has been no classification of that particular video material in Australia. There may then be a classification of that material. The clause is not very clear in that regard because that is video material as described in the clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interim the Film Censorship Board would deal with that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was making my earlier remarks, Senator Harradine asked whether I had any further material that might be of use to the Committee from the meeting of the Council of Australian Governments, the meeting of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Premiers and the Chief Ministers. I have available—and I have provided a copy of the material to Senator Harradine—a draft document entitled `Draft classification guidelines for M and MA categories', which I understand was made available for consideration by the heads of government before the meeting in Perth. I also have available a draft ordinance for discussion purposes prepared by the Office of the ACT Parliamentary Counsel, which was also circulated to the heads of government for their deliberations before they went to Perth. I table those documents, as requested by Senator Harradine.

PARA.TAB: I am not saying that these documents are precisely what the Heads of Government will give their assent to but, as I say, these matters were circulated to the Heads of Government and formed the basis for the unanimous communique, which I have read to honourable senators. The classifications set out in the document I have tabled deal with the categories `language', `sex', `violence' and `other'. For example, in relation to the M classification, which is recommended for mature audiences 15 years and over, the category of `other', which received the preliminary endorsement—shall we put it that way—of the Heads of Government, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Drug use may be discreetly depicted, but not in an advocatory manner. Supernatural and `horror' special effects may be depicted, but not if graphic or impactful.
In relation to the MA 15+ category, which is restricted to mature audiences 15 years and over unless accompanied by a parent or guardian, the `other' category is described in the following terms:
Drug use may be depicted, but not in an advocatory manner. Supernatural and "horror" special effects usually warrant an `MA' classification, but not if overly graphic or impactful.

In any reworking of the classifications in the M category—which I think all Australians and all senators in this chamber are seeking to achieve in order to respond to proper concerns in the community—the issue of drug use is as important when considering the future of our young children as the issues of language, sex or violence. I do not criticise Senator Walters for this at all but, as I understand it, her classifications do not deal with this matter. But I find it very interesting that the Heads of Government have considered that the depiction of drug use is a matter which must be attended to by the classifying authorities.

PARA.TAB: I think that we could work in extremely well with the approach of the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy to lowering the attractiveness of drug taking in the Australian community by ensuring here that parents know that if they say, `Yes, you can go along to an M film', drug use will certainly not be depicted in an advocatory way and that, if it is depicted at all, it will be only discreetly depicted. However, if parents sent their under 15-year-old to an MA film, they would know that drug use could be depicted, but once again not in an advocatory manner. I think this is a very interesting further development in the way in which Australian society is trying to come to terms with the very powerful influence of videos and films in the community. I commend the Heads of Government for that.

Also, it appears—and I cannot see this in Senator Walters's Bill—that the Heads of Government thought it important to look at the supernatural and horror special effects which form part of the fare of a lot of films which have, no doubt, a very strong impact on not only immature imaginations but perhaps especially immature imaginations. We have all seen horror films where the special effects are absolutely gruesome, graphic and frightening, even for adults. I remember taking a godson of mine to one of those horror films. He slept with a Bible under his pillow for the next three weeks to ward off the evil spirits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sure it wasn't a Labor Party meeting you went to?

—No, it was not a Labor Party meeting. I can assure Senator Parer that they are far more boring. They are certainly supernatural. We do not begin with a prayer, although some of the Sunday morning branch meetings are called prayer meetings, I think, are they not?

PARA.TAB: I think it is important to note that the Heads of Government have requested that any new M and MA classifications include reference to depictions of drug use too. As I say, I think this is an important new dimension, and I think we need time to consider it.

From my experience as Minister for Justice for several years, and as a member of the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy, I strongly believe that if we are to deal with the phenomenon of drug use in our community, we also have an obligation to our young people to ensure that films are classified in a way which does not expose them to any advocatory depiction of drug taking whatsoever. This is more important, perhaps, than all the law enforcement resources that we are prepared to put into that particular battle. I ask Senator Walters how she sees her Bill accommodating these matters? Or am I right in thinking that it does not deal with these matters that are thought to be important by the Heads of Government?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The present guidelines already cover that. I would have thought Senator Tate would know that. Let me read them.
—But they are not in yours.
—These are the guidelines the Government had. My Bill does not scrub all the guidelines; it deals only with those parts that I have indicated. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Drug use may be depicted, but not in an advocatory manner. Supernatural and "horror" special effects usually warrant an MA classification. . .

So this is not new, as Senator Tate is pretending it is. It is already part of the guidelines. Indeed, no film or video is at the moment permitted to advocate drug usage. That does not apply to any level or any classification. I would have thought Senator Tate would be aware of that. My Bill deals only with the two aspects, as I have already indicated, and my second reading speech explained that.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said in the second reading debate, I commend much of the work that Senator Walters has been involved in in raising these issues. There is no doubt that, in relation to violence, she and I have very little point of disagreement. However, as I said a couple of weeks ago in the second reading debate, I am not convinced about her manner of dealing with X-rated material. I have a couple of questions that I want to put to Senator Walters. She said a little earlier, in answer to Senator Tate, that the States wanted a national system of classification and that it was their wish that we get on with this national scheme and were opposed to X-rated material. Firstly, has Senator Walters recently canvassed the States' views? Does not the agreement of Monday supersede some of their concerns, particularly in relation to violence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no violence at all in X-rated material. The Premiers at no stage discussed the X rating, so they have not changed their minds. If they had, they would have said so. None of the Premiers are presently permitting X-rated videos to be sold within their States. As Senator Tate would be well aware, the only method for the States to get this material, because of our Constitution and the fact that there is free trade between the States, is for people to apply to the ACT and get their X-rated videos from here. It is all because the Federal Government would not abide by the decision of the Attorneys-General of every State that the Federal Government should fall into line.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tate will remember that in 1988, representing the Attorney-General in this place, he took the Bill himself. He was the one who took the Bill, denying the need to abide by the decision of the Attorneys-General of every State, and defeated it very thoroughly on those grounds. Only five minutes remain for this debate. I would like the listening public to understand exactly what the Government is on about. Government senators intend to talk out the Bill so that there will be no vote taken, and Senator Tate will be able to say that he did not vote against it.

It is absolutely unbelievable. In 1988 he was the Minister who sat at the table. He took the Bill through all its stages and then, when the vote was taken, got up and walked out and demanded a pair. He was given a pair. When one of Senator Tate's constituents wrote to him and said that he was surprised that he had voted against my Bill, he said, `If you say that outside, I will sue you because I did not do so'.He took the Bill through all its stages on behalf of the Government and then did not have the courage of his convictions to come over and vote for something that he knew was the correct thing to do. Instead, he chose the coward's way of seeking a pair and refusing—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Walters!
—I withdraw, Mr Chairman.
—I raise a point of order. I would like to continue asking a couple of questions and I am wondering—
—You can't continue when I am on my feet. It is not a point of order.
—Senator Reynolds, you will have the opportunity to speak.
—To overcome what Senator Tate is pretending is the problem, I have an amendment. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 5, page 2, after paragraph (1)(f), insert the following paragraph:
"(fa) video material that is not to be viewed by persons under the age of 18 years; or
That can be the M rating, the milder side of M, and MA should then be video material that is not suitable to be viewed by persons under the age of 18 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I seek your guidance. Obviously, that amendment has not been circulated. May I ask: is that a new clause 5(1)(f) that Senator Walters has just read out? It seems to be exactly the same as existing clause 5(1)(f). Will there be some subsequent renumbering of paragraphs in clause 5? It would be very useful if we could get a hold of that amendment to see exactly what it does define. I have to say that already I think there are a lot of unintended consequences of this Bill. Senator Lees has raised a very important one.
—The biggest unintended consequence is that you wish the Prime Minister hadn't opened his mouth in the first place.

—That is the most useless non sequitur I have ever heard. I have no idea what it means. We are getting to the stage now where amendments are being moved, and this Bill has all the potential to have unattended consequences that intrude on the privacy of people. For example, I have yet to receive an answer to the query I made and that Senator Crowley made about whether it is illegal to actually make your own home video under 4(a) or 4(b) or 4(c) and, when you make it, to give it to other consenting adults to look at. Does that become illegal under clause 5(4)(d)—which states that it is illegal to distribute, not just for money but illegal to give it to somebody else to look at?

PARA.TAB: These are the unintended consequences. I cannot imagine the Australian public putting up with the idea of someone dobbing somebody else in to say, `Did you know that Mr and Mrs Smith made a home video of themselves making love and they gave it to Mr and Mrs Jones next door, close friends, and they can now be charged and suffer a penalty up to $10,000 each?'

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that that is a red herring.

—It is not a red herring. These unintended consequences always arise when people have a censorial view about how they want to control the attitudes of society. That is exactly what they want. What does clause 4(c) mean? It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Sexual manipulation alone or between consenting adults.

Is sexual manipulation actually defined as manipulating your own sexual organ or someone else's sexual organ, or is it psychological sexual manipulation? The definition is so broad that lawyers will make a fortune out of this for years to come. These are the unintended consequences that I and others are willing to raise with Senator Walters. I do not do so to filibuster. If this Bill were passed here and went to the House of Representatives, I would bet the Sydney Harbour Bridge to two bob that Senator Walters would end up with a mess on her hands. People, ordinary decent citizens, would be charged. Senator Walters may enjoy that, but they would see it as an absolute invasion of their privacy. Senator Walters has drafted a Bill so widely—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate having expired, I shall leave the chair and report progress.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.
Debate resumed from 15 October, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendment and new clauses to be moved to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 contains a number of fairly minor amendments and a very major amendment, which was the subject of debate earlier today. The purpose of the very major amendment is to stymie the efforts of Premier Kennett in Victoria, who inherited and is attempting to rectify probably one of the worst economies this country has ever seen. This action has been described in various ways by various commentators. It was described as a `pay back Paul' action—in other words, a pay back by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to people such as John Halfpenny who assisted and supported him when he politically assassinated Mr Hawke.

PARA.TAB: First, I will touch on the minor amendments. The first amendment relates to proposed new section 202. This amendment to the Act seeks to improve the current provisions permitting agreements between State and Federal unions. There is scope for Federal unions to treat as their own members of a State union and also provision for further amalgamation of unions at the Federal level. It is interesting that this Government, while talking about ILO conventions, has spent millions of dollars of taxpayers' money supporting the amalgamation of small unions and forcing them to become big unions. The threat was, `If you don't, you will no longer survive'. The ILO has subsequently found that not to be in accordance with its conventions.

The amendment to section 299 is another attempt to give the Industrial Relations Commission the power to punish people for contempt of court. This follows the loss by the Government in the High Court in the case of Nationwide News v. Wills. The court found that the Commission had the power to prevent fair criticism of its decisions or practices. The new provision is in the same terms as that used for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. We will oppose this amendment when we come to the committee stage of the Bill.

I now turn to the more substantive Government amendments which appeared in the Senate chamber only today. There was no explanatory memorandum or second reading speech. This is the first time since I have been in the Parliament that we have been treated in such an arrogant way. It seems to reflect the Government's panic and agenda to rush this Bill through more for political reasons than any other reason. It is simply to satisfy the whims of the infamous Victorian Trades Hall Council.
What are these amendments all about? They have been summed up very well by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry in its most recent review as:

SPEECH.PARA: "Government of the unions, by the unions, for the unions. If the unions want something, they get it; if they don't want something to happen then it doesn't happen".

When the chips are down, this Labor Government—the political arm of the trade union movement—is prepared to sacrifice productivity and employment to protect its masters, the leaders of the trade union movement.

PARA.TAB: Just as this Labor Government and the trade union bosses who run the show have, after 10 years, reduced Australia to almost a Third World status, approaching the white trash of Asia, so too has the pack of Labor financial vandals and the Victorian Trades Hall Council destroyed the Victorian economy. They reduced what was the financial and manufacturing centre of Australia to a basket case in a short period of 10 years. At the recent election, the people of Victoria threw those people out because Labor and the Trades Hall Council had wrecked their State.

In today's Australian Financial Review, John Stone stated that Victoria appeared to be, quite surprisingly, the only relatively bright spot in Australia's economic future—that is, because of the reforms that were being introduced—and that Mr Keating has now moved to rub out that one relatively bright spot. He has moved to kill it off before it has even begun—the most courageous move we have seen in decades—the process of labour market deregulation which holds the principal, though of course not the only key, to becoming competitive. That is what it is all about.

The unions will not accept the democratic vote of the Victorians that they are no longer in control. The ACCI review notes that the Victorian Trades Hall Council is renowned throughout Australia for its mindless militancy and for the way it spent the last decade in stifling any attempts to improve the efficiency of Victoria's massively inefficient public sector. What the Federal arm of the unions, the Labor Government, is now doing with this legislation is helping the most backward looking union movement in Australia, and that is saying something.

This Government could not care less about the unemployed. We have asked question after question in the Senate this week about what this Government, which caused the unemployment and which was responsible for the biggest recession since the Depression, was doing about it. All we got from Senator Button were absolutely evasive answers, with some sort of kindergarten humour thrown in. It is not a matter to be treated so lightly. As I said, this Government could not care about the unemployed, the vacant shops or the enormous debt inherited by the Kennett Government, which, if recent reports are true, could be as high as some $3 billion.

For years, expenditure has exceeded revenue under Labor. Labor just kept borrowing to make up the difference. How irresponsible can one be? This Government has brought in amendments to the Industrial Relations Act which, if passed by this Parliament, will, with certainty, be subject to challenge after challenge in the High Court. The lawyers will have a field day. This legislation will be challenged because it takes away the rights of the States to control their affairs. Section 51(xxv) of the Federal Constitution states:

SPEECH.PARA: 51.The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to:-

PARA.TAB: (xxxv.)Conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes extending beyond the limits of any one State:

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, it was always clear when this Constitution was written that the States would have certain control over their own destiny and that the Federal Government would have other controls.

PARA.TAB: However, the Government says, `Don't worry too much about that'. I think Mr Keating himself said, `Let's not run all this democracy stuff too far'. They are not the words of a good leader; they are the words of a dictator. They are dictatorial words. The Government says, `Don't you worry about that; we will invoke the external affairs powers because of an ILO convention'. This particular piece of legislation does not relate to the external affairs powers but it does raise a lot of questions about constitutional validity.

Senator Cook talks about giving workers a choice. Who does Senator Cook think he is fooling? Those people in the real world are aware of what he is saying. In the compulsory union membership closed shop the workers have the same choice as workers had in Russia and Eastern Europe before their economic systems inevitably collapsed. What Senator Cook is really saying is that by whatever means, even by the dubious use of external affairs powers, he, Prime Minister Keating and the Labor Government will protect the power of a handful of trade union bullies.

Senator Cook paints an hysterical picture of employers maltreating their employees—notwithstanding the fact that 60 per cent of employees in the private sector in Victoria already work under an informal workplace program. They work under informal workplace agreements. It is the same sort of percentage throughout Australia. So the sort of untruthful hysteria we saw before the Victorian State election is now being carried over into the Federal scene.

This change in Victoria sticks in the craw of the trade unions because this is the productive sector of the Australian economy. The contractors, subcontractors and tradesmen are not only more productive but also, as a result, enjoy higher earnings. That is what the problem is. Why is it that in closed shops there is a pathological antagonism to contractors being brought on site? Anyone who has had any experience in this field will know that that is the case. Why is it that there are still signs on these closed shop sites which say `no ticket, no job'? Is that freedom? Is that the freedom that we expect in this country? The reason for it is to coerce those who do not want to pay protection money and reduce their productivity. Australians wonder why we cannot economically produce the goods that people want to buy in Australia and why it is more attractive to establish industries offshore!

I have said over and over again in this place that wage rates per se are not the problem in Australia. Our wages are less than half of Japanese wages. It is all to do with restrictive work practices and featherbedding forced on business in more affluent times. Those affluent times, sadly, are a thing of the past. The only way we are going to get out of the sorry mess that has been brought upon us by the actions of this Government is to work our way out of it. There is no option; there are no simple solutions.

As every sensible person knows, those days have long since gone. Those antediluvians in the trade unions, particularly in Victoria, either do not know what they are doing or, if they do know what they are doing, are guilty of sabotaging Australia. They have on their hands the blood of those million fellow Australians who have either lost their jobs or cannot get jobs. Why cannot those people and this Labor Government understand that by becoming more productive we will create more jobs?

There is an old-fashioned idea among those people. I have had discussions with them in the past and they have said to me that under no circumstances will they ever trade increases in wages for productivity increases. When I have asked them, `For goodness sake, why, in a competitive world do you take that old-fashioned view?', they say, `If we go down that route there will be fewer people employed', or, in the case of resource type industries, `It will reduce the life of the operations'. Mr Acting Deputy President, have you ever heard anything so archaic? Is it any wonder that Australia has the problems it has?

I will give a few examples of the hundreds of crazy work practices which have brought us to where we are and which, if allowed to continue, will destroy us. I will give only a handful of examples that have come to my notice in recent days. Firstly, a 38-hour pay week is actually a 32-hour work week. That is the common response one gets when one asks people what effect restrictive practices have on them. Secondly, painting subcontractors who go into a closed shop union site are allowed to carry only one tin of paint at a time or they are all out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to dinner, I was giving some examples of the sorts of restrictive work practices which still exist but which really should belong to the last century, particularly in view of the economic conditions that confront the country today. I mentioned two examples, and I will give two other examples of what happens where there is a totally closed shop. Of course, in this respect, one of the worst industries in Australia today continues to be the building and construction industry.
—And the lawyers and the doctors.

—Tilers who have to walk over concrete laid by a union are required to wear steel-capped boots and a hard hat. Having negotiated a metre or two of laid concrete, they are free to remove the gear, which was not necessary in the first place. This has the effect of the good contractors or subcontractors refusing to go on sites to do that sort of work. We have building unions which declare a site a construction site and then collect union dues from employers for any of their employees on the site. Once they get the money, they go. It is really nothing more than the type of protection money that is more reminiscent of the mafia style operation in the United States.

PARA.TAB: In answer to a dorothy dix question in this chamber the other day, Senator Cook raised an agreement offered by Copperart to its employees. He gave it as a shining example of what is already happening in Victoria. When it was pointed out to him that it was a voluntary agreement, that it was offered Australia-wide, and that the employees would be better off by around $40 a week, what happened? Senator Cook's heavy union mates in Victoria picketed the Chadstone store of Copperart and prevented staff and customers from entering that shop. That is not the way to get Australia out of its mess. It is a way to continue down the road to disaster. Is that what Senator Cook and Mr Keating mean when they say that they want to give people a choice? Some choice! The threat is: `Either do as we say, or we will destroy you'. Very regrettably, in many cases it works.

Often, I hear employers singled out for criticism. Maybe some of it is justified; I do not know. But it is very easy for people to sit in their armchairs while heavy-handed techniques are used against employers, and to then criticise employers when they give in. But in many instances, by not giving in, employers are sowing the seeds of their own destruction. They also feel very helpless in that they cannot do anything about it. I do not believe this is the sort of free, democratic society that Australia wants. Of course it is not. But it is the sort of society we will have if the unions and Labor are permitted to be above the law. That has been the major problem.

One of the major concerns of the more militant unions in Australia about the coalition's Jobsback package is that it entrenches voluntary unionism. It gives people the freedom to decide whether they do or do not want to join a trade union, or any other organisation—to pick up Senator Ray's earlier interjection—whether it be lawyers, doctors or anyone else.

The coalition Fightback and Jobsback plans are about providing real jobs—jobs which have been lost because of the policies of the unelected government, the unions—and its agents here in the Labor Government. It is about giving individuals the freedom to decide whether or not they want to be in a union. It is about giving them the choice to negotiate workplace agreements with or without the union movement. I should make that very clear, because that is certainly part of the Jobsback program. It will be the choice of individuals as to whether or not they wish to have the assistance of the union movement.

It is about increased productivity, so that more jobs are available. Without increased productivity—earlier today I mentioned the example of the coalmining industry—and while wage increases are greater than productivity, it is inevitable that we will see the continued demise of our industries. This will not happen to just the industries themselves. I know that people tend to look on these issues as being somewhat remote unless they are involved but, with the demise of industries, we get job losses—and, regrettably, those jobs get lost forever.

It is about improving our balance of payments so that we export more and produce more of the goods in Australia that people want to buy. It is about reducing our foreign debt, which now stands at around $9,000 for every man, woman and child. The Industry Commission pointed out in its annual report:

SPEECH.PARA: Over a million Australians are unemployed or too discouraged to look for work. The economic and social cost is enormous.

I see that I am about to run out of time. I will make the remark that, in accordance with the agreement reached with both the Labor Party and the Democrats, at the end of second reading stage I will move that this Bill be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for further consideration.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator McMullan) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator McMullan)—by leave—agreed to:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1)That the order of the Senate of 15 October 1992, referring the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits Tax Measures) Bill 1992 and the Tax Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration after the bills are read a second time, be altered to refer the bills to the committee immediately.
(2)That the committee present its report on or before 15 December 1992.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is difficult to know where to begin with this matter, because it has been claimed by some people that we cannot possibly be prepared to expose our position with regard to the principles that are involved in this amendment proposition. Yet, over the past year that I have had carriage of industrial relations matters on behalf of the Democrats, regular contributions to the industrial relations debate have appeared in all of our national media, from both major parties. Essentially, we have seen an exposition of the conflicting theories that have been proposed by those major parties.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats have contributed to that debate. I have shared platforms in the debate with Mr Howard, I have shared platforms with Mr Laurie Ferguson and I have also contributed in media discussions, both of the type involving a couple of representatives from the other parties and also in the third-party style of media discussion where one position is given and, a few hours later, a retort is given from another position.

To depict this debate as being fresh, as being a few hours old, and as requiring further detail to arrive at a conclusion, is to be dishonest, because the whole of Australia is aware that discussion is in full flight and that the positions of the major parties are well and truly being taken. A week ago, I issued a press release which set out quite clearly the position of the Democrats with regard to this aspect of the industrial relations debate. In that press release, I stated that the Democrats:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . welcomed the announcement by the Prime Minister and Senator Cook that the federal government will introduce legislation to facilitate the ability of the federal industrial relations commission to hear state cases of industrial dispute.
I followed that by saying:

Since the first hints of the Coalition's IR program, I have consistently expressed concern that there has not been sufficient explanation of the mechanism by which minimum standards could be altered in the future. With the removal of the jurisdiction of the Victorian IRC, the only vehicle for altering basic wage rates in Victoria would be the Liberal Cabinet!

I have described that as a very centralised wage fixing mechanism. I also think it is a very limited and not transparent wage fixing system. One of the advantages of our industrial relations commissions is that interested parties and those who are directly concerned present their cases in a forum which can be attended by media representatives and exposed to the public. The proceedings of the Liberal Cabinet are somewhat more restricted. My concerns in that area have not been discounted by any communications we have received subsequently.

PARA.TAB: I have the advantage—a dubious advantage I sometimes think—of living in the State of Tasmania which is often used as a microcosm or experimental test tube with regard to a number of practices. In the past we have been very proud of some educational initiatives which have taken place in Tasmania and have been used as models elsewhere.

In Tasmania in the last several months we have experienced such a program with regard to industrial relations. For the edification of listeners who are not regular subscribers to the Hobart Mercury—I suggest that might be quite a few people; but it is well read in Tasmania and it depicts the situation as it is—I will quote extensively from its editorial of 3 December this year. I apologise for the length of the quote, but it expresses the situation quite well. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Teachers, firefighters, police, prison officers and state workers under clerical awards have logic and equity on their side in their argument that they should be paid as much as their counterparts in other States.

PARA.TAB: Equity and logic, however, will come at a cost.
The majority of teachers in the state schools system this week were awarded salary rises by the Tasmanian Industrial Commission to give them parity with mainland pay rates.
Other state workers, including TAFE teachers, have signalled their intention to press for parity. They will be buoyed by the success of the teachers, and of Tasmania's nurses in 1986.

In that year, the State Government, which was headed by Mr Robin Gray, joined with the nurses in a consent award to pay national standard salaries after the profession was granted substantial pay rises through the Tasmanian Industrial Commission in 1985.
The nursing award is particularly ironic in the light of present events.
Concern has been expressed by the State Government that the Federal Government may devise ways of circumventing the industrial relations reforms of Tasmania and Victoria.
Both Victoria and Tasmania believe that federal interference is unwarranted.

SPEECH.PARA: I presume the editorial means that the Victorian and Tasmanian governments believe that Federal interference is unwarranted. The editorial continues:
Yet in 1986, the Tasmanian Liberal Government took the nursing salaries dispute away from the State Industrial Commission and asked for a federal ruling. It is a move which, in hindsight, it may rue.

PARA.TAB: There are strong arguments for providing parity with interstate wages and salaries. It takes as much effort and skill to teach in Tasmania, to police in Tasmania, and to fight fires in Tasmania, as it does in other states.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that such an observation is enlightening with regard to what is happening in Victoria. I apologise for referring to the metropolitan daily newspaper in Hobart, but I believe that the reporting of occurrences there can shed considerable light on what could eventuate in other States. The Tasmanian Liberal Government has decided that it will take to the Tasmanian workforce a reform agenda which is somewhat a mirror of proposals we have seen elsewhere. But, then again, we wonder whether that is the case. An article in the Mercury of 8 December reports on the fruition of this policy. It states:

PARA.TAB: The Building, Construction and Maintenance Division workers have known since August their jobs would go before Christmas, and most reacted with surprising calm when the axe finally fell.
But several could not contain their indignation and made their feelings known to the management representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The article quotes union official Mr Steven Royel, who said outside the Prince of Wales Bay depot of the Department of Construction:

PARA.TAB: "This is a bloody disgrace—people turn up to do a morning's work and they're sacked,

SPEECH.PARA: He is quoted again as saying:

PARA.TAB: "This is a taste of industrial relations we're going to get in the future. They're treating us like criminals.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that we need to look at what is happening in Tasmania, where that Department has been rendered ineffective by the State Government's actions.

PARA.TAB: At least the Government in Tasmania could not be accused of not having telegraphed its intentions before the State election. The Victorian Government stands accused of not having described adequately its intentions before its election. I will not purse that point; I just remark in passing that at least the Tasmanian Government gave some strong hints as to its intentions.

However, even though those intentions were telegraphed, we see repeated evidence of confusion which the electors have found very hard to sort out. The electors in Tasmania, who were given some indication as to the Government's policies, are still faced with confusion when it comes to their application. They are faced with this confusion because they are getting conflicting messages from both the serving Liberal Government and spokespersons for the coalition in the Federal sphere.

There is no better example than the recent APPM dispute in Burnie. I suppose this dispute is not so recent as I first thought; it seems recent because it burns in our memories, but it happened several months ago now. I expect that most people would remember that the State Premier, Mr Ray Groom, entered the debate offering himself as a solution seeker. He was conciliatory in his approach, seeing merit in the arguments that were being presented by the unions, the workers and also the company. He offered himself as a chairperson of the dispute.

However, Mr John Howard suggested from afar that politicians should `butt out'. Then Dr Hewson supported the company's position and espoused the values which had been expressed by the company. A plethora of local Liberal representatives at both Federal and State level represented the full spectrum of opinions about the dispute. Mr Howard then met with company representatives, or at least participants in the dispute—so much for butting out.

One can hardly blame the Tasmanian populous for being confused about exactly where their industrial relations future lies and exactly where the policies of those people who represent the coalition will go. This confusion has been stoked further. I refer again to a report from the Hobart Mercury which paints a good picture of what is going on in our southernmost State.

It may seem as though this article from the Mercury of Wednesday 9 December is concerned only with the precious Fightback proposal, but it also looks directly at the industrial relations aspect. The article, written by Mr Michael Lester, reads in part:

Both the Premier, Ray Groom, and the Minister for Resources and Energy, Robin Gray, initially questioned the federal Liberal suggestion that the proposed abolition of state payroll tax and its replacement with Commonwealth funds would create jobs.
They pointed out that rather than use the extra money to hire more people, some employers would just pocket the cash.

And the Minister for Tourism, Peter Hodgman, has given his support to industry concerns that the proposed GST might hurt the tourism industry—especially by discouraging overseas visitors to Australia.
Now Mr Groom, at least publicly, is strongly selling the expected benefits of the Fightback package.

SPEECH.PARA: Here is where the confusion is perpetuated. The article continues:

PARA.TAB: The State Government, which has introduced its own industrial-relations legislation, has gone to great lengths to distance itself from the industrial-relations policies announced by federal Liberal Leader, John Hewson, and the Liberal spokesman for industrial relations, John Howard, as part of Fightback.

SPEECH.PARA: No wonder the confusion of the Tasmanian electors continues. We really cannot get to the bottom of it. It is not just the fault of the most significant piece of printed media in Hobart; it is confusion which we see being demonstrated daily by those who speak on behalf of the Liberal side of politics.

PARA.TAB: I would suggest that the interpretations given in that article with regard to what is proposed here today are just as confusing. We have heard from that spectrum of politics the interpretation of today's proposition as being intervention. I do not see it that way at all. I do not interpret it as being intervention. I would suggest that the spectrum of opinions which emanate from the Opposition could not really be trusted to correctly interpret what it is.

This amendment will have the effect of ensuring that all Australians in uniformity continue to have a right of access to arbitration. A State government should not be able to override that right. A State government should not be able to ensure that certain individuals are disadvantaged and others not. There should be a uniformity of rights, obligations and privileges across Australia.

When faced with the confusion and the uncertainty which pervade the propositions from the coalition, I could not blame anybody for voting to stick with the uniformity that is offered by having Federal oversight. I started off by reading from the Hobart Mercury where logic is proposed as a reason for agreeing with the Government. We understand the principles being proposed here. We support the principle that all Australians should have access to dispute settling mechanisms at the Federal level; in other words, arbitration.

I foreshadow that the Democrats will be moving an amendment in the committee stage. This amendment proposes that the IRC will ensure that secret ballots have taken place, where appropriate and practicable, to give participants in a potential Federal award the opportunity to state their opinion without duress and without intimidation. For a long time the Democrats have strongly believed that the mechanism offered by a secret ballot is fundamental to industrial democracy and that democracy is well served by such a mechanism. In fact, it is a fundamental part of our own Party's organisation.

I would also address the fact that Senator Powell has distributed some amendments in her name. Whilst lengthy, those amendments are quite clear. Earlier in the debate today it was suggested that somehow or other Senator Powell had had privileged access to the Bill and therefore was able to prepare 10 pages of amendments. I suggest that Senator Powell, like me, has been able to understand the thrust of the Bill and the principles involved—I am guessing here but I think I am correct—and prepared these amendments in advance.
Senator Powell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Powell that the concept was available months ago. I acknowledge the existence of those amendments and foreshadow our agreement with them. The discussion at this second reading debate level should not involve much more than identifying the course that we should take. I see no point in speaking any further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) have hijacked democracy with the foreshadowing today of major amendments to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, which was originally introduced in this place on 15 October by Senator Bolkus representing the Minister. It was then a portfolio Bill which originally sought to make amendments to six Acts and make consequential technical amendments to several other Acts. Today, with these last minute amendments to directly attack the much needed industrial reforms initiated by the newly elected Kennett Liberal-National Government in Victoria, this Bill now becomes highly controversial and of major importance.
—And they had a mandate for that.

—As Senator Kemp says, the Victorian Government has introduced that legislation with a mandate. It is a gross abuse of the parliamentary process to proceed with the second reading debate on these major amendments before the Opposition has been given adequate time to study, analyse and consider them. It is not possible for the Opposition to do that when only the Senate and not the House of Representatives is sitting. The introduction of this legislation today is a travesty of reasonable operation of this Parliament, and it is certainly a travesty of good government.

PARA.TAB: It completely destroys any criticism that this Government might make of the speed with which the industrial reforms passed through the Victorian Parliament. Not only is this Labor Government treating this Parliament with contempt but it is also treating all of the State governments and their Premiers with contempt. The communique issued at the end of Monday's Premiers Conference, now known as the Council of Australian Governments, clearly stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth confirmed that the States and Territories will be given the opportunity to examine and comment on the legislation before it was introduced.

Most State governments only saw this legislation when we did—early yesterday—and were given only until last night to provide comments. No-one in his right mind could regard that as an adequate and reasonable degree of consultation between the Commonwealth and the States.

PARA.TAB: In particular, the Victorian Government has had no real chance to consider the detail of the legislation. Meanwhile, the New South Wales Government has not even had the opportunity to obtain comments from its Crown Solicitor on the amendments. The New South Wales Government has formally objected to the undemocratic, unnecessary haste in having this legislation debated today. I quote from that Government's letter to Senator Cook last night:

I would like to convey to you the New South Wales Government's concerns, not only with the general nature of the proposed amendments . . . but also with the speed at which the proposed amendments are being introduced into Parliament.
Such haste severely limits both reasonable discussion of the issues involved and a full examination of the (perhaps unintended) consequences of such legislative action.

SPEECH.PARA: We know all about unintended consequences of legislation from earlier disasters that this Government has introduced. The letter goes on:

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I reiterate the New South Wales Government's strong view that the proposed legislation should not be progressed at this time to allow further reasoned debate on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: It is typical of the arrogance of this Prime Minister, this Minister and this Federal Labor Government that they are proceeding with this legislation immediately, notwithstanding all of these objections.
