The new grand plan of Prime Minister Keating seeks to amend the Industrial Relations Act to encourage the Industrial Relations Commission to allow workers to move across to the Federal award system.

PARA.TAB: The Minister is ultimately seeking to alter the Act to provide access to the Federal system for workers who do not have access to a tribunal with compulsory arbitration powers; for example, the 800,000 or so Victorian workers currently paid under State awards. So we now have before us a series of fresh, highly publicised amendments to the original amending Bill which basically seek to ride roughshod over the sovereignty of States and, in particular, to subvert Victorian Premier Kennett's essential new economic reforms by providing an escape route for Victorian workers to the Federal award system.

There are three main amendments to which the coalition is implacably opposed. The first deals with the installation of a mechanism allowing Victorian workers to move into the Federal arena and away from the Kennett legislation. The structure of this amendment to section 111 of the Industrial Relations Act presents a constitutional problem in seeking to insert a new paragraph `to facilitate access to conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and prompt settlement of industrial disputes'.

This is not only a direct steal from section 51(35) of the Australian Constitution, but a fraudulent steal, because it conveniently—for the Government and its union masters—leaves out the key words from the Constitution, `extending beyond the limits of any one State'. This empowers the Industrial Relations Commission with an excessive degree of flexibility to which the coalition is opposed.

The three amendments relating to section 111 of the Industrial Relations Act, which spells out the particular powers of the Commission, are opposed outright by the coalition. The first amendment substitutes `arbitrator' for `State authority' in this subclause, which gives the bases on which the Industrial Relations Commission may dismiss a matter brought before it. One of those bases is that the matter has been dealt with by a State industrial authority. This will circumvent the role of Victoria's new Employees Relations Commission.

The Victorian Employees Relations Commission will be made irrelevant from the Industrial Relations Commission's viewpoint because, although the Victorian Commission is an industrial authority, it is not a compulsory arbitration body. In other words, the path will be clear for the Federal Industrial Relations Commission to exercise power in relation to Victorian employees, irrespective of decisions in relation to those employees by the Victorian Employees Relations Commission.

The second amendment to this section 111 removes, in States which have abandoned compulsory arbitration, from the Industrial Relations Commission the capacity to dismiss a matter where further proceedings are not in the public interest. Again, this is directed squarely at the new Victorian industrial relations system. In fact, it totally removes one of the major grounds on which employers can approach the Commission. The Government is placing its own political interests and the interests of union power ahead of the public interest.

The third amendment fails to define what constitutes `reasonable steps' and `consultation' whereby employees can be hijacked by trade unions into the Federal system. It does not provide for it to be necessary for members of a particular union to reach agreement that they want to come under a Federal award, hence any union could override a real choice in the workplace whereby employees decided to stay out of the Federal system.

The final amendment to clause 6 of the Bill adds to section 308 of the Act, and is just as outrageous as the preceding ones. It compels an employer organisation to deliver notification of the resignation of any of its members—that is, any individual firms—to the Registrar of the Industrial Relations Commission and any relevant union. This blatantly provides unions with the knowledge that an employer has left the jurisdiction of the Federal system. A penalty of $500 applies if these conditions are not met within 28 days.

This highlights the one-sided nature of this legislation. The amendment will maximise the opportunities for unions to rope employers back into the Federal system. The law should not give them this free kick, especially in a way which subjects employers to fines. The coalition is, therefore, absolutely opposed to the passage of this legislation. It is obvious that this Bill seeks to interfere with the free choice of Victorian workers to enter into workplace agreements free from the limitations of a centralised system of compulsory arbitration.

But it is not only the sovereignty and jurisdiction of the Victorian Government which is threatened by this legislation. In the letter from the NSW Government to Senator Cook last night, to which I referred earlier, notwithstanding its lack of time for adequate consideration, New South Wales expressed a number of preliminary concerns about the impact of the Bill on its State—not on its supposed target, Victoria, but on New South Wales. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: On any reading of the proposed changes, however, they represent an unwarranted challenge to the New South Wales Government's right to undertake effective administration of this State.
Among specific concerns raised by New South Wales are as follows:
Public sector chief executive service (CES) and senior executive service (SES) officers have no access to the NSW Industrial Relations Commission.
. . . problems with the operation of individual CES and SES contracts are only referable to a SES grievance mediator, who has no arbitral powers.
. . . under the proposed Federal legislation—
which we are debating this evening—

terms and conditions of employment of CES and SES officers would not be considered to be subject to compulsory arbitration or regulated by an employment agreement. Therefore, such officers could become subject to Federal award coverage. . .
Similarly, the Northern Territory Government has expressed concern about this legislation. It said:

It is therefore clearly within the interests of the Territory that the Commonwealth proposal be opposed as it would represent a significant loss of identity for the States and Territories. From the particular viewpoint of the Territory it would have a significant impact on the direction we might wish to take in relation to industrial relations should statehood be achieved at some later date.

So it can be seen that this legislation is opposed, not just by Victoria but by other States as well. The legislation is nothing more than a blatant political manoeuvre by the Prime Minister to significantly expand the Federal arbitration system. It has wide ramifications which will, therefore, be felt far beyond the immediate Victorian situation which it claims to be attempting to circumvent. I have just demonstrated how wide the concern is.

PARA.TAB: The legislation is a minefield, both for unions and for employers. If the amendments are implemented, the comfortable demarcation zone which now exists between Federal and State industrial relations systems will undoubtedly suffer fall-out. While one national system of industrial relations may suit some employers who operate as national businesses, the system would prove a nightmare for those many largely independent, but State based, operators.

Prime Minister Keating's recent comments that his Government's new legislation will create an opportunity for a return to industrial peace, will give recovery the best possible chance and will provide the best climate for continuing essential reform of the labour market is utter nonsense. What this legislation will do, if it is passed, is pass sentence on every Australian so that he or she is doomed to more political gamesmanship from a government that will obviously stop at nothing to remain in power.

The Labor Government has no principles left with which to woo the voter. It is now totally devoid of integrity, and certainly no-one will trust it after this blatant manoeuvre which is 90 per cent political and 10 per cent industrial. These amendments represent an unprecedented extension of Federal power into State and employer responsibilities, and are an interference of the first order.

The legislation is a direct threat to the sovereignty and independence of States and, what is more, it is a threat launched by an unelected Prime Minister, heading a tired and failed government on the way out, against a newly elected Premier with a fresh mandate for reform. No wonder even Keating's mates, the few remaining Labor State Premiers, expressed reservations about this jackboot approach to the States, despite their sympathy for Labor's approach to industrial relations.

At last Monday's Premiers Conference which, as I said earlier, is now called the Council of Australian Governments, the Premiers were particularly concerned about yet a further extension of the use by the Federal Government of its external affairs power under the Constitution. They are obviously not used to Prime Minister Keating's misleading statements and backflips. No wonder his media statement that the legislation would proceed immediately caused mayhem at the conference because the Premiers clearly understood that the Prime Minister had made a commitment to extended consultation through a working party which would defer the legislation until some time next year.

The Premiers have now learnt what we in opposition have long known, and what I trust the Australian people in the lead-up to the Federal election fully understand, and that is that we cannot trust this Prime Minister. All I can say to them as individuals, as must be said to the States, is that they should be warned about the threat to their own sovereignty. It is no wonder that major employer groups have united and vowed to fight this legislation. A coalition of seven peak employer bodies, representing about 75 per cent of Victoria's 180,000 employers, has today promised court challenges and vigorous workplace action in a bid to thwart the Keating Government's attempts to circumvent the Victorian Government's reforms.

This Labor Government's attempts to portray itself as a saviour of workers' rights in Victoria, as a champion of employees in that State and a custodian of Victoria's economic recovery are reprehensible. The moves are grossly detrimental to the country's attempts to move forward. We are already stuck, thanks to Prime Minister Keating's Labor Government's handing to Australia over one million unemployed—and as today's figure of 11.4 per cent confirms, that number of unemployed is continuing to rise—with sluggish growth and a massive foreign debt.

The Victorian Premier's economic and workplace reform strategies would have set the pace to drag Victorians out of their economic misery. Therefore, the steps by Labor to circumvent these proposals represent total contempt, not just for Premier Kennett and his mandate for growth, change and strength, but for all the Victorians who voted for him. No-one disputes that the previous decade of Labor government in Victoria was punished vehemently by a distressed electorate for the savage depression in which it had left all Victorians. The Victorians' wish for a fresh, unsullied government resulted in the election landslide which brought Jeff Kennett to power. His mandate is not in the least reduced by this cheap political action, first by John Halfpenny and now by the Prime Minister. Victorians do not want their Government denied manoeuvring room when dealing with their State's economic malaise. The Victorian coalition Government inherited a total economic mess, which it is attempting to set to rights. The recent posturings by the Federal Government have been set in train only to hinder and hamper that process as much as possible.

Clearly, the recent days of industrial action in Victoria and elsewhere have been dismal failures. If Victorians believe that the Prime Minister's intervention can delay them facing the reality of their barren economy, they are seriously mistaken and completely out of touch with the disastrous nature of Labor's earlier mismanagement. If Victoria is to regain its competitive edge that Labor destroyed, create jobs and assist in the restoration of confidence and living standards, labour costs must drop.

The amendments proposed by Senator Cook seek simply to postpone these necessary reforms indefinitely. That will slow down the pace of essential economic reform. Unless labour market reforms are introduced as a matter of urgency, as Premier Kennett has sought to do, the future of this country as a serious competitor on world markets must be brought into question. Under this legislation, gone will be the steps already taken to regain that urgently needed edge.

The Prime Minister has made a mockery of his own One Nation statement, claiming that the Government will bring back jobs and prosperity. Only this week, leading labour market expert, Professor Judy Sloan, the Director of the National Institute of Labour Studies, slated the Federal Government's industrial relations reform program as a disgrace. She has produced evidence showing that the work force has become more rather than less regulated over the past decade. She dismissed the key elements of the Labor Government's industrial reforms, saying the process of change in the Labor market was `circuitous, risky and costly'.

Rebutting Labor's propaganda that the labour market has become more flexible over the past decade, Professor Sloan has established that the cost of hiring labour increased from 10.3 per cent of total earnings in 1989-90 to more than 12 per cent the following year. This is a big jump in costs over a short period and does not include the cost of the superannuation guarantee charge. Professor Sloan especially attacked section 134 of the Act, under which only a certified trade union can make an enterprise agreement. With only 40 per cent of the work force unionised, the Australian people as a whole would never support this if given a direct say in the legislation. So it transpires that under this Government the system of industrial relations is flexible only as long as the powers that be agree on the terms of the flexibility. The process itself is retarding change, with only 5 per cent of the work force, or 300 agreements, having been struck under section 134.

The major purpose of this legislation is to attempt to give the Labor Party some perception of political advantage by allowing it to misrepresent the industrial relations policies of the Federal Liberal and National parties by embarking on this massive, dishonest scare campaign to encourage rejection of our Jobsback policies, which are essential if we are, as I said earlier, to make this country really competitive. It is absolutely essential that that Jobsback approach be adopted and, on the other hand, that the Labor Party's attempt at political advantage not be countenanced.

The second purpose of the legislation, of course, is to maintain the privileged position of trade unions, and in particular union leadership, and ensure that their power is not diminished as the membership of unions declines further and further. Membership of unions is now less than 30 per cent in the private sector. On all of those grounds, it is simply not possible to support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I join my colleagues in the views put before the Senate on a number of occasions today and say that I believe a matter of the importance of transferring in one fell swoop an enormous power over industrial relations from the sovereign States to the Commonwealth should be allowed significant debate in the Senate and significant consideration in committee. It should involve considerable consultation between the Commonwealth Government and the State governments over a significant period. It is a matter of enormous regret that with the incumbent Prime Minister (Mr Keating) this consultation and debate cannot take place.

PARA.TAB: In the business of politics in the 1990s, we all realise that there is an enormous imperative upon the Prime Minister to meet his own personal, grubby, short term political ends by speeding the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) through the Parliament. The more we look at what this legislation sets out to achieve, the more we come to realise that it holds within it enormous dangers for the future of Australia and for the industrial development of Australia.

I am sure that those associated with the legislation think that it is a very smart trick, that it will trip up Jeff Kennett, the Premier of Victoria, that it will stop John Halfpenny's national action, that it will stop the industrial disputes that are happening and that it will make it a little easier for the Labor Party to have some chance of winning the next Federal election. But I must say that when a Prime Minister's policy on the development of Australia, and indeed the industrial relations policy of a government, is focused not on the long term development of Australia over the next two, three, five, 10 or 50 years but on something like 10 or 12 weeks until the next election, that is when legislation deserves enormous consideration by this House of review and, of course, States House—the Senate.

This legislation will not receive proper review. We have had a very generous agreement by the Australian Democrats to refer it to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on Monday, allowing a couple of days to give notice, I presume, to constitutional lawyers and other experts in this field to come before the Committee for a one-day hearing. That will be of assistance, but this is a matter that deserves long debate in this chamber and long consideration in committee.

All of the debate in this chamber and all of the consultation promised by the Prime Minister was a charade. There will be no consultation; we have seen that. He promised in Perth on Monday that there would be consultation. Yet the legislation is in the chamber today and there has been no consultation. So that was another one of the Prime Minister's classic examples of saying one thing and doing the opposite. People have a term for that, but it is unparliamentary. It has been used too often in this Parliament during the week and I will not repeat it. Probably a `demonstrable untruth' is the parliamentary term to describe it under the current ruling of the President.

The reason why the debate here is almost sadly irrelevant is that this piece of legislation will end up in the High Court within a few months. Just as this Government's provisions to ban political broadcasting ended up in the High Court and were swept aside ignominiously by the High Court, and just as this Government's attempts to centralise corporations laws unconstitutionally were swept aside by the High Court only a couple of years ago, this Industrial Relations Bill, and these amendments we are debating tonight, will be challenged in the High Court by the States currently governed by Liberal governments. I would not be surprised to see them challenged by Labor governments, specifically the governments of Western Australia—if that is a Labor government in a couple of months time—and Queensland, which will of course be a Labor Government during the next year. We expect this law to be challenged.

I want to spend the remaining time I have tonight suggesting to the Senate why this law is constitutionally corrupt. The short term political motives of the Prime Minister and his Industrial Relations Minister, Senator Cook, in bringing this legislation forward are disgraceful and deserve the utter contempt of the electorate and all those involved in industrial relations in any way whatsoever, be it a young Australian starting out on his or her first job, or a hardened shop steward on a factory floor. I thought John Stone put it quite well in today's Australian Financial Review when he said:
The terrible reality is that in Canberra today we have in The Lodge not a parliamentarian, but a dictator. With all his faults, Mr Hawke was never that.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the reality, and that is why this legislation is before us. The constitutional matters that are before us were debated at great length back in 1891 and 1897, and the years in between, when the Constitution of Australia was debated at the original constitutional conventions.

PARA.TAB: The matter of conciliation and arbitration and whether the Federal Government should have any power at all over conciliation and arbitration were the subject of quite significant debates, mostly being a jousting match between Sir Samuel Griffith and Mr Kingston from South Australia, who was very keen to see the Federal Government have powers over industrial relations which would override the States. Over a period of six or seven years Mr Kingston actively pursed the idea of the Commonwealth having power over industrial relations matters. He was ignominiously rolled on a number of occasions and the power that the Commonwealth had in relation to industrial relations was specifically limited, as it is under section 51 (xxxv) of the Constitution, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes extending beyond the limits of any one State:
The debate over how that section read went on for years. It was a very informed debate by our very learned founding fathers of many opposing views. In the end they decided that it should be limited.

PARA.TAB: There were many views put to say why the Federal Government should not have power to intervene in the industrial affairs of a State. I thought one of the more interesting quotes, going through some of them today, was when Sir Samuel Griffith looked at the ramifications of a central power having control over the industrial affairs of all the States of Australia. I thought he must have been presuming what might happen in Victoria when he considered it. On 6 April 1891, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a question of principle. Does the hon. member mean matters of principle like that, because that might entirely depreciate the value of property in a state or drive an industry out of a state?

TALK.START.PARA: —That was 101 years ago.

—He was a man of great foresight. Sir Samuel Griffith saw that if a Federal government were to impose industrial laws upon a State that hurt that State, where the State had no control over those industrial laws, and where those laws did not match the industrial conditions in those States, then industry could indeed be driven out of that State. We can imagine that happening today. It is very popular for people to say that States' rights, the notion of sovereignty in States, the notion of having decentralised decision making is no longer popular any more and that we should have decentralised decision making. When we look at the performance of highly centralised economies across the world and highly centralised corporations in the corporate world, we see that it has been proved wrong.

PARA.TAB: The other constitutional consideration that we have before us is the reliance which we presume is upon the external affairs power—a matter which was given great debate in the constitutional debates over 100 years ago. Those who have read the constitutional debates would know that the original provision in section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution read `External affairs and treaties'. Indeed, there was great debate on whether the words `and treaties' should be included in the Constitution. The fact of the matter is that we decided to take the words `and treaties' out.

This legislation would rely on the conventions of the International Labour Organisation, the UN body on industrial relations. Again, a very distinguished founding father of Australia, the Rt Hon. G.H. Reid, on 9 September 1897, in speaking against the provision of having `and treaties' attached to the words `External affairs', said:

SPEECH.PARA: This is an expression which would be more in place in the United States Constitution, where treaties are dealt with by the President and the Senate, than in the constitution of a colony within the empire. The treaties made by her Majesty are not binding as laws on the people of the United Kingdom, and there is no penalty for disobeying them. Legislation is sometimes passed to give effect to treaties, but the treaties themselves are not laws, and indeed nations sometimes find them inconvenient, as they neglect them very seriously without involving any important legal consequences. The expression, I think, ought to be omitted. I will deal with the other suggested amendments when the time comes.

The point that the Rt Hon. G.H. Reid made so many years ago stands true today. I made the point in a debate in the Senate earlier this week that Australia will come to the unenviable position, or the stupid position, whereby we will not need parliaments because we will have international treaties and international organisations making all of the standards and passing all of the laws that we will be governed by. Indeed, we may as well just become part of the European Community and be governed by Brussels if we go down this stupid path. The Government has already admitted that in some respects our industrial laws do not abide by the conventions laid down by the ILO. We do not abide by them in relation to freedom of association and, as the current Minister for Industrial Relations points out, we do not abide by them in relation to the right to strike.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, my view—and it is not a particularly well-informed view—is that under section 51 there are a number of provisions giving the Federal Parliament power to make laws in relation to a number of aspects. I would argue that the external affairs power has had far too broad a reading by the High Court judges in the past 10 years and that it has been an absolute bastardisation of the intent of that power to apply it in a number of areas where it has been applied in the last 10 years, and certainly in relation to this area. The Constitution has quite explicitly said that the Federal Government has power to make laws in industrial relations by specifying, as it does, in section 51 (xxxv) of the Constitution:

SPEECH.PARA: Conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and settlement of disputes extending beyond the limits of any one State:
That is a quite express power which is given to the Federal Parliament and this legislation goes well and truly beyond it.

PARA.TAB: If the Government seeks to rely on that power, this legislation will be unconstitutional. If it seeks to hunt around for another head of power and chooses external affairs, I put it to the Senate that the Constitution, under section 51(xxxv), limits the power of the Federal Government in relation to industrial relations, and the Government cannot then seek to read another head of power more broadly to give itself that power.

I predict quite confidently that this legislation will be struck down by the High Court. I plead with the Australian Democrats to consider carefully whether or not they will go along again with this Federal Government's short term political plot to pass this legislation. It is the same short term political plot that it had in respect of the political broadcast legislation and the corporations law only a couple of years ago. It went to the great expense of passing these laws and then to the further great expense of having them considered by the High Court and being ignominiously thrown out by the High Court when they were proved to be wrong, as they are clearly obviously wrong, and not based on any clear constitutional foundation. I deplore the legislation and I urge the Senate to defeat it.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—I chose not to interrupt Senator Campbell during his speech, because there was no point of order taken, but it is my view that to read something into the record which is not parliamentary does not break the nexus. It is equally unparliamentary to read something as it is to describe it. I should observe that the particular expression used was `we had a dictator in the Lodge'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, with that ruling you have just taken some of my speech from me. No doubt it is a wise ruling coming from you.I really cannot contribute much further to this debate. The thoughtful, thought provoking and perceptive address by Senator Campbell really addressed all the issues in a very clear and precise way. Similarly, Senator Parer in introducing the Opposition's case on the Bill, very clearly put the case and the arguments, as did the other Liberal and National Party senators who have followed. I want very briefly—and we have been asked to be brief—to emphasise for the Government and for the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) who is in the chamber, although I see that there is no Minister in the chamber—
—I will be back in a minute.

—You are coming back, Senator Ray. There has been no leadership in the Government for the last 10 years. I do not suppose it should change now and bother to have a Minister in the chamber when these important things are being debated. Once again, the Bill will become a cause celebre in the High Court. It will, in my view, be found to be unconstitutional. We tried to warn the Government before the ad bans Bill was put through; in fact, we did warn it. It did not take any notice of us. It simply goes ahead with these things and tries to fly in the face of the Constitution. Fortunately, under our system, our Constitution, the High Court is constantly—and more often these days—pulling this Government into gear as it attempts to override the Constitution and democracy in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The question of democracy is very relevant to this Bill. It is all summed up, I suppose, by Mr Keating's thoughts on the subject. `Look', he said, `let's not run all this democracy stuff too far'. Fancy a Prime Minister saying that sort of thing! It is simply incredible, breathtaking in its arrogance, that that should be said. It was said about this particular piece of legislation. My colleague Senator Campbell quoted former Senator John Stone. In his article, former Senator Stone says:

SPEECH.PARA: In effect, Mr Keating's response—
that is, his response to this particular question of industrial relations and the Victorian Government's handling of it—
has been to say: `To hell with Victorian voters. If my ACTU mates don't like what they voted for, we are not going to allow them to have it'.

The Victorian people were in absolutely no doubt as to what Mr Kennett was proposing about what needed to be done to correct the problems in Victoria. They voted for him. They voted en masse to put in Mr Kennett and his Government and they knew that serious and quite major action had to be taken to correct those particular problems.

PARA.TAB: This Government does not seem to worry about that. This Government does not care that a Victorian election has indicated what the Victorian people want. This Government is simply going to override what the Victorian people have decided. I ask the Government again to consider the rather enormous step it is taking. It is a step that has enormous ramifications for democracy as a whole. I ask the Government to reconsider and to heed the advice of Senator Parer and his colleagues. Before I sit down, may I just say that I am again amazed at the attitude of the Australian Democrats to this particular Bill. They will no doubt be supporting the Government—

TALK.START.PARA: —They have made another deal, I guess.

—Senator Parer indicates that they have probably made another deal. In relation to this matter, I think that the words of former Senator Don Chipp probably best express what this is all about. He expresses it far better than I do. I want to quote a few paragraphs that former Senator Don Chipp wrote in the weekend's newspapers. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Not one of those Victorians who dumped Labor on October 3 was under any misapprehension about Jeff Kennett's plan to take drastic action which would cause pain.
But union leaders immediately implemented the war plan they had drawn up before the election to protect their own positions of power and tried to paralyse the State.
The plan backfired. They found a willing ally in Senator Peter Cook—
a former heavy in the Building Workers Industrial Union.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is still a member.
—Tell us when. Seventeen years ago.
—Former Senator Chipp continued:

SPEECH.PARA: He . . . Mr Keating to pass special legislation to override and frustrate the industrial relations reforms instituted by the Kennett Government.

The leopard does not lose his spots. Senator Cook is still a captive of that union. He is still a member, I understand and, of course, he is subject to the dictates of that union. Later in the article former Senator Chipp says:
Indeed, one would have thought that Messrs Keating and Cook might have experienced a touch of guilt about the chaos into which this nation has plunged during their stewardship.

That they might have felt a bit reluctant to butt into the genuine efforts of a State government which had been elected to restore order out of the appalling turmoil into which their State colleagues had delivered it.
Not so. With impertinent arrogance they have again tugged their forelocks in obeisance to the boys and girls from the union.

Of course, they can only do this with the support of the Australian Democrats. I refuse to believe a newspaper report which quotes `Democratic sources' as indicating their support for the legislation.

I share former Senator Chipp's amazement that the Democrats might even consider that. I hope that the current lot of Democrats, who really have very little in common with the original Democrats who were put there to keep the Government honest—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or one another.

—As Senator Parer says, or one another. They do not have much to do with one another either. Former Senator Chipp finds it unbelievable that the Democrats might support this legislation. He goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: After all, they were not formed to assist in perpetrating dishonest, sneaky, back-door, undemocratic politicking.
Is not that so well put? I do not think even Senator Ray could have given a better explanation of what this Bill is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was watching you try to pronounce that word. I couldn't do it either.

—I am sorry, Senator Ray. I only went to a State school. I did not have the benefit of the teaching given at some college. You were a teacher, a pretty clever man, no doubt. You get out your cane, belt people around. You try the same tricks here, but it does not work. So, teacher, you just sit back and try to learn something about it. You might learn something.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! I would not want to interrupt the stimulating conversation across the chamber but, with respect, I ask that the conversation be directed through me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am just suggesting that the teacher should go back to school and learn a bit about industrial relations and a bit about government. He has obviously learnt nothing in the last 10 years during which he has been part of this team that has brought Australia into the worst recession since the 1930s.
—The richest Prime Minister.
—With the richest Prime Minister in charge of it.
—Quick rich.

—`Quick rich', as Senator Parer interjects—a Prime Minister whom Senator Ray called a clown. As I said the other day, I sort of agree with Senator Ray: the Prime Minister certainly is a joke, and I guess that is much the same as a clown. But clowns are supposed to bring happiness and a bit of joy; this Prime Minister does not do that to anyone.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to prolong the debate and take up the time of the Senate, in spite of some encouragement from Senator Ray to keep going. I simply say to the Democrats that they should seriously consider what their former Leader, former Senator Chipp, said about this legislation. I cannot believe—and neither can Don Chipp—that the Democrats could possibly even consider supporting this sort of legislation. I urge the Democrats to read this article, to understand what Don Chipp is saying and, in due course, to join with us to oppose this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard Senator Macdonald's remarks, I am reminded of the statement which applies to the front bench of the Labor Party: `No ticket, no front bench'. The reality, as we know, is that the trade union movement controls this Labor Party. This is demonstrated no more clearly than in the amendments to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2).

PARA.TAB: The union movement—the John Halfpennys, the Bill Keltys and all those people who have had the interests of the Australian workers at heart over the last 10 years, when average earnings have been cut and one million unemployed have been created—has told the Keating Government that the industrial reforms which are occurring in Victoria must be stopped. This Labor Government and the ACTU do not want any checks or balances which might interfere with their powers, their privileges and their view of the world.

There is no question that these reforms threaten the current system of trade unionism in this country. If the Kennett reforms are allowed to continue, as they will, we will see the development of an industrial relations system which empowers individual workers and ends union monopolies. What was so terrible about the Victorian reforms which so horrified Mr Halfpenny, Mr Kelty, Senator Ray and all those characters who are so closely associated with union power in this country? What was so appalling about it all?

I will summarise these reforms. Firstly, the Kennett reforms enable employers and their employees to negotiate enterprise agreements on an individual or collective basis. What a terrible thing it is that Australian workers want to get out and talk with their bosses and between themselves to work out a cooperative agreement to their mutual benefit! That was the first aspect of the Kennett reforms which caused such shock and horror in Trades Hall.

Secondly, the Kennett reforms will make union membership voluntary and a matter for individual choice. What a terrible thing it is that Australian workers can decide whether they want to join a trade union! No more will we see the signs up on the building sites, `No ticket, no start'. That means that the trade unions will have to go out and work hard to recruit members and to make sure they serve the interests of those members. But voluntary unionism is the kiss of death to the sort of unionism that Senator Ray, John Halfpenny and their mates wish to have.

The third thing the Kennett reforms set out to do was to make secret ballots compulsory before any industrial action such as strikes or work bans is taken. Imagine workers being given a choice as to whether they wish to go on strike. It will not be a matter of John Halfpenny saying, `Everybody out', and out they all go; John Halfpenny will have to go out and convince workers in Victoria to go on strike. There will be a secret ballot—no more union bully boys—through which the individual worker can decide whether he wants to go on strike. That is heresy as far as the trade union movement in this country is concerned.

The fourth thing which really worried the trade union movement was that the Kennett reforms provide flexibility in the working hours of Victorian awards by allowing ordinary working time to be worked in any five consecutive days. It is a very important reform and, among other things, one which will be of great benefit to women. But this flexibility just cannot be allowed!

The problem with these four principles is that there is one thing they do not require: the intervention of the trade union bosses—the Bill Keltys and the John Halfpennys; under the Kennett reforms they will have a far quieter life. These Kennett reforms have to be defeated at all costs, because with them Australia will not be the country that we are used to it being. It will not be a country with 11.3 per cent unemployment, one million unemployed and falling real wages; we will not have an Australia in which the power of the union bosses remains entrenched.

The Labor Party is the political arm of the trade union movement. Senator Ray, a very senior member of the Labor Party, will confirm this. If Bill Kelty says `Jump', Senator Cook, Senator Ray and Mr Keating say `How high?'. And how high is the jump required with these amendments? Any constitutional law or mandate of a democratically elected government can be overturned to preserve union privileges. This is what it is all about.

I believe that one of the great distortions in political life in this country is the control of one of our major parties by a special interest group with very strong vested interests—the trade union movement. This has had profound effects on the workings of our democracy and the workings of our economy. A classic case which we are seeing now is that, where the interests of the ordinary workers conflict with the interests of the union bosses, the union bosses will always support the Labor Party. Their main aim is to get Keating back into office at any cost, because without Keating there will be no more power, no more privileges and no more special jobs for the union bosses. Hence, this is one of the great distortions in the political life of this country.

Questions of the links between trade union movements and major political parties have largely been resolved in western Europe. This is a major matter for public debate in the United Kingdom because the Labour Party is seeing what a gross distortion it is to give such power to unelected union officials. As I said, the prime concern of union bosses is to entrench their government in power so as to protect their rights and their privileges.

The Keating-Kelty Government in effect has been running this country for almost a decade. What has this magnificent industrial relations system, which Mr Kelty and Mr Keating put together—this great accord—produced for Australia? First, it has produced falling living standards. Even Senator Button indicated in this chamber today that average real earnings had fallen during the term of this Government. This is a Labor government whose stated intention is to try to protect the living standards of ordinary Australian workers. Yet it has cut them. That is the first thing that this magnificent industrial relations system has produced.

Secondly, the industrial relations system has produced the inevitable consequence: miserable productivity and, hence, the prospect of further falls in living standards. The third great feature of the industrial relations system, the accord, which Senator Ray, Mr Kelty and Mr Keating have supported, is one million unemployed. Today we saw the figures that indicate that in no other period in Australian history have more Australians who wish to work not been able to find work. This is the record of the Labor industrial relations system. What a fantastic record!

This is one of the most significant Bills to come before this Parliament for a long time. Firstly, it seeks to extend massively the reach of the Federal arbitration system. That is its intention, but I suggest that it has far wider implications for this country.

The second issue is that the Bill is a blatant attack on the States. This Bill destroys any notion of cooperative federalism in this country. Who will cooperate with the constitutional gangster, Paul Keating? Very few States, I suggest. The third issue this Bill brings before this chamber is that it undermines the nature of our democracy. As my colleague Senator Macdonald pointed out, when questioned on the Channel 9 Sunday program about the Government's intention—and Senator Ray will remember this—Mr Keating said, `Let's not run too far on all this democracy stuff'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I've got the speech and you're pinching every second word.
—I know it hurt you, Senator Ray. As Senator Macdonald said—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! I wonder whether the speakers might direct their remarks through the Chair. Senator Ray, I do not want to be pedantic but you are not in your seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Ray is a bit thin-skinned on these issues. The problem basically is that Senator Ray has never stood up for principles. In the end, Senator Ray just wants to remain on the front bench. He has shown a magnificent capacity to compromise any major principle. We saw it recently in relation to the Army. He will compromise any principle to stay on that front bench. I suggest to him that he does not serve his Party well, nor does he serve this country well, in the weakness he has shown over the years. The plain fact of the matter is that the Victorian Government had a mandate for its industrial relations policy. That policy, as Senator Ray can confirm, was the major issue in the State election campaign.

PARA.TAB: There is some irony in the fact that this Bill seeks to further use the Industrial Relations Commission for political purposes. You may recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, that in this chamber today and yesterday Senator Cook extolled the virtues of what he described as our `independent arbitration system'. It is interesting to reflect on the attitudes that Mr Keating, Mr Kelty and Senator Cook have had over the last year and a half towards the Industrial Relations Commission in this country. Over a prolonged period they have engaged in personal invective in order to belittle this institution. As Senator Ray can confirm, they have put in place a number of Acts of parliament to alter systematically both the Commission's powers and membership.

At the same time as the Government-ACTU attack on the system of conciliation and arbitration was continuing, the Labor Party was also moving to ensure that the members of the Commission were brought more into line with the intellectual approach that the Keltys and Keatings of this world have. There was an old joke that Senator Ray may have heard. It is not a great joke, but it tells a nice story. Why is Bill Kelty so angry? Because Justice Maddern can still create a Full Bench without an ACTU officer on it. Is that not a terrible thing?

The fact of the matter is that the Government and the ACTU have installed so many members of the Commission who have had a close association the ACTU that it is almost impossible not to have a former ACTU officer on any Full Bench. More Deputy President jobs have been created to allow for the appointment of those who may be more intellectually bound by the sort of philosophy embodied in the accord, the sort of philosophy which has led to the economic crisis that this country now faces.

Given their less than honourable approach to the Commission, it is a major step in hypocrisy for Senator Cook to say that the Commission is an important institution in this country. What did the President of the Commission, Mr Barry Maddern, say yesterday in his annual report? He attacked the Government for its policies towards the Commission. He felt that those sorts of policies could create the perception that the independence and integrity of the Commission were being undermined.

No-one knows where this matter will end. In my view, this Bill will be found to be unconstitutional. It will be a great pity if the Australian Democrats continue to support Bills that come before this Parliament and are later found to be unconstitutional. Senator Powell, who is now in the chamber, will recall the very strong support that she, as the then Leader of the Australian Democrats, gave to the political advertising Bill. That Bill was declared unconstitutional by the High Court, to the undying shame of Senator Powell and her former Party.

Senator Powell supported the amalgamations of trade unions. She supported forcing trade unions into having at least 10,000 members. At least according to the ILO conventions, which this Government constantly tells us about, that also seems to have been illegal. This legislation completes the grand third. Senator Powell will probably stand up and strongly support this Bill too, just to make sure she gets the hat trick in supporting unconstitutional Bills in this country. We expect her to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —She did redeem herself by leaving the Australian Democrats.

—We are most indebted to Senator Macdonald for reminding us of the fact that Senator Powell did resign from the Australian Democrats. But I have to say that I do not hold out much hope that she learnt much from her experience. We will see Senator Powell get up and strongly support the Bill before the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Australia is entering a period of great constitutional uncertainty. Much of that constitutional uncertainty has been caused by Australia's No. 1 constitutional gangster, Mr Keating. These pressures are coming from a wide range of directions. Senator Powell looks confused. She has probably never even heard of the Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I think the terminology used by Senator Kemp in referring to the Prime Minister as a gangster probably does contravene our Standing Orders.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I think what Senator Kemp said—he will correct me if I am wrong—is that the Prime Minister was a constitutional gangster. He was not suggesting—
—It is on the border, Senator.

—He is saying that the Prime Minister is robbing, destroying and assaulting the Constitution. I do not think there was any personal intent meant. I suppose Senator Kemp could say that himself. I am just helping you, Mr Acting Deputy President, by indicating that Senator Kemp referred to the Prime Minister as a constitutional gangster.
—Senator Kemp, I suspect that in the normal context it is probably not unparliamentary, but it is probably undesirable. It would help the chamber if you chose to withdraw that statement.

—Thank you for your advice. As you are a man whom I respect, I will accept the advice you have given me and withdraw the statement. Can I say: that great constitutional wrecker, Mr Keating? I do not know whether `vandal' is the correct word, but I think the message has come through. These pressures on our constitutional system are coming—
—Senator Kemp, I am sure you are not seeking to go around the periphery, but describing the Prime Minister as a vandal, in whatever context, is unhelpful to the debate.

—On the basis of your advice, again, that you feel it is unparliamentary, I will withdraw the statement. The pressures on our constitutional system are coming from a number of directions. There is the major attack on the States, their powers and prerogatives as represented in this Bill. That is causing widespread fear and annoyance not only amongst the conservative States but amongst the Labor States as well, and for good reason. Of course, the Mabo decision has thrown land title in Australia into doubt. The external affairs power has huge implications for the working of our Federation. The pressures are coming from a wide range of areas. Seeing Senator Schacht in the chamber I am reminded that the other constitutional pressure coming in is the desire of the Labor Party to turn this great democracy, one of the world's most successful democracies—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Kemp is starting to traverse areas well outside the Bill. We have let him go on tonight, but once he starts getting on to the republican debate within the industry relations debate—
—I haven't mentioned the word.
—There is no doubt that Senator Kemp was going to do so. Mr Acting Deputy President, I think you should ask him to get back to the Bill.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Senator Ray, you have put me in a difficult position because I have just come into the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that case I will withdraw my objection because I had not realised that you had just come into the chair.
—Senator Kemp, I ask you to keep to the subject of the Bill.
—I certainly will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are reminded, once again, that the Australian Labor Party is but the political wing of the trade union movement. Today we are seeing that political wing doing the trades unions' bidding and attempting on this occasion to extend the power of the trade union movement to override the concept of States rights, to abuse the use of the external affairs power and to make the power of the unions stretch far more tightly over non-union members than it has ever done hitherto.

PARA.TAB: This quite remarkable piece of legislation has been hastily cobbled together. We have only just received the explanatory memorandum. Indeed, we had to argue fast and furiously this morning that the Senate was entitled to see the explanatory memorandum before we commenced on the second reading debate. As I said this morning, it is a ridiculous proposition to actually speak to the second reading of a Bill when we have not seen properly all the documentation that pertains to that Bill. We might just as well stand up in the Senate and debate broad-based motions of principle. We are looking very closely at the Bill, even at the second reading stage.

It is interesting that when we look at the supplementary explanatory memorandum, which we finally received, we find that the threat by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) early on in the piece that he would use the external affairs power of the Commonwealth Constitution to bring the State industrial relations system in Victoria within the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth is attempting to be fulfilled. The coalition is quite obviously opposed to the abuse of the external affairs power in this way. Quite clearly, section 51(xxix), which gives power to the Commonwealth to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to external affairs, had an entirely different concept when it was included in the Constitution from the one to which this Government is trying to extend it today.

It is quite interesting to observe that a Minister in this Government, Senator Evans, when wearing his hat as a legal commentator of some sort or another, wrote a piece called `Australia's Constitution: time for change'. In that article, which related to this question of the external affairs power, Senator Evans wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . much will depend on how the High Court applied the test enunciated in general terms in the 1982 Koowarta case, namely that the Commonwealth is entitled to legislate on reliance on the s.51(xxix) external affairs power when the subject matter is such that failure to so act would put Australia's international standing or reputation at risk.
Australia's international reputation is in no way at risk. (Quorum formed)

PARA.TAB: I was referring to Senator Evans's treatise concerning the Koowarta case and indeed his assessment of when the external affairs power can be invoked. Senator Evans's interpretation of the Koowarta case and when the external affairs power can be invoked was expressed in this article which he wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . when the subject matter is such that failure to so act would put Australia's international standing or reputation at risk.

Australia's international reputation, as a result of the Kennett reforms in Victoria, is clearly not at risk. Indeed, one could say that that legislation has enhanced the freedom of individuals to negotiate their own relationships with employers.

PARA.TAB: For Senator Evans to have any consistency at all, presumably he must maintain the view that somehow Australia's international relationships are at risk in this area, otherwise there would be no justification for using the external affairs power. In fairness to him, he did write that piece prior to the Tasmanian dams case; but he was obviously well aware of the fetter that was placed upon the power.

The interpretation of this power was, as I said, dealt with further in the dams case and expanded in Richardson and the Forestry Commission. The qualification mentioned was outlined clearly by Brennan and Dean in the dams case. They stated that the law must be in faithful pursuit of the convention or the treaty. I question whether the law that we are attempting to enact today is in faithful pursuit of the international treaties which the Government is presumably relying upon when these very treaties may guarantee voluntary unionism in the same way as has been enacted by the Kennett Government.

Indeed, it is coalition policy to ensure that we see an end to compulsory unionism and that we see true voluntary unionism. That means that people are just as free not to join a union as they are free to join. Quite clearly, the power which is set out in the external affairs power was certainly not meant to cover this sort of case. It can be described quite properly as an abuse of the power and no doubt will be finally determined as such by a High Court challenge.

I turn now to the actual content of the amendments. According to the explanatory memorandum to the Bill, the proposed new subclause 3A provides a new object for the Industrial Relations Commission—that is, to interfere in the proper jurisdiction of the States, and Victoria in particular, in the area of labour relations. Its language is contorted; it uses the double negative. It states that its amendments will guide the AIRC in exercising its discretion under the Act relating to conciliation and arbitration.

Indeed, it uses the precise words out of the section of the Constitution dealing with conciliation and arbitration; but of course it leaves out the most important words which were mentioned earlier in the day by Senator Parer—that the power is to be invoked only when there is an interstate conflict. But this is of no concern to the drafters of this Bill or those who wish to ensure that union power is allowed to be extended.

Rather than guiding the Commission, the amendments place an obligation upon it to consider cases which it otherwise may agree not to consider in the public interest. The court is told specifically that it may not consider the public interest—some Act of parliament which says that. I use the word `court' in a very loose way because it is not a court. Indeed, that section of the legislation which we examined earlier and which attempts to give contempt powers equal to a court is again trying to make the Commission look as if it is a court.

Further, the proposed new subsection 111(1A) will force the Commission to consider the relations of employers and employees in States which do not have Federal awards applying to them, are not subject to voluntary agreement arrangements, and are not subject to compulsory arbitration under State law. This means that in a State such as Victoria the necessary micro-economic reform which is currently being introduced by the Kennett Government in the labour market will be thwarted by an enactment of the Commonwealth Government. In the State which is suffering the most in the worst recession in 60 years, the Prime Minister will not allow the necessary reforms to be introduced to enable Victoria to bring itself out of recession. This is a State which has just thrown out a Labor government which penalised that State for 10 years.

We remember that John Cain called an election in such a way as to prevent the exposure of much of the corruption that finally became evident and had been going on in Victoria prior to that election and then prior to Mrs Kirner being dumped. This was a democratic election which saw much discussion and advertising concerning industrial relations. Yet this Federal Government, acting as it is as the political wing of the trade union movement, has a power lust. It is making a grab for power to try to entrench that union power before it loses government federally.

This is only possible, at the end of the day, because of the complicity of the Australian Democrats. I think it is important to note and, indeed, to repeat the quote that my colleague Senator Kemp used when he talked about the founder of the Democrats, Senator Chipp, imploring those people who were the inheritors of his work not to vote for such atrocious legislation.

I think it is important to remember that what this Government is doing is turning the Commission into a contrivance by the Government to regulate the labour market for its own ends and for its own constituency—the trade union movement, which is on the decline and wishes to rope in those people who are presently outside its dictatorial powers to ensure that it is able to gather in additional money to fund its own campaigns. But, more particularly, it is so that its own trade union officials—the bully boys; the graduates of the John Halfpenny school of industrial relations—can show us once again the ugly face of the trade union movement.

But well we should remember that the Commission is just that—a commission, not a court. When Chief Justice Mason dealt with the previous attempt by this Government to stop people speaking in a free way about the lacklustre performance of the Industrial Relations Commission when that legislation was struck down in Nationwide News Pty Ltd v. Wills, he had this to say, `The Commission does not have the standing and status in the public mind which the court system enjoys. It was not meant to, nor should it'. This whole attempt to elevate the sort of people whom Senator Kemp described earlier—the mates of the trade union movement—to higher and more powerful positions in the land is just not on.

I believe the Parliament should take cognisance of the views of the Chief Justice in this respect and resist attempts to invest the Industrial Relations Commission with the contempt powers of the court. More particularly, at the end of the day the Democrats should, at the very least, see the abuse of the external affairs power and the abuse of the grab and lust for power by the trade union movement through its political wing—the current Labor Government.

It is a sad and sorry day when we see this sort of legislation being rammed through the Parliament. I understand that it will take until 3 o'clock tomorrow morning for this to be done because the Government is so insistent—Mr Keating made a promise that he would force through this legislation. So we will have less debate than we ought to have and there will be less scrutiny than there ought to be. But at least we have had some breakthroughs in that we will be able to have some investigation of the Bill a little later in the week. But the speeches at the second reading stage are being curtailed and, for that reason, I will curtail my own remarks at this point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my contribution to the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, I wish to make it clear that I support the Bill as introduced on 15 October and the proposed amendments of the Government, and that I will be moving amendments of my own. Earlier in the debate and earlier today, in some other debates surrounding this legislation, allegations were made that somehow or other I had some special access to this Bill and that it was for that reason that I was able to circulate today quite substantial amendments to this Bill. That is, of course, garbage.

PARA.TAB: This Bill was introduced on 15 October. I was capable, therefore, of giving instructions for the drafting of amendments which were circulated today. That was not beyond my wit. I suppose I should not find it too extraordinary that the Opposition seems to have lost the plot somewhere for the original Bill. Certainly, we have subsequently had significant amendments put forward by the Government. I just want to make it clear that my own amendments are on the basis of a Bill that was introduced back in October.

I support what the Government intends doing in this Bill and particularly by way of its amendments; that is, to improve access to Federal awards for people presently under State awards in certain circumstances. Tonight, however, I will confine my remarks to my concern for women both under the new industrial laws in Victoria which have been passed and which will come into operation fully over time and under the proposed industrial relations regime of a possible Federal coalition government. As several others have said, we do not have a lot of time for the debate. I would like to make many other points but I will confine myself to my concern about the effects on women. It is for this as much as any other reason that I support the Government's move.

Professor McCallum, Associate Professor of Labour Law at Monash University and who was, like me, a participant in the day of action in Victoria on 10 November, has had something to say on this matter. He has made the point that he believes, as I do, that `women are the ones who will bear the brunt of the pain of the Victorian State Government's industrial relations reforms'. He has also expressed some frustration that this point has not been made strongly enough, loudly enough nor often enough in the debate which has ensued since the change of government in Victoria. That is not necessarily because nobody agrees with him and nobody is concerned about this issue; it is often difficult to have concerns relating to women gain the public voice that they deserve.

However, it is somewhat encouraging to hear from the Victorian Trades Hall Council that there has been quite a surge by women towards joining unions since the Victorian State election. I certainly welcome that. I think they will need the sort of protection that they will get from the unions. In many cases women have not been members of unions because they have not found them relevant. I myself have criticised the fact that unions have not met the challenge sufficiently over the years to attract women to membership. Of course, what the unions have not been able to do in their recruitment of women for union membership Jeff Kennett has been able to do. It is about the only thing I can think of that he has ever been able to do for women.

It is important to note that the legislation in Victoria does not mention equal pay. Because equal pay provisions are included in awards and not in legislation, this fundamental aspect that must be of concern to all women is at risk. Once again, women will be placed in the position of having to fight for wage parity as part of the process of individual employment contracts.

Jan Wade, the Victorian Attorney-General and Minister responsible for Women's Affairs, takes a contrary view. She says that she does not think there is any evidence that there will be adverse effects on women. She has also used the example of New Zealand, where she claims that a freer labour market:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . has been quite advantageous because women are in growth areas. They've had an opportunity to negotiate conditions that suit them.

I have a paper from New Zealand—a country to which I have travelled three times in the last 12 months or so—which was given by Linda Hill, from the Sociology Department of the University of Canterbury, to the Women's Studies Conference in September this year. She takes a contrary view from Mrs Wade and she is in New Zealand. At the time of this conference, the Employment Contracts Act, the New Zealand legislation, was well over a year old. The legislation had its first anniversary in May 1992. The conclusion of that paper reads:

PARA.TAB: The ECA is affecting women disproportionately because of the larger numbers of women than of men work in scattered, industrially weak situations.

SPEECH.PARA: The paper at this point mentions that there are many male dominated, low skill, low paid occupations which are having similar problems. It continues:

In the name of flexibility, the ECA is impacting most heavily on those whose hours, employment and job content are often already flexible. To lower overall labour costs, the ECA attacks the weakest sections of the labour market.

PARA.TAB: The likely consequences of the labour relations changes of the ECA are not only increased individual disadvantage for women at work, not only increased negotiating disadvantage for their unions, but increasing inequality for women in NZ society as a whole. If paid work is the route to independence and social status in our capitalist and patriarchal society, then the ECA undermines the very choice, freedom and equality that its language celebrates.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a contrary view from New Zealand which perhaps I should pass on to Mrs Wade. It is important to note that the new Victorian legislation goes further than the New Zealand laws; a matter which Professor McCallum has noted. In New Zealand there is still the right to strike and workers have access to a labour court.

PARA.TAB: In Victoria, one in two female workers are under State awards compared with one in four male workers. The fact is that most of these State awards are in low paid occupations. There are historical reasons for this. Traditionally, Victoria has had quite an undeveloped industrial relations system. Victoria did not have an Industrial Relations Commission until 1981. Since the 1890s the tradition had been wages boards. Unions were not represented on these boards. This meant that unions with clout—such as the transport and communications unions, most of them male dominated—moved to the Federal sphere where they could strike better deals for their members. As a result, Victoria has the highest percentage of workers on Federal awards of any State. The unions that remained under the State system were those in which unskilled and low paid workers predominated—shop assistants, clerks, cleaners, waitresses, barmaids and so on. Now we are getting a picture as to why it is important for many people under these awards to be able to move into the Federal system. That is what this legislation will allow.

Professor McCallum has also made the point that, in his view, it is the `women who will now feel the chill winds of a "free" labour market', in the same way as the New Zealand paper I have referred to points out. Many of these workers are in situations where, even should they be brave enough to do so under the new legislation, strikes are difficult to organise. Of course, they are now faced with the situation where they will be dependent on their employers' agreement for retention of award situations. The workers are in a `take it or leave it' situation or, as Peter Boyle, the President of the Australian Small Business Association, has said, beggars can't be choosers. As I say, employees are very much dependent on employer cooperation and agreement to be able to stay within awards.

The lack of regulation under the system in Victoria will increase the differential between men's and women's wages. This concern has been raised by the Industrial Relations Commission itself even under the Labor Party's enterprise bargaining system. In this chamber I have expressed my concerns about how women are faring and will fare under that system.

Of course, the prospects under the system in Victoria are much worse. The employee relations legislation in Victoria, for instance, does not allow for sick leave to be cumulative. Many women who use that cumulative situation, not just to cover their own illnesses but to cover the care of their children or others in their family as they maintain the traditional caring role, have the right to be very concerned about that. The very punitive aspect of the Victorian legislation is of enormous concern. We could push labour costs down and down in this country, but that will not increase confidence or investment in this country, nor will it produce jobs.

As I said, there have been reports of increased inquiries by women for union protection in Victoria. I find that a rather encouraging situation. I personally know many women who previously felt no need at all to get `that political', as they have often said to me—meaning political enough to join a union—but who now have a quite different view. These include quite young women who, to this point, have taken for granted not only the benefits and advantages that they find in their working situation, but the general benefits and advantages that they have through the advancement of women, that advancement having been contributed to by the organised labour movement through this past century.

I think it is important to say a few words here about the similarity between what is happening in Victoria and the prospects under the Federal coalition's policy. In fact, the industrial relations system that we have had in this country in many ways has performed for women. Although there is still a wage differential between men and women in this country, and although Australian women's hourly earnings are about 83 per cent of men's, we are ahead of women in many similar economies. We are ahead of the US, Canada, the UK, Belgium, Holland, Germany and New Zealand, for instance. That situation is at risk under the industrial relations system put before us, and under the one in place in Victoria.

Money is not everything and, for women in particular, the issue of flexibility is important. It is true that the male dominated centralised system which has been a large part of our heritage has not performed well on that score. When Mr Howard, as industrial relations spokesperson, promotes his policy, flexibility is, and will be, a major selling point. It all sounds rather wonderful: a woman going in and negotiating flexibility with her boss. But how realistic is it really?

That is a question Adele Horin asked in an article last Tuesday in the Sydney Morning Herald. It is an extremely valid question. Those women who work in the areas I mentioned before, particularly in Victoria under the State based award system—women in clothing, food processing and retailing—lack bargaining power at the best of times, and, as Adele Horin said in her article, these are the worst of times. Some women will do well, but the bulk of women will not.

As I said, the enterprise bargaining system of the Labor Government and the ACTU has a question mark over it as well. Under the coalition, women will be dependent on being able to reach an agreement with their employers. Even if they can get agreement to stay on the award, there is no mechanism for changing the award to take account of inflation or any other processes that currently exist. Over time, the award system is bound to wither away. I take encouragement from the fact that this Government is prepared to act to assist in protecting women particularly, but all workers in positions of less influence.

About a month ago, in an address to the Home Economics Association, a Melbourne University historian, Dr Janet McCalman, spoke of the momentous changes in our cultural heritage over the past 200 years. I quote from her speech:

SPEECH.PARA: As you review the rise in domestic standards during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, you find that it is chronologically determined by the advances fought for and won by the trade union movement. First the right to combine; second the right to strike; then the right to picket; the necessity for compulsory unionism, without which strike action can be suicidal. Politics is about power and the only power and bargaining weapon the poor have is the withdrawal of their labour; and if employers can quickly find alternative labour, then industrial action is useless. The right to combine and to strike has done more for our basic decencies of civilised life than the right to vote. No-one gave the poor higher wages, safer workplaces, holidays, sick leave and controlled hours out of the kindness of their heart. It has been a painstaking and painful struggle.
The right to strike is important. The ILO thinks so, and it has told us here in Australia that we do not have enough of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't have enough strikes? Are you sure you meant that?

—The honourable senator should read the ILO reports and he will see that they say that. One of the impediments to that is the provisions of sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act. I now come to the amendments that I will propose at the committee stage of this legislation. I propose the repeal of sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act. The repeal of those provisions is ALP policy and ACTU policy. In 1978 the Trade Practices Commission itself expressed its position in relation to instituting proceedings under 45D and made the point that the Commission `would propose to limit court proceedings it might bring to cases affecting competition'. It went on to make the point that, basically, it considers this an inappropriate application within its own purview.

PARA.TAB: The ILO itself made a direct request to this Government to remove sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act on the basis that it is an impediment to the right to strike in this country. The request said:

SPEECH.PARA: It should, therefore, be permissible for workers to have recourse to sympathetic action where the initial strike in respect of which such action is taken is itself a legitimate exercise of the right to strike. These considerations led the Committee to ask the Government to provide information as to the practical application of section 45D and its associated provisions, and to indicate whether it had any plans to amend the 1974 Act so as to bring it into conformity with the requirements of the Convention.

As I said, it is also ACTU policy to bring about that repeal. My amendments will do so, and will place the questions of secondary boycotts appropriately within the Industrial Relations Act, in exactly the same terms as were proposed by former Prime Minister Bob Hawke in this Parliament in 1984. Those proposals at that time failed here in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Since then the policy of the Australian Democrats has changed. Earlier we heard Senator Bell give his commitment, which sits alongside support from a wide range of people in the community—people in the environment movement and in the labour movement, my Independent colleague Senator Chamarette, former Independent member Phil Cleary and others. I will put forward those amendments at the committee stage.

In my last moments I would like to say that I was concerned to read in the Australian Financial Review this morning that Senator Bell is taking a somewhat entrenched position with regard to this legislation on the basis of strong support for a secret ballot. I hope that that does not mean that the Democrats will in any way put at risk legislation which I consider to be absolutely vital, not just to the women who suffer and will continue to suffer under the industrial relations regime of the coalition Government of Victoria, but for all Victorians and all others around this country who need the protection that the Government's proposals within this legislation will provide. I commend my proposed amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.
