TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to Senator Bell's contribution on behalf of the Australian Democrats. He said that it is hard to know where to begin. That is quite in keeping with the Democrats, because quite often they find it hard to know when and where to finish as well. I do not find it hard to begin because the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 deals with one of the most important issues facing Australia today, and that issue is industrial relations reform. I stress the word `reform', because that is what we need. Our current industrial relations system is holding us back from climbing out of the deepest recession we have had for 60 years.

PARA.TAB: I cannot believe that at a time when we need to do everything possible to get people into work, Australian workers are unable to negotiate contracts that would enable businesses they work for to keep going and some workers are asking for improved awards and conditions under these circumstances. I want to say right from the beginning that I, like the shadow Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), believe in the right of unions to exist and the fundamental right to strike. What I do not believe in is unions single-mindedly pushing their own barrow without regard to fellow workers or the unemployed.

Things have to change. People should be allowed to negotiate with their employer if they wish. People should not be forced to join a union against their will; they should be given a choice. They should also have the choice to stay in their current award or have the union negotiate on their behalf.

I do not know why the Government is so upset about the changes which are proposed in Jobsback. If unions are doing their job, and if people want to belong, they will stay members of the union and appoint the unions to negotiate on their behalf. Of course, if unions are not doing their job, people will resign from them. The good and effective unions will keep their members; the ineffective unions will not.

This is exactly what has happened across the Tasman in New Zealand. In October, I referred to a resolution by a majority of the New Zealand Council of Trade Unions against pressing for a return to compulsory unionism. Amongst those unions which voted for this cooperation was the engineers union, which is the equivalent of the Australian Metal Workers Union. An article about this titled `Union pragmatism triumphs in NZ', which appeared in the Australian newspaper on 12 October, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Contrary to the dire predictions of employers and unions wedded to the centralised system, the New Zealand experience has shown that workplace coverage has not suddenly been fragmented as a result of open competition for workforce representation . . . despite the new framework, unions have found it relatively easy to retain coverage—provided they work for it, that is.

I have also referred in this chamber to the positive effect of the industrial relations system in New Zealand. In October this year, the international food conglomerate H.J. Heinz bought Wattie Industries for $428m. Again I quote from the article in the Australian, which reads:

It's quite clear that the Heinz hierarchy reckoned that New Zealand was a better place in which to bed down all that money than Australia, particularly because it had exporting into the Asian food market in mind.

Yet day after day the Minister for Industrial Relations sings the praises of his industrial relations system where workers lose their jobs so their colleagues can get pay rises. This is the system where employers are forced to give workers benefits they cannot afford, where businesses close because they cannot afford to pay pay rises that are demanded by unions, and where union members strike for awards and conditions that their employers and the nation cannot afford at this time. The question is whether we want to continue with the current system which, without a doubt, has contributed to our current economic crisis. Or do we want to move ahead to a system where both workers and employers have more say in the running of their own lives?

PARA.TAB: Just last week, rail workers employed by Australian National on South Australia's Eyre Peninsula had a 24-hour strike. Members of the Australian Railways Union are asking for a 10.5 per cent increase over eight months. They have rejected AN's generous offer of 4.5 per cent over 12 months, and they still have not ruled out further strike action. How can Railways Union members ask for a 10.5 per cent pay rise in the middle of the worst recession for 60 years? How can they ask for a pay rise when the average broadacre farmer who they were servicing in this area, who sends his grain to market by rail, is predicted to make a loss this year of $25,000?

I want to know whether these union members have considered that any increase in their union wages will be passed on in the form of higher freight costs to the people who can least afford it—the primary producers in those areas. I am astounded that rail workers could ask for a pay rise and go on strike when they know full well that the harvest has just begun on Eyre Peninsula and that farmers rely on rail for three-quarters of their transport to the grain terminals. Because of the unseasonal weather, it is even more important than ever to get grain from the silos to the terminals as quickly as possible. The last thing that our grain producers need in this current predicament is tonnes of grain getting wet and deteriorating before it gets to the terminal.

There is no doubt that Australian National has restructured and is a vastly more efficient service than it has been in the past, but is this the best we can do? What does it say for community spirit and understanding when rail workers not only ask for pay rises our farmers can only dream of but also jeopardise their harvest by going on strike at such a crucial time? The Australian Railways Union in this area is out of touch, both with the reality of the Australian economy and with what the community wants. The centralised wage system is also out of touch with the economy and with what the community expects at a time of deep recession.

This brings me to the policies that have been outlined in Jobsback. I believe that this is what the community wants, but the policy is not being given a fair go. As with the GST, this Government is scaremongering about our industrial relations policy, particularly on the issue of protection for workers. Protection is a very important issue, and the coalition has thought about this seriously. Whilst we recognise the rights of workers not to join a union, we also recognise that non-union members have a right to be protected.

This Government is very fond of saying that Jobsback will return us to the dim dark ages of industrial relations. This has not happened in New Zealand, and there is no evidence to suggest that it would happen here. The reason it will not happen is simple: the policy in Jobsback protects workers. I know that the Government and the unions do not want to believe this because it does not suit them. They want to be able to say that workers will be exploited under the coalition.

For the record—and so that no Labor senator with a clear conscience can state in this chamber that our policy will not protect workers—I will outline three important measures contained in the policy. Firstly, if employers and employees make a joint decision prior to the birthday of an award to stay in the current system, that is what happens. In this situation, nothing changes. I repeat: if they decide to stay jointly in the award, that is what happens.

Secondly, where either the employer or the employee does not want to stay in the current system and has not reached a workplace agreement by the birthday of the award, the current award wages and legal conditions remain as a contract until such time as both parties agree to vary it. It is not true that if the employer wants to get out of the award system but the employees do not, the employer's wishes prevail. If the employees do not want to leave the award system, they cannot be forced to. There must be joint agreement or the current award remains in place. Of course, at some point in the future that award will become out-of-date and the employer and the employees will have to renegotiate. At that stage, if those employees are still members of a union, they can nominate their union to negotiate on their behalf.

Thirdly, where an employer and employees choose to establish a workplace agreement, this agreement is subject to a number of statutory minimums: a minimum hourly rate; four weeks annual leave; two weeks non-cumulative sick leave; 12 weeks paid paternity leave after 12 months continuous employment; and the guarantee of public holidays. It should be stressed that these are minimum conditions. This new flexible scheme will be attractive to many people; for example, working mothers, students, of which I happen to be the father of three, people who would prefer to work nights or weekends, and the millions of people who rush around during their lunch hours trying to do the banking, the shopping, pay the bills and have something to eat all inside an hour.

Jobsback is designed to ensure that no employee loses any legal employment entitlement as a result of transferring from an award to a workplace agreement except by agreement. Despite what the Government and the unions say, a worker cannot lose his or her current pay and conditions except by agreement. Workers' rights will be protected not only by these measures but also by the employee advocate. The advocate will provide free help to employees who feel they are aggrieved by workplace agreements. Unlike the current system, workers will not have to belong to a union to see the advocate. The whole point of the policies in Jobsback is that employers and workers know what is best for our businesses and our economy, a centralised system does not.

When was the last time the centralised system said, `No, you can't have a pay rise because if you do your employer will have to put off another 50 workers'? When was the last time a union said, `No, we won't go for a pay rise because if we do 50 fellow union members will lose their jobs'? When was the last time a union said, `No, we won't go for a pay rise because that will put up the price of all the products we produce, and that will affect a multitude of other Australians'? At this time more than ever, Australians who are lucky enough to have jobs should not be threatening other people's livelihoods. We should be pulling together, we should be negotiating sensible outcomes, and we should be implementing the policies outlined in Jobsback.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly on the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 because I appreciate that time has nearly ended for this discussion. Much of the debate thus far has not been related to the measure. There has been a wide-ranging debate about industrial relations this evening, and I am not going to enter into that debate. I would be happy to do so in other forums or when another motion is put before the Chair. The debate tonight is about legislation which does a number of things, and I want to deal with the amendments to that legislation which have now become the key question. The amendments provide, in effect, an opportunity for workers who have been deprived of their right to independent arbitration of their wage rates and working conditions to have that right restored under certain circumstances.

PARA.TAB: We all know that in Victoria workers will be deprived of that right when the Victorian legislation comes into effect. That is a matter of deep concern to me because over the period of my service to workers through the trade union movement and in other capacities I have always upheld the right of final recourse to an arbitrator as a means of ensuring a fair go. In the late 1950s, the 1960s and the early 1970s, there was a situation of relatively full employment. I well recall that during those times it was the pro-communist Left that was demanding that arbitration be dispensed with. The slogan was `Smash arbitration'.

When I was on the ACTU Executive, that slogan was being pursued by the Left on that Executive. The moderates barely had the numbers. At one stage there was only one vote in it. Albert Monk was the President of the ACTU at the time and Harold Souter was the Secretary. Many will recall the demonstrations by the pro-communist Left in the streets of Melbourne and the anti-arbitration slogans on the banners. The whole thrust of its proposition was that arbitration should be smashed and that any decisions imposed—as it said—on workers by the capitalist court should not be able to be enforced.

Many will recall the Clarrie O'Shea case. The streets of Melbourne echoed with the demands of a number of left wing organisations that arbitration be smashed. The boot is now on the other foot. The situation at that time was very hectic for many of us in the trade union movement. Many of us saw the importance of maintaining a system of conciliation and arbitration not only because of fairness at that time to all concerned but also because we recognised the fact that, sooner or later, the situation could well change and we might need to depend upon the decisions of an independent arbitrator.

There was a considerable battle being waged within the Melbourne Trades Hall Council. Mick Jordan was the Secretary of the Council. There were a number of occasions when Mick was under extreme pressure because of his stance and the stance of the bare majority on the ACTU Executive. Of course, with relatively full employment, the bargaining whip was in the hands of those union organisations. A number of those union organisations tried desperately to force the ACTU Executive to concede. When the ACTU Executive, the Melbourne Trades Hall Council and other councils, including the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council and the New South Wales Labour Council—where Jim Kenny was the Secretary and Ralph Marsh the Assistant Secretary—refused to capitulate, what was the tactic of the pro-communist Left? The tactic was to set up shop committees, and to say that those shop committees should be able to determine matters properly provided for in awards.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was interrupted I was giving a brief thumbnail sketch of how we have come almost full circle over the last 25 years. The people who are now trying to deny to workers their rights to arbitration are of the New Right, whereas 25 years ago those who were trying to smash arbitration were the pro-communist Left. I was making the point that the streets of Melbourne echoed with the slogan `Smash arbitration' voiced by the extreme Left. Now, the streets of Melbourne have recently been full of demonstrators protesting against efforts to smash arbitration by the Kennett Government.

PARA.TAB: I was referring to another interesting fact. At that time the pro-communist Left was trying to undermine the central authority of the trade union movement. The ACTU and the Melbourne Trades Hall Council under Mick Jordan, the New South Wales Labor Council under Jim Kenny, my own Labor Council in Tasmania, and Bill Brown in South Australia were vigoruosly resisting the extreme Left's attempts to undermine the representative authority of the central organisations and of the unions that shop committees to be the organisations to negotiate directly with employers on matters of wages and working conditions.

Because of the shortage of labour in many industries, outlandish demands were made, and very often the employer had no alternative but to capitulate. So the employers and many unions whose members were affected by the strikes that occurred came to the ACTU and appealed to us to do something about it. The employers and the Federal Government came to us also in the ACTU Executive to put a stop to this nonsense. There should be proper settlement of disputes procedures and a matter should not be left to the employers and the employees through their shop committees to bargain on wages and working conditions which were award matters. (Extension of time granted)

On 6 May 1970 an agreement was reached between the ACTU, the national employers policy committee and the Government on the settlement of disputes procedures. The Minister for Labour and National Service at the time, the Hon. B.M. Snedden, and the Attorney-General, the Hon. Tom Hughes, were involved in the discussions. Billy Snedden and Tom Hughes, the representatives of the Liberal Government at the time, agreed to these proposals. I seek leave to table a copy of this agreement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very instructive and I suggest that honourable senators look at it because it recognises the critical need for unions to represent employees for the purpose of ensuring orderly industrial progress. We won the battle at that time, and the system of conciliation and arbitration was saved. Now there is an attempt to remove that inherent fairness of the system of conciliation and arbitration—the final appeal to an independent arbiter.

PARA.TAB: The only difference between then and now is that then there were labour shortages and the whip was in the hands of certain unions, which wanted to exploit their power. Now the bargaining boot is well and truly on the employer's foot because of high unemployment. I maintain now, as I maintained then, that, if there can be representative discussions between workers and employers, they should proceed in the best interests of all concerned in the workplace.

I believe the Government and the Opposition, through amendments to legislation, as well as the unions and the employer organisations, over the years have proceeded along that line with bargaining and agreements that are certified. I also firmly believe that in the end there must be an independent arbiter. If there is no agreement, particularly in the circumstances with which we are now faced, orderly industrial progress and fairness demand proper access to the arbitrator. That is what this legislation is all about.

This morning I expressed my concern that there may be some elements of this legislation which relied for their effectiveness on the external affairs head of power of the Constitution. I expressed my long-held view that State laws generally should not be overruled by the exercise by the Commonwealth Parliament of its external affairs power under the Constitution. I am now convinced that this legislation does not rely on that head of power: it relies on the proper head of power—that is, the conciliation and arbitration power in the Constitution. It does not rely on the corporations power; it relies on the appropriate power.

I am in full support of this legislation and I hope it will be passed. It is reasonable legislation. It is not excessive. It could have gone far beyond the terms which are before us. I believe it is a moderate response to a very serious challenge that had been issued particularly to the people in Victoria and to the problems that have emerged from what I believe is unthinking legislation in that State. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 is a portfolio Bill which amends 10 Acts in the industrial relations portfolio. The amendments are all designed to improve the operation of the Acts concerned or the functioning of offices or bodies established under them. Details of the changes are given in the explanatory memorandum.

PARA.TAB: Each of the proposed amendments is sensible and of real value. They have been the subject of discussions in the tripartite National Labour Consultative Council and accepted by its members. The Opposition has objected to proposed amendments to sections 202 and 299 of the Industrial Relations Act. The members of the National Labor Consultative Council have no such concerns.

Considerable attention has been given in this debate to further amendments to the Industrial Relations Act 1988 which I will be moving during the committee stage. These amendments relate to section 111 of the Industrial Relations Act and to the circumstances in which an employer may cease to be a respondent to a Federal award. Considerable discussion of the purpose and effect of the proposed amendments to section 111 has occurred since they were first announced. Regrettably, there have been some misunderstandings of the Government's policy position. Accordingly, it is appropriate for me to clarify the position and, in so doing, respond to some of the points that have been made in this debate tonight.

The Government's proposals reflect our clear policy on industrial relations. We support cooperation over conflict, choice over coercion and the proper protection of the interests of employers, workers and the general community. Such an approach provides the basis for achieving lasting economic and industrial reform fairly and flexibly.

If Australia's industrial relations system is to meet these objectives, it must guarantee employers, employees and their representatives that, where agreement cannot be reached over industrial differences, there is a fair, speedy and impartial system for resolving such problems. For most of this century, this has been achieved at the Federal and State levels by the provision of a system of conciliation and arbitration administered by independent industrial tribunals with the power to compel parties to disputes to appear before them and to make binding awards, by arbitration if necessary, to resolve the matters in dispute. The system has provided the basis for the fair and effective prevention and settlement of industrial disputes. Importantly, through awards, employees are guaranteed enforceable and equitable terms and conditions of employment.

The balance between Federal and State systems has been maintained partly by the preferences of the parties, partly by historical influences and partly by a mechanism in the Federal industrial legislation which allows the Federal Commission to not hear a matter which is appropriately left for resolution by the State industrial tribunal. In the Industrial Relations Act, that mechanism is found in paragraph 111(1)G.

Under paragraph 111(1)G, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission can dismiss or refrain from hearing a matter on various grounds, including that the Commission should defer to a State industrial authority or that further proceedings are not necessary or desirable in the public interest. For some time, the Commission acts under this provision without further hearing the matter. In this way, the Commission can leave the matter to be resolved within a State's jurisdiction if that appears to be more appropriate.

A matter should not be so dismissed where the issues in dispute cannot be resolved by the exercise of powers of compulsory arbitration in the relevant State jurisdiction in cases in which no other resolution can be achieved. On the other hand, the Commission should be able to dismiss a matter if it is merely an attempt to reopen an industrial agreement freely entered into by the parties in a State jurisdiction that permitted access to compulsory arbitration.

The proposed amendments recognise this situation. Accordingly, it is proposed to provide that the Commission may not dismiss or refrain from hearing a matter where compulsory arbitration cannot apply or could not have applied in the State concerned. Without such amendments, industrial disputes within the constitutionally authorised jurisdiction of the Commission could be left unresolved and one party or another could be in a position to impose an unfair result by using much greater bargaining power.

During the debate that has ensued, an honourable senator referred to representations made by the New South Wales Government concerning the proposed amendments. We are carefully considering these representations and other comments made by interested bodies during consultations over our proposals and will take account of any relevant points.

Reference has been made in the debate to the situation in Victoria. Recently, its Government changed the industrial laws in a way which has been widely condemned and has resulted in massive industrial friction. It has been pointed out during the debate that there is much that is objectionable in that legislation. I do not propose now to address those deficiencies, but I remind honourable senators that the Victorian legislation will, apart from abolishing existing State awards, end the process of compulsory arbitration.

Clearly, the proposed amendments to section 111 would apply to disputes or parts of disputes in Victoria. Equally, they would apply to any other jurisdiction which does not provide an appropriate system in which compulsory arbitration is available for disputes that cannot be resolved by other means. I emphasise that the proposed amendments do not direct the Commission how to decide any matter to which they apply. Their effect will be to ensure that the Commission hears and decides such a matter on its merits and that it cannot be dismissed without such a hearing.

In the last two months, Australia has been transfixed, I believe, by the debate on industrial relations. There is a special piquancy about this debate in the way the events have fallen out. The Opposition has released its industrial relations policy entitled, ironically, Jobsback. There is now very clearly a choice to be made on what policy the electors of this country prefer: the Jobsback policy or a policy of supporting an independent industrial relations commission able, when disputes arise between employers and employees, to conciliate and, in the event of the failure of conciliation, arbitrate to make an order which will settle the dispute.

That is what we have on the side the Government supports—a system which has been amended to provide extra flexibility to encourage the parties to confront the opportunity of workplace agreements or enterprise bargains with the award system as it exists acting as a safety net to protect minimum standards. On the other side, we have the so-called Jobsback proposal—a proposal which, in its simplest form, is to reduce bargaining between employers and an employee to an individual work contract. It is argued that this system contains some checks and balances to guarantee fairness. It is our contention that that is propaganda not supported by reference to the real world or reference to any particular fact.

The Opposition's policy is one that names a number of conditions that already exist in awards as if it has just discovered them. Those conditions exist, but many more conditions exist as well. The ones that have not been named by the Opposition are clearly up for grabs. They are clearly areas in which it is intended to reduce existing standards—standards that, moreover, I point out, have been determined by independent arbitration as fair and reasonable standards for that industry or group of workers.

Even in the area where the so-called minimums are named, there is no guarantee that unscrupulous employers will be in any way obliged to observe those minimums because, in the very direct representation of bargaining power between an employer and an individual employee, the possibility, where there are other people in a jobs queue to take the job of the worker, of the worker being offered a contract which is unacceptable, and having to then make a choice between being sacked or accepting unacceptable conditions, means that that employee cannot be protected in any way. They are in a position of exposure. They are in a position of exploitation. There is no fairness in the balance of bargaining forces between an employer and an employee in those circumstances and genuinely they are faced with the choice of the contract or the sack.

That is called the deregulated labour market. It is called by some the free labour market. Those words sound almost affectionate, but they mask a position of open exploitation with no real protections at all. While those words are bandied about in polite conversation and seem inoffensive, they mask a genuine effort to in fact reduce the living standards of Australians by reducing award entitlements and their wages as well.

This system is proposed on the basis that this will somehow cause the economic recovery of Australia. Taken as one element in a whole constellation of proposals from the Opposition, many of which, it seems, are currently going in for a review, what is true is this: the Opposition's proposal is to cut public expenditure, reduce the amount of public money in the economy and thus deflate the economy at a time in which it needs reflation and stimulation; in effect, in macro-economic terms, to drive the economy further into recession when every other advanced country in the world that has any sense is embracing stimulatory policies—policies that we ourselves have adopted and are applying.

But on top of that, while the economy would be driven further into the ground, there is an attempt, in the pretence that something fair is happening in industrial relations, to reduce wages as well. No effort is being made to incorporate training and skilling of the economy. There is a belief in the old ethic that we should work harder, not smarter. It is an attempt to make Australians low wage earners so that they can compete with low wage earners in near Asian countries. It is a choice that Australians will reject.

It is the Thatcher road; it is the road embraced by New Zealand; it is the road where there may be from time to time some minor short term gain, but a long term enduring loss. It is not a way in which workplace reform and higher productivity can be generated in this country. That is only achievable by working with Australians and with the institutions that they choose to represent them in the workplace; not by working against them and conducting some ideological war upon unions. This is not, as I have said, in the interests of the national economy. It is an effort to turn the economy back into the Dark Ages. It is an effort that defies the facts.

In one of the speeches in here a moment ago, I heard a complaint about industrial negotiation in the metal industry. There are often times in which people complain about industrial negotiation in the metal industry but, if we look at the facts, we see that Australia is now going through a record low in industrial disputation. Wages pressure is not pushing up prices and causing higher inflation. Our inflation level is 0.7 per cent for the year to now, and we are at a record low, below the levels of the OECD. We have the settings for a recovery—a recovery that would be lost.

Senator Harradine made a remark in the closing stages of his address that ought be emphasised by the Government. Senator Harradine was right when he said that these amendments before the chamber tonight are proposals that rely exclusively on the arbitration powers of the Constitution. We believe that they are the appropriate powers to enable a right that has existed in the Industrial Relations Act—or in its predecessor, the Conciliation and Arbitration Act—since the inception of those Acts, to be widened to take account of what was not contemplated at the time that arbitration was introduced in Australia in the early years of this century, that is, the possibility of a State abolishing access to an arbitration commission and not providing the workers and the employers in that State with a clear choice. When legislation is carried, if it is, employers will have a choice: the individual work contract—be Jeffed by Kennett—or to opt into an arbitration system with all of the protections and fairness that guarantees.

I cannot come to any other conclusion than that many of the things said by the Opposition here tonight in opposing this legislation have been aimed at denying people that choice. The argument that somehow Jeff Kennett has a mandate that we, the Commonwealth Government, should thus surrender our mandate in this field is a preposterous argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your mandate is well out of date.

—There is no doubt that Jeff Kennett has a mandate to govern in his State. We have a mandate to govern in Australia. In the exercise of our mandate, we will offer a choice to Victorians—and to any others in other States who might choose the Victorian road. Their choice will be to choose our system or that of the Opposition. I can only assume that much of the opposition comes from a fear that most people will choose our system, vote with their feet, shift their awards into the Federal jurisdiction—
—That is why union membership is falling.
—seek the protection and security—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Senator Chapman, you have interjected once already out of your seat. On the second occasion, it cannot be let pass. If you wish to interject, you will have to go back to your seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —seek the choice of fairness—
—He is nearly finished.
—Order! Senator Cook may have nearly finished; nevertheless, he is entitled to have the floor.

—and seek to access the rights and entitlements of our system rather than the individual exploitation that is possible under the Victorian system. I am happy—and I am sure this Government is, too—to have that choice decided by the Australian electorate at the appropriate time when the Prime Minister calls the election.

PARA.TAB: Much has been said about the so-called Jobsback proposition. There are a couple of things that I want to say about that, but I see that my time is almost nigh. The proposal for the employee advocate in the Jobsback proposal does not offer protection, because the employee advocate only acts after an agreement—one that I would contend is, by its nature, exploitative—has been concluded by an individual worker and an employer. It only acts then to enforce the terms of that agreement, not at industrial law with a precedent set down by the noble tradition of our Commission, but at common law—an area of archaic law from the last century which is out of time in its drum beat and is not applicable to modern day standards. The common law does not recognise the employer-employee relationship as we know it now. It regards that relationship as a master and a servant relationship—a concept that I believe is offensive to all Australians.

There are many other things that I could say about Jobsback, but let me foreshadow the next round of legislation that this Government intends to introduce. The International Labour Organisation is an agency of the United Nations. Through tripartite consultative mechanisms—that is, through conferences with equal numbers of workers, employers and representatives from government from all of its member states and by common resolution of its forum—it proclaims international labour conventions which it regards as the minimum level of international labour standard in the world. It is a standard that is, in many cases, below the prevailing standard in Australia. Clearly, an international forum such as a UN agency has to have regard for the economic needs of developing and underdeveloped countries. In its next round of legislation, this Government proposes to encode those standards in Australian industrial law as a further safety net and as a further protection for Australian workers.

The World Health Organisation is well known for prescribing world health standards in order to lift the world into a healthier environment. The International Labour Organisation, in the prescription of its standards, does the same to regulate fair labour practice. It seems appropriate for Australia, as a country that supports the United Nations system and believes in protective minimums, to encode those standards in legislation. We will direct our attention to three standards. The first standard provides for minimum wages. That springs from a convention adopted by all States and approved by all governments and the Commonwealth. In proposing to introduce this standard, we will ask the industrial relations commissions in their respective jurisdictions—the Commonwealth jurisdiction for the Commonwealth Commission and the State jurisdictions for the respective State commissions—to define a minimum labour standard in respect of each of the industries and award areas covered by those commissions.

The second standard is the equal pay convention—convention 100, convention 111, and the United Nations convention on discrimination against women in employment. Those conventions will ensure that equal pay is encoded as a principle in Australia. The third standard will be in relation to unfair dismissals—protection against being unfairly dismissed and the right to redundancy. That will ensure that there is proper behaviour and no victimisation at the point of termination of employment. They will be minimum standards.

I find it unbelievable that members of the Opposition, who purport to use every head of constitutional power that they can lay their hands on to impose Fightback on Australia, resist the encoding of United Nations conventions standards for fair labour practices in this country and are opposed to minimum wages, equal pay and unfair dismissals. The fact that members of the Opposition are opposed to them will be understood by Australian electors come election time. I can guarantee that. The fact that they are speaks volumes for their real intention in the field of industrial relations. (Time expired)

That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
