SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 makes a number of amendments to the Trade Practices Act 1974 and I will be concentrating on the three most significant areas in my remarks tonight. The first relates to the merger test, which is probably the most controversial part of the amendments.

PARA.TAB: Section 50 of the Trade Practices Act currently provides that a corporation shall not acquire shares in, or assets of, a body corporate where the acquisition would result, or be likely to result, in the corporation being in a position to dominate the market for goods or services. If the corporation is already in a position to dominate a market for goods or services, it is prohibited from acquiring shares in or assets of a competitor or likely competitor, if the acquisition would strengthen its power to dominate that market. This is, obviously, the market domination test.

This Bill amends section 50 in two ways. Firstly, where it currently applies only to acquisitions of shares in bodies corporate, pursuant to the amendment in this Bill it will also apply to the acquisition of assets of any person. Thus the merger test will be able to be applied to mergers or acquisitions between companies and partnerships, or companies and individuals. The second and most significant change is that the acquisition of shares or assets would be prohibited if it would lead to a substantial lessening of competition.

The question of whether the appropriate merger test is the market dominance test or the substantial lessening of competition test has long been a controversial one. It has been the subject of argument and almost constant review since the trade practices legislation was first introduced in 1974. At that time, a substantial lessening of competition test applied. This was changed in 1977 to the market dominance test on the grounds that there should be no unnecessary impediment, legislative or administrative, to the attainment of rationalisation of Australian industry. It was considered that the market dominance test would lead to an improvement in Australia's international competitiveness.

When the question was reviewed in 1986, it was decided to retain the market dominance test. In 1988, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs recommended the continued retention of the market dominance test and noted that there was insufficient justification for changing it. That Committee had this to say about returning to the substantial lessening of competition test:

SPEECH.PARA: It is widely accepted that this test would involve a significant lowering of the threshold, thereby subjecting a wider range of mergers to TPC scrutiny. This proposal would, therefore, have significant resource implications for the TPC. It would also reduce the level of harmonisation of Australian and New Zealand merger law. In addition, a return to the pre-1977 test would involve increased uncertainty for business, and may, therefore, impede decision-making processes.
The Trade Practices Commission in its submission to that inquiry argued against changing the market dominance test. The Government supported the findings of that Committee.

PARA.TAB: As recently as August 1991, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) stated the view that the Government was unconvinced that there was sufficient justification for reverting to the substantial lessening of competition test. However, by that stage, the inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which was an inquiry initiated by Senator Spindler, was under way. In December 1991, that Committee recommended that section 50 be amended to prohibit mergers or acquisitions which would have the effect or likely effect of substantially lessening competition in a substantial market for goods and services. Senator Kemp from this side of the chamber dissented from that recommendation.

The Committee further recommended that a number of factors be included in the Act to make clear the ambit of the new test. This position reflects the view of the current Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission, Professor Alan Fels. Professor Fels does not share the opinion of two former chairmen of the TPC, Professor Bob Baxt and Mr Bob McComas, nor the TPC itself which was arguing only two years ago for the retention of the market dominance test.

In addition to the coalition, other groups which are opposed to any change to the merger test include the Business Council of Australia, the Australian Chamber of Commerce, the Australian Mining Industry Council, the Law Council of Australia and the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants. The market dominance test has now been in operation since 1977, and a body of case law interpreting the test has now been accumulated.

One of the strongest arguments against changing the test is that it will lead to uncertainty. It will be years before enough cases have come before the courts to establish what `substantial lessening of competition' actually means. It is also apparent that many other comparable industrialised countries are tending towards market dominance tests; for example, Germany, France, Spain and New Zealand. To sum up, on balance in our view there is insufficient evidence to indicate that the merger test should be changed. Moreover, there are good reasons why the market dominance test should be retained.

This Bill also picks up the recommendation of the Senate Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs that there should be a list of the factors which a court would be required to take into account in considering whether or not the merger test had been breached, such as actual and potential level of import competition, barriers to entry and concentration in the market. Of the nine factors in the Bill, at least five are already taken into account in applying the market dominance test, as demonstrated in cases such as Australian Meat Holdings. It is entirely possible that, after another 10 or 15 years of litigation and uncertainty in the marketplace, the substantial lessening of competition test may end up being applied in much the same way as the market dominance test.

The second major change in this Bill relates to unconscionable conduct. Section 52A of the Act currently provides that a corporation shall not, in trade or commerce, in connection with the supply or possible supply of goods or services to a person, engage in unconscionable conduct. Some of the factors which can be taken into account in determining whether a corporation's dealing with a consumer has been unconscionable include: the relevant strengths of the bargaining positions of the corporation and the consumer; whether the consumer was required to comply with conditions that were not reasonably necessary for the protection of the legitimate interests of the corporation; whether the consumer was able to understand relevant documents; whether undue influence or pressure was used; and the price for which the consumer could have obtained equivalent goods or services from another supplier.

The 1990 report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology on small business in Australia recommended that section 52A be extended to commercial transactions where small business was disadvantaged in its dealings in the same way as a consumer. This would lead to great uncertainty in commercial transactions. It amounts to allowing parties to ask a court to rewrite a contract into which they voluntarily entered. It is also unnecessary. The courts have proved more than equal to the challenge of developing new remedies for inequitable dealings, through cases such as Amadio and Blomley v. Ryan.

The Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee recommended the repeal of section 52A, pursuant to which a consumer contract could be set aside on the grounds of being unconscionable. The Committee further recommended that legislation be introduced giving the Trade Practices Commission the ability to bring proceedings on behalf of a person who has a right of action at common law arising from the unconscionable conduct of another. That Committee recognised that extending the ambit of section 52A to commercial transactions would introduce substantial uncertainty into those transactions. It concluded that the existing equitable remedies dealing with unconscionable conduct, together with traditional remedies for fraud, misrepresentation, duress, undue influence and mistake provide an avenue for redress in almost all, if not every, of the serious cases where unconscionability is an issue.

According to a press release of the Attorney-General on 26 June this year, the Government intended to legislate as recommended in the 1990 House of Representatives Committee report to prohibit unconscionable conduct in commercial transactions. However, we are pleased to note that the provision proposed in this Bill does not go that far. Proposed new section 51AA prohibits corporations from engaging in behaviour that is unconscionable `within the meaning of the unwritten law, from time to time, of the States and Territories', which was the position, as I interpret it, of the Senate Committee.

This proposed provision enacts the equitable principles of unconscionable conduct as recognised by the High Court in cases such as Amadio and Blomley v. Ryan. It does not change the substantive law. It also gives the Trade Practices Commission the power to investigate alleged breaches. This amendment, in our view, strikes a sensible balance, and the coalition is supporting it.

I should note that our support for this amendment is not shared by the Franchisors Association of Australasia, which does not accept the argument that it would be neutral in effect. The Franchisors Association fears that some of the standard practices of franchisors would infringe the unconscionable conduct provision; for example, offering a franchise with renewable provisions on a `take it or leave it' basis with the franchisor being able to use its discretion freely as to the terms of any renewal.

Specifically, the Association is concerned that new section 51AA will be highly productive of litigation, that the need for a provision such as section 51AA has not been demonstrated and that the proposed changes will lead to an extension of general law principles and greater uncertainty in this area of the law. Section 51AA will implicitly encourage the courts to interfere more frequently in situations where commercial dealings are impugned as unfair, and the cost of the change will outweigh any potential benefits. It is further concerned that the Trade Practices Commission has not yet issued any draft guidelines to indicate how it intends to approach the unconscionable conduct provision.

The Franchisors Association has noted that the explanatory memorandum indicates that section 51AA would apply only to situations where a party had a special disability or was taken advantage of at the time of originally entering into a particular transaction. However, it is concerned by indications apparently from within the Trade Practices Commission that the section could be used to strike down an agreement because it had the effect at some later stage of being unfavourable to one party. From this debate the association is seeking a clear indication that the new section 51AA is intended to apply only at the time at which an agreement is entered into, and the Minister might respond to that.

The Franchisors Association's concern about proposed section 51AA is shared by the National Theatre Owners Association of Australia, although it is arguing from the opposite point of view. The National Theatre Owners Association fears that proposed section 51AA would not protect parties in a weak bargaining position against unconscionable conduct. The Association contends that independent cinemas across Australia will eventually be forced to close because of the unconscionable conduct of film distributors. Its complaints include the supply of films on a no share basis, the late supply of films, excessive film hire charges, and the failure to supply day and date release.

The Association has had trouble finding a provision in the Trade Practices Act which is appropriate to its circumstances, and its advice is that these amendments will not protect it against the conduct of film distributors of which it complains. This is because, for section 51AA to apply, the members of the Association would need to establish that they were under a special disadvantage, as was explained by the judges in Amadio's case and in Blomley v. Ryan; for example, that they lacked essential business acumen, as well as being in a weakened bargaining position.

The Association believes that in order to be protected under the Trade Practices Act against what in its opinion are the damaging trade practices of the major film distributors, the criteria for unconscionable conduct should relate only to the inequality of bargaining position. The Association believes that it is solely due to the inequality of the bargaining position of the major distributors that the distributors can impose conditions which probably fall outside the Trade Practices Act but which are nevertheless crippling for independent cinemas and are, therefore, unconscionable.

When the National Theatre Owners Association raised this matter with the Attorney-General's Department, it was suggested that the Association take up the matter of unfair business practices in concentrated markets in a submission to the national competition policy review. The Minister again may care to comment in the course of this debate, in addition to the questions raised by the Franchisors Association, on those raised by the National Theatre Owners Association. Hopefully that will be one step towards meeting their real concerns.

The third amendment to this Bill that I wish to mention relates to penalties. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs recommended that section 76(1) of the Act be amended to substantially increase the pecuniary penalties available to punish breaches of part IV of the Act, and that section 79(1) be amended to substantially increase the pecuniary penalties to punish breaches of the provisions of part V of the Act. The coalition supports the recommended increase in penalties because they have not been increased since 1974 when the Act first came into force.

With respect to part IV of the Trade Practices Act which deals with restrictive trade practices, the Bill proposes a tenfold increase in penalties for individuals, from $50,000 to $500,000, and a 40-fold increase in penalties for corporations, from $250,000 to $10m. However, not all sections within part IV are to be subject to the increased fines. No increase is proposed in sections 45D and 45E, the provisions which apply to anti-competitive conduct of trade unions.

As far as the coalition is concerned, there is absolutely no justification for imposing penalties on corporations which are 40 times greater than those imposed on trade unions. The principle at stake here is equality before the law. If a law is breached, the offender ought to be subject to the same level of penalty as any other offender. It should make no difference who one is or who one knows. In our view there is no room for a `mates rates' regime in this legislation. I therefore foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment on behalf of the coalition to ensure that breaches of sections 45D and 45E will attract the same $10m maximum penalty as the rest of the provisions in part IV.

I understand that, not surprisingly, the Australian Democrats will not be supporting our amendment. However, I am told that their argument against supporting the amendment on this occasion is based on the referral by Senator Bell to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training of certain other matters in relation to sections 45D and 45E. However, I submit that this fact should not inhibit the Democrats' support for the coalition amendments to bring the penalties that apply to trade unions into line with those that apply to other bodies corporate. Equity is something that I would have thought the Democrats would support. I point out that the terms of reference of the present Committee inquiry do not include any mention of the adequacy or otherwise of the penalties attaching to those sections. The coalition's amendment on penalties is therefore a completely separate issue.

The Government is also proposing to increase penalties for breaches of part V, which is concerned with consumer protection. The maximum fine for an individual is to be increased from $20,000 to $40,000, and the maximum for a corporation from $100,000 to $200,000. I gather that the Australian Democrats are to move in the committee stage for these fines to be further increased to $100,000 and $1m respectively. The coalition, however, on balance favours the Government's penalty in this part.

Unlike the penalties in part IV and part V, penalties have been increased relatively recently; that is, in 1986. The heavier part IV penalties apply to offences involving restrictive trade practices and are simply a different case from penalties under the consumer protection provisions in part V. We do not see the need to impose relativities as the Democrats are trying to achieve.

In summary, whilst the Bill raises many important issues, it is the exemption of trade unions from the penalty increases which will apply to everybody else under the Bill to which the coalition particularly objects, as will be reflected by the amendment which we will move in the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is discussing the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. The Trade Practices Act was enacted in 1974 to combat the inevitable trend towards monopolies as a consequence of the business world's desire to reduce competition and to increase profits at the expense of higher prices for the consumer. If we doubt that that is a fairly uniform desire in business, we have no-one better than the Business Council's representative who, at an inquiry in Canberra on 26 September 1991, stated that every business is trying to reduce competition.

PARA.TAB: This amendment Bill seeks to strengthen the provisions against mergers which lessen competition and against unconscionable conduct, while clarifying the provisions prohibiting misuse of market power, increasing monetary penalties and ensuring that written undertakings businesses have given to the Trade Practices Commission to cease or modify particular conduct are enforceable by the Trade Practices Commission.

The Democrats welcome the amendments to section 50 on mergers and acquisitions, which will prohibit acquisitions and mergers which `would have the effect, or be likely to have the effect, of substantially lessening competition in a market'. This criterion replaces the previous benchmark of market dominance. The proposed change is very welcome indeed, not least because this amendment is the culmination of a sequence of events which started with my proposed amendment in April 1991 seeking to introduce this criterion in lieu of the current market dominance benchmark. That was introduced by the Fraser Government in 1974, mainly to facilitate the takeover of the Herald and Weekly Times by News Ltd.

The proposed amendment continued life as a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Following an exhaustive inquiry, that Committee, the Cooney committee, recommended that this toughening of the anti-merger provision be introduced. I am delighted that the Government has accepted that recommendation and is now implementing it through these amendments.

Interpretation of the new merger provisions will be assisted by the inclusion of a non-exhaustive list of relevant matters which the Trade Practices Commission must consider in assessing whether a particular merger substantially lessens competition. The decision of the Commission is subject to appeal. However, the main element which makes this provision a strategic provision in boosting the international competitiveness of Australian industries is the retention and strengthening of the authorisation process. It allows for a merger to proceed if the Trade Practices Commission finds that the merger will be `a benefit to the public'.

Without limiting the range of public benefits which the TPC may examine, these amendments provide that a significant increase in the real value of exports or a significant substitution of domestic products for imported goods is to be regarded as a public benefit and consideration must also be given to any other relevant matter relating to the international competitiveness of any Australian industry. I believe that we should consider this provision as a benchmark, because it signifies a departure from the economic rationalist position of leaving it all to the market. It is proposed to insert a legislative provision which is directed towards increasing, by intervention, our international competitiveness.

Where the TPC considers that there are complex issues involved, the time limit for consideration by the Trade Practices Commission of an application for a merger authorisation is reduced from 45 to 30 days. Where there are complex issues or other special circumstances, the Trade Practices Tribunal must consider appeals from determinations made by the TPC in merger authorisation cases within 60 days.

Amendments to section 46 of the Trade Practices Act, which deals with the misuse of market power, clarify references to a competitor or person to include references to competitors or persons generally or to a particular class or classes of competitors or persons. The section does not provide divestiture as a remedy, as recommended by my dissenting opinion in the Committee report. I regret that. I would have thought it was time to put some teeth into these provisions.

The Bill further introduces a new part IVA into the Act to deal with unconscionable conduct. The existing section 52A, generally concerned with consumer transactions, is to be moved to this new part of the Act and renumbered as section 51AB. Part IVA also introduces a new provision, section 51AA, which prohibits unconscionable conduct by corporations `in trade and commerce . . . within the meaning of the unwritten law'. Although transactions covered by this new provision are already covered by equitable doctrines, the Government considers it advantageous to address the unwritten law so as to `make available remedies under the Trade Practices Act and make possible the involvement of the Trade Practices Commission'.

I believe that these amendments are particularly important for small business. For a number of years small business has been asking for unconscionable conduct to be an avenue of action open to them. So far it has been open only to consumers—that is, in a transaction between a business and a consumer. This amendment will open it up for action to be taken where unconscionable conduct is found to have taken place in business relations between two businesses.

Some of the complaints that we have received of examples of such conduct have concerned small businesses which were forced into unfavourable contracts by large shopping centre corporations leasing space to them. I have also received representations, as has the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, from franchising organisations in the poultry industry as well as from small cinema operators. After careful examination, I believe that the concerns expressed are likely to be met by the Trade Practices Act, as amended by the Bill. In particular, I believe that the concerns of small cinema operators will be met by the new section 51AA. Certainly the Democrats will support that amendment and will ensure that it passes.

Any residual concerns could best be addressed, I believe, by the inquiry into competition, announced recently by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I would also appreciate it if the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) would confirm that the terms of reference of that inquiry are wide enough for the inquiry to receive submissions on the effects the Act, as amended, is found to have in practice; for instance, by the franchising operators that have approached us.

The Bill also increases pecuniary penalties for most breaches under the competition provision in part IV. The maximum penalty for contravention by a body corporate of a part IV provision, other than sections 45D and 45E, is increased from $250,000 to $10m. The maximum penalty for a contravention of part IV by a natural person will also be increased from $50,000 to $500,000. I note that Senator Hill has foreshadowed that the Opposition's amendment will apply the increases to sections 45D and 45E. We will not support that. I will deal with his comments and with our reasons for this action during the committee stage.

The Bill also increases the penalties for breaches of the consumer protection provisions in part V from $100,000 to $200,000 for a body corporate and from $20,000 to $40,000 for a natural person. These latter amendments are clearly inadequate, and the Australian Democrats will be moving amendments to increase them. I express some regret—I was told today—that the Opposition will not be supporting those. We believe that it is important that consumers receive the same sort of protection as business people.

Further, the Bill inserts a new section 87B to provide legislative recognition of the existing practice where the Commission accepts written undertakings from businesses to cease particular conduct or to take action which will lessen the otherwise undesirable effects of their conduct. This aims to avoid the possibility of prolonged litigation. This also is supported by the Democrats. Finally, I will be moving amendments to allow representative action by the Trade Practices Commission for part V—the same sort of action that at this stage is already available for part IV.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 amends section 50 of the Trade Practices Act which changes Australia's competition policy. It will also assist small business by amending section 52A of the Trades Practices Act by not only extending unconscionable conduct to domestic and household cases but also extending unconscionable conduct by corporations, trade and commerce. Section 46 is also amended to take account of business using excessive market power for anti-competitive purposes. But the importance of this Bill is that it changes Australia's competition policy from one of market domination to lessening competition in a substantial market for goods and services.

PARA.TAB: The present position under section 50 of the Trade Practices Act is the market domination test where mergers are prohibited which would result or be likely to result in a corporation being in a position to dominate a market for goods and services. These are fine sounding words but they have proved to be totally ineffective to provide Australia's business with a legal framework that allows competition in Australia. In effect, under the competition policy as it now stands, mergers, acquisitions and takeovers can occur where only two competitors are left in a market. In some cases that may be reduced to only one manufacturer if there is deemed to be competition from imports. In reality, that is no competition policy at all.

What has happened in Australia under the open slather, laissez faire, no holds barred policy, has been a spate of takeovers, mergers and acquisitions that have become unbalanced and have not been in the best interests of Australia's business. Efficient, profitable, well-managed businesses have been swallowed up as they have been taken over in merger mania as bigger companies have gone into buying sprees using the profits of the conquered company for the next raid. Profits that should have been set aside for research and development, developing new products and upgrading of new plant and equipment, have been squandered on the never ending acquisition of new companies.

In Australia it is easier for a company to buy its competitor out than to compete with it in the marketplace. During the eighties we have seen the double combination of excessive takeovers by `corporate cowboys', aided and abetted by our inadequate competition policy. Good, reliable employing companies, ranging from Channel 7 and Channel 10 to long term country town merchants, have been taken over and then forced to close down or have their share prices reduced, or they are forced into receivership. Last year, the three major paint companies—Berger, British and Dulux—amalgamated, leaving virtually only Taubmans as the main competitor. Following this, the price rose 30 per cent.

The Allied Mills, Goodman Fielder, Gillespie bread industry takeovers eliminated any sustained price competition in the bread industry. Coles-Myer removed a substantial competitor from retail markets and built up market concentration. None of these mergers gave cheaper prices, better choice for consumers, any greater access to supplies, or any increase in jobs. In fact, in many cases the contrary applied. The other downside of this merger mania was that it allowed massive market forces to build up, whether it is in the grocery trade with 70 per cent of the total market held by Woolworths, Coles-Myer and Franklins, and the hardware market controlled by the same Woolworths, Coles-Myer, and Burns Philp. The electrical industry has not escaped either, with Vox taking over Chandlers, Errol Stewart, Billy Guys, Brashes, Alan Cash, Charlie Carter and R.S. Martin. The other players are K-Mart, Coles-Myer, Big W, Woolworths, David Jones and Retravision. Whether the industries are retail, food processing, manufacturing or abattoirs, over the last 10 years mergers have been rife in Australia.

This Bill replaces the old test under section 50 and amends it to prohibit mergers that would have the effect or likely effect of substantially lessening competition in a substantial market. This legislation has its genesis in the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, chaired by Senator Cooney, in its inquiry into mergers, monopolies and acquisitions. I was not a member of that Committee but gave evidence strongly supporting the recommendations that came forward from it. My National Party colleague Senator O'Chee also supported the change in competition policy and recorded his vote that way. In evidence, I supported the Committee's findings and I strongly support this legislation.

These changes have been part of a personal campaign of mine over the last three years. In any change of legislation that alters the boundaries of Australia's main business laws, there are going to be winners and losers. Australia's 800,000 small businesses and 150,000 farmers will welcome this legislative change. Even medium size and larger sized businesses cannot accept any longer that 80 per cent of their total output is in the hands of three of the four major retailers. These huge retail chains have the power of life and death over manufacturers and farmers. Processors and factory owners are caught between a rock and a hard place in their dealings with these huge retailing conglomerates. They either deal with them and submit themselves to the plethora of discounts, promotional fees, preferred supplier discounts, special catalogue discounts, corporate rebates, shelf space fees—just to name a few—or they do not have access to a very substantial part of Australia's retail market, which they need to gain economies of scale to run their factories at 100 per cent efficiency.

Manufacturers must have large production runs to obtain factory cost and labor efficiencies. If they go to the major chains and negotiate a deal to sell products, they get access to market share, but many are forced into a whole range of non-negotiable extra costs being imposed by the retailers. Over the last 20 years retailing has changed for the worse. Manufacturers once gave a wholesale price to the retailer. With the exception of perhaps a settlement discount, that was the price. Those utopian days have changed for the worse as far as Australian manufacturing is concerned. The bigger the retailers become, the more market they have, the more leverage they have on manufacturers, food processors and farmers, and the more that leverage is used on gaining more and more profit through screwing extra margins from various forms of rebate. In a paper prepared for the Australian dairy farmer organisation it was stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The lion's share of profits of the Australian retailer appears to be generated by rebates provided by manufacturers rather than allowing any viable return from endeavours.

That is exactly what is happening. I give an example of a manufacturer supplying to a major chain: off the normal wholesale price he pays advertising, 4 per cent; end of month settlement fee, 4 per cent; promotion and sale bill, 3 per cent; corporate supplier, 3 per cent; and discount off wholesale price, 18 per cent. That is around 40 per cent extra discount, and it is impossible to give. There is not that profit in any item to pass on to any retailer. The manufacturer must inflate his price to meet these rebates.

PARA.TAB: The point I want to make strongly is that in many cases the Australian consumer is paying higher prices because of the retail market dominance in Australia. The dominance of retailers not only is affecting the Australian manufacturing sector but also it is having a severe effect on our farmers, graziers and pig producers, and I know, Madam Acting Deputy President, that that concerns you. While this market domination is allowed to occur, the only defence primary industry has is to have statutory marketing authorities. Retailers have become the price setters, telling the food processors what they will pay. The food processor has no option if he wants to stay in business other than to bear down hard on prices that are being given to the primary producer.

Everyone is the loser. Neither the manufacturer, the processor nor the farmer is receiving a fair return for his product. The consumer misses out on lower prices from reduced competition among fewer retailers, the chance to buy more products through innovation, and the development of new products. Another effect of allowing Australia's retail sector merely to merge to where there are three chains controlling 70 per cent of the market and have huge market dominance is to give

SPEECH.PARA: them the buying power to import large quantities of subsidised surpluses from foreign countries.

PARA.TAB: It has been well documented that there are over $2 billion of food products coming into Australia and increasing year by year, products ranging from imported ham from Canada—which has over 20 subsidies—to tomatoes, canned peaches, pears, and pineapples. In fact, there is a whole smorgasbord of food flooding into Australia. Much of this food attracts foreign government subsidies. There are $412 billion worth of subsidies on primary production worldwide, and many of these surpluses end up being imported under generic brands.

To combat this loss of market share to the generic or home brand market product, the Australian fruit industry was forced to sell at cost or less than cost to achieve some factory cost recovery and to maintain market share. The fruit industry, like other Australian manufacturers, was not able to obtain a price that reflected the skills, the expertise, the investment and the experience of its processing plants or its grower shareholders. In fact, it was cross-subsidising profitable brand names with losses on generics. In some cases imports of generic brands have now gained one-third of Australia's market share, threatening the existence of some industries.

Some of these industries have won anti-dumping cases. They proved that imports of canned fruit were subsidised and were successful in having countervailing duties applied. They then increased their prices to take account of those duties, so that they would not lose money on generic brands, only to be told by the mouthpiece of the supermarket chains, Mr Bevan, the chairman of the Australian Institute of Supermarkets, that they were manipulating the markets and were threatened by further imports.

Australia does not need this type of dominance that can threaten the very existence of our primary and secondary industries. Food manufacturing is Australia's biggest industry. It generates $20 billion a year in sales. It accounts for 20 per cent of all manufacturing production and employs 16 per cent of the work force. The food industry needs consideration. It needs to be nurtured to grow and flourish and not to be driven backwards by the demands of retailers wanting more and more rebates. There are some larger manufacturers, such as Coca-Cola and Arnotts—although Arnotts looks like it has hit the skids; in fact, it has been successfully taken over—which have such accepted popular products with the consumer that they are able to stand up against the demands of huge chains, but they are the exception rather than the rule.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, is forever talking about value adding to Australia's primary products to turn Australia into the processed food bowl of South East Asia. I support him 100 per cent. But for the Australian food processing industry to flourish and grow it must have a strong domestic base. It must also have a strong primary industry that can get a return for its investment.

The foundation for a strong export industry is a strong, virile domestic industry. The market domination that we have seen built up in Australian retailing and food processing is not allowing that to happen. On 8 February, it was revealed in the Australian newspaper that the Coles-Myer Group forced its suppliers to contribute 20 per cent of the estimated first year sales of new products going into supermarkets. This 20 per cent charge amounts to many thousands of dollars. Manufacturers and retailers cannot afford the luxury of placing new products on the market.

On 22 February, Mr McQueen, the general manager of the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation, was quoted in the Australian newspaper as saying that it could cost up to $250,000 to launch a new product on to the Australian retail market. The market concentration that has been allowed to develop in Australia is wrong. It is not helping business to flourish and grow. It is restrictive and introverted. It is killing innovation and stopping new products reaching the market. There are very few small businesses that could afford to launch a new product and, I would suggest, not many big ones either at $250,000 a go.

I do not want to single out the grocery chains alone. What has happened in the food market is repeated in every other market. The hardware market is down to three or four major retailers. The electrical industry has not escaped excessive market concentration, with four or five players remaining. In Australia it does not matter what the market is, whether it be processing, retailing, manufacturing or abattoirs.

The cattle producers of Queensland are greatly concerned at the concentration of market domination which has been allowed to build up in the killing sector under the present competition policy. At present 86 per cent of slaughter capacity in North Queensland is in the hands of one abattoir owner; it is 51 per cent in central Queensland. Cattle growers are saying that the lack of competition is being reflected in the buying auctions and that the sales are not giving a true indication of value. Only a couple of weeks ago Smorgons purchased Angliss Holdings in Queensland. These abattoirs could have been sold to AMH, which would have resulted in a further concentration in the cattle processing industry in Queensland. When the purchase was made by Smorgons, there was a unanimous sigh of relief from the Queensland cattle industry.

The present situation in Queensland has resulted in high levels of control which are denying the producer competitive bidding in the yards, as well as imposing restrictions on the export and domestic product potential in the long term. A merger test under the Trade Practices Act must ensure that an adequate level of competition remains. The cattlemen of Queensland will welcome prospects of avoiding any further market concentration of market domination in the killing sector. This Bill will make it more difficult for abattoirs to merge under section 50 of the Trade Practices Act.

For the Australian economy to be market driven, market forces must be allowed to exist. A market that has excessive market power is not a free market. In many cases in Australia, through mergers, acquisitions and takeovers, those market forces no longer exist. It must also be recognised that with a small population of 17 million people, with most surviving countries using world class technology, there must be room to buy or amalgamate, but there must be a balance. That balance has moved too far one way and needs to be moved back, with a stricter substantial lessening of competition test.

The Economic Planning and Advisory Committee recently stated that Australian industry is at a point where policy makers may need to address the issue of whether merger law, developed to allow a marked degree of industry rationalisation, is still relevant in current economic conditions. The Trade Practices Commission, in its submission to the Cooney committee, is of the opinion that the present merger test has resulted in anti-competitive consequences. My own experience as a manufacturers agent for 18 years and my continual contact with both primary and secondary industry have confirmed my view that we must realign Australia's competition policy.

For the last three years I have continually campaigned to raise this issue, in parliament, within my own Party and in the press, to point out the problems that Australia's competition policy is causing the business community. It is not working for Australia; it needs to be readjusted. The argument that only big conglomerates can successfully enter the international market is wrong. I totally disagree with the Business Council of Australia in its call for world scale players to get economies of scale at the expense of small and medium sized businesses. Many efficient production companies have been swallowed up in the frenzy of takeovers in the 1980s. These companies, because of their efficiency, productivity and profits have become a target for bigger, less efficient takeover merchants who generate profits by takeovers and then deprive the acquired company of capital necessary to continue to grow and thrive.

Research in America has revealed that market domination and concentration of market power have resulted in dearer consumer prices and that many takeovers and mergers have been failures. The investment in the acquired firm rarely reaches the required return and productivity level, which takes years to be regained. Australia needs a business sector that is growing and innovative, that can develop new products and get those products on to the market, and ultimately be a strong competitor in the international marketplace.

The business sector will be made stronger by the development of a management in touch with the needs of its customers—a business that is lean, mean and efficient. Australian competition policy has failed Australia's business sector by allowing it to be cut back by takeovers and mergers, by not allowing business to have effective market access to Australia's retail sector, making it easier to buy out a competitor, rather than competing against a trade rival by either developing a better product or by reducing prices.

The introduction of the new merger test will not be the immediate panacea for Australia's business problems. The passing of this legislation will not suddenly see business have access to markets. Market concentration will not be wound back overnight. The passing of this legislation will be the first step in correcting Australia's competition policy. New retail businesses will have to grow and those businesses will have to develop. It will take a lot of time before we see competition grow in Australia. A journey of a thousand miles starts with the first step. The passing of this legislation is that first step.

This legislation will no doubt be tested in the courts. There is a lot at stake. But if the amendment to the Trade Practices Act prohibits mergers or acquisitions which would have the likely effect of substantially lessening competition in a substantial market for goods and services, then it deserves the support of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill. I was a member of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which prepared and tabled the report entitled Mergers, monopolies and acquisitions. This is what the Bill is about. Obviously I support the legislation.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased that the Government has accepted a number of the major recommendations of the Committee. I am disappointed that it did not accept one of the recommendations that Senator Spindler and I supported in a dissenting report; that is, to give the Trade Practices Commission an absolute power of divestiture. As we develop competition policy in this country in the years ahead it will become increasingly inevitable that such a power will have to be given to the Trade Practices Commission.

I know that there are many vested interests in the business community who are paranoid about such an absolute divestiture power being given. It is a power that I anticipate would probably never be used. But the fact that it is there would be a warning to corporations and business organisations that if they get too greedy there is an absolute power under the Trade Practices Act to force divestiture. This power exists in the equivalent legislation in the United States. All of these things have to be qualified by having a public interest test. It can be argued that there are circumstances in which these tests would not apply because the national interest—the public interest—is wider than just a narrow piece of competition.

I am delighted that the Government has accepted the recommendation to change the test from dominance of the market to substantial lessening of competition. This is a major step forward. I agree with many of the remarks made by Senator Boswell, who I acknowledge has been a most enthusiastic non-member of the Committee. He made sure that we boosted our efforts and kept our shoulders to the wheel in order to bring down some recommendations. I think that was indicated in his speech tonight. I know that Senator Boswell has often expressed views about big business, capitalism and so on that would be considered to the left of the Labor Party. But I suspect that that reflects his interest in representing small businesses and small farmers. Many members of the Committee had similar interests.

I would like to raise with the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) the list in clause 6 of the various tests for substantial lessening of competition. The tests are to some extent different from the ones the Committee recommended. I wonder whether, when we come to the committee stage, the Minister could give us some explanations of why the tests listed on page 3 of the Bill had to be different from the ones the Committee listed in its report. I am not saying that ours are any better, but I would like an explanation of why they are different in a number of respects.

I have already mentioned that I was disappointed that the absolute power of divestiture is not in the Bill. But I am delighted that the unconscionable conduct provision is included. It is about time that small and medium sized businesses had the opportunity to defend themselves against large organisations—whether a franchiser or a big shopping network—which have all the advantages in negotiating a contract. There is now some remedy. I believe that it will take some time for this section of the legislation to settle down and become acceptable in the community. I am sure it will. I am sure that some of the fears some people have raised about the change to this area will not come to fruition and that the unconscionable conduct amendment will be a real advantage for small business and, above all else, the Australian community.

I want to make a couple of remarks about the recent statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about competition policy. He has ordered a number of inquiries, through the Trade Practices Commission itself and by individuals looking at improving competition policy in Australia. They are all to be congratulated. They are moving into areas in which we have never before considered it necessary to have competition policy. They deal with the professions and with statutory authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, leave those alone.

—We cannot pick and choose in competition policy; it is either all in or all out. I believe that in the long run even statutory authorities have to come within the ambit of competition policy. Unfortunately, there is too much evidence that often publicly owned statutory authorities in the end take action that is against the interests of the general public and the general consumer. That may not suit everybody, but I think it will have to come if we are to protect a market and a group of producers who are subject to a statutory marketing authority.

PARA.TAB: I hope that when the competition policy initiatives of the Prime Minister come forward in the months ahead, they will not be deflected and defeated by the array of vested interests in this community. There is no doubt they will come out of the woodwork to attack these proposals to improve competition in our business community and in the community generally. We must not allow ourselves to be guided by vested interests such as the Law Council of Australia or the Business Council of Australia. They gave evidence to the Senate Committee which would have led one to believe that if we adopted any of these proposals it would be almost the equivalent of the end of the business community in Australia. I think those fears will prove to be unfounded. I do not think the Parliament or any government should give too much weight to vested interests trying to argue that by making the economy more competitive we will end up doing in Australia's business. I believe that competition policy, properly structured, will expand the business community and give more opportunities.

My final point is something that Senator Boswell touched on. Like Senator Boswell, I think the argument that we need to allow big mergers to take place to get sizeable organisations to operate in the overseas markets is false. I think we will do better in the longer run promoting our business opportunities and economic opportunities in our own region. We need to encourage many more small and medium sized businesses to get out there and promote themselves. They need to sell goods and services without having to rely on merging and being gobbled up by one or two big Australian companies. That would serve the Australian economy very well.

I am pleased, even at this late hour, to have had an opportunity to speak. As a member of the Senate Committee, I believe that our report was seminal in changing the policy of not just government but of all political parties; of changing these important tests so that we can have a more effective and competitive business policy in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators may have heard the name Mike Milken, a man who was famous as the junk bond king of the 1980s. Some honourable senators may even know the name of his bank, Drexel Burnham Lambert. But few perhaps would know the name of the chairman of the bank, one Fred Joseph. Drexel Burnham Lambert was an interesting bank because it basically ran on just one product, and that was junk bonds. The purpose of the junk bonds was to help fuel the takeover mania of the 1980s. Senator Panizza notes that he has heard of Fred Joseph.

PARA.TAB: Every year, Drexel Burnham Lambert would hold a big selling festival called the Predators Ball, usually at somewhere like the Beverley Hilton. It would be four or five days of very lavish promotion. During that time, the bank would take the opportunity to plug its message. In 1985 Fred Joseph concluded the presentation on the last night by saying to a packed audience, `For the first time in history we've levelled the playing field. The small can go after the big'. Apparently Fred Joseph was not too sure whether the message had sunk in, but afterwards in the men's washroom he heard two of the conference participants speaking. The conversation went along the lines of one saying to the other, `Did you hear what Fred said?'. The other one said, `Yeah. Wow, it's awesome'. What they did not realise, of course, was that it was wrong, because the small cannot go after the big.

In real, properly run businesses, small companies cannot go gobbling large companies. But, unfortunately, it is all too frequent that large companies go gobbling the small ones. I think if we are to have innovation in this country, if we are to have a real competitive spirit, it is most important that we safeguard small companies, especially small publicly listed companies, from the predatory attitudes of some of their larger competitors.

We all know, especially those of us who have been involved in business, that big companies sometimes lose that competitive drive and seek to replace competition by removing competition; that is, they seek to take over their rivals rather than keeping up the drive for innovation, rather than keeping the competitive edge and making sure that they remain lean and efficient and productive and competitive. Here we are in a very small country, and we talk about how we can take on the rest of the world!

One of the fallacies that float around at times is that our export drive will be led by the big companies, that only the big companies have the muscle to take on the international markets. That is not true if the big companies are not competitive, are not efficient, are not lean or are not responsive to what the market is doing out there. Those characteristics are most frequently found amongst Australia's small businesses, not Australia's large businesses.

That is why I am very proud to have been a member of this Committee and very proud to have been part of the process of handing down the recommendations which are reflected in the legislation here this evening. I am particularly proud of some of the recommendations in relation to competition and unconscionability. We all know cases of small companies or small business operators which have basically been stood over, intimidated and beaten down by the power of the big business partners with whom they have to deal. This is not a socialist perspective; it is a perspective based on real life. It is a perspective based on the evidence which was presented to our Committee, evidence that was very ably presented by my Senate leader and colleague, Senator Boswell, whose enthusiasm for this has been noted on both sides of the chamber this evening. He is a very enthusiastic supporter of small business, and I am proud to have him as my colleague. I think Senator Boswell would also be very proud to see this legislation go through tonight.

The evidence is very clear. In retailing, for example, the retailing chains have enormous power to extract extra profit margins from the people with whom they do business, their suppliers. The consequence of that has not been better prices for the consumers necessarily, but it has lead to a lessening of competition, because some of those smaller producers just could not meet the demands for extra profit margin that the retailers were asking for. As a result, because they could not get market share, because they could not get their products on the shelves—to a manufacturer, it does not matter how good his product is; if he cannot get it on the shelf it is no good to him at all—they ultimately went to the wall. That is the big problem that we face today. How do we ensure that we keep our efficient manufacturers going?

Senator Boswell has referred tonight to the drive to get Australia competitive in the food manufacturing area. The problem in that area is that we have a lot of very small food processors. For example, in the Atherton Tablelands in North Queensland we produce enormous numbers of macadamia nuts, just as are produced in New South Wales. But the companies that are processing those nuts are small operations, and the big challenge for us is to ensure that they can keep on going, keep on being productive and competitive, and are not gobbled up by subsidised competitors overseas or by large run processors who can afford to meet the demands that some of the wholesalers and retailers put on them for the extra profit margin which they wish to cream off the top. I believe that many of the recommendations in this Bill, particularly ones about unconscionability, will go to achieve those ends.

One of the problems we have in Australia is that we have never really benefited, like the United Kingdom benefited, from a series of cases in the 1970s and 1980s in relation to petrol companies. In the United Kingdom there was a series of cases in the 1970s and 1980s about the unfair and unconscionable conduct of petrol companies, which were basically standing over and unfairly exploiting their retailers. In Australia we never had those cases. As a result, there has been a hole in our law when it comes to unconscionable conduct. Those holes will to a large extent be plugged by this legislation, and I am very pleased to see that taking place.

I say that because I am one of the people who have had the dubious distinction of having to run a petrol station and roadhouse in North Queensland for six months and struggling week after week on behalf of the company to get enough money together at the end of the week to pay the oil company—I will not say which one—so that we could get the delivery for that Friday to have enough oil and petrol to keep us going over the weekend. This is the real problem we face. If we do not have curbs and brakes on excessive unconscionability, then we send many small business people—honest, hardworking people—to the wall because basically they are no match for the superior power of the large companies with which they deal. So I think the unconscionability changes are very welcome.

I believe that the changes in relation to takeovers are also very important. At the end of the day we have to remember that we always have to keep our eyes open. Sure as night follows day, the big companies—not all big companies are bad but I am referring to the big companies which are particularly disposed to causing unfair situations to occur, the big companies that are particularly disposed to using these sorts of tactics—will always try to find new tactics. I think Senator Boswell would agree from his experience in small business that there is always a new tactic that they will try to use.

I do not believe—I would not be foolish enough to believe it—that the legislation before us tonight is the panacea. It is not the be all and end all. What it will require is vigilance—vigilance on behalf of authorities such as the Trade Practices Commission. Most importantly, those authorities have to be willing to act to represent small business people who are in a situation where they are the victims of unconscionable conduct.

In the course of our work as members of parliament, we have all seen situations where unconscionable business practices have put people out of business, where the law is too expensive a tool to use to solve a problem—of course, that is another of the investigations of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee—and regulatory bodies such as the Trade Practices Commission need to be willing to step in and put a halt to it. Sometimes an injunction is not needed. Sometimes all that is needed is the Trade Practices Commission to bowl up on the doorstep of the party against whom the complaint has been made and say, `We have had some allegations that you are indulging in unconscionable conduct' and, strangely enough, the unconscionable conduct tends to cease.

Certainly in at least one case with which I have been involved, the intervention of the Trade Practices Commission—although it did not actually bring down a finding; it merely commenced an investigation—was sufficient to buy the struggling, developing small business an opportunity to get out there and establish its market share. In that particular market we now have two very good competitors. So one can see the benefits of an active and vigilant Trade Practices Commission. Those authorities have to utilise the legislation as well.

I want to make one final comment; that is, in relation to divestiture. Senator Spindler and Senator Schacht both supported the recommendation that there be a use of divestiture powers where certain companies had been involved in unconscionable conduct and so on. This is a very superficially attractive proposition. In fact, it is probably more than superficially attractive. But, on balance, I did not believe it was appropriate. I say that because of the experience in Queensland where divestiture powers were used and where the company against which the orders were made, instead of divesting and selling off the meatworks it had, it merely closed the meatworks down. I think the real danger of divestiture is that, instead of forcing the hiving off of assets and the creation of new competition, it just leads to the closure of those businesses with no competition and with a consequent loss of jobs.

I know that the two senators who have spoken this evening about the issue of divestiture genuinely believe that it is beneficial. But, at the end of the day, I felt that I could not support it because I was dreadfully afraid that divestiture would just mean loss of jobs and loss of competition rather than an increase in competition. I think that view would be supported widely in this chamber.

I am pleased to see this legislation being passed in the Senate tonight. I am very pleased to have been part of it. I also take this opportunity to thank those who contributed to the deliberations of the Committee, because they were quite long, to congratulate my friend and colleague Senator Boswell, and also to hope that through this legislation there will be some respite for small business in Australia at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now coming to the concluding stages of the second reading speeches on the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. As one would expect, in the contributions major emphasis has been placed on the mergers and acquisitions provisions. If Senator Hill was not persuaded of the need to change in this area—and he expressed it only in terms as moderate as that—then I would certainly believe that the contribution by Senator Boswell was very illustrative and very dynamically presented in a way which would be persuasive for anyone who is listening.

PARA.TAB: In so far as the comments around the chamber generally took up many of the themes which were expressed in the Cooney committee report which dealt with this matter, there is no need for me to rehearse the elements of that report which are well known to all senators who have read it assiduously to prepare themselves for the second reading debate. That Committee said, at paragraph 3.116:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee considers that the essential thrust of the Trade Practices Act should be to prohibit acts which substantially injure competition, except where public benefit can be demonstrated. This principle is embraced elsewhere in Part IV of the Act, and should also be incorporated in the merger regulation provisions.
Therefore it is not surprising that, at 3.131, we read:

The Committee recommends that section 50 of the Trade Practices Act 1974, be amended to prohibit mergers or acquisitions which would have the effect or likely effect of substantially lessening competition in a substantial market for goods and services.

It is that recommendation and the good work that went into its formulation that have been taken up by the Government. In other words, making the change from the old dominance test to the substantially lessening competition test, I think, allows us to really focus on the effect on competition in a market rather than on the dominance of a particular firm, and I believe that must lead to beneficial consequences within the Australian economy which have been alluded to or quite graphically demonstrated by contributors to the debate. Certainly the range of transactions that would be subject to a request for authorisation from the Trade Practices Commission would greatly increase over the number that are presently supervised or subject to such authorisation processes. I believe that that can be very useful indeed.

PARA.TAB: In making its decision, it will be very important that the Trade Practices Commission—and, of course, any court that is called upon to look at the way in which the Parliament has dealt with these matters—have regard to the explanatory memorandum relating to the substantially lessening competition test. I believe it may be of interest to the Senate and to those who are required to make decisions in relation to that expression for me make the following comments—and I emphasise them for their value in elaborating on the explanatory memorandum in this regard.

Following passage of this Bill through the House of Representatives a number of interested commentators have sought some further clarification of the meaning which the Government intends should be attributed to the phrase `substantially lessening competition' which will, by operation of this Bill, be introduced into section 50 of the Act in its application to mergers and takeovers. At paragraph 12 of the explanatory memorandum circulated by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) it is said that the term `is here intended to mean an effect on competition which is real or of substance, not one which must be large or weighty'. The phrases `real or of substance' and `large or weighty' are each terms which have been variously used by the courts in attributing meaning to the word `substantially'. In signifying its intention that that word as now proposed to be used in section 50 should bear the meaning `real or of substance', the Government intends that the test should apply to effects upon competition which are not merely discernible but which are material in a relative sense in the impact that they may have upon effective competition in the marketplace. I believe that that particular elaboration, which would have otherwise been contained in a longer paragraph in the explanatory memorandum, will certainly be an aid to the interpretation of the intention of the Parliament in using those words.

TAB.TAB: The factors to be considered in relation to the various tests and authorisations are set out in the Bill, not in exhaustive ways but in ways which I think will be helpful to decision makers particularly in terms of the emphasis when one reads, for example, the amended section 90 in relation to the authorising provision, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (9A)In determining what amounts to a benefit to the public for the purposes of subsection (9):
(a)the Commission must regard the following as benefits to the public (in addition to any other benefits to the public that may exist apart from this paragraph):

TAB.TAB: (i)a significant increase in the real value of exports;
(ii)a significant substitution of domestic products for imported goods; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b)without limiting the matters that may be taken into account, the Commission must take into account all other relevant matters that relate to the international competitiveness of any Australian industry.

I believe that is an important provision, particularly when linked to the section dealing with the prohibition of acquisitions that would result in a substantial lessening of competition. Once again, one reads in the non-exhaustive list of matters that may be taken into account for the purposes of determining whether the acquisition would have the effect or would be likely to have the effect of substantially lessening competition in the market, that amongst the matters which must be taken into account is:
(a)the actual and potential level of import competition in the market . . .

And so it goes on. In other words, in the structure of the Bill there is a very real adverting to the matters which must be taken into account in regard to Australia's position as a competitor in an international marketplace wanting to have within it the growth of firms which can go out and compete in the marketplace while also being conscious of the effects of overseas enterprises themselves affecting the Australian marketplace. I recall that in the early discussions about whether the Cooney committee should have this Bill referred to it, for example, this factor was a very real stimulus to the Bill being referred—to take account of the internationalisation of the Australian economy in a way which had perhaps not been the case when the Trade Practices Act was established back in the 1970s, I think, under former Senator Murphy.

PARA.TAB: Madam Acting Deputy President, I will be extremely brief, because I know that colleagues in their various rooms and hovering around the Senate door will be irritated if I am not. Basically, the question of penalties will be dealt with, I believe, more comprehensively at the committee stage. But there is no doubt that penalties for the competition provisions in part IV have not been updated since 1974, and penalties for the consumer protection provisions in part V have not been updated since 1986. If we take seriously the exercise that we are indulging in tonight and in the committee stage on Monday, it is important that the deterrent value of the penalties reflect the seriousness with which the Government and the community view corporate misbehaviour. Of course, there have been comments to that effect, even from the Bench.

There is a need to increase the level of penalties where they are useful and appropriate. In section 45D and 45E no penalty of that kind has been sought by the Minister or the Commission which alone are entitled to seek a pecuniary penalty. Other remedies have been used effectively to make those provisions operate in a way which advances the intention of the legislation.

With those exceptions, there will certainly be very significant increases to the maximum penalties for breaches of the competition provisions of part IV—$10m for corporations and $500,000 for individuals. For the consumer protection provisions, the maximum fines will be increased to $200,000 for corporations and $40,000 for individuals. That is significant indeed.

Finally, as to unconscionable conduct, I think it is important that whereas at the moment the provisions relating to unconscionable conduct are confined to those involving goods or services of a kind ordinarily acquired for personal, domestic or household use or consumption—in other words, basically consumer transactions—the new provision will prohibit unconscionable conduct by corporations in trade and commerce. Thus it will extend—but in a modified form—the prohibition now found in section 52A. I believe that is extremely important and has certainly been sought by many of the small businesses and enterprises which, for example, Senator Boswell spoke about in his contribution this evening.

Unconscionability is certainly defined in a very interesting way to bring common law or equitable doctrines and their operation in the States into the legislation and then adding the capacity of the Trade Practices Commission to play a role in ensuring that that doctrine of unconscionable conduct is applied. I believe that, for all these reasons, every contribution has pointed to many good features of this Bill such as certainly deserve the support of the Senate. I commend the second reading to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the Bill in Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.
