In response to part (d) of the question, I am advised that training course participation is based on an assessment of needs by prospective trainees and their supervisors, with all nominations being endorsed by the respective line manager. I am further advised that the Department has adopted a Training and Development Evaluation Strategy which includes provision for the evaluation of individual courses and programs and of training and development overall. This strategy meets all the evaluation and assessment requirements of the Training Guarantee Act 1990 and includes an assessment of benefits to post training performance by the line area. A Training and Development Evaluation Report is prepared annually for consideration and endorsement by the Department's Staff Development Committee.

In response to part (e) of the question, I am advised that the task of identifying specific expenditure information so as to estimate the cost of running each separate course is one which would require a significant diversion of resources, which in my view cannot be justified. The expenditure required to be identified in relation to each course includes some or all of the following: trainer salary costs for design, delivery and evaluation; participants' salary costs; course materials; administrative expenses; venue hire; consultants' fees; and, travel and accommodation costs.

However, I am advised that the net eligible expenditure by the Department on the training and development of staff during the financial year 1991-92 was in the order of $7.48m. This figure, which excludes ineligible expenditure, is the aggregate of the various training related administrative expenses expenditure, extracted from the Department's financial management computer system, and a calculation of participants and trainers (Departmental) salary costs made using the methodology and notional salary rates provided by the Public Service Commission for the purposes of its annual Human Resource Development Survey for 1991-92.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 8 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which countries have banned the cyclodiene pesticides heptachlor and chlordane and, for each pesticide, what was the reason for banning it.

(2) Would it be of concern to the Minister if, in spite of the fact that regulatory authorities in dozens of countries banned these chemicals for either health or environmental reasons, the National Health and Medical Research Council failed to find reasons to be concerned about the continued use of these chemicals in Australia, on either health or environmental grounds.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services provided an answer to the same question on 12 October 1992 (Question 2237, Hansard p. 1628-29). I have nothing further to add.

(2) Australian regulatory authorities, including the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC), are aware of the health and environmental concerns expressed about these chemicals. Their use in Australia is severely restricted and recently has been the subject of a major review by the NHMRC.

At its November 1992 meeting the NHMRC endorsed a report of the review prepared for the Council by Professor Geoffry Duggin entitled Cyclodiene Use in Australia. The Council has directed that the report be published.

The report contains eleven recommendations requiring the consideration of regulatory and research bodies. The main thrust of the report is that persistent organochlorines should no longer be used in agriculture and that, while chlordane and heptachlor should be permitted for use as a termiticide in building construction, this application should be phased out within two years, provided suitable alternatives are available.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 4 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which Defence Science and Technology Organisation Research and Development (DSTO R&D) activities have been identified under Tier 2 for Commercial Support Program (CSP) evaluation.

(2) Given that Stage I of the CSP decision process requires that the core and non-core elements of the candidate activity be clarified, has a decision been reached on the core/non-core status of the Materials Research Laboratory, Tasmania; if so, what is that decision; if not, what procedures or methodology has or will be established to reach that decision.
(3) What criteria are being used to determine whether a DSTO R&D activity should be evaluated under CSP.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) One R&D activity has been identified for evaluation under Tier 2:
(a) Food Science Research and Development (Materials Research Laboratory—Tasmania (MRL-T)).

An associated Tier 2 activity is the food production function at MRL-T. The Food Science Branch at MRL-T operates this small-scale processing line to produce freeze-dried components for ration packs for the Australian Defence Forces.
(2) Yes. Both the Food Science R&D and the production facility are non-core.

(3) Defence has decided that for the DSTO to meet its CSP obligation in R&D, it should seek to increase its level of R&D contracted-out from a present four percent of its program funds to at least eight but preferably ten percent, by 30 June 1996. This may be through either contracting out discrete R&D activities (eg. MRL-T), or the extension of R&D technical services and support contracts, R&D work placed on tertiary institutions, or through work forming part of DSTO participation in Cooperative Research Centres. There are no specific criteria for determining whether a DSTO R&D activity should be evaluated under CSP. However, DSTO will proceed to subject R&D activities to the CSP process where a contracting-out outcome of CSP would not adversely impact on the development or retention of R&D capabilities and technologies judged critical to Defence.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What, if any, secrecy provisions still apply to present and former members of the Australian Defence Force which would prevent them from speaking about the sinking of the HMAS Sydney in World War II and the subsequent investigation of that sinking.

(2) What, if any, secrecy provisions apply to present and former members of the Australian Public Service which would prevent them from speaking out about that sinking and the subsequent investigation.
(3) In which archives and storage places are the records of the investigation into the sinking of HMAS Sydney located, and what level of public access pertains to these records.
(4) What is the nature and extent of the records for which exemptions under the Archives Act have not been granted, and where are those records.

(5) Will the Minister instigate a search within the Australian War Memorial, the Australian Archives and other holdings of naval historical records to draw together all records relating to the sinking of HMAS Sydney and release these documents for public scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) This is a matter which falls within the jurisdiction of the Attorney General.
(2) This is a matter which falls within the jurisdiction of the Attorney General.

(3) Records of the investigation into the loss of HMAS Sydney may be held in any repository of Australian Archives as well as the Australian War Memorial or the Naval Historical Section, Department of Defence. The main investigation into the loss of HMAS Sydney was conducted by Mr F.B. Eldridge. His report is located in Australian Archives' Melbourne repository under MPll85/8 file 2026/19/6 and is open to public access.

As there is no complete folio level data base of Commonwealth records created since 1941 it is impossible to specifically identify every record which may relate to the loss of HMAS Sydney and the subsequent investigations. However, should a member of the public identify a Commonwealth record that is over 30 years old and still closed, access to it may be requested under Section 40 of the Archives Act.

(4) Due to the vast quantity of records available and the various descriptions under which they are listed it is impractical to provide detailed information on each file in this forum. However, such information is freely available to any member of the public through the Australian National Guide to Archival Material II (ANGAM II) database of Australian Archives. Australian Archives have already made available source analysis on files relating to HMAS Sydney. By way of example earlier this year a Mr J.W. Doohan from Western Australia was provided with an extensive source analysis by the Minister for Administrative Services. Furthermore any exemptions made under the Archives Act will appear on the ANGAM II database.

(5) There is no justification for the conduct of a nation wide search for documents which may, sometimes in an obscure way, relate to the loss of HMAS Sydney. The loss of Sydney has already been the subject of previous books and the authors of these books have conducted their own searches of the Archives. The conduct of such a search by the Government would not satisfy the sceptics and revisionist historians who will still claim that the Government of the day was hiding something. Where documents do come to light they are placed in the custody of Australian Archives. This is exactly what happened recently when a classified file relating to the loss of HMAS Sydney was located at HMAS Stirling. This file has been declassified by the Navy and placed in the custody of Australian Archives, Perth where members of the public may request access to it.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 9 November, 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a question without notice (Senate Hansard, 3 June, 1992, p.3388) concerning the proposed Harbour City Canal Estate on the Creery Wetlands at Mandurah in Western Australia, has the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) liaised with the Western Australia Environment Protection Authority (EPA) and the Department of Conservation and Land Management to `ensure that the Commonwealth's environmental concerns and, in particular, Australia's international obligations' are properly addressed in the review process; if not, why not; if so, is the ANPWS and the Commonwealth Government satisfied with the EPA's recommendation to proceed with the development.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) made two submissions to the Western Australia Environment Protection Authority (WA EPA) regarding the proposed Harbour City Canal Estate on the Creery Wetland at Mandurah. I have forwarded a copy of both of these submissions to the honourable senator. Further copies are available from the Senate Table Office. The second of these submissions was made on 22 June 1992 following an inspection of the site on 17 June 1992 by an officer of the ANPWS.

The WA EPA released their report relating to the proposed development in October 1992. The ANPWS welcomes the recognition by the WA EPA in the report of the environmental importance of the most southerly and the central portions of the Creery Wetland and considers that reservation of these areas, combined with the conditions to be imposed on the proponent for development of the remainder of the site, should serve to minimise impacts on the adjoining wetlands of the Peel-Harvey estuary. The ANPWS will continue to liaise with the relevant Western Australia agencies on these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it correct that the United States (US) Congress has cancelled $2.3m in international military education and training funding for Indonesia from its 1993 Budget as a protest against Indonesian human rights violations in East Timor.

(2)(a) What training opportunities are being offered by the Australian Defence Forces to members of the Indonesian armed forces in 1993; and (b) are any of these opportunities being offered as a result of the cancellation of the US training budget.
(3) Are any joint exercises planned for the Australian Defence Forces and the Indonesian armed forces in 1993.

(4) Will the Australian Government follow the American example and cancel all defence cooperation with Indonesia until such time as Indonesian military and government human rights violations in East Timor come to an end.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2)(a) A cooperative training package for 1993/94 has not yet been prepared but it will be similar in type and numbers to 1992/93. The training offered to the Indonesian Armed Forces in 1992/93 is listed in the following table. Not all training places offered to Indonesia are taken up.

Since 1 July 1992 sixty-one Indonesian personnel have attended courses in Australia and a further four offers have so far been accepted for the remainder of the financial year. We are as yet unsure how many of the remaining offers will be accepted by Indonesia for 1992/93.

ANSWER.PARA: Joint Services Staff College 4 Overseas Joint Warfare Course 6

PARA.TAB: (b) No.
(3) Combined exercises planned between the Indonesian armed forces and the Australian Defence Force in 1993 are:
AUSINA PATROLEX—a series of combined patrol boat surveillance exercises held in the Timor Sea.
AUSINA—a series of naval passage exercises in northern waters which occur each year.
NEW HORIZON—a more complex biennial maritime exercise involving ships and aircraft from both countries.
AUSINDO—an annual C130 Tactical Air Transport exercise. Responsibility for hosting this exercise alternates between Indonesia and Australia. AUSINDO 93 will be held in Australia.

(4) No. A close defence relationship between Australia and Indonesia is in Australia's strategic interests. This defence relationship is based on a recognition that both countries have a common interest in the maintenance of security and stability in the South East Asian region. Therefore, cooperative defence activities, such as training, study visits and joint exercises, are directed towards the development of wide ranging contacts between members of the armed forces of each country. This increases knowledge and understanding between the two defence establishments and promotes a greater appreciation of our shared interests.

This does not imply any indifference by the Australian Government to the circumstances of the East Timorese people. We maintain a close interest in developments in East Timor and have continued to seek free access to the province for the media, international organisations and aid workers. Senator Evans has raised human rights issues regularly with the Indonesian Foreign Minister, other Indonesian Ministers and in appropriate international forums.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Bureau of Statistics: Data Security

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 30 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What measures has the ABS taken to ensure that all holdings of data within the ABS are secure?
(2) Can people be confident that the information they provide to the ABS will remain confidential?

(3) Could the Minister provide an indication of the sorts of security measures which the ABS uses for its data holdings. In particular, are the computer systems password protected, are physical records of data (written, or on disk/tape) kept in secure storage, how easy is it for non-ABS staff to enter ABS premises and to access data records.

(4) Are the allegations in the Sunday Telegraph of 18 October 1992 accurate. In particular, were there long delays in implementing recommendations made about improving the security of foreign trade data. If so, why was there such a long delay in implementing those recommendations.
(5) Do the personnel practices in the ABS encourage staff to ensure the security of data accessed?

(6) Can staff who advise of possible security breaches, or security loopholes, to management be assured that such actions will not be detrimental to their employment prospects in the ABS or the public service generally?
(7) Have there been any changes to the management and personnel practices since receipt of criticisms by the Merit Protection and Review Agency this year? If so what are the nature of those changes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) By far the most important measure governing the security of ABS data holdings, which sets the context for all further, specific steps the ABS takes in this regard, is the undertaking of fidelity and secrecy which has to be given by every ABS officer. Under Section 7 of the Census and Statistics Act 1905 (CSA),

"Every officer executing any power or duty conferred or imposed on any officer under this Act or the regulations, shall, before entering into his or her duties or exercising any power under this Act, sign, in the presence of a witness, an undertaking of fidelity and secrecy in accordance with the prescribed form."
Further, under Section 19 of the CSA
"(1) A person who is, or has been, the Statistician or an officer shall not, except:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) in accordance with a determination; or
(b) for the purposes of the Act;

PARA.TAB: either directly or indirectly, divulge or communicate any information furnished in pursuance of this Act to any person (other than the person from whom the information was obtained).

(2) A person who contravenes subsection (1) . . . is guilty of an indictable offence punishable on conviction by a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment for a period not exceeding 2 years, or both.

These legal provisions are complemented by an extremely strong culture, continually reinforced at all levels in the organisation, that preservation of the confidentiality of reported data, and of the security of statistical aggregates before their public release, is central to the ABS's ability to retain the trust of its respondents that their reported data are secure from release to any third party without their consent, and the trust of its users that statistical data are made available on a completely even-handed basis.

The ABS has an enviable reputation for the preservation of the confidentiality of reported data, and for the protection of its statistical data holdings from unauthorised release. There have been no known cases of any ABS officer attempting to breach the undertaking of fidelity and secrecy.

The undertaking of fidelity and secrecy sworn by all ABS officers, and the strong confidentiality and security ethos which permeates the attitudes of ABS staff, are in themselves the most important elements of the ABS's security screen. They are reinforced by a range of measures relating to the perimeter security of all ABS offices, the security measures protecting the ABS's computing environment from any external access, and the security measures implemented for individual ABS data holdings.

The ABS has spent about $2.5 million over the last 5 years on physical security of ABS premises, to ensure that their security is effective against unauthorised access. It has devoted very large resources over many years to improve progressively the security of its data holdings, and will continue to do so. Because potentially the resources which could be devoted to perimeter and computer security are limitless, the ABS's approach to securing statistical data has to be tailored to the sensitivity of the data in question. Its specific actions are guided by a process of continual assessment of the risks involved of unauthorised access to particular data, taking account of their innate interest and degree of sensitivity.
(2) Yes. Details are given in response to Question 1.

(3) ABS data holdings are protected by a number of measures including general building security, secure storage of documents, and password protection of the computer network, host computers, software systems and databases.

The vast bulk of ABS data is held electronically in databases that reside on a variety of host computers. ABS computer systems are password protected and in many cases several passwords are required before statistical data can be accessed. Other than the use of microcomputers in "stand-alone" mode, use of ABS computing facilities requires one or more passwords.

The ABS computing environment cannot be accessed from outside ABS premises. One stand-alone minicomputer, not physically connected to the remainder of the ABS computing environment, is used for the electronic dissemination of statistics; this is the only ABS computer which can be accessed from outside the ABS.

In the ABS there are two broad categories of data that can be regarded as sensitive. The first is "unit record data" i.e. data that can be attributed to specific individuals, businesses or other organisations. The second is "sensitive output data", which consists of statistical outputs that might afford the user some advantage if accessed prior to official release (for example, the monthly Balance of Payments, the CPI, the monthly Labour Force data, and the quarterly National Accounts).

The vast bulk of the ABS data holding is in the form of "unit record data" which are in various stages of processing. These data exist in a variety of forms including completed statistical returns, computer tapes, printout, and computer databases stored on microcomputers, minicomputers, network file servers, and mainframe computers. Access to "unit record data" held in electronic form is controlled by password protection of data and systems. Access to physical forms of the data (paper, tape and disk) is controlled through building security and secure storage facilities.

In the case of "sensitive output data", the control over security of the data is stringent, with increased emphasis on, and specially tailored facilities for, the physically secure storage of printed records, computers and computer storage media. Commonwealth approved security containers are provided to store physical records and magnetic media. As well, pre-embargo access by ABS personnel to this category of data is limited, by well documented and understood procedures, to those officers with a strict "need to know".

All ABS premises are entered through electronically controlled access systems activated by individual coded keys. All persons without such keys are required to enter through an ABS staffed reception area. Particularly sensitive output data, and the personnel handling them, are located within physically isolated areas, with further internal electronically controlled access systems which are available only to staff with programmed access. ABS building perimeters are protected after hours by security guards and/or video cameras and computerised entry audit trails.

The mechanisms in place to ensure security of ABS data are under constant review. At present the Australian National Audit Office, as part of its APS-wide program of performance audits, is reviewing computer security in the ABS, with the full support of ABS management. The ABS will continue to take advantage of security technologies as they develop to the point of providing cost-effective opportunities to increase the security of ABS data holdings.
(4) The allegations in the Sunday Telegraph report of 18 October 1992 are not accurate.
Security of all the balance of payments aggregates is tight, and has been for many years. There has been no recent tightening of computer security on these data.

The last allegations concerning leaks of the monthly balance of payments data date back to the numbers for August 1987 and January 1988. The allegations were referred by the ABS to the Australian Federal Police for investigation. They found no evidence substantiating them. Further information in relation to this matter is contained in the answer to a question on notice, House of Representatives Hansard, of 22 August 1988, Question No. 959.

There is in fact little relationship between the security issues relating to the monthly balance of payments data and those relating to the computer files holding the recorded imports and exports data obtained from the Australian Customs Service. The totals for imports and exports derivable from the hundreds of thousands of records in the foreign trade computer files are incomplete and deficient in certain key respects as a basis for calculation of the balance of merchandise trade which forms part of the balance of payments measure of the balance on current account. A number of essential adjustments, typically of large value, are made to the totals for recorded imports and exports derivable from the computer files, to transform them into the publishable balance of payments components. The nature and size of those adjustments have been such that a simple "balance of trade in goods" measure, derived from the computer files holding the individual imports and exports records, would have been generally quite misleading as a basis for estimating the published measure of the balance of merchandise trade, let alone the more sensitive balance on current account.

The officers making those adjustments are a handful of senior, designated officers of the Foreign Trade and Balance of Payments Sections. The resulting statistical measures of the balance of merchandise trade, and the balance on current account, are known before publication to only the very small number of officers with a need to know, under stringent security controls. Also, those measures are not stored in the foreign trade data files, but in their own database, again under stringent security controls.
In any event, there is no evidence, from the access logs on the computer files holding the individual imports and exports records, that any unauthorised access to them has ever been attempted.

The Sunday Telegraph report referred to a review of security procedures in January 1991. That review was instituted by the management of the Foreign Trade Section, as an integral aspect of a much wider review of foreign trade systems which was scheduled for implementation from late 1991. The review of security procedures was intended to rectify certain known low level deficiencies in the security procedures relating to the Foreign Trade computer database files which were well understood, and were already being addressed by logging of all attempted database accesses. The deficiencies were not crucial in the context of the overall security of reliable, publishable statistical aggregates. However, it was considered desirable to use recent enhancements to the ABS's computer environment to remedy them if this was technically feasible at reasonable cost, and thereby simplify the security arrangements already in place.

The officer assigned to the review produced an initial draft in January 1991 which documented some of the low level security deficiencies and suggested some possible remedies. Following consideration of that paper a note was prepared by Section management in March 1991 outlining work remaining to be done for the security review and its future directions. The review was reassigned to another officer in September 1991, who subsequently completed it in March 1992. The review's final recommendations were progressively implemented in the ensuing three months, with the result that the deficiencies in security procedures were rectified in June 1992.

The overall security of the balance of payments aggregates was reviewed most recently in June 1992. The Sunday Telegraph article quoted from an interim report of that review. The review has been completed, and has shown that the security of all balance of payments measures is appropriately tight to protect those measures against any attempt to gain unauthorised pre-embargo access, and that there is no evidence that any such access has been attempted, let alone that it has occurred.

(5) Yes. As indicated in response to Question 1, all ABS staff sign an undertaking of fidelity and secrecy under the CSA on joining the ABS. The ethos of security and confidentiality is an integral part of the culture of the organisation and is continually reinforced. The "need to know" principle is rigorously observed regarding staff access to sensitive data.

(6) Yes. Staff are encouraged to and do report apparent security incidents, and a formal incident report system is in place. All investigations of apparent incidents, and associated documents, are handled confidentially. Staff advice of possible security loopholes is encouraged and followed up in all cases.

The ABS has noted the suggestion by Senator Short, in his speech to the Senate of 26 November 1992 (Senate Hansard p 3738), that an ABS officer was victimised for bringing to ABS management's attention alleged security problems with foreign trade data. The security problems referred to were well understood by management, who had assigned the job of rectifying them to the officer concerned. The ABS's actions in relation to this officer have not been influenced in any way by any allegations

ANSWER.PARA: to ABS management regarding the security of foreign trade data holdings. Those actions related to other matters. The ABS rejects any suggestion that it victimised the officer concerned.

PARA.TAB: (7) The ABS assumes that the MPRA report to which the Senator referred in the Senate on 26 November 1992, concerned that Agency's consideration of a large number of grievances from an ABS officer which had been referred to it pursuant to Public Service Regulation 84. The grievances centred on allegations that certain personnel practices had not been properly observed by the ABS.
The ABS has furnished a detailed response to the MPRA.
The actions taken by ABS in response to the findings are:
Reports made by Occupational Health and Safety Case Managers are to be worded in such a way as to prevent their (mis)interpretation as clinical diagnoses.

On the basis of advice from the Australian Government Solicitor, instructions have been issued to ensure that COMCARE determinations involving payment to ABS staff are processed upon receipt, regardless of any ABS appeal against the determination.
A direction has been issued to ensure that the Fitness for Continued Duty Instructions are correctly applied.
A direction has been issued to ensure that no medical information is sought from doctors by ABS staff, unless the officer concerned has specifically agreed to this action.

A new procedure has been introduced which provides that, where requests are received to refer grievances to the MPRA pursuant to Public Service Regulation 84, and the request contains new allegations or assertions which have not been investigated, the ABS will refer only the original grievance and the inquiry papers to the MPRA.
